An Introduction to Texas Prehistoric Archeology

Timothy K. Perttula

Our understanding of the prehistoric
archeology of Texas has come a long way
since the ﬁrst true synthesis of Texas
archeology, E. B. Sayles’s An Archaeologi-
cal Survey of Texas (1935). About twenty
years later, Dee Ann Suhm (now Story),
Alex D. Krieger, and Edward B. Jelks
published the now classic “An Introduc-
tory Handbook of Texas Archeology” in
volume 25 of theBulletin of the Texas Arche-
ological Society (1954). That 552-page
handbook presented the then-current
knowledge of the archeology of Texas as
well as an illustrated compendium of the
known pottery and projectile point types
in the state (the latter compendium was
republished separately by the Texas Arche-
ological Society and the Texas Memorial
Museum in Suhm and Jelks 1962). The
book was very well received by the pro-
fessional and avocational archeological
communities in Texas and surrounding
states, but it has been out of print for
many years.

Since that time, a truly phenomenal
number of archeological investigations
have occurred in Texas—by both avoca-
tional and professional archeologists alike
from one end of the state to the other—
and the pace of archeological work has
quickened, especially since the mid-1970s
and early 1980s. This increase in the
number of archeological investigations
across the state of Texas has greatly de-
pended on the passage of a host of federal
laws (principally the National Historic

Preservation Act of 1966, as amended;
see Hutt et al. 1999) and state regulations
(the 1969 Antiquities Code of Texas, as
amended) concerning historic preserva-
tion and the conduct of archeological
studies when development projects will
have an impact on important sites.

It is fair to state that more archeologi-
cal investigations have been completed in
the last two decades of the twentieth cen-
tury in Texas than in the seventy-ﬁve
years before then. During this time, a
host of new equipment (particularly the
personal computer and software), analyti-
cal techniques, and methods have come
to the fore (see Hester et al. 1997) that
have assisted archeologists in learning
more about the Native American peoples
that lived in Texas. New equipment and
methods include the use of accelerator
mass spectrometry for precise dating of
organic materials, global positioning sys-
tems for mapping sites, aerial photogra-
phy from satellite imagery, geographic in-
formation system analyses of different
layers of spatial information, and new
means of chemical and physical analyses
of ceramics, organic residues (including
blood), and plant and animal remains.
Archeological theories and hypotheses
have come and gone, here in Texas as
elsewhere, from culture history to the
processual approach of the “new archeol-
ogy,” to post-processualism, as well as a
diverse array of other schools of thought
that seek to explain the nature of the

5

archeological record (see M. Johnson
1999 and Trigger 1989 for cogent sum-
maries of archeological ideas). The arche-
ological record (i.e., the artifacts, sedi-
ments, structural remains, and other bits
and pieces that are found on an archeo-
logical site) in Texas is massive and con-
tinues to provide ample opportunities to
study the human past.

The Internet and the World Wide Web

have also provided unparalleled means,
unimagined even a few years ago, for
communication and data sharing between
archeologists and people interested in
archeology in the United States, as well
as across the world (see Hodder 1999).
These innovations, and future ones we
cannot even begin to conceive of, prom-
ise to expand our knowledge of the rich
archeological legacy in Texas left by the
Native American peoples that lived there
for millennia (Hester 1998). Finally, an-
other important trend in Texas is that
archeologists and Native Americans are
working together to share ideas and infor-
mation (see Bruseth et al. 2000; Thoms
1999).

Archeological overview volumes com-
missioned by the U.S. Army Corps of En-
gineers, Southwest Division (COE-SWD),
do provide a reasonably good sense of the
scope of the current archeological data
base in Texas (with more than ﬁfty-four
thousand sites recorded to date, and the
number continues to climb) and sur-
rounding states, the types of investigations

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

01-A2946  4/13/04  11:44 AM  Page 6

conducted across the state of Texas, and
the kinds of research problems and ques-
tions that have been, and continue to
be, the subject of inquiry (Hester et al.
1989b; Hofman 1996; Hofman et al.
1989b; Jeter et al. 1989; Sabo et al. 1988;
Simmons et al. 1989; Story et al. 1990).
While these volumes are extremely valu-
able research documents, they are not
broadly accessible to all those interested
in the prehistoric archeology of Texas.
Nor are the many hundreds, if not thou-
sands, of cultural resource management
technical documents of surveys and exca-
vations prepared by contract archeologi-
cal ﬁrms for clients, permit applicants,
regulatory agencies, and other govern-
ment consumers; few copies are pro-
duced, few see the light of day other than
to reside on a shelf in government agency
ofﬁces, and few are seemingly written to
be read by more than the jargon-bound
professional archeologists and cultural re-
source managers (Fagan 1995; McMana-
mon 2000; see also commentaries in
Black 1995a and Bruseth and Perttula
1995, 1–2, about Texas archeology).
Nevertheless, truly exciting and interest-
ing archeological research is being con-
ducted in this sometimes bleak forum,
in Texas, North America, and in other
countries (see, e.g., McManamon and
Hatton 2000), and innovative ways must
be found to share this knowledge with
the public and the interested avocational
archeologist, as well as the professional
archeological community.

The Texas Archeological Society

(TAS), established in 1929 and now com-
posed of more than fourteen hundred
dedicated amateur or avocational and
professional archeologists, has contrib-
uted more than its fair share over the
years to the stock of archeological knowl-
edge in the state of Texas by conducting
annual ﬁeld schools across the state since
the ﬁrst ﬁeld school in 1962 at the Gil-
bert site (41RA13) in Rains County (see
Richmond et al. 1985). The results of
these many ﬁeld school investigations
have been regularly published in the so-
ciety’s journal, the Bulletin of the Texas
Archeological Society or BTAS (see Mueg-
genborg 1994; J. Smith 1993; Turpin
and Davis 1993; Houk and Lohse 1993;
J. Wright et al. 1997; Corbin and Hart
1998; Few 1999; Rinker et al. 1999; and
Walter 1999 for recent publications of

6 / TEXAS PREHISTORY

the results of TAS ﬁeld schools). The TAS
also has helped sponsor regional ﬁeld
schools held by afﬁliated avocational
archeological societies in Texas (such as
the South Texas Archaeological Associa-
tion’s annual September ﬁeld school).

Foremost, though, among the impor-
tant roles of the TAS in communicating
the results of archeological research to
those interested in the prehistory and
early history of Texas has been the compi-
lation and publication of nearly seventy
years’ worth of archeological research in
Texas that documents human life in the
state (Perttula 1994b). In particular, from
time to time, the BTAS has taken stock of
our understanding of the archeology of
particular parts of Texas by publishing in
a single volume a number of important
articles that focus on one of the prehis-
toric cultural regions of Texas. Since 1958,
the BTAS has published papers summa-
rizing the archeology of various regions
of Texas: east Texas, central Texas, Trans-
Pecos Texas, and the central and southern
parts of the Gulf Coast; the southern
Texas coast; the Lower Pecos and eastern
Trans-Pecos; Texas Panhandle and South-
ern Plains; north-central Texas; and north-
eastern Texas (see Perttula 1995c, 8).

In 1995, the time seemed propitious
to again take stock of our current knowl-
edge of Texas archeology. Thus, the 1995
BTAS provided a summary collection
of papers on the archeology of many
different cultural and natural regions
of Texas—from the Caddo mounds of
northeastern Texas, the Archaic and Late
Prehistoric shell middens of the Gulf
Coast, the burned rock middens of cen-
tral Texas, the slab houses of Plains farm-
ers and bison hunters, to the Puebloan
villages of the Hueco Bolson and the Rio
Grande. The success of the 1995 BTAS,
the support of the TAS board of directors
in presenting the most current archeolog-
ical ﬁndings to a broad audience, and the
resulting new interest generated in the
prehistoric archeology of Texas led di-
rectly to the preparation of this book.
We had several goals in mind as we
set about compiling this volume on pre-
historic archeology of Texas—a big job
for a big state. Our primary goal is to re-
cord and communicate, in one accessible
source, what has been learned (and what
we still do not know) about all aspects
of Texas archeology from about 1950 to

2000. Second, recognizing the constantly
evolving understanding of the prehistoric
archeology of Texas as new sites are found
and explored and new ideas are proposed,
evaluated, challenged, reﬁned, and ex-
plored again, we view the book as a rare
opportunity for professional archeologists
working in Texas to take stock of what we
know (or think we know) in a compre-
hensive way and to attempt to synthesize
the very diverse character of the archeo-
logical record in Texas. In taking a broad
and synthetic view of the prehistoric
archeology of the state of Texas, our ef-
forts are a long overdue follow-up to
Sayles’s 1935 work, the classic 1954 BTAS
(Suhm et al. 1954), and other syntheses,
and we hope that the reader will ﬁnd the
present book to be a suitable accompani-
ment to those volumes.

Organization of the Volume

Following this introductory chapter,
the remaining chapters in this volume are
summaries of the current state of archeo-
logical knowledge in different cultural-
ecological regions of Texas (Fig. 1.1). The
regions are broadly deﬁned, following the
divisions recognized in the COE-SWD
overviews, physiographic zones, and bi-
otic communities (see D. E. Brown et al.
1998, ﬁg. 5 and table 4), and there are
inevitable overlaps in coverage and
presentation.

There is probably no area in North
America that is as environmentally di-
verse as Texas (Figs. 1.2 and 1.3). Within
its arbitrary boundaries are warm temper-
ate forests and woodlands, swamps and
riparian forests, and deciduous and ever-
green forests in the eastern and southeast-
ern reaches of the state; Gulf coastal
grasslands and wetlands; plains or cold
temperate grasslands in the High Plains
and in the prairies of north Texas; unique
canyonland habitats in the Edwards Pla-
teau and Llano Estacado; Chihuahuan
or warm temperate and semidesert grass-
lands along the border and the Trans-
Pecos; warm temperate desert lands with
scrub and chaparral in far south Texas;
and Tamaulipan thornscrub and semide-
ciduous forests and woodlands in south
Texas and the lower Rio Grande valley
(see Blair 1950; Diamond et al. 1987;
D. E. Brown et al. 1998). Even with sub-
stantial changes in paleoenvironmental

conditions over the last twelve thousand
years or more, from the Late Pleistocene
(ending about ten thousand years ago) to
the modern Holocene period (ten thou-
sand years ago to the present), these habi-
tats supported a plethora of wild plants
and animals that, with knowlege, skill,
and ingenuity, could be and were ex-
ploited by generations of Native Ameri-
can groups.

Consequently, it is no surprise that the
prehistoric archeology of Texas is incredi-
bly diverse. Because of this manifest di-
versity over a long span of human history
in North America, Native American
adaptations are quite varied from one bi-
otic community to another in the state,

and the chapters in this volume deal di-
rectly with the distinctive but changing
character of Native American life in the
prairies and plains, the Edwards Plateau,
the canyonlands and High Plains, the
coastal lands, the inhospitable and climat-
ically challenging deserts and mountain
basins of west Texas, and the well-watered
prairies, woodlands, and pineywoods of
eastern and northern Texas (see Fig. 1.2).
The temporal framework employed in

this book is quite straightforward and
matches the terminology and age ranges
found in other treatments of the archeol-
ogy of much of the southern, central, and
southwestern parts of North America
(Bell 1984b; Bense 1994; Cordell 1997;

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

Mainfort and Jeter 1999; O’Brien and
Wood 1998; Sassaman and Anderson
1996; Wood 1998). The prehistoric
archeology of Texas began at least 11,500
years before the present (b.p. meaning, by
convention, a.d. 1950) (Table 1.1), in the
Early Paleoindian period.1 Depending
upon the region and the archeologist, the
Paleoindian period ended between 8,000
and 9,000 b.p. across Texas and was suc-
ceeded by the Archaic period, with Early,
Middle, and Late temporal subdivisions.
Although a time of considerable diversity
in lifeways, material culture, and behav-
ior, the Archaic periods had mobile groups
across the state all characterized by a gen-
eralized hunting-foraging economy. The
Archaic periods ended between 2,000 and
1,000 years ago, and they are followed by
Late Prehistoric cultures. In some areas,
such as the High Plains, the upper Texas
Coast, east Texas, and east-central Texas,
archeologists also have deﬁned Ceramic
and/or Woodland periods that lasted
from ca. 2,000 to 1,200 years ago (see
Table 1.1). One of the more notable
archeological characteristics of this period
of time in these areas is the adoption of
pottery by these particular aboriginal
groups, and these groups also seem to
have become more sedentary than other
hunter-gatherer populations in Texas.
The Late Prehistoric period began be-
tween ca. 1,200 and 1,000 years ago and
lasted until ca. 250 years ago in Texas (see
Table 1.1), when Spanish and French
colonists, traders, and missionaries began
to settle across the area and write about
the Native Americans living in what was
to become Texas. Other than the fact that
these Late Prehistoric groups all made ar-
row points and generally used and made a
variety of ceramic wares, this period was
really a time of much diversity in the way
of life of aboriginal populations (i.e., from
mound-building Caddo farmers to bison-
hunting nomads on the High Plains).
The Late Prehistoric groups that inhab-
ited Texas can often be readily associated
with more modern Native American
groups—such as the Caddos, Wichitas,
and the Karankawas—but in other re-
gions of the state, matching the archeo-
logical record with ethnic afﬁliations is
quite a challenge (see M. Collins 1999,
table 1).

As the reader will note in the chapters

01-A2946  4/13/04  11:44 AM  Page 9

INTRODUCTION TO TEXAS PREHISTORIC ARCHEOLOGY / 9

Table 1.1. Chronological Charts for Archeological Regions in Texas

that follow, most of the Native Americans
that lived in Texas during prehistoric
times lived by hunting and collecting
plant and animal foods, and the archeo-
logical record across much of the state
provides abundant evidence for the differ-
ent kinds and ranges of camping activities
of many related and unrelated bands of
hunters and gatherers. In east Texas, the
prehistoric Caddo Indians were successful
farmers who came to depend upon the
cultivation of maize, beans, and squash to
support their complex and well-organized

societies, and they continued to live in
Texas until 1859, when they were re-
moved to Oklahoma (see F. Smith 1995,
1996). Other farming groups lived in the
western Trans-Pecos and the Panhandle,
but by a.d. 1450, these Native Americans
had either left those regions and/or
changed their lifeways and become more
nomadic hunters and gatherers again.
Who these people were is not known
with any conﬁdence; Myles R. Miller and
Nancy A. Kenmotsu (chapter 7) and
Robert L. Brooks (chapter 11) consider

these issues in detail. Similarly, the ethnic
and cultural afﬁliations of many of the
prehistoric hunting and gathering groups
that lived in Texas are debatable. The
small size of most of these groups, their
nomadic nature, the effects of introduced
European diseases and increased mortal-
ity after the mid-sixteenth to seventeenth
centuries throughout North America (for
mortality in Texas see Ewers 1973), and
the absence of direct European observa-
tions and writings leave us in many cases
with little more than the name of a group

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

01-A2946  4/13/04  11:44 AM  Page 10

10 / TEXAS PREHISTORY

and a geographic location. In spite of
these difﬁculties, in many regions archeo-
logical and historical research has estab-
lished some linkages between the prehis-
toric archeological record of tribes such as
the Caddos, the Wichitas and afﬁliated
groups, the Karankawas, the Querechos
and Teyas of the Southern Plains, the Ju-
manos, and the Mansos and Sumas in the
western Trans-Pecos. The Tonkawas, long
thought to have been prehistoric residents
of Texas (see Newcomb 1961), are now
known to have migrated into the state in
the late seventeenth century and coalesced
with Native American groups that moved
north from their original locations in
northern Mexico (see summaries in New-
comb 1993 and Prikryl 2001). Where
helpful in providing different interpreta-
tions of the prehistoric archeological rec-
ord in several regions of Texas, chapters
in this book will explore these archeologi-
cal, ethnic, and cultural relationships.

However, we begin ﬁrst with a lengthy
chapter that concerns the earliest inhabi-
tants of Texas, the Paleoindians. These
highly mobile groups lived in Texas more
than 9,000 years ago, and perhaps as long
as 11,500 to 12,000 years ago (see Table
1.1). Understanding the lifeways of these
ancient hunter-gatherers is truly a conti-
nental challenge, as our interest is not
only in how and when these peoples from
the Old World initially colonized and
settled all of North America (see, for ex-
ample, Anderson and Gillam 2000) but
also in the character of their adaptations
once they settled in different regions
within present-day Texas and bordering
states. With the recent and compelling
evidence for the settlement of the Monte
Verde site in South America by at least
12,500 years ago (see Dillehay 1997)
and the controversial discovery and study
of 9,000-year-old human remains from
the Kennewick site in Washington state
(Chatters 2000; R. Taylor et al. 1998;
D. Thomas 2000), the study of the Paleo-
indian archeology of North and South
America is currently a very exciting and
rapidly changing ﬁeld.

Chapter 2, by C. Britt Bousman,
Barry W. Baker, and Anne C. Kerr, dem-
onstrates that Texas has a substantial
post–twelve thousand-year-old Paleo-
indian archeological record, with at least
456 known archeological components
widely distributed across the state

(Fig. 1.4). Archeological research on
Paleoindian sites in the state has been
ongoing since the early 1920s at famous
archeological sites such as Lubbock Lake,
Midland, Plainview, Bonﬁre Shelter,
Horn Shelter, and Wilson-Leonard, along
with a host of others discussed in chapter
2. The authors’ exhaustive summary in-
cludes a reclassiﬁcation of all known
Paleoindian lanceolate and stemmed pro-
jectile point forms found in Texas, in
combination with a review of the geologi-
cal stratigraphy and chronology of the
better-known sites, to establish with some
conﬁdence the absolute chronology of
Clovis, Folsom-Midland, Plainview, Early
Stemmed, San Patrice and Scottsbluff,
Golondrina-Barber, and Angostura-
Thrall occupations. Bousman, Baker, and
Kerr also review the record of Paleoindian
subsistence from plant and animal re-
mains, as well as dental studies from
Paleoindian burials, and they highlight
the complexity of subsistence adaptations

by Paleoindian groups, which in most

prehistoric archeological record of the
Caddo peoples that lived there until the
mid-nineteenth century (see Fig. 1.7).

The prehistoric Caddos were a seden-
tary horticultural group that lived in dis-
persed communities, villages, hamlets,
and farmsteads, and they maintained a re-
ligious and political elite that lived on
ﬂat-topped earthen mounds and were in-
terred in accompanying burial mounds.
These elites interacted widely with their
neighbors to obtain exotic goods that
symbolized and solidiﬁed their chieﬂy au-
thority in their communities. Of particu-
lar interest in chapter 13 is a summary of
the archeology of the Late Caddoan com-
munities that lived in east Texas at the
time of initial European contact, most
notably the well-known Titus phase
(ca. a.d. 1450 –1680) Caddo groups (see
Fig. 1.7) that De Soto encountered in the
early 1540s but who had abandoned much
of the Big Cypress Bayou and Sabine River
basins by the mid- to late seventeenth
century. The Titus phase archeological
record provides a detailed accounting of
the lives of Caddo peoples immediately
before and after the entry of Europeans
into the east Texas Pineywoods.

The archeology of north Texas ranges
from the spectacular stratiﬁed Aubrey site
with Clovis-era deposits (see Fig. 1.4) to

the distinctive Late Prehistoric Southern
Plains Village archeological record (dating
from ca. a.d. 700 –1600) (see Fig. 1.7
and Drass 1998). There is a great need
for a regional synthesis of the archeologi-
cal record in this area, and the available
archeological evidence suggests there are
differences and continuities in adaptation
and technological character between Na-
tive American groups on the middle Bra-
zos, the upper and middle Trinity River
basins, and the upper reaches of the Red
River (see Drass 1998; Hofman et al.
1989b). These differences and continu-
ities can be seen in the features, subsis-
tence remains (including the use of bison
and the adoption of maize), projectile
points and ceramic styles, and the use of
different raw materials, particularly high-
quality lithics, preserved in the archeo-
logical record. Due to an unfortunate set
of circumstances, none of the archeolo-
gists working in Texas who have expertise
in the prehistory of northern Texas were
able to contribute to this volume. The
reader is referred to Drass (1998) for a re-
cent and masterful synthesis of the arche-
ology of Plains Village peoples on the
Southern Plains of northern Texas, Okla-
homa, and southern Kansas.

The chapters, for the most part, are

broadly cultural-historical in nature.
Nevertheless, they stay strongly focused
on important and current research prob-
lems recognized in each of the environ-
mentally based regions that hold par-
ticular promise for achieving a better
understanding of prehistoric (from at
least 12,000 to 12,500 years ago to before
ca. a.d. 1520) and early historic (before
ca. a.d. 1700) Native American adapta-
tions in Texas. Of course, the emphases
of the different chapters vary depending
upon the state of archeological knowledge

in a particular region of the state—rang-
ing from the discussion of one or a few to
many particular research problems and
perspectives, temporal periods, and cul-
tural manifestations—and our current
understanding of long- and short-term
cultural change across the state. Thus, the
various chapters in The Prehistory of Texas
present both careful but exhaustive con-
siderations of the Texas archeological (and
paleoenvironmental) record, while offer-
ing new, vital, and innovative means of
understanding the past.

Paleoindian Archeology in Texas

C. Britt Bousman, Barry W. Baker, and Anne C. Kerr

The following sentences are excerpts from
the ﬁrst scientiﬁc article about Paleo-
indian archeology in Texas:

Good, dependable[,] deﬁnite evidence
of human artifacts in the Pleistocene in
America has at last been found. Many
geologists and investigators have been
expecting such evidence to be turned
up. . . . In the present instance, fortu-
nately, the evidence is so dependable that
no reasonable doubt can exist that the
artifacts and fossil animals found are
contemporaneous, and that the animals
and artifacts are in original, undisturbed
Pleistocene deposits. . . . The location of
these ﬁnds is a point near the Colorado
River, near the southeastern end of the
Staked Plains, and near the little town of
Colorado, Texas, on Lone Wolf Creek.
(Cook 1925, 459 – 60)

Lone Wolf Creek (Fig. 2.1) was exca-
vated by members of the Colorado (now
Denver) Museum of Natural History in
1924, and they found the articulated re-
mains of a very large bison, now believed
to be Bison antiquus, in direct association
with three lanceolate projectile points.
Based on the size of the bison and the
depth of the remains, Harold Cook, an
honorary curator of paleontology, inferred
that they dated to the Late Pleistocene.
The 1925 article by Cook was published
six months before he and Jesse D. Figgins,
the museum director, made their ﬁrst

visit to the now-famous Folsom site in
New Mexico (Cook 1927; Figgins 1927).
Cook wrote a second, more persuasive
and conﬁdent article on the discoveries at
Lone Wolf Creek the same summer that
the initial Folsom excavations took place.
Clearly written with the Folsom discover-
ies in mind, the 1926 article, entitled
“The Antiquity of Man in America: Who
Were the First Americans? Whence Came
They?” is a rebuttal to a piece written by
Ales Hrdlicka only a few months prior in
the same journal, Scientiﬁc American. At
the time, Hrdlicka was a towering ﬁgure
in American anthropology. He strongly
advocated a model of recent immigration
of Native Americans to the New World
and refuted claims for a Pleistocene pas-
sage. In his second article, Cook, relying
on geological and paleontological meth-
ods, precisely and deftly refuted Hrdlicka’s
arguments regarding the antiquity of Na-
tive Americans. Hrdlicka (1907, 1918,
1926) believed that he could rely solely
on the lack of evidence for morphological
change reﬂected in Native American
skeletal remains. This debate occurred be-
fore the Folsom site had been accepted as
a Pleistocene-era occupation. In addition,
even though the signiﬁcance of Lone
Wolf Creek was not fully accepted by
North American archeologists until its
evidence was published a third time along
with the Folsom discoveries (Cook 1927;
Figgins 1927), it is clear from reading the
earlier articles that Cook unquestionably

15

believed Lone Wolf Creek provided the
necessary evidence to demonstrate the
presence of Native Americans during the
Pleistocene of North America (Cook
1925, 1926). Thus, this Texas site pro-
vided some of the earliest scientiﬁcally
valid evidence for the Paleoindian occu-
pation in North America.

The research that followed at Paleo-
indian sites in the 1930s and 1940s wit-
nessed remarkable discoveries in the
Southern Plains. Other pioneers of Paleo-
indian archeology in Texas include indi-
viduals such as Cyrus Ray, E. B. Sayles,
Erwin Barbour and Bertrand Schultz, and
especially Elias B. Sellards, Glen Evans,
and Grayson Meade. In 1934, Sellards
and Evans (with the Texas Memorial
Museum at the University of Texas in
Austin) excavated a site in a small playa,
near Miami in Roberts County, that con-
tained long ﬂuted projectile points and
mammoth bones (Sellards 1938). This
excavation was the ﬁrst of a Clovis site in
the state and the ﬁrst excavation by the
Sellards and Evans team.

Much later, after excavations at Mi-

ami, Buckner Ranch (also known as
Berclair Terrace), Plainview, Lubbock
Lake, and Midland in Texas, and Black-
water Draw and Milnesand in New Mex-
ico, Sellards established the “classic” se-
quence of Clovis, Folsom, Plainview, and
later (Plano) Paleoindian cultures (Sellards
1952; see also Sellards and Evans 1960).
They thought this sequence applied to

the entire Southern Plains and all of cen-
tral North America. The persistent re-
liance on this basic sequence can still be
seen in the recent prehistoric overviews
for the Southern Plains, south Texas, and
east Texas by Stephen L. Black (1989a,
1989b), Jack L. Hofman (1989), and Dee
Ann Story (1990). However, cracks are
starting to show as Hofman reviewed the
recognized complexes from a critical per-
spective and pointed out weaknesses and
unsolved problems in the data (Hofman
1989). Story chose to exclude Plainview
as an overused and meaningless label and
emphasized Clovis, Folsom, Dalton, San
Patrice, and Scottsbluff as more easily
identiﬁable and therefore more reliable
categories for the Gulf Coast Plain region
of Texas (Story 1990, 177).

Now, almost seventy-ﬁve years after
the excavation at Lone Wolf Creek, the
existence of North American Paleoindians
is not in doubt, but the record of the early
occupations of Texas by Native Ameri-
cans still contains many gaps. Today we
know that local sequences in the southern
prairies, plains, and woodlands show evi-
dence of small-scale developments with
limited distributions, and the monolithic

sequence of Paleoindian cultures proposed
by Sellards and Evans is too simple. Fur-
thermore, it is widely believed that Paleo-
indian societies were thinly distributed on
the landscape and, especially in the Pleis-
tocene, that these societies formed small
groups that occupied larger areas and
moved frequently. Even with a number of
newer detailed studies (Bamforth 1988;
M. Collins 1998b; Hofman 1994; Holli-
day 1997a; E. Johnson 1987c; L. Johnson
1989), we are still debating the nature and
structure of Paleoindian societies. This
chapter provides a brief summary and our
interpretation of this fragmentary record,
but only new, carefully designed and im-
plemented archeological research will
bridge the gaps and complete our knowl-
edge. Much remains to be done.

Typological Analysis of
Lanceolate and Stemmed
Projectile Points and the
Development of Paleoindian
Culture History

The term Paleoindian has different
meanings to different archeologists. Ac-
cording to some, the term is restricted to

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

Pleistocene peoples whose subsistence
base included the exploitation of extinct
megafauna such as mammoth, bison (Bi-
son antiquus), camel, and horse (Fiedel
1994). This point of view places Early
Holocene peoples in the Early Archaic
period. Other scholars refer to Pleistocene
peoples within the period of ca. 12,000 –
10,000 b.p. as Early Paleoindian, and Late
Paleoindian refers to those societies mak-
ing lanceolate projectile points during the
Early Holocene period of ca. 10,000 –
8,000 b.p. (E. Turner and Hester 1993).
We adopt the latter usage, but this choice
is not without difﬁculties, as we will dis-
cuss below.

The classiﬁcation of projectile points
remains one of the more dominant con-
cerns of Paleoindian archeologists in
Texas. While its importance should not
be overstated, it is clear that the entire
cultural-historical framework of Paleo-
indian archeology is highly dependent
on projectile point classiﬁcations. When
projectile points are absent from a site,
even with reliable radiocarbon dates the
depth and breadth of the conclusions we
can draw from such a site are limited.
Thus, the constructs presented in this
chapter, and Paleoindian archeology as
a whole, are intimately linked with ty-
pology. Given this context, it is instruc-
tive to review the history of how archeol-
ogists initially deﬁned these points and
how these deﬁnitions have changed
through time.

Folsom and Clovis

Certainly, the most distinct Paleo-
indian lanceolate projectile points are
those with ﬂutes (the negative scars of
elongated ﬂakes driven from the base on
both faces). The ﬁrst ﬂuted points docu-
mented in good stratigraphic contexts
were found at the Folsom site in New
Mexico. At this site, during excavation
seasons in 1926, 1927, and 1928, Jesse D.
Figgins (1927) and Harold Cook (1927)
discovered nineteen extremely well ﬂaked,
ﬂuted points in direct association with
an extinct form of bison. Later, similar
points were found at other sites in Texas,
such as Lipscomb (Fig. 2.2).

At ﬁrst, after the Folsom site was widely

accepted as evidence for Pleistocene-age
Native Americans, many archeologists did
not distinguish between the various kinds
of ﬂuted projectile points. In 1933 when
Edgar B. Howard (1935) began excavat-

02-A2946  4/13/04  11:46 AM  Page 17

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 17

ing at the Clovis site in Blackwater Draw,
he and John Cotter (1937, 1938) saw
signiﬁcant differences between what they
termed “generalized Folsom” or “Folsom-
like” as distinguished from “true Folsom”
points. Similar “Folsom-like” points were
found at Dent, Colorado, in 1932 and at
Miami, Texas, in 1934 (Fig. 2.3). By Sep-
tember, 1941, at a symposium held at
Santa Fe, New Mexico, it was agreed that
generalized Folsom would be called Clo-
vis Fluted and true Folsom would be
termed Folsom Fluted (E. Howard 1943;
Krieger 1947a). The major difference be-
tween Clovis Fluted and Folsom Fluted
was the longer ﬂutes, ﬁner ﬂaking, and
thinner cross sections in Folsom Fluted
points. It was also recognized that eastern
forms similar to Clovis existed and these
were called Ohio Fluted. The relative
temporal positions of Clovis as older and
Folsom as younger were not well under-
stood until Glen Evans’s careful analysis
of the stratigraphy at Blackwater Draw
( J. Hester et al. 1972). Archeologists have
retained the distinctions between Folsom
and Clovis and between different forms
of Clovis since the mid-twentieth century.
Numerous Clovis and Folsom points have
been discovered in Texas, and they have
been recovered from excavated sites such
as Miami, Lubbock Lake, Kincaid Shel-
ter, Bonﬁre Shelter, Aubrey, Lipscomb,
and Midland.

Unﬂuted Projectile Points
and the “Yuma Problem”

Unﬂuted lanceolate projectile point
typology presents a more difﬁcult puzzle.
E. B. Renaud’s (1931, 1932, 1934) intro-
duction of Yuma as a type illustrates this
quandary. Based on surface collections
from northeastern Colorado near Yuma,
Renaud (1931) described Yuma varieties
with careful and precise attention to size,
shape, and ﬂaking morphology (Fig. 2.4).
These characteristics are the same basic
set of observations used today, but Re-
naud’s use of surface collections and his
primary reliance on morphology instead
of context prematurely led to a series
of named types. Furthermore, Renaud
(1932, 10) thought that Yuma forms
preceded and were coeval with Folsom
forms, although Figgins (1935) and Rob-
erts (1940) suggested that Yuma points
were manufactured after the production
of Folsom projectile points had been
discontinued.

Even at this early stage, it was realized
that the Yuma typological concept failed
to provide insights. And so, through a
formal declaration at the 1941 Santa Fe
symposium (E. Howard 1943) and later
arguments offered by Hannah M. Wor-
mington (1948), “Yuma” was abandoned
in favor of more distinctive type names
such as Eden, Scottsbluff, and Oblique
Yuma. Wormington had the ﬁnal word
(1957, 103 –107) when she argued that
Yuma types were ﬂawed because of the
large degree of morphological variability
among the types and subtypes and be-
cause of Renaud’s failure to incorporate
contextual and chronological informa-
tion. Today the Yuma term is completely
abandoned, and other names are used to
reﬂect the variability that was represented
under the term.

Plainview, Golondrina, and Barber

In 1947 Alex Krieger described the
unﬂuted, parallel-ﬂaked, lanceolate pro-
jectile points from the Plainview site.
He called them Plainview and established
the concept on a detailed consideration
of morphology and context (Krieger
1947b). In doing so Krieger was one of
the ﬁrst to break ranks with the estab-
lished approach of calling all unﬂuted
projectile points Yuma. The Plainview
site, excavated in 1945, was interpreted as
a single-event bison kill with up to one
hundred killed or butchered bison (see
description below). Krieger (1947b, 938 –
52) described the points as being parallel-
sided and having concave bases with
rounded corners, grinding from base to
midpoint or slightly beyond, and two
forms of ﬂaking: irregular ﬂaking over

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

convex surfaces and collateral ﬂaking of
near equal size meeting at a medial ridge
(Fig. 2.5). Krieger amassed an impressive,
at least for the time, set of quantitative
data regarding metric dimensions, and
he compared his results with those from
other sites. It is clear that Krieger did not
ﬁnd the Yuma concept useful, and he ob-
viously thought that the limited amount
of variation he observed among the Plain-
view projectile points provided strong
evidence that this form was restricted in
time and space.

By 1954, with the publication of An
Introductory Handbook of Texas Archeology
by Dee Ann Suhm et al., the acceptable
variation for the Plainview type had
stretched well beyond the original deﬁni-
tion. The size, ﬂaking pattern, and shape
of Plainview points had all been greatly
expanded, and the type deﬁnition began
to be applied indiscriminately. This trend
began to be reversed a decade later with
the introduction of Plainview Golondrina
(golondrina being Spanish for swallow) as
a variant of the Plainview type by LeRoy
Johnson (1964) to distinguish projectile
points he excavated from the Devil’s
Mouth site in the Lower Pecos region
(Fig. 2.6). Johnson used the genus-species
concept as a way to highlight the similari-
ties and differences between Golondrina
and Plainview points. By 1977, however,
the genus-species approach had been
dropped, and only the term Golondrina
was being used to represent these un-
ﬂuted lanceolate projectile points with
distinctive ﬂared basal corners, deep basal
concavities, crescent-shaped basal thin-
ning scars, and more random ﬂaking pat-
terns (Hester 1977b).

In the early 1970s, both Joe Ben Wheat
(1972) and Cynthia Irwin-Williams et al.
(1973) had expressed serious concerns
regarding the use of the term Plainview.
It had become a label for any unﬂuted
lanceolate projectile point with parallel
sides and a concave base. Apparently, the
original tightly deﬁned Plainview type
had been transformed into a loosely de-
ﬁned, carelessly applied term reminiscent
of the Yuma concept.

In 1982, Tom Kelly published the ﬁrst

of his quantitative analyses of unﬂuted
lanceolate points. He was concerned
with the distinction between Plainview
(from the type site) and Golondrina
(from Devil’s Mouth), and he used factor

analysis and discriminant analysis to de-
velop a consistent and objective proce-
dure for determining the differences be-
tween these two types. Kelly selected
mostly basal attributes for measurement
and developed various indices to deter-
mine the typological identity of unﬂuted
lanceolate projectile points. Kelly con-
cluded (1982) that Plainview and Golon-
drina are distinct types. In addition, al-
though he did not indicate why speciﬁc
attributes were chosen, his discussion of
hafting differences indicates that these at-
tributes were useful characteristics of dif-
ferent hafting styles.

Based on the geometry of the different
point styles, Kelly (1982, 16) agreed with
W. James Judge (1973) and Ruthann
Knudson (1973, 1983) that Plainview
points were probably hafted in a bison rib
socket on a foreshaft and used primarily
as a projectile tip (Fig. 2.7). Alternatively,
he suggested that Golondrina points were
hafted on split-stem hafts with or without
foreshafts and used as both projectile
points and butchering knives. Kelly fur-
ther argued that the nature of these haft-
ing styles would require Plainview points
to be deeply set into a socketed haft and
bound with little cutting edge exposed,

while Golondrina points in a split-stem
haft would not need to be deeply set and
thus could expose more of the cutting
edge while still hafted (Kelly 1982, 17).
Kelly also reported on replication ex-
periments using Golondrina and Plain-
view points manufactured by J. B. Soll-
berger (Kelly 1982). In these experiments
a Golondrina point in a split-stem haft
easily withstood strong lateral pressures
that would be incurred during butcher-
ing, while the haft of the Plainview point
broke at weaker pressures. Kelly went on
to suggest that Plainview points were de-
signed as deeply penetrating projectile

tips for killing large animals such as bi-
son, while the basal ﬂaring of Golondrina
points would “resist penetration” of large
animals and thus were probably used for
killing medium-sized animals such as deer
or antelope and for butchering (1982, 17).
Marvin Kay’s use-wear analysis of Golon-
drina points from the Wilson-Leonard site
(1998) further supports Kelly’s hypothesis
that Golondrina points were used as both
projectiles and knives. Similar use-wear
analysis on a sufﬁcient sample of Plainview
points has yet to be done at this writing.
In a later paper, Kelly applied similar

quantitative techniques to the Brom
Cooper collection from McMullen
County, Texas, and identiﬁed a possible
variant of Plainview that was shorter and

narrower. Kelly informally called these
“Miniature Plainview” points (1983a, 28)
but recognized that he lacked good con-
textual information to distinguish these
points as a formal type.

In a third paper based on material
from the Byron Barber collection from
Gillespie County and from lanceolate
points excavated by the Texas Depart-
ment of Transportation (TxDOT) at
the Wilson-Leonard site in Williamson
County, Kelly’s quantitative analysis
(1983b) prompted him to identify a new
type that he called Barber. These are very
wide lanceolate points with slightly con-
tracting sides and very deep basal concav-
ities. Kelly (1983a, 21) noted the strati-
graphic position of Barber points below

Angostura points at Wilson-Leonard and
St. Mary’s Hall. Kelly (1983b) also sug-
gested that Barber points were hafted in
a nocked split-stem haft (Fig. 2.8). The
base of the deep concavity on Barber
points would ﬁt on this curved nock. In
sum, Kelly achieved most of the objec-
tives identiﬁed by Krieger (1944) in suc-
cessfully isolating a projectile point “type,”
that is, points with a distinctive morphol-
ogy that are restricted in space and time,
as well as supplementing the deﬁnition
with functional explication of distinctive
morphology.

Midland

Midland projectile points have also re-
ceived a considerable amount of attention

(Fig. 2.9). After excavations at the Mid-
land site (Scharbauer Ranch), Fred Wen-
dorf and Alex Krieger ﬁrst described this
type as unﬂuted Folsom points (Wendorf
et al. 1955). In 1959 they formally de-
scribed and provisionally named these
points Midland (Wendorf and Krieger
1959).

Midland points are often found in as-

sociation with Folsom points, and they
share some technological and morpholog-
ical attributes. Unﬂuted Folsom projectile
points are common in Folsom sites, and
it is not certain that these signiﬁcantly
differ from Midland points. But a few
sites have produced only Midland points,
leading to a hypothesis about an indepen-
dent Midland Complex that was contem-
porary with Folsom and shared some
characteristics in technology and lifestyle
(Blaine 1968; Irwin 1971). Wormington
(1957, 42) and Wendorf and Krieger
(1959, 67) suggest that Midland points
were too thin for ﬂuting because their
blanks were too thin at the beginning.
Martinez (1990) argues that Folsom and
Midland points from the Scharbauer
Ranch site (Midland) were probably
thicker than most Folsom points before
ﬂuting, and Hofman et al. (1990, 243 –
44) present evidence from Shifting Sands
that Midland points were thick enough
for ﬂuting. Thus, the “too thin to ﬂute”
hypothesis does not seem to be supported.
Analyses by Amick (1995), Hofman

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

22 / TEXAS PREHISTORY

(1991a, 1992), and Hofman et al. (1990)
have suggested that Midland and Folsom
projectile points are part of one techno-
logical system used by highly mobile spe-
cialized bison hunters. According to this
hypothesis, Midland points may have
been made at times when it was necessary
to conserve lithic raw material. In the
Southern Plains, where high-quality raw
materials are rare and restricted to only a
few sources, Folsom/Midland hunter-
gatherers tended not to make ﬂuted points
when their access to acceptable raw mate-
rial was limited. Because of the great skill
necessary for ﬂuting, the risk of manufac-
turing failures for Folsom points was
likely too high when there was no easy
access to fresh raw material (Amick 1995,
30 –31). Anthony Boldurian proposes
that Folsom groups, moving through the
Southern Plains, curated large bifaces in
order to extend access to acceptable mate-
rials for point manufacture at great dis-
tances from quarry sources (Boldurian
1991, 293 –94).

New research on Goshen-Plainview
technology has further complicated the
Midland point typology (Bradley and Fri-
son 1996; Frison et al. 1996). This work
indicates that Goshen-Plainview technol-
ogy shares some attributes with Folsom
technology, and in the Hell Gap assem-
blage it is difﬁcult to distinguish Midland
from Goshen-Plainview points. The re-
searchers suggest that the relationships
between Plainview, Midland, and un-
ﬂuted Folsom points need to be resolved
with more typological, stratigraphic, and
chronological study, particularly in the
Southern Plains. In light of these ﬁndings,
it is interesting to note the presence of a
large, very thin biface, usually considered
part of a Folsom tool kit (Boldurian
1991; Stanford and Broilo 1981), in the
Plainview point–dominated Ryan’s site
cache (Hartwell 1995, 172).

Angostura

Another example of a typological co-
nundrum is offered by Angostura points.
Jack Hughes (1949) brieﬂy described
lanceolate projectile points that he called
Long points, which had been excavated at
the Ray Long site in South Dakota at the
planned Angostura Reservoir. Richard
Wheeler (1954), during further excava-
tions at the same site, renamed these
points Angostura. In the same year, Suhm

et al. (1954) published a description based
on specimens from Texas. Wormington
supported the new name for points from
the Ray Long site (1957, 138 – 40) and it
was generally accepted, but she added to
the confusion by illustrating a point from
a site other than Ray Long (Greiser 1985).
Herbert Alexander’s excavations at
Levi Rock Shelter (1962, 1963, 1974,
1982) suggested that similar points
should be called Plainview-Angostura and
that a single group was responsible for
producing both forms. Birmingham and
Hester (1976) proposed the name Victo-
ria Angostura for a large, broad-bladed,
strongly constricted stemmed point from
the coastal plains of Texas. With his quan-
titative approach, Kelly distinguished
three variants of Angostura points—
Texas Angostura, Victoria Angostura,
and Zella Angostura—and suggested that
all were forms within the general range
(Kelly 1983a). It was not until the mid-
1990s that a formal description was pub-
lished on the original Angostura points,
which were distinguished on the basis of
a diagonal ﬂaking pattern and not on
shape and size (Wheeler 1995). Thoms
(1994) assessed the “Angostura” problem
and presented new evidence from the
Richard Beene site indicating that Angos-
tura points occurred near the end of the
Paleoindian period. Alternatively, Elton
Prewitt (1981) placed Angostura within
the Early Archaic period, based on his ex-
cavations at the Loeve site in Williamson
County.

Reclassiﬁcation of Selected
Lanceolate Points

As a response to the typological prob-
lems that have grown up around unﬂuted
Paleoindian projectile points, a recent
and comprehensive effort to classify these
points in Texas systematically was under-
taken during the TARL Wilson-Leonard
project (Dial et al. 1998; Kerr and Dial
1998). This analysis incorporated a larger
set of attributes partially derived from
Kelly’s original list (1982), considered a
much larger sample (182 points from
ﬁfteen sites) that included many of the
original points from many of the type
sites, and used different statistical proce-
dures (cluster analysis, discriminant
analysis, and analysis of variance). Lance-
olate points from Plainview, Wilson-

cupations that took place between 8800
and 8100 b.p. Levi Rock Shelter is poorly
dated, and the Tombstone Bluff speci-
mens are from a surface context. The cur-
rent evidence on stratigraphy, chronology,
or technology for Angostura cannot dis-
tinguish temporal or functional signiﬁ-
cance for the morphological variations
reﬂected by clusters 1–5. Therefore, this
wide range of variation has to be accepted
for now as part of the Angostura type
deﬁnition.

Lubbock

Also present in clusters 3 –5 are three
previously named Lubbock points from
Lubbock Lake (Holliday and Johnson
1990, ﬁg. 8; Knudson et al. 1998) and a
previously classiﬁed Plainview point from
Bonﬁre Shelter (Dibble and Lorrain
1968, ﬁg. 14d, specimen no. 392). These
four points share a similar contracting
stem morphology with Angostura but
differ from Angostura in ﬂaking pattern
and age. Specimen no. 392 is from Bone
Bed 2, Component C, at Bonﬁre Shelter
(Fig. 2.12) and is from the same unit as
the radiocarbon dates ranging between
10,230 and 9920 b.p. (see below). The
Lubbock points from Lubbock Lake are
associated with a radiocarbon age of 9950
! 120 b.p. Thus, these points from Lub-
bock Lake and Bonﬁre Shelter appear to
date to a similar interval (approximately
10,300 to 9900 b.p.) and are not contem-
porary with the Angostura points from
the Wilson-Leonard or Richard Beene
sites. Although there are only four speci-
mens in the sample, they present a com-
pelling pattern. But more specimens in
good stratigraphic and chronological con-
text would add better support for its type
status.

Thrall

The points within clusters 6 and 9
(Fig. 2.13) are easily distinguished from
the other contracting stem groups by very
thick stems and are predominantly from
Wilson-Leonard, with one specimen from
the Wiley Williams site. These points oc-
cur above Angostura specimens in Early
Archaic contexts at Wilson-Leonard
(Unit IIIa). Due to their distinctive mor-
phology and stratigraphic position, they
have been named Thrall. Thrall points
show some morphological similarity to
Victoria forms identiﬁed in Birmingham

Fig. 2.10. Metric attributes used in quantitative analysis of unﬂuted lanceolate points.

Leonard, Ryan’s site, Beidleman Ranch,
Bonﬁre Shelter, Lubbock Lake, St. Mary’s
Hall, Levi Rock Shelter, Milnesand (New
Mexico), Winkler-1 site, Sloan (Arkansas
Dalton), Devil’s Mouth, Baker Cave,
Tombstone Bluff, and Wiley Williams
were used in this analysis.

The variables used included ﬁve mea-

surements taken from the base or stem
segment of a lanceolate point and three
ratios developed from those measure-
ments to provide an indication of point
geometry at a standardized but approxi-
mate position of the haft (Fig. 2.10). Al-
though other measurements were taken,
the decision was made that the basal vari-
ables would provide the most dependable
measures of the original manufactured
point morphology. This decision was
based on the assumptions that the basal
variables would be less affected by dam-
age or resharpening than other measure-
ments that could be taken on the medial
or distal portions of points and that the
base of a point reﬂects differences in haft-
ing strategies, like a footprint reﬂects a
foot.

The results of this analysis are striking.
The cluster analysis identiﬁed twenty-one
clusters, and only four individual lanceo-
late points were left unclassiﬁed as out-
liers. Discriminant analysis suggested that
these clusters were coherent, and the
analysis of variance procedure determined
which attributes offered the greatest diag-
nostic potential. Two broad morphologi-

cal categories of lanceolate forms were
identiﬁed: contracting stem and parallel
stem forms. To assess the typological sta-
tus of the morphological clusters the
stratigraphic and chronological afﬁliations
of the individual clusters were also exam-
ined. This examination led to the conclu-
sion that several of the individual clusters
could be combined to form groups that
in some cases reached the level of types.
As new stratigraphic and chronological
evidence comes forth, the status of these
groups can be reviewed and revised, but
for the present, this analysis is the least
subjective classiﬁcation of unﬂuted lance-
olate points. A summary of this analysis
brings a fresh outlook to Paleoindian pro-
jectile point typology.

convex to slightly concave. The speci-
mens from Wilson-Leonard are all be-
lieved to have been discarded during oc-

Points with Deep Basal Concavities

The ﬁnal six clusters are characterized

thick, parallel stems. These clusters dis-

Atypical St. Mary’s Hall

The exception is cluster 16, which con-
tains specimens called atypical St. Mary’s
Hall (Fig. 2.19). These points have stem
width and thickness proportions similar
to those of St. Mary’s Hall but have atypi-

these specimens differ from the rest of the
lanceolates with deep basal concavities by
their narrower stem widths and shallower
basal concavities. The specimens are from
the St. Mary’s Hall and Wilson-Leonard
sites and are temporally comparable to
the St. Mary’s Hall type.

(Fig. 2.20). While cluster 17 contains
mostly points with slightly contracting

stems identiﬁed as Barber, cluster 18 has
points with slightly expanding stems
characteristic of Golondrina, and cluster
19 comprises primarily Dalton points
(from the Sloan site in Arkansas) with the
deepest basal concavities. The specimens
in clusters 20 and 21, with wider stems
than seen in the other clusters, show a
range from Golondrina to Barber.

These clusters illustrate the full range
of basal shape present in all three types.
This range, however, renders such basal
characteristics useless for assigning typol-
ogy among points with deep basal con-
cavities. A look at ﬂaking pattern gener-
ally distinguishes Dalton points, which
show more controlled and regular ﬂaking
than either Golondrina or Barber. Based
on the dates from Rodgers Shelter in Mis-
souri (Wood and McMillan 1976), it ap-
pears that Dalton points may be older
than Golondrina. With most of the mor-
phological continuum from Golondrina
to Barber present in the Golondrina
type site collection from Devil’s Mouth
(L. Johnson 1964; see Fig. 2.6), at present
there is no stratigraphic or chronological
evidence that supports their separation as
types. Also, Hester (1995, ﬁg. 10; see also
Hester, chapter 4, this volume) illustrates
a cache of Golondrina points from south
Texas, and the specimens show the full
range between Golondrina and Barber.

Stemmed Points

Stemmed points have been found in
apparent Paleoindian contexts at a num-
ber of sites in west, central, and south

Texas. The clear occurrence of stemmed
points stratiﬁed above and below com-
ponents with lanceolate projectile points
in a well-dated context at the Wilson-
Leonard site highlights the difﬁculty of
equating Paleoindian status with only
those components having lanceolate pro-
jectile points. In the last half of the twen-
tieth century as many as four different
stemmed forms may have been found on
Paleoindian sites in Texas.

Wilson

At the Devil’s Mouth site, LeRoy
Johnson (1964) and William Sorrow
(1968) found expanding stem projec-
tile points with basal grinding in layers
they believed were Paleoindian in age
(Fig. 2.21). Johnson (1964, 55 –57, and
ﬁgs. 17–18) indicates that these were
found in the Upper Gravels in Area C,
while Sorrow (1968) found stemmed
forms in Strata O and P of Area D. Other
sites with early stemmed points include
the Landslide site (Sorrow et al. 1967),
the Merrell site (Campbell 1948), and
possibly Horn Shelter No. 2, Northern
Area (Forrester 1985). Ellen Sue Turner
and Thomas Hester (1993) refer to these
points as early stemmed. Similar points
have been found in surface contexts at
other sites, but the excavations at Wilson-
Leonard uncovered a large intact occupa-
tion within the Leanne Soil (Bousman
1998a).

Two forms occur at Wilson-Leonard.
The most common form (see Fig. 2.21) is
very similar to those from Devil’s Mouth,

to those found at Buckner Ranch (see be-

expanding stems with ﬂat to slightly con-
cave bases, and the shoulder morphology
extends from prominent to slightly
barbed. The sides and base of stems are
ground. At Wilson-Leonard, most of the
specimens are complete, although often
they are intensively resharpened and thus
blade length varies. The specimens with
the longer blades all have a long triangu-
lar shape that becomes arched near the
tip but have a very short, squat triangular
shape as resharpening progresses. The

major difference between the Devil’s
Mouth and Wilson-Leonard specimens is
that the latter are consistently thicker and
have shorter stems. It is unclear if this is
a difference in the production of these
points or a difference in the available raw
materials.

Marvin Kay (1998) conducted a use
wear analysis of the Wilson points at Wil-
son-Leonard, and it indicated that many
of them had complex use histories. Some
were used ﬁrst as points and then later as
knives, some were resharpened, another
was used ﬁrst as a knife and then showed
evidence of impact fractures, one was ﬁrst

a point and then retooled into a burin,
and a ﬁnal specimen was used ﬁrst as a
point and then recycled into a scraper.
Bousman’s analysis (1998a) of the Wilson
and Late Paleoindian materials at Wilson-
Leonard suggested that the stemmed pro-
jectile points were less likely to break
than were lanceolate forms and that this
could be one reason for the eventual shift
to stemmed forms.

A number of sites have points with
broad, moderately short blades, shallow
side-notched stems, and concave bases

Clarence Webb (1946) originally de-

points. They all fall within the morpho-
logical range of San Patrice. These points
appear to date between 9500 and 8000

be done before this distinctive form can
be considered securely dated.

Big Sandy

At Wilson-Leonard a single triangu-
lar point with a narrow side notch was
identiﬁed as Big Sandy (see Fig. 2.23).
This form is not common in Texas, and
we believe that Wilson-Leonard is the
only site producing an excavated speci-
men in a dated context.

Summary

The above section discusses the evi-
dence for Texas Paleoindian projectile
point typology. A number of distinctive
morphological forms carry signiﬁcant cul-
tural-historical information. These forms
include Clovis, Folsom, Plainview,
Golondrina-Barber, Wilson, St. Mary’s
Hall, Dalton, Scottsbluff, Angostura,
Berclair, San Patrice, Big Sandy, Lub-
bock, and Thrall. With this larger array
of more ﬁnely tuned point types it is pos-
sible to begin the work needed to im-
prove the chronological-stratigraphic
range of these forms. Then, with greater
conﬁdence, researchers will be able to de-
velop more anthropologically and behav-
iorally focused analyses of Paleoindian
archeology in Texas.

Geological Stratigraphy
and Site Descriptions

The geological setting of the great ma-

jority of Paleoindian sites can be easily
summarized: most are surface occurrences
and do not occur in a buried context.
However, a few sites have been discovered
in buried contexts, and the geological set-
tings were documented to varying degrees.
The geological stratigraphy of Paleo-

indian sites in Texas, especially on the
Llano Estacado, has recently been re-
viewed in detail by Vance Holliday
(1997a), and a full treatment is not war-
ranted here. Nevertheless, a discussion of
the stratigraphic settings of sites with well-
recorded stratigraphy is essential for the
presentation of other sources of evidence.
Holliday (1997a) does rename strati-
graphic units at many of the sites; how-
ever, in this chapter, when possible, the
original stratigraphic nomenclature from
the site reports or most complete descrip-
tion is used. Holliday (1997a) demon-
strates that most Paleoindian sites occur
in a limited number of depositional envi-
ronments in the High Plains. These are
alluvial, eolian, and playa settings. To this
can be added rockshelters from the Lower
Pecos and central Texas regions. Of
course, these are the most widespread
geological settings where Late Pleistocene
and Holocene deposits accumulate, so
buried sites should be found in them.
Few other areas have excavated Paleo-
indian sites, and the geological contexts

of Paleoindian sites in these other regions
remain poorly understood. Additionally,
no true coastal Paleoindian sites are
known because the Pleistocene coasts
were ﬂooded by rising sea levels that
have probably inundated sites.

Lubbock Lake (41LU1)

To date, the best studied and most
carefully documented Paleoindian strati-
graphic sequence is from the site of Lub-
bock Lake (E. Johnson 1987c). Lubbock
Lake is actually a complex series of indi-
vidual excavations conducted during four
separate stages by different institutions
over many years in the same general seg-
ment of Yellowhouse Draw (Fig. 2.24).
This portion of Yellowhouse Draw had a
series of springs that dried in the 1930s,
and a U-shaped pond was dug by the
Works Progress Administration (WPA) in
the hopes of reactivating the springs. The
ﬁrst archeological excavation was directed
by Joe Ben Wheat (1974) for the WPA in
1939. The second effort was directed by
Sellards, Evans, and Meade under the
auspices of the Texas Memorial Museum,

and the excavations occurred sporadically
between 1948 and 1955. F. E. Green re-
newed excavations in 1959 and 1960 for
the West Texas Museum at Texas Tech
University. The most recent phase of in-
vestigations has been directed by Eileen
Johnson. She and Vance Holliday worked
together from the mid-1970s forward on
the Lubbock Lake Project (see also John-
son and Holliday, chapter 9, this vol-
ume). It is the stratigraphic record estab-
lished for Lubbock Lake initially by Glen
Evans (stratigraphic notes for Stations B,
D, E, F, G, H, I, and M on ﬁle at TARL)
and reﬁned in works by Stafford (1981),
Holliday and Allen (1987), and Holliday
(1995d, 1997a) that is presented here.

Five primary units were identiﬁed and
numbered consecutively (1–5) from bot-
tom to top (Fig. 2.25). These sediments
were deposited in a Pleistocene cut chan-
nel. Stratum 1 at the bottom is alluvial
sand and gravel, and it contains the oldest
archeological remains, probably Clovis
aged. Stratum 2, conformable above Stra-
tum 1, consists of multiple facies: 2A, 2B,
2e, and 2s. In Holliday’s nomenclature

the letter e indicates an eolian deposit and
the letter s represents slope wash. Within
facies 2A are a number of thin distinctive
depositional units called local beds (LB1–
4) composed of diatomite, thin lens of
diatomite interstratiﬁed with sands, and
diatomaceous muds.

Stratum 2 contained the original Fol-

som materials excavated by Sellards,
Evans, and Meade at Station D in 1951.
Stratum 2B is composed of a paludal mud
and has slope (2s) and eolian (2e) facies.
Fine subdivisions, also called local beds,
were identiﬁed in Stratum 2s. These are
identiﬁed by the letters a, b, and c. Buried
bone in Stratum 2B, excavated by Evans
and Meade in 1950 at Station M, was
originally believed to be Folsom in age.
The radiocarbon age of 9883 ! 350 b.p.
was thought to be the ﬁrst radiocarbon
date on Folsom material in North Amer-
ica, even though diagnostic artifacts were
not present, but later stratigraphic work
demonstrated that this material was actu-
ally younger in age. The upper part of
Stratum 2B is weathered to form the First-
view soil, with the period of soil formation

spanning the period between 8500 and
6300 b.p. Above Stratum 2 are Strata 3, 4,
and 5, and these units contain Archaic and
Late Prehistoric components (see Johnson
and Holliday, chapter 9, this volume).

Wilson-Leonard (41WM235)

Wilson-Leonard is another recently
excavated site with a well-studied strati-
graphic record (Goldberg and Holliday
1998). This site is in central Texas and
presents the most complete single cul-
tural sequence in that portion of the state
(M. Collins 1998b). Wilson-Leonard is
situated in a Late Pleistocene and Holo-
cene terrace of Brushy Creek in southern
Williamson County. It is signiﬁcant for
demonstrating the existence of a stemmed
projectile point component (called Wil-
son) stratiﬁed above and below classic
lanceolate Paleoindian occupations.

The Wilson component represents the

remains discarded from a series of resi-
dential camps, with artifacts and bone
scattered around multiple hearths, and
the interment of a middle-aged woman in
a shallow burial pit (Bousman 1998a).

Below the Wilson component is the so-
called Bone Bed component (M. Collins
1998a). This level contains the scattered
remains of butchered bison and a single
horse bone at the bottom of a stream
channel. Only a single projectile point
was found in the Bone Bed component,
and Kerr and Dial’s (1998) statistical
analysis suggests that it is most similar
to Plainview, although Collins’s techno-
logical analysis demonstrates similarities
with Folsom/Midland ﬂaking technology
(M. Collins 1998a). Clovis materials were
discovered below the Bone Bed compo-
nent in a gravel unit (M. Collins 1998a).
Above the Wilson component is a stra-
tum with a variety of unﬂuted lanceolate
Paleoindian projectile points, including
Golondrina-Barber, St. Mary’s Hall,
Scottsbluff, San Patrice, Big Sandy, and
Angostura (Bousman 1998a). Capping
the Paleoindian strata is a stratum that
contains the complete central Texas Ar-
chaic and Late Prehistoric sequence (see
M. Collins, chapter 3, this volume).

Goldberg and Holliday (1998) divided

the deposits into three primary units:

Unit I, Unit II, and Unit III, and these
are subdivided into a series of more dis-
crete deposits (Fig. 2.26). Starting at the
bottom, Unit Igl is an alluvial unit that
sits unconformably on bedrock. It is
composed of a gravel bar complex con-
taining Clovis materials that form the
bottom of a Pleistocene-aged channel.
Unit Igl interdigitates with and is covered
by a thin silty alluvial deposit called Unit
Isi. In the central portion of the site at
the location of the excavation block, and
above Unit Isi, is a clayey cienega (pond)
that largely plugs a Pleistocene channel.
In Unit Isi below the cienega deposit
(Unit Icl) is the Bone Bed component.
The cienega deposit is virtually archeolog-
ically sterile, and no diagnostic artifacts
were recovered in those sediments. Above
the cienega and the lateral silty alluvial de-
posits (Unit Isi) is the Leanne Soil (Holli-
day 1992) with the Wilson component.
Goldberg and Holliday (1998) label the
Leanne Soil as Unit Ic. Above Unit Ic is a
silty deposit, called Unit Id, that forms
the uppermost subunit of Unit I, and it
also contains Wilson component materi-
als. The upper boundary of Unit I con-
sists of eroded Unit Ic or Unit Id sedi-
ments. Unit II is above Unit I, and it has
much more poorly sorted sediments that
appear to be from colluvial and alluvial
sources. Within Unit II are a series of
Late Paleoindian occupations that cannot
be separated stratigraphically, although
the lowermost materials are primarily
Golondrina-Barber points; the middle
portion of the unit has St. Mary’s Hall
and a series of parallel-sided lanceolate
forms, and the upper portion has Angos-
tura points. The upper boundary of Unit
II represents an unconformity that in

places is marked by the excavation of
Early Archaic ovens with early split-stem
forms such as Gower and Hoxie. Unit III
contains the remaining portion of the
Holocene cultural record.

Aubrey (41DN479)

In 1988 C. Reid Ferring discovered
the Aubrey site, which was deeply buried
in the ﬂoodplain of the Elm Fork of the
Trinity River in Denton County. This
Clovis site was exposed when the U.S.
Army Corps of Engineers excavated a
deep trench during the construction of
the outﬂow channel for Ray Roberts
Lake. Ferring (1989a, 1989b, 1989c,
1990a, 1990b, 1992) conducted exten-
sive excavations and geoarcheological
work at the site.

Ferring identiﬁed eight geological
units at the Aubrey site (Fig. 2.27). The
sequence is well dated (see below) and be-
gins sometime before ﬁfteen thousand
years ago, when the Elm Fork began to
downcut its Late Pleistocene ﬂoodplain
and isolate the Denton Creek terrace.
The downcutting was deep enough to
erode bedrock and carve a deeper chan-
nel. At the base of this channel a sand
and gravel bar (Unit A) formed, and
on its surface Clovis hunter-gatherers
camped near the stream. Unit B1 is silts,
clays, and peat that were deposited in a
spring-fed pool. This pool formed in a
low depression on the Unit A sand and
gravel bar. Ferring argues that little allu-
vial deposition occurred during the for-
mation of Unit B1. Unit B2 consists of
peat, spring travertines, and tufas depos-
ited in the pool. While this apparently
was a period of increased spring ﬂow,
there was still very little alluvial deposi-

tion. Unit C comprises cross-bedded tu-
fas and marls deposited in the pool by
spring seep. These deposits change to silty
and sandy marls at the pool margins
when colluvial deposits are introduced
from the Pleistocene terrace. Unit D is a
sand and gravel colluvial deposit that pro-
graded from the western portion of the
pool and formed the “red wedge” unit.
After the “red wedge” was deposited, the
surface was stable or eroding in the main
axis of the channel. Clovis-related arti-
facts and discarded materials were left on
the surface of the “red wedge,” the eroded
pond deposits, and the exposed surface of
the Unit A sand and gravel bar (see
Fig. 2.27). Unit E is interstratiﬁed clay
and thin marl beds. These beds mark the
renewed deposition of pool deposits. In
the eastern portion of the site renewed al-
luviation deposited Unit F sediments.
Unit G is clay and silt alluvium that rap-
idly covered the remainder of the Clovis
occupation during the Early Holocene.
The top of Unit G weathered in the
Middle Holocene to form a soil. Unit H
is overbank clays and silts that apparently
accumulated during the Late Holocene.
This unit covers Unit G, and a soil has
formed on its surface as well.

Miami (41RB1)

Bones were ﬁrst discovered by Charles
Puckett on the C. R. Cowan Ranch near
Miami, Texas, in 1933. These discoveries
were reported to Judge J. A. Mead of Mi-
ami, who excavated a small area of the
site in 1934 and found mammoth teeth
and a “stone dart point lying directly be-
tween two ribs of one of the big mam-
moths” (Science News Letter 1935, 92).
In 1937, Sellards and Glen Evans ex-

Horn Shelter No. 2 (41BQ46)

Horn Shelter No. 2 is a large, east-
facing overhang (46 by 7.6 m) on the
right bank of the Brazos River north of
Waco. The shelter is naturally divided into
southern and northern areas. The north-
ern area is reported by Forrester (1985)
and the southern area by Watt (1978)
and Redder (1985). The Paleoindian ma-
terials recovered by Watt and Redder in
the southern shelter are discussed here.
The deposits were divided into

twenty-seven strata (Fig. 2.30), and these
fall into three groups (Redder 1985;
D. Young 1988). Strata 1–3 consist of an-
cient ﬂuvial deposits of the Brazos River,
Strata 4 –11 formed in slowly aggrading
shelters with intensive human occupa-
tion, and Strata 12 –27 are ﬂuvial de-
posits that formed from recent ﬂooding
of the Brazos River, human occupation,
and recent disturbances.

The lowest stratigraphic units are dis-
cussed here. Stratum 1 (Bottom Sand) is
a sterile, ﬁne, compacted dark red sand.
Stratum 2 (River Gravel) is a coarse sand
and limestone gravel unit with faunal re-
mains and a possible human tooth. Stra-
tum 3 (Yellowish Clay) is a yellowish clay
