with some sand, limestone clasts, and cal-
cium carbonate nodules. A hearth, a few
ﬂakes, and fragmented bone were found
in this stratum. Turtle (Geochelone sp. or
Gopherus sp.) remains were dated to
10,150 ! 120 b.p. (see below). Scattered
limestone roof fall was found on the up-
per surface of Stratum 3.

Stratum 4 (Shaley Red) consisted of
thin limestone spalls coated with red clay.
This stratum apparently represents the
rapid decomposition of the back wall and
roof of the shelter. A few lithic ﬂakes
were found in this unit. Stratum 5 (Cave
Deposit) is ﬁne-grained decomposed shel-
ter debris. This stratum is subdivided into
two members and seven substrata. The
lower member includes Substrata 5a, 5b,
5c, and 5d, while the upper member con-
sists of 5e, 5f, and 5g.

Stratum 5a (Lower Member–Clean
Cave Fill) is described as “clean cave ﬁll.”
In the lower portion of Stratum 5a was a
low density of ﬂaking debris and an
unﬂuted lanceolate that Story (1990,
186) believes is a Clovis point. There
were two Folsom points in the upper por-
tion of Stratum 5a. Strata 5b (Lower
Member–Third Red) and 5c (Lower
Member–Second Red) are thin layers of
red clay interstratiﬁed within Stratum 5a.
Stratum 5d (Lower Member–Ash Lens
Drag Down) is also a layer of red clay, al-
though it is much more extensive than
Strata 5b and 5c. Five hearths with
charcoal, ash, and bone lenses were
documented in Stratum 5d, and it also
contained a considerable amount of
occupational debris (including bone
needles), but no projectile points. Stra-
tum 5e (Upper Member–Clean Cave
Fill) was described as similar to Stratum
5a: “clean and sparkling white” (Redder
1985, 41). Stratum 5f (Upper Member–
Light Gray) is the “same type of deposit
but has been slightly dirtied by human
occupation” (Redder 1985, 41). Abun-
dant occupational debris—including
San Patrice and Scottsbluff projectile
points—were recovered from Stratum 5f.
Stratum 5g (Upper Member–Heavy
Gray) is a very dark midden deposit with
abundant occupational debris, San Patrice
points, four radiocarbon assays of 9500
! 200 b.p., 10,030 ! 130 b.p., 9980 !
370 b.p., and 10,310 ! 150 b.p., and a
double burial (see below).

Stratum 6 (Red Gray Mix) is believed

to be a combination of “cave deposit” and
red river sand. An anthropogenic cause
for the mixing is suggested, and a moder-
ate concentration of debris in this stratum
includes a Scottsbluff point. Stratum 7
(Rocky Red) is a reddish-brown sandy
clay with abundant angular limestone
fragments. Redder also describes “hori-
zontal ﬁngers of cave deposit” that extend
into the stratum (Redder 1985, 52), and
a proﬁle published by Young (1988, ﬁg.
2) shows a stringer from Stratum 7 pro-
jecting into Stratum 5e. Artifacts found
in this stratum include Brazos Fishtailed
(San Patrice) points and two “Edgewood-
looking” points that are assumed to be
Archaic. Because of the apparently long
period of time represented by Stratum 7,
Redder (1985, 52) thought this deposit
was an enigma. However, while the drip
line was not shown, the geometry, posi-
tion, and sediment content suggest that
this may be a homogeneous talus deposit
that accumulated over a fairly long period
of time. Stratum 7 imparts a slope on
most of the Prehistoric deposits in the
front of the shelter.

Stratum 8 (Red Sand) is in the back
portion of the shelter and is a red ﬂuvial
sand. Four substrata were deﬁned. Three
of these (Strata 8a, 8b, and 8c) were iden-
tiﬁed as cultural occupations interstratiﬁed
within Stratum 8. Stratum 8a (Double
Cemented) includes two thin calcium
carbonate– cemented sand layers with a
red clay layer between. Immediately be-
low the lower cemented sand layer is a
thin occupation zone with a low density
of stone artifacts and bone. No tempo-
rally diagnostic materials were found in
this layer. Stratum 8b (Plainview 2) is an
occupation zone cemented to sand. Four
projectile points from it were classiﬁed
as Plainview but could be Golondrina-
Barber within Kerr’s classiﬁcation. A
single radiocarbon date of 8400 ! 110
b.p. was obtained on snail shells. Stratum
8c (Plainview 1) is a layer of red sand
with small angular limestone spalls that
separates two layers of red clay below and
above. Two projectile points were found
in Stratum 8c, both of which can be
classiﬁed as Golondrina-Barber. The
fourth substratum is Stratum 8d (Red,
White Spotted). It is a red sand with scat-
tered calcium carbonate nodules that give
the layer a spotted appearance. This layer
appears to be a continuation of Stratum

8, but it is almost separated from the re-
mainder of Stratum 8 by the Archaic
midden (Stratum 10) and a looter’s hole
(Stratum 17).

The remaining strata cap and some-

times mark the disturbance of the de-
posits with Paleoindian materials (Redder
1985; Watt 1978). The sediments at
Horn Shelter No. 2 document the com-
plex accumulation of sediments as well as
the presence of prehistoric and historic
occupants for at least ten thousand years.
The Brazos River, the shelter itself, and
the various occupants have all contrib-
uted to this record.

Lipscomb (41LP1)

Lipscomb Bison Quarry was excavated

ﬁrst in 1939 by Erwin H. Barbour and
C. Bertrand Schultz from the Nebraska
State Museum (Barbour and Schultz
1941; Schultz 1943). Brief excavations
were also undertaken in 1946 by the Ne-
braska State Museum and in 1960 by
C. Vance Haynes and George Agogino
(Hofman 1995; Hofman et al. 1991).
Hofman and his collaborators renewed
investigations in 1988 and the analysis
continues (Hofman 1995; Hofman and
Todd 1990; Hofman et al. 1989a, 1991b).
Lipscomb is located near a small tributary
of Wolf Creek, itself a tributary of the
North Canadian River, in the Texas Pan-
handle. Detailed descriptions are not
available, but a proﬁle presented by Hof-
man (1995) indicates that the bone bed
was near the top of, and on the edge of, a
Late Pleistocene arroyo ﬁll that rests un-
conformably on eroded Ogallala Forma-
tion deposits (Fig. 2.31).

Bonﬁre Shelter (41VV218)

David S. Dibble excavated Bonﬁre
Shelter in 1963 – 64 (Dibble and Lorrain
1968), and it was reexcavated by Lee
Bement and Solveig Turpin in 1986
(Bement 1986). This site is a large rock-
shelter of eroded limestone in deeply en-
trenched Mile Creek in the southwest
corner of the Stockton Plateau. Mile
Creek is a short, dry tributary of the Rio
Grande, and their conﬂuence is approxi-
mately 25 km upstream from the Pecos
River conﬂuence with the Rio Grande.
The shelter is elongated (125 m long by
24 m deep) and forms a smooth crescent
overhang.

Dibble and Lorrain (1968) suggested

Fig. 2.31. Lipscomb stratigraphy (after Hofman 1995).

that Bonﬁre Shelter was eroded by the
meandering Mile Creek. In front of the
shelter are huge limestone blocks that
have collapsed from the overhang, and
these are the largest clasts that make up
an extensive talus deposit in front of the
shelter. The large talus blocks project ap-
proximately 6.5 m above the surface de-
posits in the shelter. This surface and the
buried deposits below slope down toward
the back of the shelter, and it is clear
that the talus cone formed these sloping
deposits.

Dibble identiﬁed three depositional

zones and three bone beds at Bonﬁre
(Dibble and Lorrain 1968, 24 –27). The
lowest deposit is Zone 1 (Fig. 2.32), a
rubble deposit composed of weathered
limestone spalls and light gray silt. In a
number of proﬁles Dibble identiﬁed spall
lines that marked the accumulation of
roof fall on the slope of the talus cone. In
the central portion of the site, Bone Bed
1 (Bement’s stratum H-1) sits directly on
Zone 1 deposits. Bone Bed 1 consists
only of a scattering of bone and was not
a marked concentration.

Zone 2 is a thick heterogeneous unit
of limestone spalls and silt. In most of the
shelter it sits unconformably on Zone 1
deposits, and Dibble suggested that it ac-
cumulated through roof fall and slope
wash from above the shelter and down
the talus. In the central portion of the site
Zone 2 could be subdivided. Zone 2a is
a tan to light brown silt and small lime-
stone spalls. It forms a bench along the
rear wall of the shelter. Zone 2b is a light
brown silt with fewer limestone spalls,
and it covers Zone 2a. Occasionally thin
horizontal beds could be observed in

Zone 2b. Dibble mapped Bone Bed 2 as
below and above Zone 2a deposits.

Bone Bed 2 is an extensive and moder-

ately thick accumulation of bone that is
concentrated in the central portion of the
shelter and around the ﬂanks of the talus
cone. Given the concentration and num-
ber of bison, their position in the shelter,
their existence in this deep canyon with
very limited access, and the general up-
land topography, Dibble (Dibble and
Lorrain 1968, 69 –74) effectively argued
that the bison remains in Bone Bed 2
represented the use of this site as a jump.
In the southern part of the shelter
three separate bone bed components were
recognized. Component A at the bottom
was unburned bone in sandy silt and
limestone spalls. Component B, in the
middle, was a thinner band of heavily
charred and broken bone and carbon-
stained silts. At the top, Component C
consisted of unburned bone in a sandy
silt and limestone spall matrix. Hearth 1,
with charcoal, correlated with Compo-
nent C in Bone Bed 2. Also found in
Component C was a projectile point
(specimen 392) that Kerr and Dial’s
analysis clustered with Lubbock points at
the Lubbock Lake site. A Folsom point
(specimen 327) was found in Component
A. The Bone Bed 2 radiocarbon dates
were derived from charcoal in the Com-
ponent C hearth. The other lanceolate
points were found in Bone Bed 2 but in
areas where the individual components
could not be recognized.

Plainview (41HA1)

The Plainview site was discovered in a

caliche pit in Running Water Draw in

1944 and was excavated in 1945 by Sel-
lards, Evans, Meade, and Krieger. They
excavated approximately 500 square feet
of a dense bone bed composed of disartic-
ulated and articulated bison bone that
was approximately 62 feet long, 10 feet
wide, and up to 1.5 feet thick. They did
not excavate the entire bone bed, and
only a small number of stone artifacts
were found in direct association. Later ex-
cavations in 1976 and 1977 by Eddie
Guffee (1979) demonstrated that the
bone bed was clearly larger than that ex-
posed in the original excavation. The
reader is referred to Speer (1990) for a
detailed history of these investigations.
The Plainview site is signiﬁcant because
of its potential to help clarify our ideas
regarding Paleoindian culture history,
Pleistocene bison evolution, and Paleo-
indian hunting strategies.

This discussion of the geology is de-
rived from Sellards et al. (1947) and Hol-
liday (1995d, 1997a). Running Water
Draw has cut through the Blackwater
Draw and Ogallala Formations on the
High Plains. Sellards et al. (1947, 936)
describe the valley ﬁll as consisting of
three main units: a basal zone of cross-
bedded sands and water-worn caliche
gravels a few inches to 3.5 feet thick; a
middle massive zone of compact sandy
clay 5 to 8 feet thick; and an upper dark
sandy soil 1.5 to 3 feet thick. Sellards
et al. indicate that the bone bed “rested
directly on caliche bedrock, but near the
upstream and downstream ends it was
separated from bedrock by a few inches of
the valley ﬁll” (1947, 931). They go on to
say that the “basal zone of cross-bedded
sands and water worn caliche gravels . . .

other section of the article they also indi-

within a former channel of Running Wa-

indicated by the thin layer of pond sedi-

bones in the upper part and by the pres-
ence of abundant fresh-water inverte-
brates” (Sellards et al. 1947, 934).

Sometime after 1945 the original pit

was enlarged, and two additional pits
were excavated. In the 1970s the original
pit was ﬁlled with garbage.

Holliday (1995d, 1997a) studied

proﬁles that were visible during the 1980s
and 1990s, and his descriptions provide a
more detailed but, because of the contin-
ued destruction and alteration of the site,
limited view of the geological context of
the Plainview site. Unfortunately, the
bone bed was completely destroyed
and/or covered over by the time Holliday
began to work at the site. He suggests
that the bone bed was sitting on a caliche
bench formed by two earlier erosion
events (Fig. 2.33). The oldest and deepest
channel that eroded one edge of the
bench is ﬁlled with Stratum 1, a sand and
gravel deposit. This channel is easily cor-
related to the Sellards et al. (1947) basal
unit. A second erosional event, possibly a
later meander, is marked by a smaller
channel ﬁlled with Stratum 1m deposits.
This is an organic-rich, loamy, mud facies
of Stratum 1. These deposits could be
similar to those described by Sellards
et al. as the “thin layer of pond sediment”
(1947, 934). Overlying Stratum 1 are
very thin, discontinuous, and contorted
lenses of organic-rich mud. This is Stra-
tum 2. Above Stratum 2 is Stratum 3
with lacustrine carbonate and eolian fa-
cies, and it seals all the lower deposits and
probably the Plainview occupation. Fur-
thermore, Holliday (1997a, 109) ob-
served Roberta Speer’s excavated blocks of
bone removed by Sellards, and the bone
was within a grayish-brown sandy loam
above a gravel.

Holliday (1999, personal communica-
tion) believes that the bone bed is strati-
graphically in and above Stratum 2m and
above Stratum 1 and that the Stratum 2m
radiocarbon assay is too young. Neverthe-
less, Holliday illustrates the approximate
position of the bone bed as being on the
caliche bench and over Stratum 1m, and

Devil’s Mouth (41V188)

Three excavation seasons at this site

during the late 1950s and 1960s
identiﬁed a deep sequence of alluvial de-
posits at the mouth of the Devils River
and the Rio Grande west of Del Rio,
Texas. LeRoy Johnson (1961a) conducted
initial test excavation in 1959 and re-
turned for more extensive excavations in
1961– 62 (L. Johnson 1964) in Areas A,
B, and C (Fig. 2.34). In order to resolve a
number of speciﬁc stratigraphic issues,
particularly the relationship between de-
posits in Areas A and C that contained

42 / TEXAS PREHISTORY

Paleoindian materials, William Sorrow
conducted a second set of excavations in
1967 (Sorrow 1968).

For Areas A and B, Johnson (1964,
19 –22) describes twenty-four strata and
illustrates the constructional history of
the terrace. These areas were placed on
the edge of the terrace. Johnson (1964,
19) divides the deposits into upper and
lower sections and uses as the dividing
boundary an erosional unconformity that
truncated the lower section (Fig. 2.35).
He suggests that in the upper section
Strata 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, and 13 are “alter-
nate zones of midden soil” and Strata 2,
4, 6, 8, 10, and 12 are eolian sand. Pre-
historic artifacts and features are more
common in the “midden soil” strata (L.
Johnson 1964, 19). While an anthro-
pogenic contribution to these strata is
clear, the photographs accompanying his
work suggest that these are pedogenic
soils. In the lower section, Strata 14, 16,
19, and parts of 22 and 24 are silty sands,
while Strata 15, 17, and 20 are silts. Stra-
tum 18 is deﬁned as “midden soil,” and
again it is probably a result of anthro-
pogenic and pedogenic processes. Stra-

tum 21 consists of alternating bands of
sand, silty sand, and silt, and Stratum 23
is a clay layer. Prehistoric artifacts and
features were found to occur thinly in the
silty sand layers, although no artifacts
were found in Stratum 24. An Angostura
point was found in the lower portion of
Stratum 21, and Johnson (1964, 52) il-
lustrates a Lerma-like point found in
Stratum 22 that should probably be con-
sidered a preform rather than a point.
In Area C, Johnson (1964, 22 –26)
and Sorrow (1968, 12 –13) observed tan
silts and sands overlying gravel deposits.
Area C was in a truncated portion of the
terrace near the Rio Grande–Devils River
conﬂuence (see Fig. 2.34). The gravels
were divided into Upper Gravels and
Lower Gravels, and they sat unconform-
ably on water-eroded ﬂuted limestone
bedrock. The archeologically sterile Lower
Gravels were igneous and metamorphic
pebbles and cobbles. The Upper Gravels
had limestone and chert cobbles with thin
lenses of red clay and sand that dipped
toward the streams. Within the Upper
Gravels were a number of Paleoindian
points (Angostura, Golondrina, and

Baker Cave (41VV213)

Baker Cave is in northern Val Verde
County on a northeast-facing cliff eroded
by a tributary of the Devils River. The
overhang forms a large semicircular shel-
ter that is 47 by 22 m in length and
depth. The site was ﬁrst excavated by
James Word between 1962 and 1966
(Word and Douglas 1970). Excavations
were renewed by John Greer in 1968

(Greer 1968a), by Thomas R. Hester and
Robert Heizer in 1976 (Hester 1978a,
1980a, 1980b; Chadderdon 1983), and
by Ken Brown in 1984. Word and Doug-
las (1970) and Chadderdon (1983) pro-
vide the most complete and detailed pub-
lished stratigraphic descriptions. The
deposits were a complex series of inter-
locking lenses and layers of sediment, or-
ganic matter, and artifactual debris. Word
and Douglas (1970, 10 –14) grouped
the various strata into ﬁve major zones
(Fig. 2.36), the lowest of which dates to
the Paleoindian period. Sediments be-
tween occupational layers were not in-

Fig. 2.36. Baker Cave stratigraphy (after Word and Douglas 1970).

Wilson forms) and other lithic artifacts.
These artifacts were not abraded and may
be in near-primary context. The overly-
ing tan silts and sands contain rare arti-
facts and charcoal. Johnson (1964, 25)
correlates these silts and sands in Area C
to Stratum 24 in Area A (see Fig. 2.35).
Area D was excavated by Sorrow on
the west slope of the terrace (see Fig. 2.34).
Sorrow (1968, 10 –12) described twenty-
one strata but used a letter system because
he could not directly correlate Johnson’s
Area A strata to his Area D deposits (see
Fig. 2.35). Strata A, C /D, E, F, and H
are dark silts and ﬁne-grained sands with
artifacts and ﬁre-cracked rock. Strata B, J,
L, M, N, O, Q, and T are tan silts. In the
middle of Strata M, N, and O were Bar-
ber and Thrall projectile points, while at
the bottom of these strata were nondiag-
nostic lanceolate projectile points. Strata
G, I, K are gray-tan silts. Stratum P is col-
luvium with coarse limestone spalls in
sand. Within Stratum P, Sorrow (1968,
43) recovered four Wilson projectile
points (Sorrow’s Group 1) and one pos-
sible Angostura point. Sorrow (1968,
46 – 47) obtained a single radiocarbon
date (8780 ! 310 b.p.) from Stratum P.
Stratum R is a compact red-tan silt, and
Stratum S is a thin red clay silt lens. Stra-
tum U is a compact cemented calcareous
tan silt. Stratum V is bedded igneous
sands. Stratum W is small limestone

Charcoal from immediately below the

Lake Theo (41BI70)

Two bone beds were excavated by Billy
R. Harrison and his collaborators at Lake
Theo in the Rolling Plains (Harrison and
Smith 1975; Harrison and Killen 1978).
The lower bed is poorly dated but con-
tained Folsom points in clear association
with Bison antiquus, and the upper bone
bed is associated with an unﬂuted parallel
stem lanceolate point that was classiﬁed
as Plainview. The stratigraphy was ﬁrst
described by Harrison (Harrison and
Smith 1975; Harrison and Killen 1978)
but has been re-described by Holliday
(E. Johnson et al. 1982; Holliday 1997a).
Holliday identiﬁed ten stratigraphic
units and ﬁve soils (Fig. 2.38). The basal
units are a set of three ﬁning-upward
stratigraphic units that are capped by a
soil (S1). Unit 1 is ﬂuvial gravels and
sands. Above, Unit 2 has loams to silty
clay loams that probably were deposited
as overbank alluvium. The lowest soil
correlates to Unit 3, a clay, and two ra-
diocarbon dates indicate it is Pleistocene
in age. Units 4, 5, and 6 comprise an-
other set of ﬁning-upward sediments that
are also capped by a soil (S2). In the
lower portion of this Ab3 horizon is a
Plainview component, and below this (in
a Bwb3 horizon) is the Folsom occupa-
tion. Dates on organic matter in the soil
and the bone date to the Early Holocene.
Above this soil are three additional sets of
sediments, each capped by a soil (S3, S4,
and S5). Organic matter in S3 (Ab2 hori-
zon) dates to the Middle Holocene, while
organic matter in S4 (Ab1) dates to the
Late Holocene. In many parts of the site,
S4 (Ab1 horizon) and its associated depo-
sitional units (Unit 8 and Unit 9) were
removed by erosion, and Unit 10 directly
overlies S3.

Loeve (41WM133)

Excavations by Frank Eddy (1973),
Clell Bond (1978), and Elton Prewitt
(1982) exposed a thick and complex
stratigraphy at the Loeve site along the
north bank of the San Gabriel River in
eastern Williamson County. Eddy (1973)

02-A2946  4/13/04  11:50 AM  Page 45

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 45

Fig. 2.39. Loeve stratigraphy (after Prewitt 1982).

identiﬁed three primary stratigraphic
units, labeled I, II, and III from top to
bottom. The most intensive excavations
in the Paleoindian deposits were con-
ducted by Prewitt (1982). Prewitt re-
moved deposits from stratigraphic Units I
and II. He mapped a series of gravel and
clay lenses that he believed formed as a
point bar and that comprised strati-
graphic Unit III sediments.

Prewitt (1982, 234 –36) deﬁned six
subunits of stratigraphic Unit III and la-
beled these sequentially from top to bot-
tom (Fig. 2.39). Stratum III-1 is a light
grayish-brown massive clay with dispersed
gravel stringers. This stratum forms a
transitional zone between the gravel de-
posits below and the alluvial soils above
in stratigraphic Unit II. Stratum III-2 is a
complex series of size-graded gravel lenses
interspersed with clay lenses. Stratum III-
3 is a large clay lens with occasional gravel
lenses and stringers. Stratum III-3 pinches
out up and downstream. Stratum III-4
is a complex series of size-graded gravel
lenses and occasional clay lenses. This de-
posit is clearly distinguished from upper
and lower deposits and thins downstream.
Stratum III-5 is a thick gray clay deposit
that thins downstream and appears to
merge with Strata III-2 and III-3. Stra-
tum III-6 was not clearly visible due to
slumping deposits, but it consists of size-
graded gravels that range from pebble to
small boulder sizes. Prewitt (1982, 236)
believes that Stratum III-6 is Pleistocene
in age and that the overlying deposits date
to the Early Holocene.

Prewitt (1982) recovered from Stra-
tum III-1 a modest lithic artifact assem-
blage that has Angostura projectile points.
He assigned them to the Circleville phase
(Prewitt 1981, 1982).

Levi Rock Shelter (41TV49)

Herbert Alexander (1962, 1963,
1974) ﬁrst excavated Levi Rock Shelter
for his master’s thesis, and he excavated
there again in 1974 and 1977 (Alexander
1982). Levi Rock Shelter is in the eastern
Edwards Plateau in a northern wall of a
canyon cut by Lick Creek, a tributary of
the Pedernales River.

Alexander (1963) deﬁned ﬁve strati-
graphic zones (Fig. 2.40). At the bottom,
Zone I was a loose, light tan to yellow-
tan roof spall that was grainy in texture.
Large boulders from the roof were pres-
ent in Zone I. Alexander (1963) described
Zone II as earth-like in texture, tan-gray,
and containing no spalls, and the lower
boundary was abrupt. In 1972, Alexander
described this zone as a compact gray
midden soil, but in 1982 he described it
as “light tan, compact ﬁll and was decid-
edly cultural” (Alexander 1982, 136).
Zone III was a red-orange sand lens with
very few artifacts. Zone IV was a light
gray to brown, smooth textured and com-
pact. The uppermost zone, Zone V, was a
loose tan ﬁll (Alexander 1963), or a dark
brown (Alexander 1974) to brown (Alex-
ander 1982) dusty ﬁll.

Alexander (1982) found very few arti-
facts in Zone I, and he believed these few
represented a pre-Clovis occupation. He

Fig. 2.40. Levi Rock Shelter stratigraphy
(after Alexander 1963).

considered the archeological materials in
Zone II to be Clovis in age, Zone III to
be sterile, Zone IV to be Plainview, and
Zone V to be Archaic in afﬁliation. Based
on photographs provided by Bill Rich-
mond and the presence of Clovis and An-
gostura points in Zone II, the lower two
zones seem likely to be bioturbated. Cer-
tainly, much ﬁrmer evidence is needed
before a pre-Clovis occupation can be ac-
cepted at the Levi Rock Shelter.

Richard Beene (41BX831)

Thoms (1992, 1995) and Thoms et al.
(1996) discuss the 1991 and 1995 excava-
tion of an Angostura component in Block
T in the spillway trench excavated for the
now defunct Applewhite Reservoir, which
was along the Medina River in southern
Bexar County. The full report is unpub-
lished, but geoarcheological research by
Rolfe Mandel identiﬁed ﬁve major buried
soils in a 20-m thick Applewhite terrace

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

02-A2946  4/13/04  11:50 AM  Page 46

46 / TEXAS PREHISTORY

(Fig. 2.41). The soils are distinguished by
slightly darker colors, but the terrace is
extremely silty throughout. The oldest
soil is the Somerset Paleosol, which dates
to approximately 30,000 b.p. Late Pleis-
tocene sand and gravel channel ﬁlls are
inset unconformably against the Somerset
Paleosol. Stratigraphically above and
welded onto the Somerset Paleosol is the
Perez Paleosol. This soil is Early Holo-
cene in age and contains the Angostura
component, with possible rock-lined
cooking ovens. Above this are the Elm
Creek, Medina, and Leon Creek Paleo-
sols. These date to the Middle and Late
Holocene and contain Archaic compo-
nents. Late Prehistoric occupations were
recovered in the modern surface soil.

Rex Rodgers (41BI42)

This bison kill site was excavated in
1974 as part of the Mackenzie Reservoir
investigations (Willey et al. 1978b). San
Patrice and unidentiﬁed lanceolate pro-
jectile points that are similar to Plainview
points were reported in association with
at least six bison. The Rex Rodgers site
is in a terrace remnant within the Tule
Creek canyon. Willey et al. (1978b, 57–
60) indicates that the bison were found in
two concentrations draped on and below
a bench of eroded ﬂoodplain alluvium
(Fig. 2.42). The higher concentration of
bone rested on the alluvium bench, silts,
and sands overlying shales and sandstones
that comprised the Late Triassic Trujillo
Formation. The lower bone concentra-
tion was on a sand and gravel layer. These
bones were covered by “light-colored
laminated and cross-bedded stream-
channel sands” (Willey et al. 1978b, 57).
The channel sands contained masses of
shale and clay as well as sandstone slabs.
The materials were believed to be talus
debris dislodged from the side of the
nearby canyon wall.

Absolute Chronology

To date, thirty-two Paleoindian sites in
Texas have been dated by radiometric ab-
solute dating techniques (Table 2.1), and
a wide variety of materials, such as cal-
cium carbonate, bone, mussel shell, sedi-
ments, and charcoal, were selected for
radiocarbon analysis. Most of these radio-
metric assays are radiocarbon dates
(n"243), but uranium series (n"4) and
optical stimulated luminescence or OSL

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

Fig. 2.41. Richard Beene stratigraphy (after Thoms et al. 1996).

Fig. 2.42. Rex Rodgers stratigraphy (after Willey et al. 1978b).

(n"6) techniques have also been used.
The technique of radiocarbon dating has
also undergone a dramatic shift from
solid carbon to accelerator mass spec-
trometry (AMS) during its ﬁrst ﬁfty
years. These changes in technique and se-
lection of varying materials have created a
chronological record with varying degrees
of accuracy, and the recent extension of
the calibrated scale to the Paleoindian pe-
riod provides a more realistic measure of
time, although calibration is not without
its own set of problems.

Table 2.1 lists all available Paleoindian

radiometric determinations. In the dis-
cussion below we selectively use these
assays based on our present selection of
reliable assays. Different authors would
probably choose a different set of dates
than that generated by our own effort
at chronological hygiene (e.g., Springs
1989; R. Taylor et al. 1996), but we de-

cided that the full set of determinations
should be presented in this synthesis.

The most signiﬁcant improvement to
the development of absolute chronologies
is the development of AMS radiocarbon
dating. Irrespective of material, this tech-
nique produces age estimates with ex-
tremely small standard deviations, and
this greatly reduces the estimated age
ranges. Also, the ability to obtain accurate
radiocarbon dates from small samples
(Stafford 1998) opens a wide vista for
chronometric applications in Paleoindian
sites in Texas, and AMS is beginning to
be used on Paleoindian samples exclu-
sively. Still, because most available radio-
carbon assays employed conventional
Beta-decay methods, the standard devia-
tion can be very large and the chronologi-
cal resolution very low.

It is apparent that obtaining greater
resolution on Paleoindian chronologies

02-A2946  4/13/04  11:50 AM  Page 47

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 47

will require the extensive use of AMS
methods, but this alone is not enough.
As the following discussion indicates, the
most reliable chronologies come from
those sites with good stratigraphic con-
texts that have been intensively and
chronologically sampled. These sites pro-
duce a sequence of absolute dates in dif-
ferent levels that act to constrain the en-
tire sequence through time. No longer
can we depend on sites that have only one
or a few determinations. Along with tree-
ring and coral calibration, stratigraphi-
cally constrained assays provide the best
method for determining the age and the
time spans for events and periods during
the Paleoindian stage.

The recent extension of calibrated ages

into the Paleoindian stage dramatically
demonstrates that radiocarbon time is
stretched and compressed on a calendrical
time scale (Stuiver and Braziunas 1993;
Stuiver and Reimer 1993; R. Taylor et al.
1996; Fiedel 1999). Fig. 2.43 illustrates
that the difference between calibrated and
radiocarbon years is neither stable nor
constantly changing. The decreasing por-
tions of the slope (7.5 –7.8 kyr, 8.3 –8.6
kyr, 8.75 –9.16 kyr, and 9.65 –9.95 kyr),
called valleys, represent periods when
radiocarbon years are compressed into
shorter spans, while the increasing por-
tions of the slope (7.8 –8.3 kyr, 8.6 –8.75
kyr, 9.16 –9.4 kyr, 9.4 –9.65 kyr, and
9.95 –10.4 kyr), called peaks, are periods
when radiocarbon years represent longer
spans of time. The period between 10.4
and 12.0 kyr is a fairly stable portion of
the record, called a plateau, but Fiedel
(1999) indicates that this may also con-
tain some peaks and valleys. The peak be-
tween 9.95 and 10.4 kyr is particularly
important as many events seem to occur
during or span this interval, and thus
much more time is represented in this in-
terval than the radiocarbon dates reﬂect.
The difference between calibrated
and radiocarbon year scales can be illus-
trated by the assays from Lubbock Lake
(Figs. 2.44a, b). The best estimates for
the ages are listed in the legend boxes next
to the stratigraphic units. Stratigraphic
units without ages did not produce reli-
able age estimates. The age estimates are
derived by inspecting the entire string of
assays, which are ordered chronologically
by stratigraphic unit. This arrangement
allows a visual inspection and the elimi-
nation of age estimates that overlap age

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

Fig. 2.43. Difference between calibrated and radiocarbon years plotted on radiocarbon time
scale.

ranges from adjacent strata. One major
difference between the two chronologies
is the total amount of time represented
by each. On the radiocarbon scale, ap-
proximately 6,250 years are present (be-
tween 12,650 and 6400 b.p.). On the cal-
ibrated scale, however, 7,777 years are
present (14,874 –7097 b.p.). This differ-
ence represents an additional 1,527 years
on the calibrated scale. Arguments con-
cerning human behavior that may be time
dependent may have signiﬁcantly differ-
ent patterns on calibrated versus radiocar-
bon time scales. Another important dif-
ference is that there seems to be a plateau
of stratigraphic units clustering around
10,000 b.p. on the radiocarbon scale.
This plateau is stretched out on the cali-
brated scale.

Obviously, calibrated scales at Lub-
bock Lake provide better chronological
resolution. However, demonstrating the
usefulness of calibrated scales at Lubbock
Lake does not necessarily provide a reli-
able strategy for the remainder of Paleo-
indian sites with radiometric ages. By the
use of stratigraphically constrained age es-
timates, roughly half the Lubbock Lake
assays can be eliminated as inaccurate or
not feasible. No other site, not even Wil-
son-Leonard, has such a well-constrained
chronological record. If half the assays
from the remaining sites are unreliable,
then we are a long way from developing
a reliable chronological record for the

Paleoindian occupation of Texas. The sit-
uation is compounded when calibrated
ages are used because of the multiple in-
tercepts problem. Thus, without a clear
pathway to a calibrated scale, we have
opted to continue to work on the radio-
carbon scale, and we fully realize the po-
tential for unreliable assays and com-
pressed and stretched time scales.

Clovis Chronology

The absolute chronology for Clovis
occupations in Texas is reasonably estab-
lished at only three sites: Aubrey, Lubbock
Lake, and Miami. Three radiocarbon as-
says from below the Clovis occupation
at Miami establish a maximum age of
11,415 ! 125 b.p. for the component,
and two radiocarbon ages above the Clo-
vis component at Miami provide a mini-
mum age of 10,345 ! 330 b.p. (Holliday
et al. 1994). At Lubbock Lake, three de-
terminations are associated with Clovis.
The ﬁrst is actually from Stratum 1B at
41LU26 and is 11,100 ! 80 b.p. (Holli-
day et al. 1983). The other two determi-
nations are from Area 2. Feature FA2-1
in Stratum 1B has been identiﬁed as a
Clovis-age feature and is associated with an
assay of 11,100 ! 100 b.p. Feature FA2-2
is identiﬁed as Clovis and associated with
an assay of 9660 ! 100 b.p. The Clovis
assignments at Lubbock Lake are based
on stratigraphic position rather than the
recovery of diagnostic projectile points.

48 / TEXAS PREHISTORY

Fig. 2.44. Lubbock Lake radiocarbon assays: (a) plotted stratigraphically on radiocarbon time scale; (b) plotted stratigraphically on calibrated
time scale.

The oldest reliable radiocarbon assays as-
sociated with Clovis are from the Aubrey
site. These are 11,542 ! 111 b.p. and
11,590 ! 93 b.p. (Ferring 1994a). Except
for the Lubbock Lake assay associated with
Area 2, Feature FA2-2, all these determi-
nations suggest that Clovis could date
within the range of 11,500 to 11,100 b.p.
It is important to note that the bone
bed component in Stratum Isi at Wilson-
Leonard is stratiﬁed below three radiocar-
bon assays in Stratum Icl (10,920 ! 70
b.p., 11,190 ! 100 b.p., and 11,400 !
110 b.p.) that suggest it may be of Clovis
age, but Clovis materials are found below
this bone bed assemblage in the Igl gravel
bar. Also, Bone Bed 1 at Bonﬁre Shelter
(Stratum H-1) is dated to 12,460 ! 490
b.p. (Dibble and Lorrain 1968; Bement
1986), and even though this component
is lacking stone tools, it may represent a
Clovis or even a pre-Clovis occupation.
The anomalously old radiocarbon dates
from the Lewisville site near Dallas are
now known to have been on a low-grade

coal that apparently was used by the Paleo-
indian group for fuel. These age estimates
can now be safely ignored and the Lewis-
ville site should be accepted as a valid
Clovis occupation (Crook and Harris
1957, 1958, 1961; Stanford et al. 1995).
McFaddin Beach produced an 11,100 !
750 b.p. age on a tusk. However, this site
consists of materials, including a Clovis
point, that have washed up on the Gulf
shore, and the context is not secure.

Folsom-Midland Chronology

In Texas the number of sites with dated

Folsom or Midland occupations is only
slightly more than for Clovis sites. These
Folsom or Midland sites include Bonﬁre
Shelter, Midland, Lubbock Lake, Kincaid
Shelter, and Lipscomb. At Bonﬁre Shelter
a single Folsom point was found in a bone
bed with unﬂuted lanceolate points. Four
radiocarbon assays (9920 ! 150 b.p.,
10,100 ! 300 b.p., 10,230 ! 160 b.p.,
and 10,280 ! 430 b.p.) were obtained
on charcoal from a hearth in the bone

bed; however, the hearth was at the top of
the bone bed in Component C and the
Folsom point was from the bottom of
Component A. These assays strongly sug-
gest that the Bonﬁre bone bed had accu-
mulated by 9900 to 10,300 b.p., but this
range provides only a terminal date for the
Paleoindian use of the shelter. The Folsom
component at Bonﬁre Shelter must be
considered undated. Furthermore, the ca.
10,000 b.p. date is associated with a form
of projectile point that Kerr suggests is
similar to the Lubbock points at Lubbock
Lake (Knudson et al. 1998).

The dating situation is more complex

at the Midland site. No wood charcoal
was dated, and some less reliable materials
were selected for radiocarbon dating. Also,
two rarely used absolute dating tech-
niques (OSL and uranium-series) were
applied at the site. Compounding this sit-
uation is the problem of association and
stratigraphy. A major stratigraphic prob-
lem is the recent recognition that two red
sand units occur both above and below

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

02-A2946  4/13/04  11:50 AM  Page 49

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 49

Fig. 2.44. (continued)

the gray sand (Holliday and Meltzer
1996), which makes it impossible to de-
termine with which red sand many of the
radiometric samples were associated.

As discussed above, Holliday and Melt-
zer (1996) suggest that the in situ Folsom
occupation at Locality 3 is at the base of
the upper Red Sand, which is possibly
older than the Gray Sand. Wendorf (et al.
1955) and Wendorf and Krieger (1959)
argued that the Folsom component was
younger than the Gray Sand. The human
remains were found on the surface of the
Gray Sand. The recent uranium-series as-
say on the human remains from Midland
(calibrated to 11,600 ! 800 b.p.) is very
close to the calibrated 2-sigma range of
the radiocarbon assays at Wilson-Leonard
that are believed to bracket the calibrated
age of the Wilson component burial
(11,005 –10,682 b.p. and 11,910 –10,996
b.p.). Also, two of the stemmed projectile
points illustrated by Wendorf et al. (1955)
may be Wilson points.

At Lubbock Lake, a Folsom com-

ponent (FA6-8) was excavated in Stra-
tum 2A LB2. No diagnostic artifacts were
found in association. Radiocarbon assays
from this stratum are 10,060 ! 170 b.p.,
10,195 ! 165 b.p., 10,360 ! 80 b.p.,
and 10,540 ! 100 b.p. Only the last as-
say was run on charcoal, and it may be
the most accurate age estimate for a Lub-
bock Lake Folsom component even
though it was collected from a nonoccu-
pational context in Trench 109. Further-
more, it is the only Folsom or Clovis as-
say from Lubbock Lake used by R. Taylor
et al. in their 1996 review of Early Paleo-
indian radiocarbon assays.

The radiocarbon dates from Folsom
components at Kincaid Shelter and Lub-
bock Lake are younger than the range of
ages now accepted as Folsom (Haynes
1992), and conﬁrming the accuracy of
these age estimates requires further assess-
ments. Unfortunately, the absolute assays
from Lipscomb (see Table 2.1) do not
help clarify the age of Folsom or Midland
components in Texas. Thus, at least in

Texas, the radiocarbon age of Folsom sites
is not well established.

Plainview Chronology

The absolute chronology of Plainview
components in the Southern Plains is not
very well known. At the Plainview site it-
self only bone, sediment, and snail shell
have been dated, and the results are not
clear cut. Holliday (1997a) argues that
the occupation surface is positioned be-
tween the upper portion of Unit Im
dated to 10,940 b.p. and the lower por-
tion of Unit 3. However, it seems reason-
able to suggest that the occupation is at
least as old as the oldest bone apatite assay
at 10,200 b.p. One interpretation of the
stratigraphy (see above) could allow an
age estimate contemporary with the
10,940 b.p. assay. This estimate would
agree with the age estimate of the pos-
sible Plainview component at Wilson-
Leonard and with the estimates for
Goshen-Plainview components at the
Mill Iron site (Frison 1996).

At Lubbock Lake twelve radiocarbon
assays associated with Plainview compo-
nents range in age from 11,770 ! 140
b.p. to 7220 ! 80 b.p., and average 9520
b.p. All of these assays are on sediment or
bone, and charcoal assays from Lubbock
Lake are desperately needed to bolster the
existing radiocarbon chronology. Com-
pared to Wilson-Leonard and perhaps the
Plainview site, the Plainview components
at Lubbock Lake appear to be fairly
young. As discussed above, Kerr and
Dial’s 1998 quantitative analysis of pro-
jectile points did not classify any of the
points at Lubbock Lake as Plainview
points. Rather, these were grouped into
Lubbock points and St. Mary’s Hall
forms, and the dating at Lubbock Lake
may support this hypothesis.

At Horace Rivers ﬁve assays average
8990 b.p. The Horace Rivers material is
clearly very young, but these points were
not available for study and it is unclear if
they can be grouped with St. Mary’s Hall
forms. The Plainview component at Lake
Theo again is dated by inferior materials
(bone and sediment). The average radio-
carbon age of this site is 9185 b.p. An-
other possible Plainview component at
the Rex Rodgers site is dated by only one
assay at 9118 ! 83 b.p. Ryan’s site has
three assays, but none is in direct associa-
tion with the Plainview component. As
discussed earlier, Bonﬁre Shelter has been
proposed as one of the best-dated Plain-
view components in Texas. These age es-
timates suggest an average age of 10,130
b.p.; however, the date is associated with
a Lubbock point (see Kerr and Dial 1998).
The bone bed component in Stratum Isi
at Wilson-Leonard is stratiﬁed below
radiocarbon assays of 10,920 ! 70 b.p.,
11,190 ! 100 b.p., and 11,400 ! 110
b.p. These assays were run on sediment,
but the entire cienega sequence is well
constrained by multiple charcoal dates in
the Leanne Soil. Only more research will
help determine if this component at
Wilson-Leonard is truly associated with
Plainview.

At present, a case can be made for pro-

posing the existence of “early” or “true”
Plainview components and “late” Plain-
view or St. Mary’s Hall components. This
case is compounded, however, by the
misclassiﬁcation of a number of parallel-
stemmed lanceolate forms, at least in cen-
tral and south Texas, as Plainview. As

60 / TEXAS PREHISTORY

Kerr and Dial’s (1998) analysis showed,
many of these forms, especially in central
and south Texas, can now be considered
to be St. Mary’s Hall, but a small number
appear to be similar to true Plainview and
date fully to the Pleistocene. Still, there
clearly are parallel-stemmed lanceolate
projectile point forms, similar to Plain-
view, that are not Pleistocene in age.

Early Stemmed Projectile
Point Chronology

In 1940 Sellards and Evans published
the results of their excavations at Berclair
Terrace in Bee County. These excavations
took place long before radiocarbon dat-
ing, but among other discoveries they re-
ported the occurrence of stemmed projec-
tile points at depths that were clearly
Paleoindian in age. Few, if any, archeolo-
gists accepted these remains as Paleo-
indian, and the signiﬁcance of this dis-
covery remained on the back pages of
Texas archeology. In the 1960s LeRoy
Johnson and later William Sorrow exca-
vated early stemmed projectile points at
the Devil’s Mouth site (L. Johnson 1964;
Sorrow 1968). These projectile points
were again found at great depths, and
Sorrow obtained an 8780 ! 310 b.p. esti-
mate for the age of this occupation. In
1982, Leland Patterson (et al. 1987;
1995) obtained a date of 9920 ! 530
b.p. for a stemmed projectile point hori-
zon at 41WH19, but many were still not
ready to accept the possibility of the exis-
tence of a stemmed projectile point hori-
zon in the Paleoindian period.

It was not until the excavation and
analysis of the Wilson-Leonard site that it
became clear that a stemmed projectile
point horizon did indeed occur within
the Paleoindian period (Bousman 1998a;
M. Collins 1998b). At Wilson-Leonard,
the Wilson component was dated from
9990 ! 70 to 9530 ! 30 b.p. The Wil-
son-Leonard data conﬁrmed Patterson’s
results from 41WH19 and indicated that
stemmed Wilson points occurred strati-
graphically below Golondrina-Barber, St.
Mary’s Hall, and Angostura forms. Inter-
estingly, Wilson points bear a close re-
semblance to Kirk projectile points from
the southeastern United States, but ap-
parently Kirk components are found to
date between approximately 9500 and
9000 b.p. (D. Anderson and Sassaman
1996; Sassaman 1996).

San Patrice and Scottsbluff
Chronology

Only three excavated and dated sites
have produced projectile points that can
be classiﬁed as San Patrice: Wilson-
Leonard, Horn Shelter, and Rex Rodgers.
Rex Rodgers has only one bone apatite
date of 9118 ! 83 b.p., and it is suspect.
The bison remains from Rex Rodgers are
very large in size, which may indicate a
Late Pleistocene age for this occupation.
Horn Shelter produced four dates of
9500 ! 200, 9980 ! 370, 10,030 !
130, and 10,310 ! 150 b.p. The San
Patrice points at Wilson-Leonard are in
the middle of Unit II, which is dated be-
tween 9500 and 8400 b.p. Evidence from
all three sites suggests that San Patrice
points date between 10,300 and 9000 b.p.
Two Scottsbluff bases were found in

Unit II at Wilson-Leonard (Bousman
1998a). Very few have been found in
buried contexts. Buckner Ranch is one
exception (Sellards 1940), and more re-
cent investigations at Landa Park in New
Braunfels are another (Arnn and Bous-
man 1997). In no case was a reasonable
age estimate produced for this projectile
point form.

Golondrina-Barber Chronology

Three sites provide reasonable chrono-
logical information on Golondrina-Barber
components. Wilson-Leonard has these
points in Unit II, dated between 9500
and 8400 b.p. Most Golondrina-Barber
points are from the lower portion of Unit
II and certainly date to the older portion
of this time range. Baker Cave produced
four charcoal samples in direct association
with Golondrina points: 9180 ! 220,
9020 ! 150, 9030 ! 230, and 8910 !
140 b.p. These dates form a very tight
range. This ca. 9000 b.p. age range is
conﬁrmed by a single radiocarbon date
(8940 ! 700 b.p.) at the Lambs Creek
Knoll site in east-central Texas (Fields
1990; see also Fields, chapter 12, this
volume).

Angostura and Thrall Chronology

Few sites have well-dated Angostura
components. At the Richard Beene site in
southern Bexar County, an Angostura
component has associated radiocarbon
assays of 8805 ! 75 and 8640 ! 60 b.p.
At Wilson-Leonard, Angostura points are
poorly stratiﬁed within Unit II (dated be-

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

02-A2946  4/13/04  11:50 AM  Page 61

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 61

tween 9500 and 8400 b.p.), and they ap-
pear to date to the younger portion of
this time range. The radiocarbon dates as-
sociated with Angostura components at
Levi Rock Shelter and the Loeve site are
not well constrained (see Table 2.1) and
contribute little toward deﬁning the chro-
nology of Angostura points in Texas. The
Hausman Road site in Bexar County
(Tennis et al. 1996) has an age of 7920 !
50 b.p. for an Angostura component, but
it is difﬁcult to know if this is a reason-
able age, although Angostura and Thrall
points were found at Wilson-Leonard in
deposits that postdate 8400 b.p.

Components and Site
Distributions

A number of attempts have been made

since the mid-1980s to document more
fully the distribution of Paleoindian ma-
terials in limited areas across Texas (Hes-
ter 1980a, 1980b; L. Johnson 1964; Kib-
ler 1991, 1992; Largent 1995, et al. 1991;

Meltzer 1986, 1987; Meltzer and Bever
1995; Perttula 1989a, 1993c; Prewitt
1995; Story 1990). These efforts have fo-
cused mostly on obtaining information
from avocational and professional archeol-
ogists on a broad scale.

The majority of articles on Paleoindian
archeology in Texas consist of short pieces
concerning diagnostic point identiﬁca-
tions or descriptions, and the literature is
too numerous to include here. Usually
points are tallied by county, and individ-
ual sites are not reported. This current ef-
fort differs in that we used only the sites
in the TARL ﬁles or in publications. We
fully realize that this is an incomplete rec-
ord of Paleoindian occupation in Texas,
but it represents the locales with the most
complete information. As such, these lo-
cales can be revisited and further docu-
mented. According to the records at TARL
in 1994, 456 sites have recorded Paleo-
indian components, and 714 components
are documented (Table 2.2). These rec-
ords leave much to be desired, but they

constitute one of the foundation stones
for the Paleoindian record in Texas. The
problems in these records mirror the prob-
lems in the larger Paleoindian data base.
First among these are inconsistencies
in the recorded information, particularly
in projectile point typology and compo-
nent afﬁliation. For example, we have
lumped Plainview, a true Early Paleo-
indian type, with St. Mary’s Hall, Barber,
and other parallel-stemmed lanceolate
projectile point types that clearly date to
the Holocene because these have been
consistently confused by many archeolo-
gists working in Texas over the years. It
is impossible to unravel this typological
hodgepodge with the existing data on ﬁle
at TARL. To date, we believe that only
the Plainview site, Ryan’s site, Beidleman
Ranch, Bonﬁre Shelter, and possibly the
Bone Bed point at Wilson-Leonard qual-
ify as “Plainview” components (see typo-
logical discussions above). Other “true”
Plainview sites may exist but are too
poorly documented to be accepted.

A second problem is the lack of consis-

tency used to record these sites. Ninety-
three sites do not have enough informa-
tion to determine cultural afﬁliation. A
number also lack locational information.
Other problems certainly hide just under
the surface, but it is still worth scrutiniz-
ing the record.

If we look at the number of deﬁnite
Early, that is to say Pleistocene, Paleo-
indian components (n"143 or 20 per-
cent) versus the number of probable Late
Paleoindian components (n"571 or
80 percent), it is clear that a distinct in-
crease in Paleoindian components oc-
curred during the Holocene period. It is
unclear to what degree these shifts in
component numbers reﬂect shifts in pop-
ulation, but it is not unreasonable to sug-
gest that there was an associated increase
in Paleoindian population numbers from
the Pleistocene to the Holocene.

If we look at the number of Paleo-
indian components documented per site
(Table 2.3), more than 75 percent have
only one component, and more than
91 percent have three or fewer compo-
nents. Five or more components occur
at only twenty-one sites (less than 5 per-
cent). These sparse data do not constitute
a strong record demonstrating repeated
reoccupation of sites during the entire
Paleoindian period.

Another way to look at these patterns

is to compare the number of sites by
component with single or multiple com-
ponents (Table 2.4). Along with the raw
counts and the chi-square test of signiﬁ-
cance, we have calculated the adjusted
residuals to help identify signiﬁcant varia-
tions. The chi-square test is highly signiﬁ-
cant, and the adjusted residuals with val-
ues that are greater than 2, or less than
$2, are signiﬁcant at a 0.05 level of sig-
niﬁcance. We use the adjusted residuals
to recognize three patterns in these dis-
tributions. First, among Clovis, Folsom,
Wilson, and Scottsbluff sites there is a

The distribution of all recorded Paleo-
indian sites in Texas is shown in Fig. 2.45.
Some large gaps are instantly visible.
These include the Trans-Pecos, High

Plains, far south Texas, west-central Texas,
and western north-central Texas. The

The distribution of Clovis sites is
spread throughout the entire state, sug-
gesting that the Early Paleoindian groups
occupied all regions during this well-rec-
ognized period (see Fig. 2.46b). Also, the
number of Clovis sites is perhaps surpris-
ing for this early period, but this distribu-
tion is supported by Meltzer and Bever’s
(1995) distributional study.

Although Folsom/Midland sites ap-
pear to be more common in the prairies
and grasslands (see Fig. 2.46c), they are
unexpectedly common in east Texas
(Story 1990). Many investigators have
suggested that Folsom/Midland hunter-
gatherers were specialized bison hunters
(e.g., Hofman 1991b), but their occur-
rence in east Texas, when the pollen data
from east-central Texas indicates that
woodlands would have been extensive
(Bousman 1998b), suggests a more com-
plex adaptation.

The distribution of stemmed projectile

points associated with Paleoindian occu-
pations in the southern portion of the
state is also surprising (see Fig. 2.46d).
Among other sites, these included the
early stemmed components from the
Devil’s Mouth site in the Lower Pecos,
the Wilson component from the Wilson-
Leonard site near Austin, the stemmed
points from Berclair Terrace in Bee
County, and the stemmed component
from 41WH19. These sites may or may

San Patrice and Scottsbluff site distri-
butions are presented in Figs. 2.46h and

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 75

These distribution maps provide a vi-
sual source of information to assess some
of the biases in the Paleoindian archeo-
logical record of Texas. For example, only
one site from the Trans-Pecos region is on
record at TARL (see also Miller and Ken-
motsu, chapter 7, this volume). Obvi-
ously this area is grossly under repre-
sented. South Texas below the Nueces
River and even the High Plains may also
be inadequately represented. Recorder bi-
ases apparently account for the comple-
mentary spatial patterns between Golon-
drina and Dalton. Nevertheless, these
maps do provide a glimpse of cultural
patterns during the Paleoindian period.

Subsistence

The study of Paleoindian archeology
has been intimately tied to questions of
diet and subsistence. As high-proﬁle Late
Pleistocene mammoth and bison kill sites
began to be examined, simple models
were developed characterizing Paleo-
indians along a continuum from Clovis
mammoth hunters to Folsom bison
hunters to generalized Early Archaic
hunter-gatherers. Historically, all lanceo-
late projectile points were equated with
big-game hunting. We now know that
these models were oversimpliﬁed. As cul-
tural and radiocarbon chronologies for
the Late Pleistocene/Early Holocene
transition become more complex and
difﬁcult to interpret, so too do answers to
questions focusing on subsistence adapta-
tions of the ﬁrst Americans.

The geographic variability within
Texas provides a unique opportunity for
addressing questions of variability in
Paleoindian subsistence. Faunal data from
Texas Paleoindian sites are summarized
below by Early Paleoindian (Pleistocene)
and Late Paleoindian (post-Pleistocene)
afﬁliations. A synopsis of these faunal
samples is presented in Table 2.5. Sites
with more questionable, or previously
discounted associations, are also included
in the table, but are not elaborated on in
the text.

Early Paleoindian

As previous portions of this chapter
have emphasized, the cultural chronology
of Paleoindian archeology is by no means
straightforward. For example, our metric
analysis and interpretation of Texas Paleo-

indian points as presented here contrasts
in several cases with other published in-
terpretations of these artifacts. Thus, it
remains difﬁcult to characterize in detail
the subsistence strategies of various Paleo-
indian populations when these cultural
afﬁliations and the absolute chronologies,
themselves, are in question.

Clovis.

The earliest Paleoindian sites from
Texas have yielded signiﬁcant faunal data
illustrating that Clovis peoples exploited a
broad range of animal species. This con-
trasts with the traditional view of Clovis
peoples as strictly mammoth hunters.
Foremost among these are the Aubrey
(Ferring 1989a, 1990b, 1995b; D. Hall
1996), Lewisville (Stanford 1982, 1983;
Stanford et al. 1995; D. Winkler 1982),
and Lubbock Lake sites (E. Johnson
1987c, 1991, 1995a, 1995b; Kreutzer
1987, 1988).

Aubrey is signiﬁcant in that its Clovis

faunal sample contains more than four
thousand elements (many burned) dis-
tributed in bone clusters around hearth
areas. A broad range of large and small
taxa are present, including Bison sp., deer,
rabbit, pocket gopher, vole, squirrel,
birds, turtles, and snakes (Ferring 1989a).
A full report on the site was in progress as
of 2001.

The faunal assemblage from the
Lewisville site also reﬂects a generalized
Clovis subsistence base as illustrated in a
paper by Stanford et al. (1995) titled
“Early Paleoindian Diet Breadth as Seen
from the Lewisville Site, Texas: Critter
Buffet as an Alternative to Mammoth
Barbeque.” They note that a broad range
of both vertebrate and invertebrate spe-
cies were recovered from feature contexts,
indicating that Clovis peoples introduced
these animals into the site as part of a
broad-based subsistence economy. While
a detailed report on these assemblages has
not been published, Dale A. Winkler
(1982) described the faunal assemblage
from Dennis Stanford’s 1978 –80 excava-
tions, in part to address questions of Clo-
vis diet.

Taxa identiﬁed by Winkler include
ﬁsh, box turtle (Terrapene carolina), poi-
sonous snake (Viperidae), water snake
(Nerodia sp.), alligator (Alligator mississip-
piensis), bird (Falconiformes), shrew
(Cryptotis parva), eastern mole (Scalopus

aquaticus), rabbit (Sylvilagus cf.
ﬂoridanus), prairie dog (Cynomys ludovi-
cianus), squirrel (Sciurus cf. niger), gopher
(Geomys bursarius), mouse (Oryzomys
palustris and Peromyscus sp.), rat (Sig-
modon hispidus and Neotoma ﬂoridana),
vole (Microtus sp. and Synaptomys sp.),
canid (Canis dirus), mammoth (Mam-
muthus sp.), horse (Equus sp.), and white-
tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus). Re-
garding taphonomy, Winkler noted that
the assemblage is highly fragmented and
that much of the bone is burned and was
recovered from features interpreted as
hearths (D. Winkler 1982, 17–18).
Overall, the assemblage is dominated by
turtles, rabbits, wood rats, and deer.

Clovis components from the Lubbock

Lake site also yielded a diverse range of
faunal subsistence data. Eileen Johnson,
who has worked extensively at the site,
was one of the ﬁrst Texas archeologists to
discuss in detail the concept that Paleo-
indians exploited a diverse range of both
large and small animal species (E. John-
son 1977). Clovis components from the
Lubbock Lake site have produced at least
seventy-six different species, including a
broad range of ﬁsh, salamanders, frogs,
turtles, tortoises, snakes, lizards, ducks,
other birds, shrews, rabbits, sciurids, go-
phers, mice, rats, voles, muskrat, canids,
mammoth, horse, camel, bison, and other
extinct Pleistocene faunas (E. Johnson
1986a, 252).

The Clovis-age megafaunal processing

station at Lubbock Lake is designated
FA2-1 (E. Johnson 1987a, 121; E. John-
son and Holliday 1985). Seven big-game
species were recovered: mammoth, camel,
horse (two species), extinct bison, short-
faced bear, and giant armadillo. An ex-
tensive list of small taxa, representing nu-
merous habitats, was also identiﬁed (E.
Johnson 1987c, 49 –89). Mammoth re-
mains dominate the processing station.
Portions of one adult and two young
mammoth were recovered. Activities
reﬂected at the site include secondary
butchering, marrow processing, and bone
quarrying. The site is signiﬁcant in that
it shows the Early Paleoindian processing
of a broad range of both megafauna and
smaller taxa at a single locale.

Other Clovis sites from Texas with
faunal assemblages include the Gault site
(41BL323), Sand Creek, Poverty Hill
(41HQ1), and the Miami site (41RB1).

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 79

conditions tend to produce diverse taxo-
nomic assemblages at water holes.

The overall picture reﬂected by Texas

Clovis assemblages is that while mam-
moth hunting was certainly part of the
Clovis subsistence repertoire, a broader
range of animals was also exploited. Clo-
vis mammoth sites that have been identi-
ﬁed in the state tend to be concentrated
on the Llano Estacado.

Clovis/Folsom

The chronology of other Early Paleo-
indian faunal samples from Texas is less
straightforward than for the Clovis sites
discussed above. Samples considered here
to be Clovis/Folsom include Pavo Real
(41BX52), Kincaid Shelter (41UV2), and
McLean (41TA29).

From the Pavo Real site, Jerry Hender-

son and Glen Goode (1991) described a
Paleoindian component with three Clovis
points, seven Folsom points, and six Fol-
som preforms. Two apparent hearths
yielded a meager faunal sample of one bi-
son tooth fragment and three unidentiﬁ-
able bone fragments.

Kincaid Shelter (M. Collins 1990b;

M. Collins et al. 1989b; Hester et al.
1985) produced both Clovis and Folsom
points along with a diverse faunal assem-
blage in Zone 4. Taxa included slider
turtle (Pseudemys sp.), box turtle (Ter-
rapene carolina), alligator (Alligator sp.),
armadillo (Dasypus novemcinctus), pocket
mouse (Perognathus hispidus), badger
(Taxidea taxus), raccoon (Procyon lotor),
extinct horse, and mammoth. The verte-
brate taphonomy of rockshelter deposits
is always difﬁcult to interpret, but if these
taxa do indeed reﬂect human procure-
ment (a detailed study has not been pub-
lished), it again illustrates a broad subsis-
tence base among early Paleoindians.

The McLean site, reported by Bryan
and Ray (1938), Ray (1942), and Ray and
Bryan (1938), was discovered in 1929 by
Cyrus Ray about 75 km southwest of
Abilene. Ray apparently collected materi-
als from the site before a 1938 excavation.
The site is reported to have produced evi-
dence of extinct mammoths and a Clovis
point in alluvium along Mulberry Creek.
However, illustrated points include forms
that today could be classiﬁed as Clovis,
Folsom, and Golondrina (Ray 1942);
these are clearly the result of multiple oc-
cupations. No fauna remains other than

Fig. 2.47. Plan of mammoth bones at the Duewall-Newberry site (after Steele and Carlson
1989a).

Investigations are currently being con-
ducted by Michael B. Collins at the Gault
site, situated in Bell County (M. Collins
1998c). Preliminary results indicate that
mammoth, horse, and bison remains were
associated with projectile points and knap-
ping debris. Collins suggests that “Clovis
and Folsom technologies were partly con-
temporary at this site” (1998d, 9). The
Sand Creek mammoth site (E. Johnson
et al. 1994) is situated approximately
30 km downstream from the Lubbock
Lake site. The remains of a mammoth
(Mammuthus columbi) were recovered
there in Yellowhouse Canyon, eroding
from Late Pleistocene lacustrine deposits.
The partial skeleton (694 bone segments
were mapped) was associated with a chert
tool. The types of bone fracturing noted
suggested that humans may have played
a role in their breakage. The chert tool is
not diagnostic but has bifacial ﬂaking and
use wear. The site is included here as a
probable Clovis site.

Poverty Hill (41HQ1), also on the
Llano Estacado, produced a Clovis point
associated with mammoth tusk fragments.
Wayne Parker (1983) reports this as a
possible Paleoindian mammoth kill site.
The central Texas Duewall-Newberry
site (41BZ76) had no stone artifacts, al-
though detailed taphonomic analysis by
D. Gentry Steele and David L. Carlson
strongly suggests this was a Paleoindian
mammoth butchering site (Carlson and
Steele 1992; Carlson et al. 1984; Steele
1990; Steele and Carlson 1984, 1989a,
1989b). This suggestion is based on bone

breakage patterns and what has been inter-
preted as piles of bones stacked by Paleo-
indian hunters or scavengers (Fig. 2.47).
More widely known among Texas
Paleoindian mammoth sites is the Miami
site, also known as Cowan Ranch (Hol-
liday et al. 1991, 1994; J. J. Saunders
1980; Sellards 1938, 1952). The site was
the third Clovis mammoth kill site to be
investigated in North America (Sellards
1938). Evans and Sellards conducted in-
vestigations there, excavating the partial
remains of ﬁve mammoths ( J. J. Saunders
1980). They were found with three Clo-
vis points and a nondiagnostic stone tool.
The site was reinvestigated by Holliday
et al. (1991, 1994). They recovered an
additional 336 bone and tooth fragments.
Sellards (1952, 23) originally proposed
that the Miami mammoths probably died
of natural causes at a water hole during a
drought and were butchered and scav-
enged by Clovis peoples. J. J. Saunders’s
(1980) analysis of the skeletons, however,
showed that three of the ﬁve mammoths
were mature or nearly mature and two
were immature. His study suggested that
these age proﬁles compare favorably with
matriarchal family unit structures of
modern elephants, thus supporting Saun-
ders’s herd confrontation model ( J. J.
Saunders 1977), in which a single family
unit was confronted, contained, and dis-
patched by Clovis hunters ( J. J. Saunders
1980). The lack of other fauna in the as-
semblage also makes it unlikely that the
scavenging model is accurate in this case.
Shipman (1975) has noted that drought

80 / TEXAS PREHISTORY

mammoth were recovered, and the bones
were scattered. Thomas N. Campbell,
who was Ray’s ﬁeld assistant during the
July, 1938, excavation, doubts that Clovis
materials and the mammoth were in di-
rect association (Campbell, 1978 letter to
Thomas R. Hester). The fauna and Clo-
vis point association, and thus the gener-
ally accepted interpretation of McLean as
a Clovis mammoth kill, must remain in
serious question.

Folsom/Midland

Additional Early Paleoindian sites
include those classiﬁed here as Folsom/
Midland. These assemblages include Lake
Theo, Lipscomb, Lubbock Lake, Lub-
bock Landﬁll, Scharbauer (Midland), and
Shifting Sands.

Two bone beds were excavated at Lake
Theo in the Rolling Plains (Harrison and
Smith 1975; Harrison and Killen 1978).
The lower bed contained Folsom points
in association with Bison antiquus, and
the upper bone bed is associated with an
unﬂuted parallel-stemmed lanceolate
point that was classiﬁed as Plainview. The
Folsom/Midland component contained
524 bison bones from at least twelve ani-
mals, and Harrison and Smith (1975,74)
interpreted the site as a butchering station
and camp site, rather than a kill site, based
on element representation, possible bone
stacking, and the lithic assemblage. Age
estimation of the bison suggested a late
summer or early fall kill.

Lipscomb is another key Paleoindian
site, and it is cited widely in discussions
of Folsom lifeways (Barbour and Schultz
1941; Hofman 1995; Hofman and
Todd 1990, 1995; Hofman et al. 1989a,
1991b; Schultz 1943; Todd 1991; Todd
et al. 1990, 1992). At least ﬁfty individ-
ual Bison antiquus were recovered there
(Fig. 2.48). Interpretation of the site has
varied greatly over the years. It has been
described as a ﬁre drive, an arroyo trap, a
snow drift trap, and a surround (Hofman
et al. 1991b, 162). Reinvestigation of the
site was carried out in 1988 (Hofman
et al. 1991b). A notable feature of the
faunal sample is the incomplete butcher-
ing of the bison. This feature, in conjunc-
tion with limited marrow extraction from
the bison, may reﬂect a gourmet butcher-
ing strategy in which only choice parts
are removed, or it may reﬂect warm
weather conditions in which the group

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

Fig. 2.48. Map of bison excavated by Barbour and Schultz in the 1939 season at Lipscomb (after
Hofman 1995).

could not fully exploit the meat before it
spoiled (Hofman et al. 1991b, 184). De-
tails on the topographic setting and na-
ture of the kill episode itself are yet to be
resolved.

The Shifting Sands site (41WK21)
represents another Folsom/Midland pe-
riod bison procurement site (Amick et al.
1989; Amick and Rose 1990; Hofman
et al. 1990). The site produced thousands
of Folsom/Midland artifacts and bison
bones (Bison sp.) from a series of dune
blowouts (Amick et al. 1989). More than
four hundred Folsom/Midland artifacts

and thousands of pieces of chipping de-
bris were collected. At least one bison
kill /butchery event was identiﬁed from
Area 3 (Hofman et al. 1990). Although
the bones lack butchering marks, a
butchering episode is suggested based on
the occurrence of projectile point frag-
ments, choppers, and ﬂake tools, along
with a low debris density associated with
the bones (Hofman et al. 1990, 233).
While mammoth bones were also found
at the site, these were recovered from
Area 2 and had no associated artifacts.
Additional Folsom/Midland subsis-

02-A2946  4/13/04  11:51 AM  Page 81

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 81

tence evidence is available from the Lub-
bock Lake site. The Folsom bison kill
there is designated FA6-8 (E. Johnson
1987a, 124). The sample includes at least
three bison (one subadult and two adults)
that were killed and processed at the lo-
cale. Processing activities associated with
the skeletons included bone stacking, car-
cass processing, limited marrow process-
ing, and expedient bone tool manufac-
ture. Eileen Johnson (1987c) interprets
most of the bone breakage as the result of
tool manufacture rather than marrow ex-
traction. Muskrat bones from the locale
have cut marks, again illustrating the ex-
ploitation of both large and small taxa by
Folsom hunters. Other freshwater ﬁsh
and turtles were also recovered here.

Another Folsom example is the City of
Lubbock landﬁll site, located in Blackwa-
ter Draw outside of Lubbock, Texas (D.
Brown 1993; E. Johnson 1993b, 1994a).
The site appears to have been occupied
repeatedly by Folsom-age peoples. A prob-
able bison butchering episode occurred,
along with possible food processing and
camping activities based on sequential
hearths and burned bone. The site had a
signiﬁcant faunal assemblage consisting of
11,078 specimens. The majority of these
were recovered from ﬁne-screen process-
ing of matrix samples, highlighting the
importance of reﬁned recovery methods
when addressing questions of subsistence
data and environmental change. Folsom-
aged fauna recovered from Stratum 2 in-
cluded catﬁsh, pond slider, frog, ground
squirrel, prairie dog, pocket gopher,
vole, muskrat, and extinct bison (Bison
antiquus).

A ﬁnal Folsom/Midland faunal assem-

blage considered here is from the Mid-
land (Scharbauer) site (Gazin 1955; Hol-
liday and Meltzer 1996; Quinn 1955;
Wendorf et al. 1955; Wendorf and Krieger
1959). As previously described, the geo-
chronology of this site is very complex
and all of the faunal sample is not neces-
sarily reﬂective of human subsistence re-
mains, nor is it associated with the Folsom
or Midland occupations. A diverse range
of extinct and extant taxa were found,
including horse, bison, peccary, camel,
antelope, mammoth, bird, turtle, sloth,
cervid, rabbit, rat, prairie dog, mouse,
and wolf (Wendorf et al. 1955, 132).
Overall, Folsom components from
Texas that do contain faunal assemblages

have included bison. However, a broad
range of taxa is also represented at many
sites. If representative of human procure-
ment, these faunal assemblages suggest
additional and diverse hunting and pro-
curement methods for Folsom hunters.
These ﬁndings are similar to those of
Daniel S. Amick (1994a), who noted that
while the Folsom diet seems to have been
primarily organized around bison pro-
curement, at least thirty-three other spe-
cies of animals have been recovered from
Folsom sites in the American Southwest.

Folsom/Plainview

Perhaps the best known of Texas Paleo-
indian sites is Bonﬁre Shelter (41VV218)
in Val Verde County (see also Turpin,
chapter 8, this volume). Dibble identiﬁed
three depositional zones and three bone
beds at Bonﬁre Shelter (Dibble and Lor-
rain 1968, 24 –27). The oldest, Bone Bed
1, consisted of a small amount of bone
not clearly associated with humans. It in-
cluded the remains of camel, horse, mam-
moth, and bison. Bone Bed III was Ar-
chaic in age, reﬂecting a modern bison
jump. Bone Bed II was a thick bison de-
posit with points typed as Plainview, along
with a Folsom point in the lower portion
of the bed and a Lubbock point in the
top of the bone bed. The bison were
identiﬁed as B. antiquus or B. occidentalis.
It is clear they were driven off the bluff
and butchered on site in the sheltered
area below. The standards of analysis set
by Dibble and Lorrain (who analyzed the
bison bone) more than thirty years ago
are hard to match even today.

Lorrain suggested that Bone Bed 2
represents several drives of small herds
throughout different seasons. It likely
represents three groups of animals killed
in separate jumps. Approximately 120 bi-
son were identiﬁed from Bone Bed 2.
Ages ranged from immature to mature.
Approximately equal numbers of males
and females were represented. The sea-
son(s) of the drives could not be deter-
mined. Butchering appears to have taken
place completely within the shelter. Ani-
mals were ﬁrst skinned and cut into large
segments that were moved to another
area of the shelter for further processing.
Other animals recovered from Bone Bed
II included pocket gopher, pocket mouse,
white-footed mouse, cotton rat, wood rat,
horse, and snake.

Plainview-Milnesand

Plainview sites from Texas with faunal

assemblages include Beidleman Ranch,
Lake Theo, Lone Wolf Creek, Wilson-
Leonard, Lubbock Lake, and the Plain-
view site. Located between two tributaries
of the Brazos River, the Beidleman Ranch
site had a bone bed of extinct bison in as-
sociation with two Plainview points. The
bone sample included “jaws, vertebrae,
leg bones, one skull, and numerous teeth”
(Suhm 1961, 208). The site, excavated
by WPA crews in 1939, was surmised
by Suhm (1961) to be the scene of a bi-
son kill.

The Wilson-Leonard site in central
Texas also produced a Plainview bison
component known as the Bone Bed Com-
ponent (Baker 1998; M. Collins 1998c;
M. Collins et al. 1993; Masson and
Collins 1995). This component dates to
greater than 11,000 b.p. (Stafford 1998),
and along with other valuable informa-
tion it provides evidence that Plainview
occupations are truly Pleistocene in age.
Excavations by TxDOT (using quarter-
inch screening) yielded 32 bison bones
and a single horse navicular from this
component, along with a diverse range
of other animals, including musk turtle,
indeterminate small mammal, medium/
large-sized mammal, large mammal, bi-
son-sized mammal, rabbit/hare, indeter-
minate artiodactyl, and large artiodactyl.
Burned bone totaled 134 specimens, in-
cluding two unidentiﬁed turtle elements
and three bison elements. Spiral fractures
were identiﬁed on a large artiodactyl frag-
ment and a bison humerus and meta-
carpal. At least two individual bison are
represented in the bone bed, including an
adult and a juvenile (based on the pres-
ence of two right astragali). Age structure
was based on dentition and epiphyseal fu-
sion. The wide range of elements present
(including low utility elements) suggests
the bison were killed and butchered at or
near the site (Baker 1998). Later excava-
tions at the site by TARL recovered an
additional 236 faunal specimens from
eighth-inch screening. The sample is
dominated by indeterminate fragments
(n"121). Taxa include turtle, jackrabbit,
cottontail, and bison.

Lone Wolf Creek was one of the ﬁrst
archeological sites that provided solid evi-
dence for the presence of Pleistocene hu-
mans in North America (Cook 1925,
