82 / TEXAS PREHISTORY

1926, 1927; Figgins 1927; Hay and Cook
1930; Wormington 1957, 110 –11).
There, the articulated bones of an extinct
bison were jacketed and removed in block
form using paleontological excavation
techniques. Upon further excavation in
the laboratory, three Milnesand points
were recovered from the skeleton. This
site was crucial for documenting human
associations with extinct faunas and for
beginning to address the question of
Paleoindian subsistence. While the Lone
Wolf Creek projectile points are now
classiﬁed as Plainview, it was not until
two decades later that the Plainview type
site itself was excavated.

The Plainview site (41HA1) bison bed
was discovered in 1933, and caliche quar-
rying operations continued to expose
more of the bed until 1941, when mining
for the road-grade stone ceased (Speer
1990). The site was excavated in 1945 by
Glen Evans, Grayson Meade, E. H. Sel-
lards, and others. Amazingly, more than
one hundred bison were discovered in
association with human artifacts. The
deﬁnitive report was published by Sel-
lards et al. (1947). The skeletons of late-
term fetuses suggested that the bison kill
event occurred in the spring. The bison
bones were recovered from pond sedi-
ments, suggesting the bison stampeded
into the water hole. All of the lithic tools
were recovered from the top part of the
bone bed; thus Sellards et al. (1947) pro-
posed that the Plainview hunters shot
down at the herd from a bluff.

Over the decades, other investigations

have been conducted at the Plainview
site (Speer 1990). Guffee (1979), for ex-
ample, recovered an additional thirty-ﬁve
hundred bison bones and fragments from
the site, but a complete analysis has never
been undertaken. Recently, Jose Luis
Lanata and C. Britt Bousman measured
the metapodials in an attempt to deter-
mine the size of the bison and compare
these bones to other samples from the
Southern Plains. The size of the Plain-
view bison metacarpals (Fig. 2.49) shows
that these bison were very large, and in
fact larger than the measured bison from
Bonﬁre Shelter and Milnesand but not
Rex Rodgers (Bousman et al n.d.). If the
evolution of bison in the Southern Plains
reﬂected a simple unilinear decrease in
size from Bison antiquus to Bison bison,
then it is possible that Plainview is older
than Bonﬁre Shelter.

et al. n.d.)

Investigations at Lake Theo in 1977
uncovered a Plainview bison component
that postdated the Folsom/Midland
sample recovered there in 1974 (Harrison
and Killen 1978). The bone bed (West
Trench 7) contained the remains of at
least three individuals (Harrison and
Killen 1978, 34). Metric analysis sug-
gested that an adult male, an adult fe-
male, and a juvenile of indeterminate sex
were represented.

In contrast to Folsom sites, the Plain-
view sites from Texas predominantly re-
ﬂect bison procurement locales to the
exclusion of other animal species. Con-
sidering that the majority of these Plain-
view sites were excavated prior to the now
common practice of ﬁne screening and
bulk matrix processing, part of this pattern
may be the result of sampling strategies.

Late Paleoindian

Late Paleoindian sites (those dating to
the Early Holocene) have produced fau-
nal samples and subsistence data from a
number of locales. These include site
41WH19, Baker Cave, Big Lake, Horace
Rivers, Lubbock Lake, Rex Rodgers,
Richard Beene, Seminole-Rose, and
Wilson-Leonard.

William McClure analyzed a Late
Paleoindian faunal sample from 41WH19
along the Texas coast (McClure 1983;
Patterson et al. 1987, 19 –26). The site
contains Paleoindian through Late Prehis-

toric archeological deposits. Stratum 3
and the upper portions of Stratum 4 are
interpreted as Late Paleoindian in age.
Area A had a mammoth or mastodon
bone fragment, although its cultural asso-
ciation is unclear. Fauna from Strata 3
and 4 of Area B included gar, bowﬁn,
freshwater drum, sunﬁsh, colubrid snake,
softshell turtle, rodents, rabbit, bison, and
deer. Patterson et al. note that “small ﬁsh,
turtles, snakes, and deer were used as
food resources during the entire occupa-
tion sequence” (1987, 25).

The Horace Rivers site (41HH23) is
reported by Robert J. Mallouf and Rolfe
D. Mandel (1997) as a late Plainview site,
although we have suggested it may repre-
sent a St. Mary’s Hall component. The
diverse faunal assemblage includes bison,
antelope, deer, rabbits, muskrats, wolves,
badgers, skunks, squirrels, prairie dogs,
birds, snakes, turtles, lizards, frogs, ﬁsh,
and mussels (Mallouf and Mandel 1997).
The faunal sample suggests these Paleo-
indians were broad-spectrum generalists
and not specialized big-game hunters.

The Richard Beene site (41BX831) in
Bexar County produced a small (n"726)
Late Paleoindian faunal sample (B. Baker
1992, 1993; Baker and Steele 1992;
Flaigg 1996; Thoms 1992, 1995; Thoms
et al. 1996; Thoms and Mandel 1992).
Only twenty-ﬁve specimens were identi-
ﬁed to the taxonomic level of class. These
faunal remains were recovered from strata

02-A2946  4/13/04  11:51 AM  Page 83

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 83

that yielded a wide variety of cultural ma-
terial, including intact and partially intact
features. Some of the bone is burned.
Taxa include ﬁsh, snake, small mammal,
rabbit, small rodent, gopher, wood rat,
and unidentiﬁed artiodactyl; no bison-
sized bone was present in this sample.
The sample reﬂects riparian and forest
edge exploitation.

The Wilson-Leonard site in central

Texas has multiple Late Paleoindian
components (Bousman 1998a; see also
M. Collins, chapter 3, this volume). The
Wilson component from Stratum Isi(c)
had a moderate-sized sample from quar-
ter-inch screening (n"1,847), with Ki-
nosternid turtle, bird, rodent, jackrabbit,
cottontail, cf. Canis sp., deer, and bi-
son. The sample is extensively burned
(n"1,509 or 82 percent). The eighth-
inch sample (n"1,521) had a similar fau-
nal component of Kinosternid turtle,
snake, large bird, bison-sized mammal,
shrew, jackrabbit, cottontail, cf. ground
squirrel, gopher, wood rat, and indeter-
minate artiodactyl. More than 70 percent
was also burned. TARL ﬁne screening
also recovered bird eggshell from the Wil-
son component.

A second Late Paleoindian component

from Wilson-Leonard is a mixture of
Golondrina, Barber, and St. Mary’s Hall
materials in Stratum II. In terms of fauna,
excavations by TxDOT recovered 1,542
specimens. Taxa included turtle, large
bird, bison-sized mammal, jackrabbit,
cottontail, canid, and pronghorn/deer.
Later excavations by TARL produced an
additional 4,593 elements, with ﬁsh,
turtle, lizard/snake, jackrabbit, cf. cotton-
tail, gopher, wood rat, carnivore, and
deer. These Late Paleoindian components
from Wilson-Leonard reﬂect the diverse
exploitation of riparian, forest, and grass-
land species.

Baker Cave, in Val Verde County, of-
fers unique insights into Late Paleoindian
subsistence (Chadderdon 1983; Hester
1978a, 1983, 1986a; Hester and Shafer
1995; Word and Douglas 1970). Faunal
and ﬂoral data recovered from a Golon-
drina hearth with multiple episodes of
use provide clear evidence for broad-
spectrum adaptations during the Late
Pleistocene/Early Holocene transition. As
Hester noted, “These sites have been im-
portant in dispelling the big game hunter
myth that has so commonly surrounded
the study of Paleo-Indian cultures”

(1983, 101). The Golondrina hearth pro-
duced the remains of sixteen species of
seeds and fruit, eight wood species, eleven
mammal species, six ﬁsh species, and sev-
enteen reptile species (including snakes
and lizards). This estimate of diversity is
conservative, since not all of the hearth
ﬁll has been processed and analyzed (Hes-
ter 1983). Hester (1983, 116) also makes
the key observation that while distinc-
tions can continue to be made between
Paleoindian and Archaic populations
based on lithic technologies, we cannot
continue to do so on the basis of subsis-
tence adaptations.

The Seminole-Rose site had a bison
bone bed that Hofman et al. (1990) in-
terpret as afﬁliated with Cody Complex
Firstview artifacts. No spiral fractures or
cut marks have been identiﬁed on the
bone, though some specimens are burned.
At least four bison are represented from
at least three age groups.

The Big Lake site (41RG13) in Reagan

County is reported by Turpin (1994b)
and Turpin et al. (1992, 1997). At least
ten bison were identiﬁed from a single
event kill dating to ca. 8000 b.p. The
herd, composed of calves, juveniles, and
cows, became stuck in saturated lacus-
trine clays and were dispatched. This in-
terpretation is strongly supported by the
fact that the limb bones of the bison were
still vertically embedded in the deposits.
While the taxonomy of the genus Bison
is not clear cut, the bones were smaller
than those of Bison antiquus and larger
than B. bison, falling within the size range
of female B. occidentalis (Turpin et al.
1997, 130).

The Rex Rodgers site (41BI42) also
represents a bison procurement site, al-
though its chronological assignment is
less clear (Speer 1975, 1978a, 1978b).
Chronometric dates for the bison post-
date the Pleistocene, although their large
size is more in line with earlier bison pop-
ulations. While projectile points from the
site have been described as Plainview-like,
it is possible they are St. Mary’s Hall
and/or parallel-sided stem. Six or more
bison are represented, including a juve-
nile and adult males and females. Charles
Reher (in Speer 1978b, 119) inferred a
winter kill for the bison ( January through
March) based on tooth wear.

The “Plainview” locale at the Lubbock

Lake site is designated FA6-11 (E. John-
son 1987a, 126). Although the associated

projectile points were originally typed as
Plainview, the reclassiﬁcation by Kerr in-
dicates the type to be St. Mary’s Hall
(Kerr and Dial 1998). Four primary con-
centrations contained a minimum of six
bison, with each group representing an
individual. A fetus, three subadults, and
two adults were identiﬁed. Meat and hide
processing is reﬂected. Interestingly, nine
muskrats were disarticulated and concen-
trated around the carcasses. Cut marks
were noted on four of the muskrat bones
(E. Johnson 1987a, 129). Other animals
included ducks, pronghorn, and deer.
This faunal pattern is similar to that
noted at the Lubbock Lake Folsom locale.
A second Plainview bison kill locale at
Lubbock Lake has been designated FA9-
1. Here, at least ﬁve bison are represented
(E. Johnson 1987a, 129).

Late Paleoindian (Firstview) locales at
Lubbock Lake include FA6-3, FA5-8/10,
and FA6-3(?) (E. Johnson 1987a, 129 –
31). The ﬁrst of these (FA6-3) yielded at
least seven bison stacked in bone piles.
They included three fetuses, two calves,
and two adults. The animals were in-
completely butchered, suggesting that
selective cuts of meat were chosen. The
second locale (FA5-8/10) had little sub-
sistence data. The assemblage included
percussion ﬂakes but no bone tools. At
least two bison (a fetus and a subadult)
were present. The third locale has been
interpreted both as a plant processing and
harvesting area (Bamforth 1985) and as a
camp (E. Johnson and Holliday 1981).
The area consists of a wide lithic and food
debris scatter. Animals present are prong-
horn, jackrabbit, cottontail, mallard, cin-
namon teal, gadwall, pintail, and grouse.
As with Early Paleoindian sites from

Texas, these Late Paleoindian samples
reﬂect a diversity in subsistence econo-
mies. In part, this situation is a reﬂection
of the geographic diversity and differen-
tial species availability across prehistoric
Texas, but it may also reﬂect differences
in seasonal food procuring strategies.

Discussion

Our understanding of Paleoindian
subsistence has progressed signiﬁcantly
throughout much of the twentieth cen-
tury, although much remains unknown.
Progress has come from advances in the
ﬁelds of zooarcheology and taphonomy
and through more reﬁned ﬁeld recovery
techniques. These techniques have con-

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

02-A2946  4/13/04  11:51 AM  Page 84

tributed greatly to our understanding of
the nature and context of subsistence data.
In contrast, detailed botanical evidence is
still lacking in most cases, especially from
Early Paleoindian components. Other po-
tential avenues for investigating questions
of Paleoindian subsistence include artifact
residue analysis, hair analysis (e.g., studies
by researchers at the Center for the Study
of the First Americans), and studies of
Paleoindian skeletons. As described be-
low, in fact, the results of dental micro-
wear studies of the Wilson-Leonard Paleo-
indian skeleton differ little from those of
later Archaic groups, suggesting an overall
continuity in subsistence strategies.

Human Remains

Texas has yielded several of the most
important Paleoindian skeletons recov-
ered from North America. These ﬁnds
have been crucial for understanding the
migration, biology, and burial customs of
the earliest known inhabitants of the con-
tinent. Several early reports of Pleistocene
human skeletons from the state, however,
have proven unveriﬁed or discounted.
Even these examples, though, played im-
portant roles in establishing research pro-
grams focusing on methods and questions
regarding the antiquity of humans in
North America. Overall, these early ex-
amples reﬂect the common problem in
American archeology at that time of doc-
umenting the Pleistocene presence of hu-
mans in North America (Meltzer 1993a,
1993b). The disciplines of geoarcheology,
radiocarbon dating, and zooarcheology,
which contribute extensively to today’s re-
search on human habitation, were still
very much in their infancy. In many
cases, these early skeleton-bearing strata
had been accidentally discovered by geol-
ogists, who then investigated the sites and
contributed greatly to our understanding
of the strata’s formation processes (Holli-
day 1997a).

Poorly Understood Burials
Lagow Sand Pit

Several years before the Folsom site
discovery (Figgins 1927), Shuler (1923)
reported on human remains associated
with Pleistocene faunas from the Lagow
Sand Pit in Dallas. This sand pit had
long been a source of Pleistocene fossil
specimens for paleontologists at Southern
Methodist University. Pit workers recov-

84 / TEXAS PREHISTORY

ered the remains of an adult male human
there in 1920. Chemical analysis of the
human bones and extinct camel from the
site indicated, at that time, that the hu-
man remains and extinct fauna had un-
dergone the same degree of fossilization,
suggesting they were contemporaneous
(Shuler 1923). Despite the potential im-
portance of the ﬁnd, the results were
largely ignored.

For many years previously, the phys-

ical anthropologist Ales Hrdlicka had
staunchly argued against the presence of
Pleistocene humans in North America,
setting an intellectual tone for rigorous
validation of such claims (reminiscent of
current debates regarding pre-Clovis oc-
cupations in the Americas). It was not
until Sellards (1952) reviewed the site
that it again gained notice. Shortly there-
after, Crook and Harris (1957, 1958) de-
scribed the context of the Lagow Sand Pit
human remains in their analysis of the
Lewisville site material.

This increased attention led Kenneth
P. Oakley and William W. Howells (1961)
to conduct further chemical tests on the
bones. They applied the F-U-N test to
the human and faunal remains from the
site to measure their ﬂuorine, uranium,
and nitrogen content. This test was the
same one used to prove the Piltdown for-
gery (Bowie and Davidson 1955). The
differing amounts of these chemicals
showed that the human bones from the
Lagow Sand Pit were not contemporane-
ous with the Pleistocene faunas. Crook
(1961) reinterpreted the human skeleton
as intrusive into the Upper Shuler yel-
low sand, with a possible Early Archaic
afﬁliation.

Denton Creek

The wide attention ultimately given to

the Lagow Sand Pit skeleton contrasts
with less well known examples from Texas.
Claude Albritton and Pattillo (1940), for
example, described a possible Pleistocene
skeleton from Denton Creek, a branch of
the Elm Fork of the Trinity River. The
skeleton was found in sand approximately
six feet below the surface of a terrace.
Albritton and Pattillo suggested that if it
proved to be contemporaneous with the
sand deposit, the skeleton could be Pleis-
tocene in age. The accompanying skeletal
analysis by Marcus Goldstein concluded
the skeleton was that of a female approxi-
mately sixty years old. Several medical

disorders were indicated, including ante-
mortem tooth loss, periostitis, and arthri-
tis. It was not determined in the ﬁeld
whether the skeleton was deposited along
with the ﬂuvial sands or represented a hu-
man interment intrusive into the deposit.
Goldstein’s assessment of the complete-
ness of the skeletal remains, however, sug-
gested to him that the skeleton was a hu-
man burial.

J. C. Putnam Skeleton

In 1945, Frank H. H. Roberts, Jr., of
the Smithsonian Institution described a
possible Pleistocene human burial from
the Abilene, Texas, area (Roberts 1945).
The discovery was made in 1943 by boys
swimming in the Clear Fork of the Brazos
River. The ﬁnd was reported to Dr.
Cyrus N. Ray, a well-known ﬁgure in
Texas archeology (see E. Davis 1979;
Tunnell 2000). Ray and others removed
the skeleton, which was buried in a
tightly ﬂexed position on its left side. The
burial pit contained a mixture of ash and
charcoal, and the tip of a biface was re-
covered in the burial ﬁll (Roberts 1945,
10 –11). The pit was in deposits known
as Elm Creek silts, believed to be Late
Pleistocene in age (Roberts 1945, 17).
Hoping to clarify the chronological posi-
tion of the skeleton, Ray conducted an
extensive but fruitless search for animal
bones and artifacts along the river.
The heavy brow ridges and thick
frontal bone of the skeleton, which con-
trasts with more contemporary Native
American populations, suggested to Ray
and Roberts that this might represent an
early and signiﬁcant human skeleton.
The skeleton was sent to Dr. Harry L.
Shapiro, chairman of the Department of
Anthropology at the American Museum
of Natural History, who agreed, stating
that “the frontal does have an exception-
ally heavy brow ridge and an apparently
sharply receding forehead. This suggests a
primitive form of recent man” (quoted in
Roberts 1945, 45).

T. Dale Stewart, curator of the Divi-
sion of Physical Anthropology at the U.S.
National Museum, spent additional time
reconstructing and studying these re-
mains. He concluded that the “skeleton
presents no unusual features setting it
apart from other remains of known
American Indians from this region”
(Stewart 1945, 38). He did not comment
on the speculation regarding the heavy

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 85

brow ridge. As Wormington (1957, 225 –
26) noted, despite the fact that the skele-
ton was recovered from deeply buried
silts, its age remained uncertain.

The summary in Roberts’s paper

(1945, 29) is noteworthy, for it reiterated
that investigators attempting to deter-
mine the chronological age of apparently
early skeletons should have a detailed un-
derstanding of the strata in which the
bones are deposited rather than focusing
on skeletal morphology alone. This con-
cept of dating based on skeletal morphol-
ogy was reviewed several years later by
Stewart (1949).

Brazos River Skeleton and Extinct Fauna
In another case, Adams (1949) re-
ported on a ﬁnd along the Brazos River.
It contained four individuals (two female,
one male, and one infant), which he indi-
cated were associated with a hearth. Other
associated remains included extinct glyp-
todont, bison, and ground sloth. While
his report describes the osteological fea-
tures of the human skeletons in detail, no
additional contextual information was
presented to allow evaluation of their pos-
sible Pleistocene association. To our
knowledge, this association has never
been reevaluated.

Midland (Scharbauer Ranch).

The Midland site and skeleton were
discovered in 1953 when Keith Glasscock
noted human bones and projectile points
eroding from a blowout in a dry channel
of Monahans Draw, near Midland, Texas
(Albritton 1955; Holliday 1997a; Holli-
day and Meltzer 1996; McKinney 1992;
Oakley and Rixon 1958; Stewart 1955;
Wendorf and Krieger 1959; Wendorf
et al. 1955; Wormington 1957, 241– 46).
The projectile points from the site formed
the Midland type collection, a newly rec-
ognized Paleoindian point. The site had
been previously investigated in 1950 by
Sellards and Evans during a paleontologi-
cal survey, although no archeological ma-
terials were encountered at that time.

Detailed archaeological investigations
of the site were ﬁrst carried out by Alex
D. Krieger and Fred Wendorf, then with
the Museum of New Mexico. The age of
the Midland skeleton has always been
difﬁcult to interpret. The skeleton was in-
terpreted as being at least ten thousand
years old and was widely regarded as the
ﬁrst well-documented Paleoindian skele-

ton from North America (Wendorf and
Krieger 1959).

Initial test pits at the site produced ad-
ditional cranial fragments, a rib fragment,
and a metacarpal (Wendorf et al. 1955,
40 – 41). The bones were scattered over
an area of four feet by three feet wide,
and they were heavily weathered and
fragmented. No burial pit was evident.
The bones included cranial and a small
amount of postcranial material, and
Stewart (1955, 77) reconstructed the
skull in hopes of gaining information on
its “physical type.” In addition to the par-
tial cranium (the mandible was not recov-
ered), at least two metacarpals and a ﬁrst
rib fragment were identiﬁed. A possible
phalanx and metacarpal fragment were
also present. Many fragments were too
small to be identiﬁed.

The gracile features, including small
brow ridges and slight muscle attachment
areas on the occiput, indicated the skele-
ton belonged to a female. Stewart esti-
mated an age at death of thirty years based
on cranial suture closure. This age seemed
consistent with the moderate-to-extreme
wear on the eight maxillary teeth. Medical
disorders included an odontome, de-
scribed by Stewart as a possible super-
numerary tooth. Stewart (1955, 90) stated
that the remains probably represent a
single individual. The skull is relatively
long (dolichocranic), a feature common in
many Texas archeological skeletal samples.
Problems of interpreting the skeleton

have centered on chronological issues
(Holliday and Meltzer 1996). Five de-
ﬂation basins (blowouts) form the Mid-
land site. Locality 1, which yielded the
human skeletal remains, is situated along
Monahans Draw, a tributary of the Colo-
rado River system in Texas. Initial test ex-
cavations where the human bones were
found yielded other human remains and
fossil animal species. Nearby blowouts
produced Folsom points. The association
was difﬁcult to interpret, although it was
suggested (Holliday and Meltzer 1996)
that the Folsom materials in the sur-
rounding blowouts may have come from
strata overlaying the one that produced
the human remains. This situation sug-
gested that the skeleton was older than
Folsom (Holliday and Meltzer 1996,
758 –59; Wendorf et al. 1955, 41– 42).

Ultimately, the human bones were de-

scribed as resting on and just below the
eroding surface of the Gray Sand, but

dating the human bones has remained
problematic (see Holliday 1997a and
Holliday and Meltzer 1996 for a more
detailed geoarcheological interpretation
of the site). Wendorf and Krieger (1959),
armed with new radiocarbon and U-Th
assays, argued that the Midland human
skull predated Folsom and was possibly
as much as twenty thousand years old.
While Fred Smith (1976) included the
Midland skeleton in his review of North
American Paleoindian skeletons, Gentry
Steele and Joseph Powell (1992) did not
because of unresolved questions regarding
the age of the skeleton.

Reinvestigation of the site by Vance

Holliday and David Meltzer between
1989 and 1992 was carried out to further
address its geochronology and to test an
initial suggestion by Ernst Antevs that the
Gray Sand in Locality 1 might actually
represent an Early to Middle Holocene
unit (Holliday and Meltzer 1996, 64).
At the same time, McKinney (1992) pro-
posed a date of 11,600 ! 800 b.p. for the
Midland skeleton, thus concluding that
it was Clovis in age and represented the
oldest Paleoindian skeleton known from
North America. As with much of the
Midland site, this date too has been ques-
tioned (Holliday and Meltzer 1996, 769).
Holliday and Meltzer’s (1996) investi-

gations produced no clear answers, and
they found no strong evidence to support
a pre-Folsom afﬁliation for the skeleton.
Radiocarbon chronologies from other
sites on the Southern High Plains suggest
“the bone may be the same age as or
younger than Folsom (#11,000 b.p.)”
(Holliday and Meltzer 1996, 770). The
issue of whether or not the skeleton is
from a Holocene age population is unre-
solved. Further direct dating of the skele-
ton itself will be required if we are to ad-
dress these questions.

Shifting Sands

Hofman et al. (1990, 234) described
several adult human molars from Shifting
Sands, a Folsom-Midland site in western
Texas. The site is on the southern margin
of the Llano Estacado in a series of deep
blowouts. A large number of Folsom and
Midland tools, along with chipping de-
bris, have been recovered there, and one
area yielded bison remains from a kill /
butchering event.

The human molars were collected
from Area 2, apparently in anatomical

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

02-A2946  4/13/04  11:51 AM  Page 86

position. Several Folsom and Midland
points were also recovered there, as the
area had undergone deﬂation from wind
erosion. As Hofman et al. (1990, 234)
note, a deﬁnite Folsom-Midland afﬁlia-
tion for these teeth has not been estab-
lished. However, Steele (1998, table 31-
1) includes these teeth in his summary of
afﬁrmed and probable North American
Paleoindians. His table lists these teeth as
representing an individual ﬁfteen to
twenty years of age, with an estimated
antiquity of 10,000 to 8500 b.p.

Well-Documented Paleoindian Burials
Thus far, the discussion of human
remains has focused on possible or dis-
counted examples of Paleoindian skele-
tons from Texas. Two Texas archeological
sites, however, are widely recognized for
their contribution to our understanding
of Paleoindian biology and burial prac-
tices. These include Horn Shelter and
Wilson-Leonard, described below.

Horn Rock Shelter No. 2

Horn Rock Shelter No. 2 is a well-
dated and stratiﬁed rockshelter on the
Brazos River in central Texas (Forrester
1985; Redder 1985; Redder and Fox
1988; Steele 1989; Watt 1978; D. Young
1985, 1986, 1988; D. Young et al. 1987).
A double Paleoindian burial consisting of
an adult and a child was discovered in the
shelter in 1970. Radiocarbon assays from
the stratum yielding the burials ranged
from 10,310 to 9500 b.p. (Watt 1978)
(see Table 2.1). This burial represented
the ﬁrst well-dated Paleoindian skeletal
material from Texas and one of the few
such examples from North America. Sev-
eral features make it extremely important
to Paleoindian studies: the presence of
two individuals, information on burial
practices, its well-stratiﬁed and dated
context, the completeness of the skele-
tons, and the presence of grave goods.
The burials were excavated in 1970
by Frank Watt and Albert Redder. The
Paleoindian skeletons were recovered
from Substratum 5E. The burial pit origi-
nated in Substratum 5G (D. Young et al.
1987, 277). Substratum 5G also yielded
what have come to be known as ﬂuted
Brazos Fishtailed projectile points, lying
below a stratum that yielded Plainview
points. The adult has been described as
Burial One and the child as Burial Two
(D. Young et al. 1987).

86 / TEXAS PREHISTORY

The burials were recovered 4.42 m be-

low the present rockshelter surface. The
skeletons were virtually complete. The
adult and child were buried in ﬂexed po-
sitions on their left sides. The child was
facing the back of the adult. Numerous
grave goods were associated with the bur-
ial (D. Young et al. 1987, 278). The head
of the adult rested in one of three inverted
turtle shells that had been stacked on top
of each other. Two other turtle carapaces
were placed by the adult’s pelvis and face.
The vertebrae on the inside of these turtle
shells had been scraped, showing they
were intentionally cleaned (Redder 1985).
Additional grave goods included shell
beads, bird claws, sandstone slabs, antler
billets, perforated nonhuman canines,
bone and stone tools, and red ochre. The
importance of red ochre in burial rituals
in Paleoindian sites is now well recog-
nized (Roper 1991). In addition to these
materials, nineteen sandstone slabs were
used to cover the Horn Shelter burial.
The skeletons have been thoroughly

analyzed by Diane Young Holliday
(D. Young 1985, 1986, 1988; D. Young
et al. 1987). Given the rarity of Paleo-
indian skeletons, both skeletons are amaz-
ingly intact. The child is estimated to be
roughly twelve years old based on dental
eruption, dental calciﬁcation, and the lack
of fused postcranial epiphyses. It is often
difﬁcult to determine the sex of children
from skeletal material, although Young
et al. (1987, 290) interpret this individual
as male based on the morphology of cra-
nial and pelvic features. No evidence of
trauma was noted, but the right maxillary
sinus shows signs of minor infection.

The adult was estimated to be male
based on nonmetric and metric features,
as well as the presence of traditional male
tools (in this case antler billets) as grave
goods. He was estimated to be in his mid-
thirties to early forties at the time of death.
This estimate is based on epiphyseal fu-
sion, third molar eruption and wear, ec-
tocranial suture fusion, degenerative bone
changes, and auricular surface wear.

Examples of medical disorders on this

skeleton include an infection of the left
maxillary sinus, as was seen in the child.
The left third cuneiform and navicular
(foot bones) showed abnormal bone re-
sorption and deposition. A healed frac-
ture was noted on the left foot. Interest-
ingly, an odontome was noted on the
upper dentition, a feature also seen in the

Midland skeleton (Stewart 1955, 88). In
addition, the Horn Shelter adult male
had antemortem tooth loss. At the time
of death, he would have had only two or
three functional chewing surfaces on his
teeth (D. Young et al. 1987, 281, 284).
The teeth were too heavily worn to deter-
mine dental features such as Carabelli’s
cusps and shovel-shaped incisors.1 Stature
of the adult male was estimated at be-
tween 161 and 169 cm, or between 5 feet,
3 inches, and 5 feet, 6 inches, in height.
A comparison of the Horn Shelter Paleo-
indians with later central Texas skeletal
populations revealed no signiﬁcant differ-
ences in cranial features, postcranial fea-
tures, or discrete traits (D. Young et al.
1987).

Wilson-Leonard

The Wilson-Leonard site is the most
recent Texas archeological site to yield a
Paleoindian skeleton and among the most
well known (Parvin 1983; Phelps et al.
1994; Stafford et al. 1987; Steele 1989,
1994, 1998; Weir 1985). This central
Texas site is in Williamson County along
Brushy Creek. Excavated by TxDOT and
TARL throughout the 1980s and 1990s,
the site is signiﬁcant because of its strati-
ﬁed, well-dated nature, and the Paleo-
indian components are especially signiﬁ-
cant (see M. Collins 1998c).

The Paleoindian burial, designated
Burial 2 or Wilson-Leonard II, is also
known locally as the Leander skeleton be-
cause of the site’s proximity to the town
of Leander, Texas. The skeleton was dis-
covered in 1983 when archeologists with
TxDOT conducted excavations along the
planned extension of Farm Road 1431.
The burial pit of the Wilson-Leonard
Paleoindian skeleton originated in the
lower portion of what was designated the
Leanne Soil and extended into underly-
ing sediments (E20/S74 and E20/S72,
Levels 31A–34B). The skeleton appears
to date between 10,000 and 9600 b.p.

Interpreted as a female, this body was

found lying on her right side with her
head resting on her hands (Fig. 2.50).
Her legs were ﬂexed and crossed, with her
knees drawn toward her chest. The orien-
tation of the burial was roughly in a
northeast/southwest direction. Her head
was to the north and faced west. Grave
goods in the burial included a shark
tooth, a grindstone/chopper, and a lime-
stone cobble.

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 87

macroscopic and microscopic level. While
the Paleoindian sample is small, Powell
and his coauthors’ studies show that Paleo-
indians have a higher frequency of ab-
scesses than Archaic assemblages but a
lower rate of caries. The degree of alveolar
resorption between the two groups is
roughly the same.

The Wilson-Leonard Paleoindian had
frequent pits and evidence of moderate to
large striations on the teeth. The ﬂattened
tooth wear indicates either the consump-
tion of hard, gritty foods, or long-term
use of the teeth (Powell and Steele 1994),
a pattern similar to that of Archaic hunters
and gatherers. Overall, Powell and Steele
concluded that the Wilson-Leonard fe-
male—like other Paleoindians whose
skeletons have been studied—had a diet
that may not have differed greatly be-
tween Paleoindians and later hunter-
gatherers of the Archaic.

In terms of population afﬁnity, Steele
(1998, 1453) noted that Wilson-Leonard
II has shoveling of the upper incisors, a
common trait in American Indian popu-
lations but comparatively rare in Euro-
peans. Wilson-Leonard II is similar to
other Paleoindian skeletons from other
states (such as Gordon Creek, Colorado,
and Pelican Rapids, Minnesota) in having
a relatively long, narrow cranium along
with a narrow and short face with moder-
ate alveolar prognathism. Detailed multi-
variate analysis (Powell 1995; Powell and
Steele 1993; Steele and Powell 1992,
1993, 1994) indicates that the Wilson-
Leonard II and other Paleoindian skele-
tons differ from both recent North
American Indians and northeast Asians,
resembling instead a more generalized
Asian stock (Steele 1998, 1456). This dis-
tinction has important implications for
questions regarding the peopling of the
New World. These and other questions
are actively being investigated by physical
anthropologists.

Future Inquiry

In 1970, the Texas paleontologist Bob

Slaughter, then of the Shuler Museum
of Paleontology at Southern Methodist
University, published a short (and largely
ignored) paper titled “Were the First
Americans Caucasoid?” In that paper, he
suggested that the earliest Americans may
have been Caucasoid, related in some
form to the Ainu, inhabitants of the Kuril
Islands of northern Japan.

Fig. 2.50. Map of Wilson-Leonard burial of female (after Steele 1998).

The skull was crushed from post-
mortem compaction. Many other bones
were also fractured. The majority of the
hand and foot bones were missing, al-
though very little rodent activity was
noted by excavators in the burial pit.
Mechanical and chemical degradation
was extensive.

The assessment of sex was made from

the gracile cranial features, mandible
morphology, pelvic features, and the rela-
tively gracile nature of the long bones
(Steele 1998). She was probably an ado-
lescent or young adult (early twenties)
at the time of death. This estimate was
based on epiphyseal fusion, cranial suture
fusion, and third molar eruption and
wear. She was relatively short, with a
stature estimation of 158 cm (5 feet,
2 inches). This skeleton is only the sec-
ond Paleoindian female from North
America for which stature has been esti-
mated (Steele 1998).

D. Gentry Steele, of Texas A&M Uni-
versity, analyzed the skeleton and worked
in conjunction with B. P. Gatliff to pro-

duce the ﬁrst facial reconstruction of a
Paleoindian skull (Phelps et al. 1994;
Steele and Powell 1993). Based on this
reconstruction, the cranium and face of
this person are thought to have been rela-
tively narrow, showing a moderate degree
of alveolar prognathism (Steele 1998).
The only medical disorders observed were
associated with the dental arcade. These
include caries, an apical abscess, ante-
mortem tooth loss, a cracked tooth, and
alveolar resorption. Several of the teeth
also show disproportionate amounts of
wear. This skeleton is one of only two
Paleoindian burials that show cavities.
Along with the Horn Shelter male, this
female is the second Paleoindian identi-
ﬁed with antemortem tooth loss.

In an attempt to address questions of
health and specialized big game hunting
versus generalized diets for Paleoindians,
Powell et al. (1993) and Powell and Steele
(1992, 1994) examined the Wilson-
Leonard skeleton and other Paleoindian
skeletons for dental disorders and occlusal
wear. This examination was done at the

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 89

This suggestion takes on heightened
interest given current descriptions of the
widely publicized Kennewick Man Paleo-
indian skeleton from Washington state
(R. Taylor et al. 1998). Although widely
debated, preliminary descriptions of this
skeleton have noted its Caucasoid cranial
features. As R. Ervin Taylor and his co-
authors note, this skeleton has “raised
the possibility that some of the earliest
American human populations have no
modern descendants in the New World”
(R. Taylor et al. 1998, 1171). This and
other recent Paleoindian skeleton ﬁnds
from across the country have tremendous
implications for our understanding of the
peopling of the New World (K. Wright
1999). Comparison of such skeletons
with the well-preserved materials previ-
ously recovered from Texas should con-
tinue to prove enlightening. These con-
tributions from human paleobiology
may also lead to a revision in the Paleo-
indian lexicon; Taylor et al. (1998,
1171), for example, now differentiate
between the terms Paleoindian and
Paleoamerican.

Assemblage Comparisons and
Lithic Technology

Assemblage Patterns

The published record of assemblage
composition for reliable excavated Paleo-
indian components in Texas contains
many gaps. This situation is due to a
number of factors. First, some site reports
are not published. Second, even when site
publications exist, often they are not fully
published and complete assemblage data
are omitted. Third, many sites are known
only from surface collections, which are
not considered reliable for assemblage
deﬁnition. Fourth, archeologists often do
not devote enough effort toward isolating
components when excavating multiple
occupancy sites. Compounding these
self-made problems is the very real pres-
ervation bias in the archeological record.
Because of these limitations, it is very
difﬁcult to discuss assemblage variation
among Paleoindian components in Texas.
What follows, while brief, is a reﬂection
of the Paleoindian archeological record
with all its limitations and biases.

Table 2.6 lists the composition of
twenty-one excavated Paleoindian assem-
blages. Other excavated assemblages were
not included because the time span was
great, we were unsure about the collec-
tion methods, or the material was not
fully published. In some cases these “as-
semblages” represent mixed components.
For example, the Unit II assemblage from
Wilson-Leonard (Bousman 1998a) and
the Lake Theo assemblage (Harrison and
Smith 1975; Harrison and Killen 1978)
represent multiple components. How-
ever, the mixed component assemblages
included represent a limited time span
(Early or Late Paleoindian), and a speciﬁc
location.

The assemblages in Table 2.6 are or-

dered by the percentage of projectile
points in the overall tool assemblage.
Debitage counts were not always avail-
able, and these are included when pos-
sible but are not used in the percentage
calculations. The counts from Lubbock
Lake are based on individual feature as-
semblages presented in Table 2.7. The
Lubbock Lake assemblages were lumped

into cultural groupings because of low ar-

A number of interesting patterns are
apparent in the assemblage information.
First, excavated assemblages are only pres-
ent from central Texas, the Lower Pecos,
and the Plains. Sites from other regions
either have not been excavated (e.g., east
Texas) or have not been fully published
(e.g., Aubrey). Secondly, most sites have
very small artifact counts. Except for the
Bone Bed, Wilson, and Late Paleoindian
components at Wilson-Leonard and the
Firstview assemblage from Lubbock Lake,
no assemblages have more than a hun-
dred stone tools. Central Texas assem-
blages are generally the largest, but these

are dominated by assemblages from a
single site, Wilson-Leonard. Plains assem-
blages are generally smaller than those
from the Lower Pecos.

Table 2.8 summarizes the information
in Table 2.6 cross-classiﬁed by region and
site function. It is no surprise that kill /
butchery site assemblages are dominated
by projectile points and unifacial tools,
except in central Texas. However, the
central Texas kill /butchery sample is
represented by only one assemblage, the
Bone Bed component at Wilson-Leonard.
Camps in all regions have low percentages
of projectile points but high percentages
of unifacial tools, core/choppers, and
pecked/groundstone tools.

and the Late Paleoindian component in
the Upper Gravels at Devil’s Mouth.
Both are in derived contexts, and little
can be said concerning their different as-
semblages. As most kill /butchery sites
and only one camp are in the Plains, this
region’s overall assemblage reﬂects this
bias. In central Texas, most assemblages
can be related to camp activities, and the
only kill /butchery assemblage had only
one projectile point; thus this region’s as-
semblages reﬂect this bias as well.

Table 2.9 again averages the percent-
ages presented in Table 2.6, but it cross-
classiﬁes them by region and period.
Early Paleoindian assemblages dominate
the Plains assemblages, but Late Paleo-
indian assemblages are rare in the Plains
sites. Lubbock Lake dominates the Plains
record and provides the most complete
set of assemblage information. The Early
Paleoindian assemblages are dominated
by projectile points and unifacial tools,
except in central Texas. Early Paleoindian
assemblages in the Plains have a surpris-
ingly high percentage of pecked/ground-
stone tools, and these frequencies are the
result of chopping tools in Clovis assem-
blages at Lubbock Lake. Particularly in
central Texas and the Lower Pecos, Late
Paleoindian assemblages are characterized
by fewer projectile points and a more
even distribution of tool forms. The
single Late Paleoindian assemblage in the
Plains (Firstview at Lubbock Lake) is
dominated by unifacial tools.

Technological Studies

Paleoindian technological studies are
well known but still not commonly done
in Texas. Most efforts have focused on the
production of points (Knudson 1983;
Sollberger 1985, 1988; Tunnell 1977),
but recently Michael Collins (1999b) has
investigated the production of blades in
Clovis assemblages.

Michael Collins et al. (1989b) and
Collins (1999) present studies of Clovis
biface and blade manufacture in the
Southern Plains and surrounding regions.
Clovis points are made on large elongated
ﬂakes and thinned by the removal of dis-
tinctive expanding ﬂakes that span the
entire width of the biface (Fig. 2.51).
These thinning ﬂakes can overshoot to re-
move the opposite bifacial edge. More
careful trimming retained the lanceolate

Building on Earl Green’s (1963) initial

discovery and several others across the
state (see M. Collins 1990b; M. Collins
and Headrick 1992; Goode and Mallouf
1991; Henderson and Goode 1991; Houk
et al. 1997; Mallouf 1989; B. Young and
Collins 1989), Collins (1999) argues per-
suasively that prismatic blade technology
was clearly a formal component in the
Clovis lithic repertoire. Conical and
wedge-shaped blade cores occur, but
conical cores are the most common. The
platforms on conical blade cores are
roughly circular, prepared by the removal
of broad but short ﬂakes that often hinge
(Fig. 2.52). This hinging produces large
central knots on the platform. Blade scars
on the slides of the blade cores often are
missing negative bulbs of percussion, sug-
gesting to Collins that core platforms

display strong curvature. Blades were not
used in the manufacture of points, but
they were occasionally used to make end
scrapers, scrapers, and burins.

Curtis Tunnell (1977) has proposed a
staged model for the production of ﬂuted
Folsom points (Fig. 2.53). His sequence
begins with the selection of a large ﬂake
(1 on Fig. 2.53), which is then bifacially
reduced and the platform prepared on the
base for the removal of the ﬁrst channel
ﬂake (2). The channel ﬂake is removed
ﬁrst on one side (3), preparing the plat-
form again (4), and then the second
channel ﬂake (5) is removed. At that
stage, the point is trimmed and shaped,
and ﬁnally the lateral edges are ground to

produce the point’s ﬁnal form (6). Rarely,
channel ﬂakes are made into miniature
points (7). In some cases, channel ﬂakes
can overshoot (8), but if the preform is
long enough they can still be used for the
production of shorter points (9 –11).
Basal fractures also occur (12), and occa-
sionally these are still used (13) for the
production of points (14). Hinged chan-
nel ﬂakes can also occur on the second
channel ﬂake removal (15), and if the
preform is long enough, these too can be
made into short points (16). As Hofman
(1991a) and Amick (1994c, 1995) have
argued, the production of Folsom ﬂuted
points is error prone, and when raw ma-
terials are rare, unﬂuted points would

more likely be made. They also suggest
that the availability of raw materials stim-
ulates the production of Folsom and
Midland points.

The general lithic strategies of Folsom

groups in the Southern Plains involved
the production and curation of large, thin
bifaces (Boldurian 1991; Hofman et al.
1990; Stanford and Broilo 1981). Blade
production is rare or absent (M. Collins
and Headrick 1992). The biface thinning
ﬂakes detached from the large (up to 140
mm in length; see Hofman et al. 1990)
Folsom bifaces were used as blanks for
points or other tools. Amick (1994c,
1995), Hofman (1991a, 1992), and Hof-
man et al. (1990) have argued that the

PALEOINDIAN ARCHEOLOGY IN TEXAS / 93

production of Folsom ﬂuted points is
prone to failure, and as groups moved
away from good raw material sources,
they began to expend their curated mate-
rials, presumably in the form of these
large, thin bifaces. When raw materials
were scarce, unﬂuted (i.e., Midland)
points were more likely to be made than
the ﬂuted Folsom points, in order to con-
serve raw materials. Thus, the availability
of lithic raw materials stimulated the pro-
duction of Folsom or Midland points.

Raw Material Use

The use of nonlocal raw materials is
well known in the Paleoindian archeolog-
ical literature (Hofman et al. 1991a). Re-
searchers have proposed numerous mod-
els to account for the use of nonlocal
materials. For example, Edwin N. Wilm-
sen (1973) argued that raw materials were
exchanged across territorial boundaries
and that the frequencies of nonlocal raw
materials could be used to reconstruct the
boundaries. David J. Meltzer (1989c) at-
tempted to determine if transportation of

raw materials within large territories or
exchange across territorial boundaries
accounts for the patterns in nonlocal ma-
terials in Paleoindian assemblages. As
Meltzer recognized, equiﬁnality is a seri-
ous problem, unfortunately. Raw mate-
rial availability inﬂuenced the point pro-
duction strategies of Folsom/Midland
hunters (Amick 1994c, 1995; Hofman
1991a).

The documentation of nonlocal raw
material use is fraught with problems be-
cause of the difﬁculty in identifying stone
sources, but recent studies in the south-
ern prairies, plains, and woodlands have
helped identify and clarify the character-
istics of stone sources (see Banks 1990;
Frederick and Ringstaff 1994; Hofman
et al. 1991a; Holliday 1997a; Holliday
and Welty 1981). As Tables 2.10 –2.15
indicate, the general pattern of greater use
of nonlocal raw materials in the Paleo-
indian period, particularly the Early
Paleoindian period, is supported by the
few studies with quantitative data from
Texas. It is not surprising that raw materi-

als were transported great distances on
the Plains, where usable raw materials are
scarce and high-quality raw materials are
virtually nonexistent. However, even at
Wilson-Leonard on the eastern Balcones
Escarpment, the frequent occurrence of
nonlocal raw materials in Early Paleo-
indian components suggests the impor-
tance of transporting high-quality stone
material. Nevertheless, local sources,
such as Manning Fused Glass (K. Brown
1976, 1995b) and Pisgah Ridge chert
(D. McGregor 1993), were also utilized.
These data suggest that Paleoindian
territorial boundaries were probably quite
large, but the presence of an obsidian
point from a Mexican source at Kincaid
Shelter and an obsidian point from a New
Mexico source at Lubbock Lake demon-
strates that some form of exchange was
also utilized (Hester et al. 1988). Conse-
quently, we are at the point that Meltzer
(1989c) reached: knowing that territorial
expansion and exchange both existed but
being unable to identify the individual
effects.

Table 2.11). These data indicate that
nonlocal raw materials are used more of-
ten in the Early Paleoindian period than

during the Late Paleoindian occupations.
Projectile points, unifaces, and bifaces are
consistently made of nonlocal materials,
but this selectivity declined through time.
Projectile points are made of nonlocal raw
materials more often than are unifaces or

bifaces. The selection of high-quality
nonlocal raw materials for projectile
points is also common at the Lake Theo,
Rex Rodgers, and Plainview sites (see
Tables 2.12 –2.14).

Engraved Stones

Engraved stones are found in Paleo-
indian contexts at the Gault site and the
Bone Bed component at Wilson-Leonard
(M. Collins 1998a; Collins et al. 1991,
1992; Hester et al. 1992). The engraved
stones from Gault (Fig. 2.54) may be as-
sociated with a Clovis component, but
the engraved stone from Wilson-Leonard
(see Fig. 2.15) is associated with the
Plainview component.

One engraved stone at Gault has a
rectangular pattern, but the other has
been characterized as depicting plants
(Hester et al. 1992, 5). Other engraved
stones have been recovered from the Fol-
som component at Blackwater Draw ( J.
Hester et al. 1972). Recently, a painted
bison skull was excavated at the Folsom
Cooper site in western Oklahoma (Be-
ment 1999). This painted skull, along
with the engraved stones from Paleo-
indian contexts in Texas, suggests that a
symbolic system that involved decorating
stones and skull painting was present in
the Early Paleoindian period in the South-
ern Plains. It seems reasonable to suggest
that these symbolic items were part of a
religious belief system, but more discover-

ies and better interpretations are needed
to further understand how this system
may have been organized.

Transitions to the Archaic

The transformations that led from the

Paleoindian to the Archaic societies are
poorly understood. Early Paleoindian
groups existed during a period when the
climate and environment, and thus the
available food resources, were markedly
different from those available to Late
Paleoindian and Archaic groups in the
Holocene period. Even within the Early
Paleoindian period, as the record of Pleis-
tocene fauna extinctions demonstrates
(Martin and Klein 1984), these societies
had to adapt to a dynamic, evolving
environment.

It is clear that the subsistence shift
from the exploitation of extinct mega-
fauna that typiﬁes Paleoindian societies
to one based on Holocene faunas marks
the most visible transformation. How-
ever, it is not a transformation that re-
ﬂects human choice as much as it is a
response to environmentally determined
availability. Evidence from the Golon-

drina component at Baker Cave, the An-
gostura component at the Richard Beene
site, and the unknown component at
Berger’s Bluff suggest that the move to-
ward more intensive exploitation and
processing of small food items in bulk
occurred at least by the Late Paleoindian
period and perhaps even earlier. There is
widespread evidence for one distinction
between the Late Pleistocene occupants
and their Early Holocene counterparts,
and that is the greater use of nonlocal raw
materials and, by inference, larger territo-
ries during the Pleistocene. With the
publication of the Wilson component at
Wilson-Leonard, the simple model of
lanceolate projectile point Paleoindian
tool-making traditions and stemmed pro-
jectile point Archaic tool-making tradi-
tions breaks down, at least in terms of
simple period deﬁnitions. Clearly, all the
societies that have been discussed above
represent small-scale egalitarian groups,
but so do the Early Archaic groups that
followed. Obviously, the groups that have
been included in the Early Paleoindian
period (e.g., Clovis, Folsom, and Plain-
view) can easily be considered as Paleo-
indian, but it is the groups listed as Late
Paleoindian that provide the more serious
problem. In strict behavioral terms, these
groups could just as easily be considered
Archaic. This issue will be debated for
years to come.

Archeology in Central Texas

Michael B. Collins

This chapter reviews the archeological
record of Native Americans in the cen-
tral Texas archeological region and con-
siders selected aspects of the nature of
the evidence and how archeologists have
studied that evidence. Previous reviews
have covered these same topics compre-
hensively (see D. Suhm 1960; D. Suhm
et al. 1954) or selectively (e.g., Black
1989b; M. Collins 1995; Creel 1991a;
G. Ellis 1994; M. Howard 1991; L. John-
son 1967; L. Johnson and Goode 1994;
Lintz 1993; W. McKinney 1981; Prewitt
1981, 1985; Weir 1976). “An Introduc-
tory Handbook of Texas Archeology”
by Suhm et al. (1954) established a for-
mal structure of archeological inquiry
for the entire state, and the diverse
data gathered over the ﬁrst half of the
twentieth century were organized and
synthesized.

Although successive metamorphoses
have rendered the particulars of the 1954
handbook virtually unrecognizable in
current practice, each revision was built
on what had gone before, so that much of
what we know today rests on sturdy foun-
dations laid a half century prior to this
writing. Typologies of ceramics and pro-
jectile points published in the handbook
have remained more intact than the other
cultural constructs. In his introduction to
the handbook, Alex D. Krieger (D. Suhm
et al. 1954, 2 –10) also established a num-
ber of the tenets of typology that continue

to underlie some artifact classiﬁcations in
the state.

The review published by Dee Ann
Suhm in 1960 is the ﬁrst metamorphosis,
beginning by offering a smaller and less
rigidly bounded delineation of “central
Texas” (D. Suhm 1960, ﬁg. 1). Among
the lasting contributions of the review are
good visual (D. Suhm 1960, ﬁgs. 2 and
3) and descriptive (D. Suhm 1960, 89 –
103) images of the nature of the central
Texas archeological data base, particularly
its key sites. Historic Indian groups in
central Texas received greater treatment,
and Suhm’s review also reﬂects the be-
ginnings of the preoccupation with pre-
historic chronology building that over-
whelmed the research effort over the next
twenty-ﬁve years and dominated subse-
quent reviews and syntheses. At the time
Suhm actually wrote her review (in 1958),
only one radiocarbon date was available
for a central Texas site (D. Suhm 1960,
88), and analyses of stratiﬁed site excava-
tions were too few to use as a basis for
establishing a chronology.

Since 1960, the several reviews that
have been written focused on topical,
temporal, or theoretical issues of central
Texas archeology. Some of these have
been more inﬂuential than others, but as
this chapter will show, none has ade-
quately considered the nature of the re-
gion’s archeological record. The vast data
base that now exists for central Texas can-

101

not be adequately synthesized and pre-
sented in the space available. This essay
attempts instead to

• critique aspects of the practice of

archeology in central Texas,

• offer a brief summation of what we

currently know, and

• consider some ways by which we might

know signiﬁcantly more (and have greater
conﬁdence in that knowledge) by the time
the next review is written.

It is necessary to critique the manner
of our work because archeology rarely an-
swers questions that have not been asked
and because the questions asked and the
ways they are addressed in any archeolog-
ical paradigm largely dictate the nature of
the substantive ﬁndings. Over most of
the second half of the twentieth century,
archeological efforts in central Texas have
excessively emphasized questions of chro-
nology, have failed to identify and sustain
a focus on but a few other issues of sub-
stance, and have not yielded adequate ex-
planations for the nature of the archeo-
logical record.

Inexplicably, the preoccupation with
chronology prevailed without the devel-
opment of a very effective methodology
for its pursuit. Speciﬁcally, although the
sondage technique was adopted, the great-
est effort has been expended on precisely
the kinds of sites with the least potential

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

03-A2946  4/13/04  11:54 AM  Page 102

for yielding good chronological infor-
mation, while sites having that potential
languished with comparatively little atten-
tion. There have been many data generated
but not much synthesis of those data.

It is encouraging to note that during
the 1990s, four trends emerged that lead
me to believe that the prospect is good
for signiﬁcantly improved research in the
archeology of the region (see G. Ellis
1994). First, we have begun to better rec-
ognize the nature of the archeological
record and how it was formed, as well as
the greater need for data quality over data
quantity. Second, preoccupation with
chronological issues has begun to give
way to a sustained concern with several
questions of human adaptation. Third,
research now reﬂects an awareness of
great data potential that had long been
overlooked, and the relevance of data to
the questions asked is being scrutinized.
Finally, archeologists working in central
Texas are noticeably less provincial than
has long been the case (Perttula 1995c).
Thus, “The future of archaeological re-
search in the Edwards Plateau and adja-
cent areas will be considerably less gloomy
if the region can get the attention it de-
serves, and if its synthesis is addressed to
a national or international audience that
will be critical of any local misadven-
tures” (L. Johnson 1991, 21–22).

Do not take what has just been said to

mean that I do not consider chronology
to be the backbone of archeological in-
quiry. Archeology is a historical science,
and constantly improving chronological
control of the past must remain a primary
objective, but only as the framework for or-
dering more substantive inquiries and ﬁnd-
ings. In this vein, much has been said
about the validity and meaning of various
temporal frameworks offered for central
Texas prehistory. In spite of the use of
terms such as phase, and the discussion of
phases in ways suggesting they have eth-
nic meaning, the foremost purpose of
such constructs has been temporal order-
ing of archeological material culture.
These constructs are based largely on
morphological (supposedly stylistic)
trends in artifact forms and, as such, are
archeological style periods, not unlike style
periods (e.g., Victorian, Greek Revival, or
Tudor) used by architects. Eileen Johnson
(1987c, 1991) has suggested that some of
our archeological style periods be called

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

102 / PR AIRIES AND PLAINS

patterns, and I (M. Collins et al. 1990)
have proposed the label intervals. Either
of these is better suited than phase, to
which we both object, but I continue to
prefer interval, ﬁrst because it emphasizes
the main thrust—time—and, second,
because pattern implies that we know
more about the material cultural compo-
sition of some of the time slices than I be-
lieve we do. Whatever we call the seg-
ments of our temporal framework, their
function is to order cultural change,
which is the essential basis for under-
standing cultural processes.

Central Texas as an
Archeological Area

Culture areas (Kroeber 1939) and
their archeological counterparts (e.g., as
used in G. Willey 1966) have long served
to focus attention on regions of shared
cultural traits. At any single moment in
time, culture area boundaries often can be
drawn relatively easily. Some boundaries
persist for centuries or millennia, but oth-
ers shift and blur over time. The longer
the time period under consideration, the

more arbitrary boundaries become. Much
of North America might be considered a
single culture area during Clovis times,
but by a.d. 1000 scores of areas would be
needed, with each embracing the same
degree of material culture sameness seen
in all of Clovisdom.

Any delineation of the central Texas

archeological area is highly arbitrary.
Conversely, to draw boundaries based on
careful considerations of material cultural
sameness would result in a sequence of
perhaps a dozen central Texas areas of
quite different sizes and shapes—an un-
manageable array for the purposes of this
essay. So, for the present discussion, Pre-
witt’s delineation (1981, 71, ﬁg. 2) of the
central Texas archeological area (Fig. 3.1)
has been used as a descriptive framework,
but its boundaries have not been adhered
to rigidly as regards certain archeological
and geological data that inform on key is-
sues in the local record. Also, this delin-
eation is selected with the proviso that,
like any such arbitrary construct, it is
more satisfactory for some parts of the pre-
historic record than for others.

The elements (artifacts and features)
that make up or accompany camp sites
sometimes occur apart from camps.
These include caches, isolated artifacts,
burials, bedrock mortars, and rock art
(see Fig. 3.3d), all of which are known to

(1986), Ian Hodder (1978), David Clarke
(1977), James Ebert (1992), and others
have noted in general, and G. Lain Ellis
(1994, 54 –56) has discussed speciﬁcally
for the central Texas culture area (see also
L. W. Ellis et al. 1995), our spatial con-
cepts can seriously impair our efforts to
interpret past human adaptations. In the
past eleven thousand years, there proba-
bly has never been any cultural group
whose key resources, geographic range, or
political sphere conformed even approxi-
mately to what archeologists designate as
“central Texas.” The concerns raised by
these writers refer primarily to investigat-
ing the prehistory of central Texas; it is
still convenient to use the cultural area
rubric when describing its archeological
record.

The central Texas archeological area is
roughly 84,300 km2, or 12 percent of the
area of the state. As of January, 1995, re-
corded archeological sites for central Texas
numbered 11,355, which could be as low
as 10 to 20 percent of the actual number,
judging from site densities in a few thor-
oughly surveyed areas. Documented sites
are in open areas on various topographic
features, along blufﬂines, in rockshelters,
and in caves; site characteristics differ
greatly, but they afford clues as to the
function or functions of any given site, or
to a component within a site (Table 3.1).
In central Texas, the most common
kind of site recognized is an accumulation
of debris (burned rock, stone chipping
residue, pottery sherds) and diverse utili-
tarian objects (grinding stones, hammer-
stones, unifaces, and bifaces), sometimes
in great quantities. Although various
more speciﬁc interpretations (“base
camps,” “extractive sites,” and so forth)
have been offered, it is probably safest to
say that the vast majority of these repre-
sent the residue from one or more periods
of habitation; in simpliﬁed terms, these
are camp sites where people stayed for a
time, regardless of their more speciﬁc pur-
poses for being at that location. Camps
are found in all settings (see Table 3.1 and
Fig. 3.2): in the open, along bluffs, in
rockshelters, and even a few in caves such
as Scorpion and Halls (Table 3.2). Fea-
tures found at camps include just about
all kinds: hearths (Fig. 3.2a), knapping
areas, graves, caches, pits, houses, and
many others. Some of the more conspicu-
ous and, therefore, most commonly noted

Cemeteries, in and away from camps, are
known in the prehistoric record of central
Texas and have been found in rockshelters
(Watt 1936), open localities (Loeve-Fox,
Frisch Auf!), and in vertical shaft caves
(Hitzfelder, Mason Burial Cave).

Few animal kill sites have been docu-
mented in central Texas. The Late Pre-
historic bison skeleton (Feature 66) at
Loeve-Fox is one possible example (Pre-
witt 1982, 73 –79). Another is inferred
from fossilized bison bones and Folsom
points dislodged by treasure hunters from
the ﬂoor of Kincaid Rockshelter, where it

seems a bison died after it was wounded
but was not retrieved by Folsom hunters
(M. Collins 1990b).

Chert has been the most important
kind of toolstone throughout the pre-
history of central Texas, and the area is
rich in the quantity and quality of this raw
material (Banks 1990). This wealth is re-
ﬂected in numerous sites where chert was
acquired (quarries), acquired and knapped
(quarry/workshops [see Fig. 3.2d]), or
just knapped (lithic scatters).

Each of these kinds of sites has its own

characteristic parameters. The diverse

kinds of sites are not equally visible to
the archeologist; their interpretive poten-
tial varies greatly; they were never equally
numerous; and they have survived the
vagaries of nature at different rates. Ef-
forts to interpret and compare patterns
of land use over time, or to estimate such
things as relative population sizes, are
heavily burdened with these sampling
issues.

As a natural area, central Texas is di-
verse. Its single most signiﬁcant feature is
a prominent fault scarp, the Balcones Es-
carpment, that arcs from northeast to

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

03-A2946  4/13/04  11:54 AM  Page 105

ARCHEOLOGY IN CENTR AL TEXAS / 105

southwest around the center of central
Texas and breaks the area into two con-
trasting subareas (Fig. 3.4a). The larger
subarea is north and west of the scarp, on
its upside. Most of this is dissected pla-
teau land of resistant limestone and thin
upland soils, but deeply eroded crystalline
rocks—the Central Texas Mineral Re-
gion—are present as well. The prevailing
vegetation is oak and juniper savanna. Of
roughly half the size of the larger subarea
is the smaller subarea, south and east of
the scarp, on its downside. This is part
of the coastal plain, a region of relatively
soft bedrock and deep soils. Most of this
subarea is prairie with deep clayey soils,
but a narrow strip along its eastern mar-
gin is post oak forest standing on deep
sandy soils.

Along the escarpment lies a great eco-
tone (see Fig. 3.4a) where natural condi-
tions are transitional between the plateau
to the west and north and the prairies to
the east and south. More importantly, it
is beneﬁcial for humans to occupy an
ecotone whence they can readily access
contrasting resources in the adjacent
biomes and capitalize on the resource
diversity of the transitional zone.

Annual precipitation decreases from
east to west across central Texas from
near 100 cm to 55 cm. The primary
water resources for pre-industrial peoples
are streams and springs. Two river sys-
tems, the Brazos and the Colorado, drain
approximately 75 percent of the central
Texas area (see Fig. 3.4b); the remaining
25 percent is roughly equally divided into
the catchments of the Nueces, San Anto-
nio, and Guadalupe Rivers (see Fig. 3.4b).
Generally, drainage is toward the south-
east. Of the 281 springs documented
for Texas, 139 (49 percent) are in the
area, including both of the state’s very
large springs (!100 cubic feet per sec-
ond), and 12 of the state’s 17 large (10 to
100 cubic feet per second) springs (Brune
1975).

Change, as it is everywhere, is and al-
ways has been unrelenting across the land
of central Texas. Wind, water, and gravity
move earth material from place to place;
lakes, streams, and springs ﬂourish and
fail; caves and rockshelters form, enlarge,
degrade, and collapse. The delicate bal-
ances between soils, climates, plants, and
animals are ceaselessly being adjusted.
Terra ﬁrma is but an illusion.

Landscape Evolution from
Earthquakes to Earthworms

Foremost among deﬁciencies in the
methodology by which most of the cen-
tral Texas archeological record has been
built is an inadequate recognition of the
dynamic nature of the physical environ-
ment. Landscape evolution has profound
implications for archeological inquiry.
Issues of long-term changes in climate
(Bryant 1977; Bryant and Shafer 1977;
Bryant and Holloway 1985) and biotic
communities (e.g., Dillehay 1974) have
received considerable attention from
archeologists, but these issues are like
words without music when played against
a static terrain. A few examples will illus-
trate the importance of integrating arche-
ological inquiry with an understanding of
landscape change—whether one is study-
ing a region or a single sit

Most archeological surveys, until re-
cent years, were conducted without the
explicit objective of discovering buried
sites (e.g., Shafer et al. 1964). Even
though awareness of the need for subsur-
face reconnaissance has increased (e.g.,
J. W. Saunders et al. 1992), much of our
archeological data base was generated
without this awareness and is signiﬁcantly
biased as a result. Corollary to discovering
buried sites is the recognition that in some
areas landscape change has been sufﬁcient
to obliterate sites. The important point
here is that geologic and pedogenic pro-
cesses have nonrandomly altered, buried,
and destroyed sites (e.g., Abbott 1995).
Examples from different areas of central
Texas are instructive.

Fluvial Systems

Simpliﬁed depictions of site distribu-
tions from archeological surveys in three
reservoirs along the Colorado River clearly
illustrate one aspect of this bias. In two of
the three project areas (Figs. 3.5 and 3.6),
virtually no sites were recorded on the
inside of bends in the river ( Jackson
and Woolsey 1938; Shafer 1967). In the
third area (Fig. 3.7), only a few sites,
“ephemeral and not worthy of excava-
tion” (M. Collins 1995, 368) were noted
on the inside of bends (Texas Archeologi-
cal Research Laboratory [TARL] ﬁles).
Are we to infer that people almost never
chose to live on the inside of river bends?
No, I suggest we are to infer instead that
the surveys failed to discover sites buried

03-A2946  4/13/04  11:54 AM  Page 107

ARCHEOLOGY IN CENTR AL TEXAS / 107

upper reaches of small streams (Blum and
Valastro 1989; M. Collins et al. 1990).
S. Alan Skinner (1974) found larger sites
typically occurring along the main trunk
of the Guadalupe River, with small sites
being more characteristic of the tributar-
ies. He interpreted this situation to reﬂect
an Archaic settlement pattern with base
camps on the large river linked to extrac-
tive sites in the smaller valleys. However,
this conclusion cannot be valid because
the archeological record formed differ-
ently along the main trunk and its tribu-
taries. Exposed Early Archaic sites are
extremely infrequent in the main Guada-
lupe valley, probably because most of
them are deeply buried in Late Holocene
alluvium, whereas in the upper reaches of
tributaries, where little deposition has oc-
curred since the Early Holocene, compo-
nents dating throughout the Archaic are
present, often mixed together in multi-
component sites on long-stable surfaces
(M. Collins et al. 1990, 13 –15).

Finally, recent mapping and dating of
allostratigraphic units in the valley of the
Colorado River downstream from the
Balcones Escarpment (Blum 1992) has
shown that major changes have taken
place in a much shorter time frame than
previously inferred (e.g., Baker and Pen-
teado-Orellana 1978).1 During the cul-
turally relevant past (ca. 12,000 b.p. to
the present), four periods of Colorado
River valley geomorphic history can be
recognized, based on Blum’s ﬁndings
(1992), as relevant to the formation of
the archeological record in the eastern
part of central Texas.

At approximately twelve thousand
years ago, the river had downcut in its
older valley ﬁll and was cutting into
bedrock. High surfaces of the older ﬁll
(the Eagle Lake Alloformation that had
built up during the period between
18,000 and 15,000 b.p.) were exposed as
terraces along the river as possible locali-
ties for any very early sites to form. Sig-
niﬁcant portions of this landform were
subsequently cut away, but scores of
square kilometers are still present in the
central Texas stretch of the lower Colo-
rado River valley. From then until about
thirty-ﬁve hundred years ago, the valley
ﬂoor aggraded, forming a unit mapped as
Member 1 of the Columbus Bend Allo-
formation. This unit dates from about
eleven thousand to thirty-three hundred
years ago and often exceeds 10 m in
