OCCUPATION OF CENTR AL AND LOWER TEXAS C OAST / 179

such as shell. Several dates are reported
by Gail L. Bailey and C. Britt Bousman
(1990) from sites along a major west-to-
east trending drainage ditch in Hidalgo
and Willacy Counties. At 41HG128,
chert ﬂakes were recovered in possible
association with Late Prehistoric char-
coal ranging in age from 480 to 120 b.p.
A human burial at 41WY113 produced
a date of 1088 b.p. on bone collagen,
and most of the artifacts at the site ap-
parently date to after 1260 b.p. (Bousman
et al. 1990, 138 –39). Collins, Hall, and
Bousman (1989a) reported much older
dates of 3622 b.p. and 3215 b.p. from
41HG118 near the inland margin of the
greater delta area; assays were run on the
organic fraction of Holocene cumulic
soils that were believed to be contempo-
raneous with nondiagnostic cultural ma-
terials. These researchers point out the
potential of dates derived from soils in
an area nearly devoid of other datable
materials. Finally, testing at the Horse
Island site (41CF29) on the lower Laguna
Madre mainland shoreline resulted in the
recovery of a human burial that produced
a 1-sigma calibrated age range of 1352 –
1261 b.p. on human bone (Eling et al.
1993).

The poor understanding of areal chro-
nology is matched by a general lack of in-
sight into synchronic patterns of prehis-
toric resource use and settlement patterns.
Although various researchers have noted
that sites are situated in different topo-
graphical settings and environmental
zones (Bousman et al. 1990; Mallouf et al.
1977; Prewitt 1974a), the relatively small
number of excavations and only sparse
data on subsistence and seasonality pro-
vide little empirical basis for inferences
concerning intraregional variations in sub-
sistence activities at different sites within
different ecological zones. It seems clear
from the available ethnohistorical data
that the native peoples of the delta area
subsisted by hunting, plant gathering, and
ﬁshing (Salinas 1990), and there is noth-
ing in the known archeological record to
suggest otherwise. Thus, it can be assumed
that prehistoric groups were more or less
mobile, establishing temporary/seasonal
camps with proximity to economically
useful resources.

Steve A. Tomka and Britt Bousman
(1990) identiﬁed several resource zones
within the area (see Fig. 5.25) and ranked

them according to biotic productivity.
These different zones are the Rio Grande
ﬂoodplain and delta, the coast, the low-
land plain, the upland plain, and the sand
sheet. Since these zones are based primar-
ily on assumed productivity, they differ in
some ways from earlier sets of environ-
mental zones based largely on geomor-
phic criteria (Day et al. 1981; G. Hall
et al. 1987; Mallouf et al. 1977).

Tomka (1990) has suggested that dif-

ferent resource zones would have seen
variable intensity of occupation according
to the spatial concentration and pre-
dictability of biotic resources. He presents
three alternative models of prehistoric
land use, based on assumptions that (a)
hunter-gatherers in the area were more or
less highly mobile in their settlement and
subsistence patterns and (b) resource
zones would have been used according to
the optimal availability of highly ranked
food resources. Tomka further suggested
that mobility would have operated within
one of three hypothetical patterns of
group territoriality, as follows:

1. Groups moved about within a single
large territory. In this model, intra-areal ter-
ritorial boundaries did not exist; people
moved throughout the Rio Grande deltaic
plain with free access to any of the several
resource zones.

2. Rio Grande territorial groups. Here,
each of several groups operated within its
own territory. Territories were elongate and
parallel and ran north-south, and each pro-
vided direct access to the Rio Grande ﬂood-
plain along its southern edge. Only the
easternmost territory provided access to
the coast.

3. Coastal territorial groups. Again, there

were several parallel, elongate territories,
but in this case they ran east-west, so that
each provided free access to the coast. Only
the southernmost territory included the
Rio Grande and its wooded ﬂoodplain
and delta.

Tomka and Bousman (1990) at-
tempted to test the three models using
lithic data from sites in three (sand sheet,
upland plain, and lowland plain) of the
ﬁve resource zones. They based their
analyses on twelve lithic artifact catego-
ries, which they postulated would be dif-
ferentially distributed within the region
according to patterns of lithic material

transport that reﬂected movement of
goods and people according to one or an-
other of the territoriality models. The
working assumption was that, since lithic
raw material sources were found only on
the upland plain at the inland margin of
the delta region, the kinds of lithics on
sites in different locales would have to
reﬂect established mobility patterns, since
raw material would have been unavailable
in most places. Each of the twelve lithic
categories was assigned an expected value
for a given resource zone, and its actual
representation at a site was then deter-
mined to be greater or less than the ex-
pected value. Ideally, one of the three ter-
ritorial models would be supported when
the actual values matched those predicted
according to the spatial parameters of the
model.

None of the spatial models was either
clearly conﬁrmed or negated by the lithic
data, however, suggesting that either (a)
none of the territorial models reﬂect the
actual spatial organization of prehistoric
adaptive patterns, or (b) the distribution
of lithic materials is not a reliable indica-
tor of prehistoric patterns of settlement
and biotic resource procurement. It may
be relevant to note that the distributions
of lithic artifacts on Late Prehistoric sites
along the central Texas coast do not con-
form in a patterned way to basic settle-
ment and subsistence patterns as deﬁned
on the basis of independent criteria; the
movement of lithic materials through the
system apparently did not depend on
the mobility patterns involved in the pro-
curement of biotic subsistence resources
(Ricklis and Cox 1993).

Regardless of the utility of lithic analy-
ses for deﬁning patterns of biotic resource
procurement, the environmental zones
deﬁned by Tomka and Bousman may
eventually provide the most useful basis
for elucidating prehistoric subsistence and
settlement patterns. Deﬁning these basic
patterns in the Rio Grande delta area will
depend upon the acquisition of data on
subsistence and seasonality from a num-
ber of sites within each resource zone.

Research ﬁndings at the Horse Island

site (41CF29) on the Laguna Madre
mainland shoreline (Eling et al. 1993)
suggest that analyses of marine ﬁsh oto-
liths can provide crucial information on
the seasonality of ﬁshing on the lower
coast. Eling examined one hundred black

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

05-A2946  4/13/04  12:00 PM  Page 180

drum otoliths from test excavations at the
site and found that most ﬁsh died during
the late fall through spring. Relatively
little ﬁshing seems to have taken place
during the summer/early fall part of the
annual cycle. More data from other sites
in the area will be needed to determine
if this was a recurrent seasonal pattern
along the lower coast. It is interesting that
Early Historic Spanish documents suggest
that native peoples in northern Tamauli-
pas engaged in ﬁshing mainly during the
winter, when inland plant resources were
minimal in terms of seasonal productivity
(Salinas 1990, 117). Additional archeo-
logical seasonality studies may show that
coastal ﬁshing was an important winter
subsistence focus, as it apparently was to
the north along the central Texas coast.
Another point that emerges from
ethnohistorical research is that the Rio
Grande delta was a rich biotic zone that
supported a relatively high human popu-
lation density. Even as late as the middle
of the eighteenth century, after native
populations had generally been reduced
by Old World epidemic diseases, the area
may have been home to as many as ﬁfteen
thousand people (Salinas 1990, 138). It
remains to be determined whether indige-
nous populations were as highly mobile
as assumed by Tomka (1990) or whether
the rich resource zones of the delta proper
and the Rio Grande and its ﬂoodplain
woodlands, along with the productive
ﬁsheries of lower Laguna Madre, sustained
relatively large groups for signiﬁcantly

180 / COASTAL GROUPS

long segments of the annual cycle. Con-
ceivably, populations may have aggregated
seasonally during the cooler months in
these zones and then dispersed into
smaller bands to gather plant foods and
hunt during the summer, as suggested by
the very limited ethnohistorical data.

Sites in Cameron County tend to ex-

hibit higher densities of cultural debris
than sites situated farther from the Rio
Grande delta (M. Collins 1990, personal
communication). It may be that most
professionally investigated sites show low
densities of material and thus suggest rel-
atively short-term occupations by highly
mobile groups only because they are lo-
cated in marginal areas that have fortu-
itously been investigated within the
framework of cultural resource manage-
ment projects (e.g., the various sites re-
ported in inland Willacy and Hidalgo
Counties along artiﬁcial drainage ditches
[see Bousman et al. 1990; M. Collins
et al. 1989a; Day et al. 1981]). Indeed,
Hester (1969b, 163) has suggested that
sizable cemeteries in the southern part
of the region, in proximity to the Rio
Grande, may represent coastal-riverine
occupations by groups that practiced only
limited mobility and buried their dead at
favored locations. Systematic investiga-
tions of sites in more highly productive
resource zones on the lower Texas coast
may then give a signiﬁcantly different pic-
ture of aboriginal adaptive patterns than
is currently available from the archeologi-
cal record of the region.

The Archeology of the Native American
Occupation of Southeast Texas

Robert A. Ricklis

The area of southeast Texas straddling
major environmental ecotones was occu-
pied by nonagricultural native populations
from Paleoindian times through the pe-
riod of early European contact. The cul-
ture history for coastal and inland south-
east Texas is reviewed here, with emphasis
on differences in prehistoric artifact as-
semblages in the context of long-term
environmental change and basic human-
ecological patterns of subsistence, settle-
ment, and demography. Attention is
devoted to recent key ﬁndings that signiﬁ-
cantly augment earlier regional overviews.
Generally, the currently available data sug-
gest that southeast Texas offers an archeo-
logical record of both intra-regional cul-
tural development and linkages with
developments in adjoining regions.

The Area and Scope of Interest

Southeast Texas includes the upper
Texas coast, from the Sabine River south-
westward to the Brazos River delta, as
well as the adjacent inland coastal plain
(Fig. 6.1). This environmentally diverse
area was home to hunting-and-gathering
populations from Paleoindian times up to
and into the Early Historic period of
Euro-American exploration and coloniza-
tion. The region straddles two broad eco-
tones: along a roughly east-west transect,
the vast woodlands of southeastern North
America give way to the more or less
open grassland prairies of the midconti-

nent; from north to south, the Gulf of
Mexico coastal zone presents a mosaic of
landforms, bays, lagoons, and riverine es-
tuaries that have broad salinity gradients
and a mix of low marshy areas that inter-
face with well-drained higher ground and
attendant variations in ﬂora.

The most detailed archeological work

in the area has been done in the coastal
zone, for which cultural chronologies and
models of long-term cultural and demo-
graphic change have been developed
(Ambler 1967, 1970, 1973; Aten 1983;
Patterson 1987, 1991a; Wheat 1953). In-
vestigations in the adjacent interior of
southeast Texas have been less successful
in deﬁning long-term cultural patterns, in
large part because work has been focused
on archeological sites with temporally
mixed deposits and also because investi-
gations have had less continuity in re-
search perspectives and goals. Thus, the
greater part of this chapter focuses on the
coastal zone, for which it is possible to of-
fer a fairly coherent summary of the pre-
historic cultural history.

This regional overview is by necessity
selective, given the quantity of archeolog-
ical data generated in recent decades.
Therefore, the approach here is to sum-
marize available information, with partic-
ular attention given to important ﬁndings
that postdate the detailed overviews of re-
gional research (Guy 1990) and prehis-
tory (Aten 1983; Story 1990) presented
elsewhere.

181

The Environment

The implicit theoretical perspective
here is human-ecological, insofar as cul-
tures are complex adaptive systems in
continuous interaction, via the human
ecosystem, with the temporal dynamics
and spatial variability of their environ-
ment. Southeast Texas is part of the
Western Gulf Coastal Plain (Fenneman
1938). The coastal zone is ﬂat, except for
incised stream channels and low stabilized
dunes, ridges, and swales fringing seaward
barrier island shorelines. Moving inland,
topography becomes slightly rolling, al-
though local relief is never great.

Except for localized Holocene eolian
and alluvial deposits, the surface geology
of the ﬂat coastal zone consists of broad
ﬂuvial deltaic sandy and silty clays of the
Pleistocene Beaumont Formation. The
ﬂat topography is broken only by local-
ized dune and ridge-and-swale formations
on barrier islands and by incised stream
valleys containing Holocene alluvium
and terminal Pleistocene silty clay alluvial
Deweyville terraces (Aten 1966; W. Fisher
et al. 1972). Moving inland, stream val-
leys are partly ﬁlled with Holocene allu-
vium, and numerous small natural sand
mounds occur on ﬂoodplains.

Climate is generally mild, with hot
summer months and cool-to-warm win-
ters. During the winter months, frequent
cold fronts move through the area, push-
ing temperatures to near or below freez-

Fig. 6.1. Map of southeast Texas indicating major rivers and coastal bays and broad zones of
vegetation: 1, longleaf pine and mixed pine–hardwood forests; 2, oak savannas and grasslands;
3, coastal upland prairie; 4, coastal marsh–prairie zone (simpliﬁed from Diamond et al. 1987).

ing. There is a signiﬁcant moisture gradi-
ent from east to west, so that the eastern
part of the area experiences an average
annual precipitation of ﬁfty-four inches,
while the western sector averages about
forty inches (Carr 1967).

Several major vegetation zones can
be identiﬁed in the region (see Fig. 6.1).
Along the coast, marsh plant communi-
ties occupy low-lying, inundated, or
poorly drained areas, while higher and
better-drained ground generally supports
shortgrasses. In river delta areas at the
mouths of major streams such as the
Brazos, San Jacinto, and Trinity Rivers,
brackish marshes interdigitate with water-
tolerant arboreal vegetation (e.g., cypress)
and in better-drained areas, with mixed
hardwood forests. On coastal uplands be-
tween streams and low-lying marshes are
extensive tallgrass coastal prairies. Farther
inland, the western part of the area is
characterized by upland oak savannas and
prairies on slightly rolling terrain. To the

east, the interior supports more or less
dense longleaf pine forest, along the west-
ern margin of the extensive southern U.S.
pine woodlands (Diamond et al. 1987).

The Texas coast is a low-relief coastline
marked by a series of shallow-water estu-
arine embayments. Like such areas else-
where, these estuaries are characterized by
high primary productivity (Odum 1971;
Whittaker 1975) that provided prehistoric
peoples with abundant and predictable
aquatic resources (see, e.g., Bernstein
1993; Perlman 1980; Yesner 1980). On
the upper Texas coast, major protected
bay/lagoon systems are Sabine Lake and
the Galveston Bay system with extensive
back-barrier lagoons and shallow, low-
salinity secondary bays. The open Gulf is
connected to the estuaries by a few nar-
row tidal passes, near which bay/lagoon
waters tend to have moderate-to-high
salinities. Toward river-inﬂuenced areas
with the bays, salinities are lower, so that
the estuaries are characterized by variable

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

salinities and corresponding changes in
ﬂoral and faunal biota according to the
salinity preferences of species.

A number of economically important

marine ﬁshes inhabit the estuaries, in-
cluding black drum, redﬁsh (or red drum),
seatrout, and sheepshead (Hoese and
Moore 1977; Shew et al. 1981). These
ﬁsh are tolerant of a wide range in salinity,
and their bones and otoliths have been
identiﬁed in archeological contexts from
the barrier islands inland to brackish wa-
ter deltaic areas. Also ranging throughout
the estuaries are gar ﬁsh, the prehistoric
exploitation of which is indicated by bones
and scales at shoreline sites throughout
the area.

The wooded ﬂoodplains from stream
mouths and farther inland are home to
various economically useful animals,
most notably white-tailed deer, as well as
various smaller mammals and reptiles.
Herds of antelope and bison roamed the
inland prairies in the western part of
southeast Texas in Late Prehistoric and
Early Historic times.

Patterns of
Paleoenvironmental Change

Recent research in southeast Texas and
nearby areas has highlighted two kinds of
fundamental, long-term environmental
changes, both of which probably have
signiﬁcant implications for understanding
human adaptations within the region.
Relevant to both inland and coastal areas
are major ﬂuctuations in climate. Impor-
tant for elucidating long-term patterns of
coastal settlement and estuarine resource
use is the evolution of the coastline dur-
ing the Holocene and concomitant shifts
in biotic productivity.

A Brief Overview of
Long-Term Climate Change

Although there is a dearth of informa-
tion from southeast Texas per se, studies
in neighboring areas suggest broad tem-
poral trends in climate. Since the south-
east Texas area straddles the transition
from moist eastern woodlands to the
drier prairies to the west, major past ﬂuc-
tuations in climate may have signiﬁcantly
affected the distributions of ﬂoral and
faunal resources within the region.

Extensive studies of fossil pollen from
the eastern United States indicate that in
terminal Pleistocene times, ca. 18,000 –

06-A2946  4/13/04  12:02 PM  Page 183

OCCUPATION OF SOUTHEAST TEXAS / 183

10,000 years b.p., generally moister and
cooler conditions than those of the pres-
ent prevailed in south-central North
America. Consequently, the eastern wood-
lands extended farther west than today,
and all of the southeastern part of present
Texas was within a broad belt of mixed
oak–hickory–southern pine forest. In-
creasing temperatures and aridity charac-
terized the Hypsithermal Interval of the
Middle Holocene, ca. 8000 – 4000 b.p.,
and open grasslands came to characterize
the central plains, with oak savannas
along the transition zone with the eastern
woodlands (Delcourt and Delcourt
1981).

Pollen data from east-central Texas
bog sites are in agreement with this gen-
eralized model and provide some infor-
mation on climate changes during the
later part of the Holocene. Michael B.
Collins and C. Britt Bousman (with Pert-
tula 1993) have synthesized pollen data
from Boriak and South Soefje bogs (from
Bryant 1969, 1977; Holloway and Bryant
1984; Holloway et al. 1987) to show a
generally high arboreal pollen between
ca. 17,000 and 8000 b.p., followed by a
signiﬁcant reduction in arboreal pollen
from 8000 to 5000/4000 b.p. and an in-
crease after ca. 4000 b.p. They interpret
these data to indicate a gradual shift to
drier climate during the Middle Holo-
cene and a return to relatively mesic con-
ditions in the Late Holocene. They also
cite stable isotope data from sediment
samples in the Jewett Mine area of east
Texas as generally supporting their in-
terpretation of the pollen data (M. Col-
lins and Bousman with Perttula 1993,
59 – 64).

From farther west in the central Texas

area, a variety of indicators tend to sup-
port the general model offered by M. Col-
lins and Bousman (1993). At Hall’s Cave
on the Edwards Plateau, faunal data, par-
ticularly the proportional changes be-
tween the least shrew and the desert
shrew, suggest a trend toward drier cli-
mate after ca. 8000 b.p., with a peak in
aridity around 5000 – 4000 b.p. and then
more mesic conditions by ca. 3000 b.p.
(see also M. Collins, chapter 3, this vol-
ume). Also for central Texas, LeRoy John-
son (1995) suggests on the basis of allu-
vial depositional sequences that the
climate was relatively dry between ca.
6000 and 3000 b.p.

It has yet to be determined to what ex-

tent these changes affected the relatively
moist region of most of southeast Texas.
However, recent ﬁndings at the Eagle’s
Ridge site (41CH252) in the Trinity
River delta area suggest a drier-than-
modern climate during the Middle Holo-
cene. At the base of a Late Holocene cu-
mulic soil of largely eolian origin Lee
Nordt and colleagues (1998) found a
weathered and eroded surface of a Late
Pleistocene Deweyville terrace, suggesting
reduced vegetation cover and presumably
drier conditions prior to a return to more
mesic conditions with increased ground
cover and a Late Holocene depositional
regime (Ricklis 1998a).

Holocene Sea Level Rise and the
Evolution of the Coastal Environment

During the Late Pleistocene, when sea
level was some one hundred meters below
its present position, southeast-ﬂowing
streams along the Texas coastal plain
downcut to create a series of subparallel
incised valleys. As global temperatures in-
creased after ca. 18,000 b.p., worldwide
glacial melting resulted in rapid sea level
rise. By ca. 9000 b.p. the coastal valleys
were inundated by marine waters to
form the precursors of the modern bays
(L. Brown et al. 1976; Byrne 1975;
W. Fisher et al. 1972). Sea levels then
rose to approximately modern levels by
ca. 3500 –3000 b.p.

Recent global models of glacial melt-

ing and sea level rise suggest a gradual
pattern of the rise and approximation of
modern sea level by ca. 5000 b.p. (Tush-
ingham and Peltier 1991, 1992). How-
ever, detailed sea level curves must be
constructed at the regional scale, since
global models tend to mask interregional
variability (Fairbridge 1992). While eu-
static sea level change had to have been
globally uniform, regional geologic vari-
ables (i.e., hydroisostatic rebound and
coastal subsidence) resulted in differences
in the timing and rate of relative sea level
rise on speciﬁc coastlines.

For the northwest Gulf Coast, various
geologic studies have suggested that Ho-
locene sea level rise was discontinuous,
with episodes of rapid rise alternating
with periods of slow rise, stillstand, or
slight regression (Curray 1960; Frazier
1974; H. Nelson and Bray 1970; Paine
1987, 1991). More recent studies of seis-
mic and core data from Galveston Bay
and adjacent offshore areas conﬁrm the

earlier research, insofar as a stepwise, dis-
continuous rise is broken by intervals of
more or less stable sea level as indicated
by diagnostic bay/lagoon and offshore
sediment facies ( J. Anderson and Thomas
1991; J. Anderson et al. 1992; M. Thomas
and Anderson 1994). These ﬁndings can
be summarized to suggest the following
basic pattern of Holocene sea level change
(from M. Thomas and Anderson 1994):

1. Rapid sea level rise before 10,000 b.p.,

with a subsequent stillstand of uncertain
duration;

2. Resumed rapid rise to another still-

stand or period of slow rise between
ca. 8700 and 7000 b.p.;

3. Rapid rise after 7000 b.p., followed
by a mid-Holocene stillstand beginning by
ca. 6000 b.p.;

4. Before 3500/3000 b.p., rapid sea
level rise followed by attainment of modern
sea level.

For the central Texas coast, Jeffrey G.

Paine (1987, 1991) has posited an ap-
proximately one-meter highstand prior to
ﬁnal sea level stabilization in the Late Ho-
locene, based on radiocarbon-dated clay
dune sediments on the shoreline of Co-
pano Bay. Paine interprets the dated sedi-
ments to be currently at elevations too
high for active clay dune development,
meaning that sea level was somewhat
higher than modern mean sea level when
the dune sediments were deposited
through eolian transport of clay particles
from shoreline mud ﬂats. Since the sedi-
ments date to between ca. 5300 and
2600 b.p., Paine suggests that the postu-
lated highstand occurred sometime dur-
ing that interval, perhaps most likely after
ca. 4400 b.p. If this was the case, it may
be suggested that the highstand correlated
with the period of ﬁnal rapid sea level rise
suggested by the ﬁndings of J. John B.
Anderson and M. A. Thomas, sometime
prior to modern stillstand at ca. 3500/
3000 b.p.

Dated geologic sediments from the
Mitchell Ridge site (41GV66) on Galves-
ton Island provide relevant data that sup-
port the postulates of a mid-Holocene
stillstand followed by a sea level high-
stand prior to attainment of modern sea
level. A geologic cross section at this site
revealed deposits of water-worn estuarine
shell (oyster, scallop, whelk) and sand to
elevations of two to three meters above

Two samples of estuarine shell were ra-

and calibrated), with 1-sigma age ranges
falling between 5990 and 5300 b.p. Since
these shells were of common estuarine
(as opposed to high-salinity marine) spe-
cies, they suggest the existence of a mid-
Holocene estuarine environment with
protective barriers of the kind that would
develop during a period of stable sea level.
The subsequent redeposition of the shells
to form the highest core of Galveston Is-
land suggests a highstand. The shift to an
eolian depositional regime by the Late
Holocene is indicated by the eolian ﬁne
sand soil that caps the island core. The
lower ridge and swales seaward of the is-
land core provided a ready sediment
source for the ﬁne sand soil mantle, and
presumably they represent seaward accre-
tion under conditions of the slightly lower
modern sea level stillstand.

Paleoindian Evidence
in Southeast Texas
(ca. 11,500 – 8000 B.P.)

Archeological excavation of a Paleo-
indian site has yet to be undertaken in
southeast Texas. Numerous Paleoindian
artifacts, particularly projectile points,
have been surface-collected in the region
(see L. Johnson 1989; Story 1990). Al-
though diagnostic points have also been
found in excavated contexts (e.g., Patter-
son 1980, 1995; Wheat 1953), these have
been mixed with materials of later (Ar-
chaic) periods.

The scattered ﬁnds include projectile
points representing both Early and Late
Paleoindian manifestations (see Bousman
et al., chapter 2, this volume). The earlier
ﬂuted point traditions are represented by
Clovis and Folsom points. Clovis speci-
mens, dated across much of North Amer-
ica to ca. 11,500 b.p., tend to occur along
major stream drainages. A number of
Clovis points have been found at the Mc-
Faddin Beach locality (Long 1977); al-

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

though this site is currently on the Gulf
shoreline east of Bolivar Peninsula, dur-
ing terminal Pleistocene times when sea
level was lower than today, it was situated
on a tributary stream drainage. Isolated
Folsom points have been recovered from
excavations at site 41WH19 in Wharton
County (Patterson et al. 1987) and at two
sites in Harris County (Patterson et al.
1987, 1990), while Larry Banks (1992)
reports a specimen from McFaddin Beach.
Later Paleoindian occupation is repre-
sented by ﬁnds of San Patrice and Scotts-
bluff points (L. Johnson 1989; Story
1990), again mostly along major streams.
In the more western part of southeast
Texas, Plainview and Angostura points
have been found (Patterson 1995).

Because no discrete Paleoindian com-
ponents have yet been found or investi-
gated within southeast Texas, little can be
concluded about adaptive patterns except
that they doubtless involved some mix of
hunting and gathering. The fact that most
recovered points are of high-grade lithic
materials that are scarce or absent in
southeast Texas suggests a widespread
movement of peoples and materials.
LeRoy Johnson (1989) has suggested that
deteriorating climatic conditions on the
Great Plains during the Early Holocene
prompted Paleoindian peoples to move
into the margins of the eastern woodlands,
where some degree of interaction and ac-
culturation took place between the new-
comers and resident Paleoindian groups.

The Archaic Stage in
Inland Southeast Texas
(ca. 8000 –1500 B.P.)

The Archaic in Texas is generally

deﬁned by pre- or nonhorticultural adap-
tations and pre-ceramic and pre–bow-
and- arrow hunting technologies (e.g.,
Hester 1980a; Prewitt 1981; D. Suhm
et al. 1954). Numerous Archaic sites have
been found in inland southeast Texas,
mainly along stream courses. Often mixed
with post-Archaic remains, the Archaic
components at these sites are represented
by various types of ﬂaked stone dart points
and other lithic tools.

Dee Ann Story (1990, 222) notes that

although there are some similarities be-
tween the dart point assemblages of south-
east Texas and more northerly part of east
Texas, there are enough differences to
suggest two distinct sequences. She points

06-A2946  4/13/04  12:02 PM  Page 185

OCCUPATION OF SOUTHEAST TEXAS / 185

to the absence in southeast Texas of Early
Archaic types such as Palmer, Johnson,
and side-notched points related to the
Graham Cave and Big Sandy types. Story
(1990) also notes that later central Texas
types such as Pedernales are sometimes
found in southeast Texas and that during
the Late Archaic, Kent and Gary types
predominate, which is not the case in
northeast Texas.

The very general outlines of a dart
point chronology have been worked out
for southeast Texas (Fig. 6.3). Story
(1990, 221–23) suggests that a typo-
logical cluster of expanded-stem types
dominates the Early Archaic (before

ca. 6000 b.p.); included in this group are
early side-notched and early stemmed
forms and corner-notched points of the
Keithville, Neches River, and Trinity
types (see also Ensor 1990). These are
followed by massively barbed points of
the Bell /Calf Creek series, as well as un-
stemmed Tortugas points and stemmed
Wells points. Leland W. Patterson (1995)
suggests that Bell /Calf Creek points are
found mainly within the prairie zone of
the central-to-western part of the region,
which accords with their general distribu-
tion from southern and central Texas
into Oklahoma and beyond (see, e.g.,
M. Collins 1994a, 90 –100).

Fig. 6.3. General dart point sequence of major types in southeast Texas.

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

A variety of Middle Archaic types is
reported from the area, including Yar-
brough, Bulverde, Travis, and, in the
western sector, Pedernales. The predomi-
nant Late Archaic types are Kent and
Gary, with Ensor and Godley points
common in the western reaches of south-
east Texas. It is generally thought that the
Kent form precedes that of the contract-
ing stem Gary, though the two types may
overlap chronologically (Ensor 1990; En-
sor and White 1998; Story 1990).

A general dearth of faunal and macro-
botanical remains at inland Archaic sites
precludes the drawing of inferences about
adaptive patterns beyond the assumption
of some mix of hunting-and-gathering
subsistence practices. A shift to the use of
poorer quality and more local lithic re-
sources in Late Archaic times suggests re-
duced group mobility and more tightly
deﬁned group territories (Story 1990).

Several Middle to Late Archaic ceme-

tery sites have been reported from the
coastal prairies in the western part of
southeast Texas. Most notable are the
large cemeteries at the Ernest Witte site
(41AU36) in the lower Brazos River
drainage, which contained two strati-
graphically distinct cemeteries, designated
Group 1 and Group 2 (G. Hall 1981).
The Group 1 cemetery, containing the
remains of sixty-one individuals, was the
earlier, with two uncalibrated (and per-
haps not entirely reliable) dates of 3270 !
70 b.p. and 4120 ! 100 b.p. on bone
apatite. Most burials were in extended
position, with heads oriented to the
southeast. Few burials contained grave
goods.

The Group 2 cemetery, of Late Ar-
chaic age, was considerably larger, con-
taining the remains of 145 individuals in
extended position with heads commonly
oriented to the northeast (G. Hall 1981).
Chronological control is weak, since only
two radiocarbon dates on human bone
apatite were obtained. The two dates, cor-
rected for 13C /12C, are 2470 ! 130 b.p.
and 1590 ! 80 b.p. These calibrate, fol-
lowing Stuiver and Reimer (1993), to
1-sigma age ranges of 2750 –2350 b.p. and
1550 –1360 b.p. Grant D. Hall (1981, 53)
deemed the later date to best represent the
age of the cemetery, based on the pres-
ence of Fairland and Ensor dart points in
graves. However, the points were not
abundant, and the large number of buri-
als and the fact that some intruded into

06-A2946  4/13/04  12:02 PM  Page 186

others suggest long-term use of the locale,
as noted by Story (1990, 240).

A wide array of grave goods was pres-
ent with the Group 2 interments. Lithics
included dart points, corner-tanged
knives, groundstone “boat stones” and a
gorget, bone (hair?) pins, and conch shell
beads and pendants. The distributions of
offerings according to age and sex suggest
an essentially egalitarian social organiza-
tion, though Hall (1981, 88) suggested
that a couple of burials with relatively
large amounts of goods might represent
high-status individuals.

Although Ernest Witte is the largest-
known Late Archaic cemetery in the area,
other cemeteries with grave goods and of
Late Archaic age have been documented
in the general area. These include the
Crestmont site in Wharton County (Ver-
non 1989), the Albert George site in Fort
Bend County, the Morhiss site and Blue
Bayou sites in Victoria County (G. Hall
1995a, 49 –50; Huebner and Comuzzie
1992), and the Goebel site in Austin
County (G. Hall 1995a, 52 –53).

Clearly, by Late Archaic times ceme-
teries were an integral part of cultural be-
havior along the inland margins of the
coastal prairie zone. Story (1985) has sug-
gested that the establishment of discrete
cemeteries served as expressions of group
territoriality in a systemic response to
regionally growing populations. Hall
(1995b) concurs and hypothesizes that
the ﬂoodplains of regional streams pro-
vided a superabundance of food resources
(e.g., nuts) that contributed to overall
population growth.

The Coastal Archaic
(ca. 5000 –2200 B.P.)

In his seminal work on the upper
Texas coast, Lawrence E. Aten (1983)
noted that intensive shoreline occupation
and resource extraction emerged with the
attainment of modern sea level stillstand
after ca. 4000 b.p. While this theory is
probably generally valid, subsequent ﬁnd-
ings suggest a longer history of coastal re-
source use in the area. Deposits of arche-
ological shell at site 41GV53 near Clear
Lake (a secondary bay connected with Gal-
veston Bay) have yielded mid-Holocene
radiocarbon ages (Hines 1992), and re-
cent ﬁndings at the Eagle’s Ridge site in
the Trinity River delta area have indicated

186 / COASTAL GROUPS

more or less intensive shellﬁsh (Rangia
cuneata, oyster) gathering by 4500 b.p. or
shortly thereafter (Ensor 1998a). Analyses
of rangia shells from cores slightly off-
shore suggest the presence of shell mid-
dens along now-submerged upland
stream margins, pointing to probable oc-
cupation of the Early Holocene coastal
margin (Gagliano 1977; Stright 1986,
1990). Given these ﬁndings, it is likely
that considerable evidence for Early to
Middle Holocene shoreline occupation
now rests under transgressive marine wa-
ters and later Holocene bay, estuarine,
and alluvial sediments.

The best evidence for relatively early
Archaic occupation comes from 41GV53
(Hines 1992) and the Eagle’s Ridge site
(Ensor 1995, 1998a). At 41GV53, four
discrete strata of rangia middens were
identiﬁed (Hines 1992; Howard et al.
1991). The uppermost shell stratum,
Zone B, contained artifacts and radiocar-
bon-dated rangia shells pertaining to the
Late Prehistoric period. The immediately
underlying Zone C was a relatively thick
shell midden radiocarbon dated to the
last millennium b.c. and containing Kent
dart points. The lowest two shell strata,
Zones D and E, yielded respective ages
(corrected for 13C /12C but uncalibrated)
of 3900 –3600 b.p. and 5000 – 4200 b.p.
(Hines 1992, 13 –14).

At Eagle’s Ridge extensive excavations
in a dense stratiﬁed shell midden resulted
in recovery of the most complete Archaic
sequence yet identiﬁed for the upper
Texas coast. Numerous small hearth fea-
tures and a large sample of artifacts rang-
ing in age from the Early Archaic through
the Early Ceramic period were found in
stratigraphic superposition (Ensor and
Ricklis 1998).

The site consists of an elongate, dense

shell midden (mostly Rangia cuneata,
but also some oyster) resting on the mar-
gin of a Deweyville terrace immediately
east of the Charlotte swamp. The site is
moderately large, covering an area of ap-
proximately six thousand square meters.
Testing (Ensor 1995) and subsequent
extensive excavation (Ensor and Ricklis
1998) revealed three major strata. Stra-
tum 1, 25 to 30 cm thick, was a dark
brown, organically enriched silty clay soil
devoid of shell. Abundant evidence of
Early Ceramic period occupation was
found in the lower part of Stratum 1.

Stratum 2 was a fairly thick (50 cm) shell
midden. At the central part of the site,
Stratum 2 was a single shell midden zone
with no discernible breaks. Around the
margins of the site, however, Stratum 2
was clearly separated into upper (Stratum
2-A) and lower (Stratum 2-C) parts, with
a thin (10 cm) intervening zone of shell-
free silty clay soil designated as Stratum
2-B. Stratum 2-C produced abundant
evidence of Middle Archaic occupation,
while Stratum 2-A contained Late Ar-
chaic materials. Although the two sub-
strata could not be discerned at the core
of the site, there was a clear break in the
kinds of artifacts found, indicating that
the Middle and Late Archaic components
were distinct across the entire site. The
underlying Pleistocene Deweyville terrace
clay was designated as Stratum 3. Late
Paleoindian as well as Early and Middle
Archaic materials were found on the sur-
face of Stratum 3, indicating long-term
deposition/accumulation of materials on
a stable or deﬂated surface.

The lower part of the Stratum 2 (and
2-C) shell midden produced a variety of
Middle Archaic dart point types, includ-
ing Yarbrough, Bulverde, Carrollton,
Morhiss, Palmillas, and Travis; Yarbrough
and Bulverde were the most common.
Other lithics include unifacial micro-
liths, small bifacial drills or perforators
(Fig. 6.4), cores, biface fragments, uti-
lized ﬂakes, and debitage (Ensor and
White 1998). In general the ﬂaked lithics
were of high-grade materials of extralocal
origin, most prominently Edwards chert.
Bone preservation was good throughout
Stratum 2, and bone artifacts from the
Middle Archaic zone include projectile
points (including the socketed deer meta-
podial form), awls, a rectangular imple-
ment (a gaming piece?), beads, and mis-
cellaneous pieces of cut or grooved bone
(Ensor 1998b). Shell artifacts include a
barrel-shaped conch columella bead, cut
rangia and gastropod shells, and perfo-
rated oyster and rangia valves (Ensor
1998b).

The upper part of Stratum 2 (includ-
ing 2-A), representing a Late Archaic oc-
cupation, produced a lithic assemblage in
marked contrast to that from the Middle
Archaic component. The preponderant
raw material was a poor-to-fair grade
siliciﬁed wood that probably originated in
stream gravels within the southeast Texas

over that for the earlier Archaic. Aten
(1983) has suggested a signiﬁcantly grow-
ing population by the end of the Archaic,
perhaps in part the result of new and more
efﬁcient extraction technologies such as
ﬁsh weirs (though empirical evidence for
such is lacking from the region). The sta-
bilization of sea level by ca. 3000 b.p. and
the attendant formation of extensive estu-
arine shallows behind emergent Late Ho-
locene barrier islands may have provided
the ecological basis for increased human
carrying capacity and population growth.

Holocene Evolution of the
Coastal Environment and
Human Shoreline Occupation
during the Archaic

Recent research on the central coast of
Texas has suggested that prehistoric occu-
pation of the shoreline zone and intensity
of estuarine resource procurement were
not long-term constants but rather ﬂuctu-
ated in response to ecological changes
linked to patterns of Holocene sea level
rise (Ricklis 1993a, 1995b, 1995d; Rick-
lis and Blum 1997; Ricklis and Cox
1991). Since eustatic sea level rise is a
uniform global phenomenon, it is reason-
able to expect that, within the limits of
local geologic variables, a similar long-
term pattern should also have been mani-
fest on the upper Texas coast.

On the basis of the corrected and cali-
brated radiocarbon ages from forty-seven
stratigraphically discrete shell midden
components on the central coast, three
major periods of shoreline occupation
have been suggested: ca. 7500 – 6800 b.p.,
ca. 5900 – 4200 b.p., and after ca. 3100
b.p. (Ricklis 1993a; Ricklis and Blum
1997; Ricklis and Cox 1991; see also
Ricklis, chapter 5, this volume). These
time intervals are separated by approxi-
mately one-thousand-year breaks in the
chronology of shell midden deposition
(ca. 6800 –5900 b.p. and 4200 –3100
b.p.), suggesting a signiﬁcant reduction
of shoreline occupation. Given that the
great majority of the central coast sites are
on uplands well above the elevation of
physical processes that would obscure or
remove evidence of occupation (e.g., in-
undation, shoreline sedimentation, or
erosion), it is unlikely that the chronolog-
ical hiatuses are the result of differential
preservation or visibility of sites.

area (see Ensor and White 1998, 334 –
36). The Late Archaic dart point assem-
blage (Ensor and White 1998) showed
remarkably little variability, consisting
mostly of specimens of the Kent type
along with a small number of Palmillas
points and, in the top few centimeters, a
few Gary points (possibly associated with
the earliest Ceramic period occupation at
the site). Late Archaic bone artifacts in-
clude awls, points, modiﬁed antler tines,
a bead, a drilled canine tooth, and pieces
of cut or grooved bone. Worked shell
consisted of a discoidal bead, cut rangia
valves, and perforated oyster and rangia
valves (Ensor 1998b).

Analysis of the abundant and well-
preserved faunal remains from Eagle’s
Ridge produced similar results in both
the Middle and Late Archaic samples.
White-tailed deer constituted the highest
percentage (80 percent or more) of the
animal biomass. Fish were second in im-
portance, though representing only about
10 percent of the biomass. Important es-
tuarine species include black drum, red-
ﬁsh, sheepshead, seatrout, mullet, and At-
lantic croaker. Various freshwater species
were also represented. The small remain-
der of the procured biomass was made up
of various other mammals and reptiles.
Unfortunately, these analyses did not ac-
count for shellﬁsh, so it is unclear precisely
what proportion of the meat diet com-
prised rangia and oyster. Judging by the
profusion of shells in Stratum 2, it is likely

that estuarine bivalves contributed signiﬁ-
cantly to the Middle and Late Archaic
diets at the site.

By Late Archaic times, after ca. 3000
b.p., there is abundant evidence for hu-
man occupation and estuarine resource
use on the upper Texas coast, particularly
in the Galveston Bay area. Numerous
rangia shell middens that date at least in
part to this period have been reported
(e.g., Ambler 1967, 1970; Aten 1983;
Aten et al. 1976; Dillehay 1975; Gadus
and Howard 1990; Gilmore 1974; Wein-
stein and Whelan 1987). Nearly all sites
are along the shores of secondary bays
or in the estuarine zones around river
mouths and delta areas. There is observ-
able variation in the size and thickness
of shell midden deposits, suggesting, as
noted by Tom Dillehay (1975), intersite
differences in group size and occupational
intensity. Clearly, estuarine resources
(ﬁsh, shellﬁsh) were signiﬁcant compo-
nents in the prehistoric subsistence econ-
omy, though the presence of terrestrial
mammal and reptile remains at most sites
indicated a mix of exploited resource
zones.

Because sites are considerably more
numerous for the Late Archaic than for
previous periods, a signiﬁcant population
growth has been suggested. Patterson
(1987, 1995) has noted that by Late Ar-
chaic times the number of recorded sites
in the coastal zone, relative to the lengths
of the time intervals involved, increases

Since estuarine resources tend to be
abundant, concentrated, and predictable,
and, especially in the case of shellﬁsh, eas-
ily procured, it is reasonable to assume
that the major breaks in occupation rep-
resent periods during which shoreline
zones were insufﬁciently productive to
sustain relatively intensive human occu-
pation. With this premise in mind, it has
been suggested that the periods of occu-
pation represent times of relatively stable
Holocene sea level, during which ongoing
bay sedimentation created broad estuarine
shallows with high photosynthetic pri-
mary productivity and abundant organic
nutrients from plant detritus generated by
shoreline marshes and shallow-water
grassﬂats (Ricklis 1993a; Ricklis and
Blum 1997; Ricklis and Cox 1991). In
turn, abundant organic detritus and phy-
toplankton provided the basis for a rich
food chain of primary and secondary
consumer populations (e.g., crustaceans,
molluscs, and ﬁsh). Such conditions are
generally recognized as the basis for rich
estuarine resources along shallow-relief
coastlines (see, e.g., Bernstein 1993;
Odum 1971) of the kind that tend to
support relatively high hunter-gatherer
population densities (see, e.g., Perlman
1980; Widmer 1988; Yesner 1980).

By contrast, the apparent hiatuses in
shoreline occupation likely correlate with
times of reduced biotic productivity. In
fact, as discussed earlier, recent geologic
research has suggested periods of unsta-
ble, rapidly rising sea level that approxi-
mate the timing of the hiatus in shoreline
occupation indicated for the central coast;
periods of stillstand are suggested for
ca. 8700 –7000 b.p., 6000 – 4000 b.p.,
and after 3500 b.p.; intervening episodes
of rapid sea level rise are placed after
ca. 7000 b.p. and after ca. 4000 b.p. Be-
cause the episodes of rapid rise correlated
temporally with breaks in shoreline occu-
pation, it can be posited that rapidly ris-
ing sea level negatively affected estuarine
ecosystems through the inundation of
shoreline shallows and the destruction or
signiﬁcant reduction of ecologically criti-
cal shallow-water marshes and grassﬂats.
It has been demonstrated that increased
salinities resulting from marine transgres-
sion have dramatic impacts on marshland
biota (Cooper 1974; Pezeshki et al. 1987),
and that destruction of shoreline shallows
virtually eliminates populations of pri-
mary consumers (such as shrimp) that

form important links in the estuarine
food chain (Mock 1966).

A review of the chronometric data for
shoreline shell midden sites in the Galves-
ton Bay area in fact indicates a temporal
hiatus in the fourth millennium b.p.,
with a resumed shoreline occupation by
ca. 3000 b.p. At 41GV53 (Hines 1993)
and at Eagle’s Ridge (41CH252), well-
dated occupational sequences show clear
breaks prior to 3000 b.p. These breaks are
shown in Fig. 6.5, which depicts the plots
of centroids for the corrected radiocarbon
ages from the two sites. The same hiatus
in the radiocarbon sequence is seen in the
collected radiocarbon data from the entire
Galveston Bay area, as shown in Fig. 6.6.
The great majority of radiocarbon dates

from the Galveston Bay area are derived
from assays on samples of Rangia cuneata
shell, since wood charcoal is generally
scarce in archeological deposits. Because
there is currently no ﬁrm consensus as to
how to adjust/calibrate rangia dates after
they have been corrected for 13C /12C,
Figs. 6.5 and 6.6 show the centroids of
the corrected dates without further ad-
justment. (In cases where published assay
results do not include the 13C /12C correc-
tion, a total of three hundred years has
been added to the uncorrected age, since
this ﬁgure closely approximates the aver-
age correction factor for numerous rangia
samples from various sites in the area [see
Ensor and Ricklis 1998; Gadus and How-
ard 1990; Weinstein 1991].)

Some archeologists in the area have

used a marine calibration for rangia

(Hines 1993; Kibler et al. 1996), while
others have employed a “freshwater” cor-
rection factor to adjust for the assumed
effect of inorganic carbon from dissolved
carbonates (Aten 1983; Ensor 1995),
both of which result in adjustments of
the corrected date toward the present by
two hundred or more years. I (in Ensor
and Ricklis 1998) have suggested that
these adjustments may be inappropriate,
since (a) rangia was gathered from shal-
low estuarine waters that were largely
isolated from marine upwelling of old
organic carbon; (b) the freshwater correc-
tion factor is only assumed and has not
been empirically tested; (c) most “paired”
shell-charcoal samples from the area that
purportedly show divergences between
ages of wood charcoal and ages of shell,
and that are the basis for estimating ma-
rine and freshwater corrections, come
from arbitrary excavation levels or gross
stratigraphic units and thus cannot be
shown to be associated within truly con-
temporaneous depositional contexts, and
(d) true paired samples from discrete con-
texts on the Texas coast (sealed lenses or
thin occupational zones rather than arbi-
trary levels or gross stratigraphic units)
have produced virtually identical ages,
once shell is corrected for 13C /12C (Rick-
lis 1994a, 1995b; Ricklis and Blum
1997). These factors strongly suggest that
an atmospheric calibration may in fact be
more appropriate, since shallow and pro-
tected estuaries, like smaller lakes (Stuiver
et al. 1986), may represent an essentially
atmospheric carbon reservoir.

The Ceramic Period

By deﬁnition, the Archaic period in
southeast Texas ends with the introduc-
tion of ceramics. It is generally accepted
that pottery ﬁrst appeared along the
coast around two thousand years ago
through diffusion of ceramic technology
from Louisiana and/or the Lower Mis-
sissippi Valley (Aten 1983, 1984; Shafer
1975a; Story 1990). The earliest upper
Texas coast pottery thus has a Tchefuncte
cast (see Aten 1983; Phillips 1970; Wein-
stein 1986), with thick vessel walls,
poorly wedged, contorted, and untem-
pered paste, and at least in some cases,
ﬂat bases. In inland southeast Texas, pot-
tery was introduced several centuries
later, probably disseminating from the
coastal zone where sandy-paste wares
of the Goose Creek series (Aten 1983;
D. Suhm and Jelks 1962) had come into
prominence.

While the earliest pottery serves as a
time marker and indicates extraregional
interaction and inﬂuence, and may also
have increased efﬁciency in food process-
ing (Aten 1983), there are currently no
indications of major changes in lifeways
during the Early Ceramic period. The re-
current presence of ceramic components
overlying earlier Archaic ones along bay-
shores and river drainages suggests funda-
mental continuities in settlement and sub-
sistence patterns (see Ambler 1967; Aten
1983; Aten et al. 1976; Ensor 1987, 1995;
Ensor and Carlson 1988; Gadus and
Howard 1990; Hines 1993; R. Moore
1994, 1995; Nash and Rogers 1992;
Weinstein and Whelan 1987; Wheat
1953).

Two perspectives have been articulated
to broadly deﬁne Ceramic period cultures
in southeast Texas. Shafer (1975a) and
Aten (1984) have suggested a general
afﬁliation with the Woodland cultures of
the eastern United States, noting that
pottery not only disseminated from that
direction but also retained various stylis-
tic attributes similar to pre-Mississippian
period ceramics of Louisiana and the
Lower Mississippi Valley. On the other
hand, Story (1990, 256) suggests that
southeast Texas is archeologically distinct,
with a fairly homogeneous ceramic

and Howard 1990; Hines 1993; Weinstein 1991; Weinstein et al. 1989).

Until there is a better understanding
of shell midden site formation processes
that potentially mix noncontemporane-
ous shell and charcoal and until a large
number of clearly paired shell-charcoal
samples are available from the upper
Texas coast, there will be questions about
how to adjust shell dates. Sufﬁce it to say
at this point that, regardless of the kind of
adjustment used, the currently available
data appear to indicate a ﬁve-hundred-
year or more hiatus in shell midden depo-
sition during the fourth millennium b.p.

Judging from the data shown in

Fig. 6.6, the postulated occupational hia-
tus on the upper Texas coast was about
half the duration of that suggested for
the central coast. Localized differences
in estuarine sedimentation rates and the
geometry of estuarine basins may par-
tially account for this, since these factors
bear on the relation between changing sea
level and the extent of high-productivity

shallows. On the other hand, if the cor-
rected shell dates for the upper coast are
calibrated atmospherically, the temporal
hiatus there would fall between ca. 3900
and 3100 b.p., thus more nearly match-
ing that for the central coast. (Given the
timing of ﬂuctuations in atmospheric 14C,
corrected ages falling between 3000 and
2500 b.p. would change little when cali-
brated, while ages older than 3500 b.p.
would increase by several hundred years
or more [Stuiver and Reimer 1993].)
In any case, the currently available
data suggest a considerable time depth for
shoreline occupation and estuarine re-
source use on the upper Texas coast, with
a signiﬁcant break in the fourth millen-
nium b.p. As on the central coast, con-
tinuous occupation began with the estab-
lishment of relatively stable sea level and
essentially modern, high-productivity es-
tuaries by ca. 3000 b.p. At that time there
emerged the ecological conditions that

The Ceramic Period on
the Upper Texas Coast

Aten (1983) has placed the appearance

of pottery in the Galveston Bay area at
ca. a.d. 100, based on radiocarbon-dated
rangia shell from site components of his
Clear Lake period, which he dates from
a.d. 100 to 425. He further suggests that
pottery appears by around 70 b.c. to the
east in the Sabine Lake area (at the mouth
of the Sabine River), based on a single ra-
diocarbon date on rangia shell.

The Clear Lake period is marked by
a mix of pottery types, including Tche-
functe Plain, occasional examples of
Tchefuncte Stamped (rocker stamped);
Mandeville Plain (Fig. 6.8); O’Neal
Plain, var. Conway; and Goose Creek
Plain, var. Anahuac. As mentioned above,
Tchefuncte ware is thick walled and ex-
hibits contorted paste; in the Galveston
Bay area, it lacks temper or signiﬁcant in-
clusions of sand and frequently exhibits
vertical or oblique ridge-and-furrow sur-
face treatment (see Fig. 6.8a, c). Mande-
ville Plain is the same as Tchefuncte Plain,
except that the paste is sandy, probably
due to natural sand inclusions in the clay.
Tchefuncte and Mandeville vessels were
simple jars or deep bowls, sometimes
with ﬂat bases (see Fig. 6.8b), but they
lack the four small feet often found in
Lower Mississippi Valley samples (see
Ellis and Ensor 1998; Phillips 1970,

163). Goose Creek Plain, var. unspeciﬁed,
which Aten places at the end of his Clear
Lake period and which later became the
predominant pottery type, is relatively
thin walled, with well-wedged, homoge-
neous sandy paste. Goose Creek Plain,
var. Anahuac, is an intermediate and
probably transitional type, exhibiting a
somewhat contorted paste and often
thick walls but generally being thinner
with better clay wedging than Mandeville
Plain (Aten 1983; Ellis and Ensor 1998;
Ensor 1995).

Ceramic Period Chronology

Aten (1983) has devised a series of
named periods that last between 225 and
350 years. Aten’s periods are deﬁned on
the basis of (a) changes in pottery types
or in the proportional representation of
types (see Aten’s discussion of typological
seriation [1983, 283]) and/or (b) the in-
troduction or disappearance of a few key
nonceramic artifact forms, such as sock-
eted bone points, arrow or dart points,
and small ﬂaked lithic drills (Table 6.1).

Diachronic Trends during the
Ceramic Period on the Coast

The Early Ceramic Period

As mentioned above, there is consider-

able evidence for continuity in site loca-
tions and basic settlement/subsistence
patterns between the end of the Archaic
and the Early Ceramic periods; sites con-
tinue to consist mostly of rangia middens
along secondary bay margins or riverine
estuaries. The beginning of the period is
thus currently recognizable only on the
basis of changes in certain artifact classes.
Limited data on lithics suggest that the
Kent point of Late Archaic times was su-
perseded by the contracting-stem Gary
type (see, e.g., Aten 1983; Ensor and
White 1998). The introduction of Tche-

deville sherds were most common in the
top few centimeters of the Stratum 2 ran-
gia shell midden, while Goose Creek
Plain, var. Anahuac, along with a few
sherds of Goose Creek Incised and Goose
Creek Plain, var. unspeciﬁed, were clus-
tered at the base of the overlying nonshell
Stratum 1 (Ellis and Ensor 1998; Ensor
1995, 1998a).

Rangia shells at the very top of Stra-

tum 2 at Eagle’s Ridge produced cor-
rected radiocarbon ages of ca. 2000 –
2500 b.p. (Ensor and Ricklis 1998), sug-
gesting that the earliest pottery at the site
may date to this time; however, the pre-
cise age of the samples will depend on how
they are further adjusted/calibrated (see
discussion in Ensor and Ricklis 1998).
Given these ﬁndings, it is possible that the
earliest pottery in the Galveston Bay area
is coeval with the Tchula period ceramics
in Louisiana, dated at ca. 600 b.c.– a.d. 1
(see, e.g., Weinstein 1986), obviating the
need to invoke a major “lag” in the diffu-
sion of ceramics from coastal Louisiana
into southeast Texas (as suggested by
Aten 1983). The base of Stratum 1 at
Eagle’s Ridge is dated by consistent radio-
carbon assay results on deer bone collagen
to ca. 1800 b.p. The relative abundance
in this zone of Goose Creek Plain, var.
Anahuac, along with sherds of Goose
Creek Incised, suggests an evolution of
Goose Creek ware out of Tchefuncte/
Mandeville pottery (Ellis and Ensor 1998;
Ensor 1995), supporting Aten’s postulated
shift in ceramics within the time range of
his Clear Lake period.

By this time, the pottery in the Gal-
veston Bay area exhibits little similarity
to contemporaneous (Marksville) material
in Louisiana. Sandy-paste Goose Creek
Plain predominates, and Goose Creek In-
cised exhibits very simple designs usually
consisting of one to three parallel hori-
zontal incisions under rim exteriors (Aten
1983, 218, 283). The more elaborate in-
cised designs and zoned stamping of the
Marksville ceramics are absent and vessel
shapes are simple jars or deep bowls with
rounded or conoidal, noded bases. The
ubiquity in the area of simple, sandy-
paste pottery provides a general link with
the Early Ceramic period in east Texas
(see Perttula 1995a; Story 1990), where
simple sandy-paste ceramics are predomi-
nant prior to the emergence of horticul-
tural Caddoan adaptations and an associ-

The Late Prehistoric Period

By around a.d. 700, the introduction
of the bow and arrow on the upper Texas
coast is evidenced by the appearance of
small, light straight- and expanded-stem
stone arrow point types (Alba, Catahoula,
and Scallorn types; see E. Turner and
Hester 1993). Following the generally es-
tablished framework for Texas archeology,
the appearance of arrow points can be
taken to mark the beginning of the Late
Prehistoric period (see, e.g., Hester
1980b; Prewitt 1981, 1985). Patterson’s
(1991a, 1995) suggestion that unifacial
arrow points were present by ca. 4000 b.p.
has not received general acceptance. Simi-
larly, his argument (Patterson 1991a) that
the generally late Perdiz type was present
by ca. a.d. 600 in southeast Texas is ques-
tionable, given the widespread appear-
ance of the type across Texas only after
ca. a.d. 1250 (e.g., L. Johnson 1994;
Mallouf 1987; Prewitt 1985; E. Turner
and Hester 1993). Patterson’s (1991a)
early placement of this type appears to be
based on its co-occurrence with earlier
projectile point types in vertically mixed
site deposits (see discussion in Ricklis
1993b).

Recent ﬁndings at the Mitchell Ridge
site (41GV66) on Galveston Island sug-
gest that the Late Prehistoric can be di-
vided, as elsewhere in Texas, into two
subperiods. At Mitchell Ridge, an Initial
Late Prehistoric subperiod (Ricklis 1994a)
is associated with the introduction of the
bow and arrow, as represented by Scallorn
arrow points. The Final Late Prehistoric
subperiod at the site to a degree corre-
sponds with changes taking place through-
out most of Texas, as marked by the ap-
pearance of the Toyah phase (Prewitt
1985) or horizon (Black 1986) in inland
areas as well as the Rockport phase on the
central Texas coast (Ricklis 1992b, 1995b,
1996). These changes involved the ap-

and knives were scarce at Mitchell Ridge,
but that situation is not surprising con-

bison were hunted on the mainland, so
that only selected meaty elements were
brought to Mitchell Ridge. Beveled
knives and end scrapers are in fact found
at mainland sites (see, e.g., Wheat 1953),
where bison kill sites (e.g., the White Oak
Bayou site in Harris County [McReynolds
et al. 1988]) have been found. The Late
Prehistoric inﬂux of bison onto the Texas
coastal prairies by ca. a.d. 1300 (Huebner
1991; Ricklis 1992a) must have found a
response among coastal populations who,
as did inland groups, adopted a function-
ally associated lithic tool kit.

During the Late Prehistoric, ceramics
underwent some discernible technological
and stylistic modiﬁcations. Grog temper-
ing was introduced, presumably from the
east, a change which Aten (1983) places
at ca. a.d. 1000. (Given the actual ten-
dency for radiocarbon dates in his se-
quence to be older than site age estimates
based on ceramic seriation, this introduc-
tion may have occurred somewhat ear-
lier.) Also, bone tempering is introduced,
although it was always present in a mi-
nority of sherds. Vessels continue to be
simple bowls, jars, and constricted-neck
ollas (Fig. 6.13), but decorations become
more elaborate. The decorated bands on
rim exteriors tend to be wider than previ-

Long-Term Cultural
Processes and Patterns

Settlement Patterns in the Coastal Zone
Aten (1983) has suggested for the up-

per coast of Texas a long-term and very
basic pattern of settlement involving ag-
gregation in large inland winter villages
and spring-summer dispersal into smaller
bands along the coast. The postulated
winter aggregation was based on historic
references to a number of large cool-season
inland camps, although this information
has never been presented in detail. The
spring-summer use of the coastal zone
estuaries was suggested on the basis of
seasonality analyses on rangia clam shells
(Aten 1981); however, some archeologists
have more recently questioned the relia-

bility of the method (Patterson and Gard-
ner 1993; Weinstein et al. 1989; Aten’s
rangia seasonality method is currently
undergoing rigorous reexamination to
determine if any modiﬁcations should be
made in the approach [Lawrence Aten
1997, personal communication]).

Other methods of seasonality analysis

can and should be routinely applied on
upper Texas coast archeological sites. Fish
otoliths, often found in abundance, as
well as oyster shells, when present, hold
considerable potential for seasonality
studies. At the Eagle’s Ridge site, both
otoliths (Stringer 1998) and oyster valves
(Ricklis 1998b) were employed and,
while the results showed a somewhat
broader seasonal spectrum than that indi-
cated by rangia seasonality at the site
(Zimmerman 1995), all three methods
indicated a general emphasis on warm
weather occupation (Ricklis 1998a).

At the Mitchell Ridge site on the la-
goonal side of Galveston Island (Ricklis
1994a), seasonality analysis on otoliths

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

and oysters suggested an emphasis on fall-
winter occupation, which agrees with
Cabeza de Vaca’s sixteenth-century obser-
vation that the native inhabitants of the
upper coast barrier islands spent the fall
and winter on the island and moved to
the mainland during the spring. If Aten’s
seasonality results on rangia prove to be
reliable, the spring-summer occupation of
the “coast” may actually refer to the more
inland areas around secondary bays and
river deltas; at least during the Late Pre-
historic, signiﬁcant fall-winter occupation
may have been focused on the landward
side of the barrier islands. Certainly, the
problem of seasonal locations of subsis-
tence activities and seasonal aggregation
and dispersal of populations merits fur-
ther investigation.

Population Growth and the Emergence
of Incipient Sociocultural Complexity
Aten (1983) has suggested that grow-
ing populations along the coast by Early
Ceramic times were a systemic catalyst for
successive ﬁssioning of social groups; as a
group’s numbers approached four hun-
dred or so, it split, thus conserving exist-
ing social mechanisms with an essentially
egalitarian social order. By Early Historic
times, the native Attakapan-speaking
Akokisa of the area comprised a number
of macrobands of several hundred people;
these groups were seen by Aten to have
been the end result of the long-term
ﬁssioning process. Aten further suggested
that these groups resided in large villages
away from the shoreline during the win-
ter and then dispersed along the coast
in smaller bands during the spring and
summer.

Patterson (1987, 1995) has also posited

a long-term trend toward higher coastal
population density during Late Archaic
times, although he suggests that by Late
Prehistoric times population growth had
slowed or stabilized. Patterson’s empirical
bases for these postulates are the number
of recorded sites for each major time
period in relation to the length of each
period. The idea of long-term net popu-
lation growth on the upper Texas coast
has intuitive appeal, considering the
high biotic productivity of the Late
Holocene estuarine environment and
the general ethnographic fact that coastal
hunter-gatherer populations tend toward
relatively high densities as well as some

dence of grave offerings than the other
three, suggesting a spatial segregation of
mortuary wealth. In the cemetery desig-
nated as Area 4, 91 percent of the grave
pits contained burial goods, as compared
with 20 to 25 percent in the other three
cemeteries (Fig. 6.18). Moreover, the
combined graves in Area 4 yielded twenty-
four distinct classes of grave goods whereas
the other three cemeteries produced only
between one and three classes of goods.
These ﬁndings strongly suggest a spatial
segregation of relatively high-status buri-
als, as would be expected in a social sys-
tem involving some degree of internal
ranking (see, e.g., J. Brown 1981; Fried
1967; Mainfort 1985; O’Shea 1984).

That a single cultural pattern is repre-
sented by all four cemeteries (as opposed
to different cultural groups with differing
mortuary behavior) is indicated by funda-
mental similarities among all four ceme-
teries in other aspects of mortuary behav-
ior, especially the virtually consistent
orientation of heads to the southeast
(Ricklis 1994a, 467– 68). Also, the dif-
ferential amounts of grave goods cannot
be ascribed to diachronic change in mor-
tuary behavior since (a) all four cemeter-
ies contained Late Prehistoric burials,
(b) two cemeteries (Areas 1 and 4) con-
tained burials that were radiocarbon dated
to the Late Prehistoric, Protohistoric, and
Early Historic periods, and (c) burials in
Area 4 contained abundant and varied
goods regardless of the time period.

Also possibly relevant to the question
of population growth is the fact that the
overwhelming majority of the archeologi-
cal evidence for settlement at Mitchell
Ridge and other barrier island sites per-
tains to the Late Prehistoric period. A to-
tal of thirty radiocarbon assays on burials
and features at Mitchell Ridge indicate
that, while there was some use of the site
by ca. 2000 b.p., intensive occupation
began only by ca. a.d. 700/800 (Ricklis
1994a). Similarly, other investigated sites
on upper coast barrier islands, namely the
Caplen site on Bolivar Peninsula (Aten
1983; T. N. Campbell 1957) and the Ja-
maica Beach site on Galveston Island
(Aten 1983), were occupied mainly dur-
ing the Late Prehistoric period and later.
Seasonality analyses on ﬁsh otoliths and
oyster shells from Mitchell Ridge suggest
a seasonal emphasis on fall-winter occu-
pation, which, judging from the extensive

Demographic and Cultural Change
during Protohistoric and
Early Historic Times

The best information recovered to date
on fundamental processes operating dur-
ing the Protohistoric and Early Historic
periods comes, once again, from Mitchell
Ridge. The Protohistoric period was rec-
ognizable at the site on the basis of radio-

carbon-dated burials and an occupation
area that falls into the earliest period of
the Euro-American presence on the upper
Texas Gulf coast (ca. a.d. 1500 –1700).
Little change from the Final Late
Prehistoric is evidenced in basic subsis-
tence practices during the Protohistoric;
faunal data from Feature 9, a series of
overlapping pits containing abundant
camp debris (dated to a 1-sigma range of
a.d. 1450 –1640), shows no major differ-
ence in proportional representation of
species from those recovered from a dis-
crete Final Late Prehistoric midden in
the area of a major block excavation
(with a combined 1-sigma date range of
a.d. 1280 –1450 on four hearth features).
Judging by the data from these areas,
both periods saw a major reliance on
ﬁshing, with additional signiﬁcant dietary

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

input from hunting (primarily white-
tailed deer, although bison elements were
also present) and trapping of the hispid
cotton rats that still abound today on
much of Galveston Island (Ricklis 1994a,
89 –97). There is no evidence for signiﬁ-
cant change in mortuary patterns during
the Protohistoric, since single primary in-
terments and some secondary burials are
still the rule, and the deceased were buried
in the same discrete cemeteries used dur-
ing Late Prehistoric times.

There is some suggestion of an in-
creased variety of arrow point types being
used in Protohistoric times. The over-
whelmingly predominant arrow point in
the Final Late Prehistoric was the Perdiz
type, whereas the excavations in Protohis-
toric Feature 9 yielded a mix of Perdiz,
Bulbar Stemmed, and unstemmed round-
based and lozenge-shaped arrow points
(Fig. 6.19).

Signiﬁcantly, a Protohistoric burial of
a child (Feature 82), with a 1-sigma range
of a.d. 1480 –1650, contained a complete
necklace of native-made tubular conch
shell beads and large blue-green glass
beads of the Itchuknee Plain type. The
latter are commonly found in late six-
teenth- and early seventeenth-century
contexts in the Southeast, and it is the
most common glass bead type on early
seventeenth-century Spanish mission sites
in Florida (Deagan 1987, 171; Marvin
Smith 1993, personal communication).
This ﬁnd indicates that native peoples on
the upper Texas coast had limited access
to European goods (or, at least, glass
beads) in the Protohistoric period, per-
haps obtained via down-the-line exchange
with coastal groups to the east.

By Early Historic times (ca. a.d. 1700 –

1800), major social and demographic
changes were taking place on the upper
Texas coast. Documentary evidence indi-
cates that French fur traders were operat-
ing along the northwest Gulf coast at
least as early as 1720 and that by mid-
century a trading post was established at
the mouth of the Trinity River for the
deerskin trade with the local Akokisa.
The activities of this period are reﬂected
in several of the Mitchell Ridge burials,
which contain early to middle eighteenth-
century glass beads, iron spikes and nails,
a brass hawk bell of typical French style,
and a glass mirror fragment.

to support Aten’s (1983) suggestion of
