or (4) the Palo Duro and Plains Wood-
land cultural traditions actually represent
many different groups (rather than just
two) who interacted with each other in
various ways (as allies or enemies) at dif-
ferent times.

The extent of the Palo Duro Complex

to the east is uncertain. Diagnostic Palo
Duro artifacts were not recovered in the
surveys and testing at Truscott (Etchieson
et al. 1978) and Crowell (Etchieson et al.
1979) Reservoirs, nor have they been re-
ported elsewhere in the Texas Rolling
Plains. Thus, it is not certain whether
Palo Duro peoples avoided the region or
perhaps ventured there occasionally but
left behind no diagnostic artifacts that
archeologists have recognized. It does
seem unlikely that residential bases would
be common in some parts of the Texas
Rolling Plains. Even if some riverine areas
had sufﬁcient fresh water and other re-
sources to support such occupations,
these areas would have been isolated oases
within a sea of saline water and sparse re-
sources. And, being outside their primary
territory, such isolated villages would have
been much more vulnerable to attack.

It is not known whether the Palo Duro
Complex extends south into the canyon-
lands of the upper Colorado River drain-
age. Little archeological work has been re-
ported immediately south of Lake Alan
Henry, but one gets the impression that
Deadman’s-like points and Mogollon pot-
tery are rare. No pottery or early stemmed
arrow points were found during recent
survey and testing at Mitchell Reservoir,
but Scallorn-like points indicate that
some occupations occurred during Late
Prehistoric I times (Lintz et al. 1991,
1993). There are not sufﬁcient archeolog-
ical data to indicate whether the upper
Colorado River (in Borden, Dawson,
Howard, Mitchell, and Scurry Counties)
was or was not occupied by Palo Duro
peoples. The Big Spring site (Sommer
1971) in Howard County, for example,
has produced artifacts similar to those of
the Palo Duro Complex, but the context
and age of these materials are not certain.
If this site represents a Palo Duro compo-
nent, which is possible, it would provide
evidence that the complex does extend
into the upper Colorado River drainage.
Immediately southeast of the Palo
Duro Complex is the aceramic Blow Out
Mountain phase. It is possible that this

poorly deﬁned cultural entity is misrepre-
sented because the apparent absence of
ceramics may be due to inadequate arche-
ological sampling. The Blow Out Moun-
tain phase appears to be different from
the Palo Duro Complex in some ways,
but the projectile points are similar.
While no true Deadman’s points are re-
ported in the area, the arrow points of
the Blow Out Mountain phase include
stemmed Bonham-like varieties that look
like Deadman’s with shorter barbs or
without barbs (see Creel 1990, ﬁg. 42;
Wulfkuhle 1986, ﬁg. 132), and they are
quite similar to many of the stemmed
points found at Palo Duro sites. Not
much is known about the Blow Out
Mountain phase because the East Levee
site (41TG91) is the only site that has
been investigated intensively (Creel
1990), except for burials. Thus, it is quite
speculative to comment on the relation-
ship between the Palo Duro and Blow
Out Mountain cultures at this time.

A large number of excavated burials
have been attributed to the Blow Out
Mountain phase, and they constitute an
important data base. Unfortunately, pub-
lished data are nonexistent or inadequate
for most of these burials, and none have
been radiocarbon dated. In the 1930s,
Cyrus Ray (1932, 1933, 1936, 1946) in-
vestigated numerous burials found on
prominent hills and ridges, both as iso-
lated cairn-covered burials and as large
rock cairns containing individual and
multiple graves. These “covered mounds”
or “stone cist mounds” as Ray (1932,
1933) called them, represent cemeteries
that usually contain primary burials in
ﬂexed positions, but cremated remains
are sometimes present as well. Many
burials in the region are found inside
rock-lined cists, but most contain few
grave goods and no diagnostics. Hence,
their association with the Blow Out
Mountain phase is tentative and is based
on the fact that some of the burials have
stemmed (Bonham-like) arrow points as-
sociated with them. It is interesting that
Ray (1933, 23) suggests a southwestern
origin for the cist-lined graves observed in
many of the Abilene-area burial mounds,
but the diversity of Blow Out Mountain
mortuary traits (e.g., lined and unlined
graves, with and without cairns, contain-
ing primary interments, bundle burials,
and cremations) has not been studied in

any detail. What is important, however,
is that the stemmed points in Blow Out
Mountain burials are somewhat similar to
points found in the Palo Duro Complex,
and the contexts of many of the points
indicate that they represent the cause of
death rather than grave offerings.

The Roberts Covered Mound No. 3
(probably in Taylor County) is a good ex-
ample of a Blow Out Mountain phase
cemetery, and Ray (1933) reports that
this mound contained ten individual in-
terments. Two were bundle burials,
found in the upper part of the mound,
and one of these had a stemmed (Alba-
like) arrow point associated with it (Ray
1933, plate 8). The other eight were pri-
mary ﬂexed burials in individual cists,
and very few artifacts were found in asso-
ciation (a bison toe bone and a bone awl
are the only items mentioned). Five of the
primary burials had no mandibles, and
their absence could not be attributed to
any form of disturbance. Ray (1933, 19 –
20) suggested that the jaws had been taken
as war trophies. A mandible also was miss-
ing from one cist grave in the nearby Al-
exander Mound (Ray 1933, 22).

Robert E. Forrester (1951) reports
similar ﬁndings in a series of burials in
Shackelford County. Eighteen individuals
were found in four separate burial areas,
or “burial plots,” within three hundred
yards along a creek terrace. Of particular
interest, two young males in Burial Plot
II (a single grave) had been killed. Both
had stemmed arrow points found in con-
texts indicating that they were the cause
of death. One individual was missing his
hands and feet, and cut marks on the dis-
tal end of the ulna suggest that they were
removed as war trophies. In addition, the
charred mandible of a child was found in
the chest area of one skeleton, indicating
that this war trophy had been worn as a
pendant.

Of nine individuals in Burial Plot III,
which is similar to Ray’s (1933) covered-
mound cemeteries, two adult males
(Skeletons 4 and 5) were buried with
grave offerings reminiscent of those in
Palo Duro Complex burials (i.e., mussel
shells and deer bone tools). A stemmed
arrow point was found in association with
one man (Skeleton 4) who had been
buried in a single grave with three other
people (Skeletons 1–3 are an elderly fe-
male and two infants). The point has

proximal and distal breaks that appear to
be impact related (the proximal break is
almost identical to the one on the arrow
point embedded in the humerus of Skele-
ton 2 in Burial Plot II), and the point
probably represents the cause of death.
If this interpretation is correct, it is quite
possible that the other three individuals
buried in the same grave also were killed.
None of the Shackelford County buri-

als have been radiocarbon dated, but the
association with early types of arrow points
indicates that they date to Late Prehistoric
I times and also suggests a likely afﬁliation
with the Blow Out Mountain phase (Creel
1990, 17). These points are basically simi-
lar to the Alba, Bonham, and Sabinal
styles, but they do not quite ﬁt into a
single type. Forrester (1987) has since sug-
gested that they be called Moran points.
Several cairn burials have been found
in and near O. H. Ivie Reservoir in Con-
cho, Coleman, and Runnels Counties, and
two of them date to Late Prehistoric I
times. Although it is not yet reported in
detail, Lintz et al. (1993, 647– 49) men-
tion a burial excavated by the Concho
Valley Archeological Society at 41CN94
that is similar to the Shackelford County
burials and yielded a Sabinal arrow point
( J. A. Jaquier 1993, personal communica-
tion). At 41CC237, a child cremation
and a bundle burial of an adult male prob-
ably were interred at the same time in a
single cairn-covered grave (Lintz et al.
1993, 649 –59). Although the artifacts
found in the burial pit (thin bifacial pre-
forms, unifacial tools, debitage, modiﬁed
limonite fragments, and nineteen Olivella
shell beads) are not temporally sensitive,
a radiocarbon date of a.d. 280 –570 (cali-
brated) was obtained on bone collagen
from the adult skeleton. A possible cut
mark observed on one rib may be evi-
dence of dismemberment, and the man-
dible is notably absent from the burial.

The evidence for violence in Blow Out
Mountain phase burials (and in culturally
unassigned burials such as at 41CC237)
is intriguing, but it is too early to draw
any ﬁrm conclusions. Perhaps the Palo
Duro peoples were engaged in conﬂicts
with peoples to the south and southeast,
as well as with groups to the north and
northeast. The taking of human jaws as
war trophies attests to the intensity of the
hostilities, which had perhaps escalated to
the point of all-out warfare.

PALO DURO COMPLEX / 327

To the west and southwest of the Palo
Duro Complex are the Middle Pecos and
Eastern Jornada Mogollon culture areas.
Lying between is a sizable portion of the
Llano Estacado that one would think
was virtually uninhabited based on the
paucity of published archeological data.
While this perception may be true to an
extent, there is evidence that people tra-
versed the Llano using southeastward-
ﬂowing drainages as highways, and there
is evidence for more-than-ephemeral Late
Prehistoric occupations at some large
playa and pluvial lakes on the southern
Llano. The only well-documented Late
Prehistoric playa lake site in the southern
Llano Estacado is the Salt Cedar site
(M. Collins 1968). Occupations at this
residential base, which currently marks the
easternmost edge of the Eastern Jornada
Mogollon, date primarily after a.d. 1100
but may have begun during Late Prehis-
toric I times.

Based on survey evidence alone, it may

be speculated that the Palo Duro Com-
plex extends up onto the eastern edge of
the southern Llano Estacado. The possi-
bility that a Palo Duro component may
be present in Lynn County has been
mentioned, and early stemmed arrow
points and Jornada brownware pottery
have been found at several playa lake sites
in Lubbock County (C. Brown 1985,
1990a, 1990b, 1991a, 1991b, n.d.). The
presence of Palo Duro occupations on the
southern Llano has yet to be conﬁrmed
through excavations, but it is possible that
at least a few components did exist around
playa and pluvial lakes. If this is the case,
there is still much to be learned about
how these High Plains sites ﬁt into the
overall Palo Duro subsistence and settle-
ment pattern.

Despite the geographic gap in the re-
gional data, the Palo Duro Complex con-
tains deﬁnite evidence, in the form of
brownware pottery, that there was some
transfer of material culture from the Jor-
nada Mogollon area across the southern
Llano Estacado and into the Caprock
Canyonlands. There also is other circum-
stantial evidence for some form of cul-
tural interaction and exchange of ideas
between Jornada Mogollon and Palo Duro
peoples. It is this author’s opinion, appar-
ently one that is also shared by J. Brett
Cruse (1992) and Jack Hughes (1991),
that the interaction between these groups

was direct, that the Jornada inﬂuence
upon the Palo Duro culture was quite
strong and consistent through time, and
that it involved much more than just the
acquisition of pots. The nature and ex-
tent of the interaction between the East-
ern Jornada peoples and the Palo Duro
culture is a research problem that is likely
to be controversial. Although the ideas
discussed below admittedly are specula-
tive, it is hoped that they will spur debate
between southwestern and Southern
Plains archeologists.

Pottery constitutes the only direct evi-
dence for inﬂuence from the Jornada Mo-
gollon area. Almost all of the pottery
sherds found at Palo Duro sites are iden-
tiﬁed generically as some variety of Jor-
nada Mogollon brownware. Most are
tempered with crushed igneous rocks and
are indisputably of nonlocal origin when
found in the Texas Panhandle Plains. The
varieties that have been identiﬁed ( Jor-
nada Brown, Alma Plain, El Paso Brown,
Roswell Brown, South Pecos Brown,
Middle Pecos Micaceous, and McKenzie
Brown) were manufactured in the Jor-
nada Mogollon or Middle Pecos areas,
and very few brownware sherds have been
identiﬁed as possibly being locally made
wares. The consistent presence of small
quantities of nonlocal brownwares in
many Texas sites indicates that the Palo
Duro peoples maintained at least periodic
contact with Jornada Mogollon peoples
over a long period of time. Pottery sherds
are not very abundant, but sometimes as
many as four vessels are represented at a
single Palo Duro site. Ceramics are sufﬁ-
ciently scarce to indicate that the supply
of pots was rather limited, perhaps be-
cause Palo Duro groups did not make
journeys to the Jornada region on an an-
nual or regular basis, or perhaps because
of the high labor cost involved in trans-
porting large, fragile vessels over long
distances on foot. Exactly how the pots
made their way into the Panhandle Plains
region is not known. Although interme-
diary groups could have been involved,
the relatively short distance between the
Caprock Canyonlands and the Pecos
River valley (250 to 300 km) suggests
that Palo Duro peoples acquired pots di-
rectly from the Eastern Jornada groups.
Other evidence for the Palo Duro
Complex having been inﬂuenced by the
Jornada Mogollon culture is circumstan-

328 / HIGH PLAINS AND CANYONLANDS

tial, but it is nonetheless strong. The ar-
chitectural similarities between the Palo
Duro and Eastern Jornada pithouses are
particularly intriguing. Various research-
ers have noted similarities between the
Palo Duro pithouses and those of the Jor-
nada Mogollon area, while noting the
lack of similarities with houses of nearby
Plains Woodland and Plains Village Com-
plexes (Boyd 1995a, 1995b; Boyd et al.
1994, 116 –17, 260; Cruse 1992, 127–
29; J. Hughes 1991, 26). Although rect-
angular and circular pithouses are found
among many cultures and the shape alone
is not diagnostic, when the combination
of traits is considered, the closest archi-
tectural parallels are clearly to the west
and southwest rather than to the north or
east. It is notable also that pithouses in the
Jornada Mogollon area exhibit consider-
able architectural variability, and if the
sample of three is any indication, so do
the pithouses of the Palo Duro Complex.
Rectangular structures—both surface
and pithouses—are known for Southern
Plains Woodland and Plains Village Com-
plexes, but they are very different from
those at the Kent Creek site (Boyd et al.
1994, 116). In contrast, Cruse (1992,
127–29) notes that many architectural
traits observed for the Kent Creek pit-
houses are similar to those seen in Jornada
Mogollon pithouses. Particularly diagnos-
tic are the ramped entryways, which are a
common feature in Jornada pithouses but
are not seen in any Plains Woodland or
Plains Village houses. Other architectural
parallels between Kent Creek and Mogo-
llon pithouses include small trough fea-
tures or steps just inside the entryway,
comparable variability in interior ﬂoor
area, the use of a single large roof support
post, and the practice of subﬂoor burials
inside houses.

In addition, there is one example that

shows a striking parallel between Kent
Creek and the Jornada area. A rectangular
pithouse (Pitroom R-2) excavated at the
Merchant site in Lea County, New Mex-
ico, is very similar in size, shape, and en-
try conﬁguration to Structure 2 at Kent
Creek (see Leslie 1965, ﬁg. 3, with Cruse
1992, ﬁgs. 6 and 10). Unfortunately,
there are no radiocarbon dates directly as-
sociated with either structure, and R. H.
Leslie’s (1965) assessment that the Mer-
chant site dates to the ﬁfteenth century is
based solely on a few decorated pottery
sherds (which make up only a small per-

centage of the total ceramic assemblage)
and could be very misleading. Cruse
(1992, 129) notes that the elongated
trough features along the front and back
walls of Structure 2 are unique to the
Kent Creek pithouses.

Similarly, the ephemeral pithouse at

the Sam Wahl site has no analogs in
nearby Plains Woodland or Plains Village
Complexes, but very similar round to
oval structures are present in the Key-
stone Dam area near El Paso (Carmi-
chael 1985, 142 – 49; O’Laughlin 1980,
135 – 49) and at the Fox Place and King
Ranch sites near Roswell (Wiseman
1981, 174 –75; 1988, 229; 1993, per-
sonal communication). The Keystone
Dam structures date earlier (ca. 550 b.c.
to a.d. 150) than the Sam Wahl pithouse,
while the King Ranch structures are later
(ca. a.d. 1150 –1300). Unpublished dates
for the Fox Place pithouses indicate they
were used in the 1200s and 1300s (Regge
Wiseman 1997, personal communica-
tion). Southwestern pithouse occupations
are continually being pushed back earlier
in time, and it seems likely that Jornada
Mogollon pithouses will prove to be the
prototypes for those in the Caprock
Canyonlands.

There also are broad similarities in the
subsistence strategies and settlement pat-
terns of the Palo Duro and Eastern Jor-
nada peoples. Mesquite and shin oak have
been identiﬁed as probable staple foods
utilized by both groups. Except for a
slightly lower rainfall and minor differ-
ences in plant and animal communities,
the Mescalero Escarpment on the west
edge of the Llano Estacado is in many
ways similar to the Caprock Escarpment.
Consequently, it should not be surprising
that human populations adapted to these
areas in a similar manner. Many of the
subsistence and settlement pattern char-
acteristics proposed for the Eastern Jor-
nada area are similar to adaptive strategies
that Palo Duro peoples may have em-
ployed in the Caprock Canyonlands.
Leslie (1979) notes that the Querecho-
Maljamar phases are characterized by pit-
house villages and seasonal camp sites, a
heavy dependence upon plant foods, the
predominant use of oval basin metates
and convex-faced manos, and the domi-
nant use of a variety of corner-notched
arrow points.

The same amount of variability in ar-

row point morphology within the Palo

Duro Complex is evident in the arrow
points of the pithouse period in the East-
ern Jornada area (Leslie 1978). The cor-
ner- and basal-notched stemmed arrow
points of the Palo Duro Complex are
very similar to and exhibit the same range
of variability as Leslie’s (1978) Types 3A
through 3E, including occasional serrated
blades. These points are associated with
Leslie’s (1978, ﬁg. 13) Querecho phase,
although the dates that he gives for this
phase are probably far too recent. Jelinek
(1967, 103 –105, 110) also documents a
similar variety of points in the Late Ar-
chaic through Late 18 Mile phases and
notes that serration is most strongly asso-
ciated with pithouse occupations of the
Early 18 Mile through Early Mesita Ne-
gra phases (a.d. 800 to 1100).

Similarly, the most common points as-

sociated with the Blow Out Mountain
phase are a variety of stemmed points
that do not ﬁt neatly into a single type
but are similar to arrow points of the Palo
Duro Complex and Eastern Jornada areas
(e.g., Type 3D in Leslie 1978). Regardless
of the names one assigns to them, there
seems to be some morphological continu-
ity between the stemmed arrow points of
the Palo Duro Complex, the Blow Out
Mountain phase, the Eastern Jornada,
and Middle Pecos areas. While corner-
notched dart points (i.e., Ellis-like points)
of the Panhandle Plains Late Archaic bi-
son hunters may be the prototypes for
ubiquitous Scallorn-like arrow points of
the Lake Creek and Palo Duro Com-
plexes, the unusual Deadman’s arrow
points seem to appear suddenly and
rather early (probably before a.d. 500).
There is no precursor evident among
Southern Plains Late Archaic points, and
it is possible that the prototype for Dead-
man’s points may be found in the Shumla
dart points of the Lower Pecos and south
Texas areas. Shumla-like dart points are
present but rare throughout much of the
Jornada area at least as far west as Las
Cruces, New Mexico (MacNeish 1993b,
179). In addition, the corner-notched to
stemmed (and sometimes serrated) Pen-
dejo points found in southern New Mex-
ico (along with Shumla and Hueco
points) are quite similar to the early
stemmed arrow points found in the Cap-
rock Canyonlands and west-central Texas.
In the Jornada area, Pendejo points are
found in the Late Archaic and in the
Mesilla phase (MacNeish 1993b, 183 –

84), and they could be the prototype for
similar arrow points in the Palo Duro
Complex and Blow Out Mountain phase.

The rather sudden appearance of
Deadman’s-like arrow points may only
signal the adoption of the bow and arrow
by indigenous groups, or it may mark the
appearance of new peoples in the Cap-
rock Canyonlands (i.e., the Palo Duro
Complex) and in west-central Texas (i.e.,
the Blow Out Mountain phase). This au-
thor prefers the latter interpretation and
suggests that strong evidence for the ar-
rival of new peoples is found in the buri-
als throughout the region. A growing
amount of evidence—some deﬁnitive,
some circumstantial— denotes the forma-
tion of territorial boundaries and increas-
ingly widespread violence among many
Southern Plains cultures during the ﬁrst
millennium a.d. These events set the stage
for the escalating warfare seen during later
Plains Village times (Brooks 1994a).

If Palo Duro peoples were newcomers

to the Caprock Canyonlands sometime
between a.d. 1 and 500, where did they
come from? Perhaps Krieger (1946, 80 –
82) was on the right track in the mid-
twentieth century when he observed that
there was virtually no difference in the
archeology of the New Mexico and Texas
portions of the southern Llano Estacado.
He suggested that the Southern High
Plains had been “actually inhabited by
Puebloans, if only seasonally” (Krieger
1946, 80). Given the evidence for cul-
tural inﬂuence from the west, one must
look to the Jornada Mogollon region (in-
cluding its eastern extension east of the
Pecos River) as the most likely area of ori-
gin for many cultural traits of the Palo
Duro Complex. It is not suggested that
Palo Duro peoples were direct lineal de-
scendants of Jornada Mogollon peoples.
Although this certainly is one possibility,
there simply is not enough evidence to
support such a statement. There is sufﬁ-
cient evidence, however, to suggest that
Palo Duro peoples may have been descen-
dants of hunter-gatherers who, having
lived in close contact with Jornada Mogo-
llon peoples in what is now southeastern
New Mexico and far western Texas, mi-
grated east or northeastward onto the
Southern Plains.

What became of the Palo Duro Com-
plex is equally problematic and perplex-
ing. Without going into the myriad of
possibilities regarding the fate of this cul-

PALO DURO COMPLEX / 329

ture, the most logical idea is one that
links the Palo Duro Complex (and per-
haps the Blow Out Mountain phase) with
the Toyah phase of central and south
Texas. Harry Shafer (1977) originally
proposed that the Toyah culture was de-
rived from Southern Plains bison-hunting
peoples who migrated southward. LeRoy
Johnson (1994, 271–81) has elaborated
upon this idea and proposes that the clas-
sic Toyah phase retains enough subtle
traits, primarily in pottery styles and
manufacturing techniques, to link it to
the Jornada Mogollon cultural tradition.
While much of its material culture repre-
sents classic Plains bison-hunting gear
(i.e., the beveled Harahey skinning knives
and Plains-style hafted end scrapers), the
pointed-stemmed Perdiz point is distinc-
tive, and its logical prototype is found in
the stemmed arrow points of the Blow
Out Mountain culture. Johnson (1994)
suggests that Toyah peoples are descen-
dants of groups who made Jornada Mo-
gollon–tradition pottery, slightly modi-
ﬁed their stemmed arrow points into the
distinctive Perdiz style, and adopted a
Plains bison-hunting lifestyle. He also
suggests that the Mogollon inﬂuence may
have been indirect and that the earliest
Toyah peoples could have come from the
Southern Plains rather than from the Jor-
nada Mogollon region.

I would further modify Johnson’s
(1994) hypothesis and suggest that the
Blow Out Mountain phase is somehow
related to the Palo Duro Complex. Al-
though purely conjectural, these manifes-
tations may prove to be northern and
southern variants of the same cultural
tradition. The stemmed Bonham-like ar-
row points that characterize the Blow
Out Mountain phase are little more than
modiﬁed Deadman’s points, but the latter
represent the earliest narrow-stemmed ar-
row point form in the Texas Panhandle
Plains. Consequently, the Deadman’s
point is the logical prototype for the
stemmed Blow Out Mountain points and
ultimately, if Johnson (1994) is correct,
for Perdiz points as well. Although it will
be difﬁcult to determine whether the Palo
Duro Complex and the Blow Out Moun-
tain phase are ancestral to the Toyah
phase, this hypothesis is worth testing.
One possible scenario is that, as the
climate dried and bison populations in-
creased in the Southern Plains around
a.d. 1100 –1300, peoples of the Palo

Duro Complex and the Blow Out Moun-
tain phase quickly adopted a Plains bison-
hunting lifestyle and material culture, and
they began to migrate southward. This
migration may have been spurred, in a
domino effect, by pressures from south-
ward-migrating Athapaskan-speaking
peoples who moved from the Central
Plains into the Southern Plains around
a.d. 1300 –1400 (but that is another
story altogether). The wide geographic
range and the extreme archeological vari-
ability that characterize the Toyah phase
may be partially explained if these proto-
Toyah peoples spread throughout central
and south Texas within one or two centu-
ries and eventually displaced or assimi-
lated with but also adopted traits from in-
digenous groups.

Summary of Conclusions

The Palo Duro Complex has been
redeﬁned in light of recent archeological
ﬁnds. The complex dates to the period
between a.d. 500 and 1100/1200, and a
wide range of activities and site functions
are inferred for the three types of habita-
tion sites that are recognized. The Kent
Creek and Sam Wahl sites are identiﬁed
as residential bases where people lived in
pithouses while procuring, processing,
storing, and consuming a wide range of
wild plant foods. Mesquite beans and
shin oak acorns have been identiﬁed as
possible staples, but other plants such as
goosefoot and buffalo gourds also may
have been important foods. Although no
cultigens have been found, this situation
does not preclude the possibility that lim-
ited horticulture was practiced at residen-
tial sites. Occupations at these villages
were at least seasonal (i.e., during late
summer to fall harvest and into winter)
and may have been biseasonal (i.e., dur-
ing planting and then again during fall
harvest and into winter).

Palo Duro peoples lived in rockshelters

and open camps at various times of the
year and for different reasons. Some rock-
shelters were occupied on a sporadic and
ephemeral basis, while others were more
intensively used and may have served as
relatively permanent bases. Some camp
sites were little more than specialized pro-
cessing sites where baking and grinding
of plant foods were the primary activities,
while others were multifunctional bases
where considerable hunting and process-

10-A2946  4/13/04  12:21 PM  Page 330

330 / HIGH PLAINS AND CANYONLANDS

ing of animals was done. Deer and small
animals appear to have been the principal
game animals. Bison were hunted but do
not appear to have been a major food re-
source, and the evidence suggests that
populations may have been relatively low.
Palo Duro culture is now viewed as
representing semisedentary peoples who
maintained a high degree of residential
mobility in order to exploit a wide range
of resources that were locally available
and abundant on a seasonal basis. Sites
of this complex are found mainly in the
Caprock Canyonlands, an ecological sub-
region that offered the most predictable
and widest range of subsistence resources
(water, plants, and animals) within a rela-
tively arid landscape. The home territory
for Palo Duro peoples was in the upper
drainages of the Red and Brazos Rivers,
although they may have ranged on occa-
sion north into the Canadian River valley,
east into the Rolling Plains, south into
the upper Colorado River drainage, and
west onto the Llano Estacado.

Human burials provide evidence of
widespread violence in and around the
Caprock Canyonlands during the Late
Prehistoric I period, and the Palo Duro
culture may have come into periodic con-
tact with enemy peoples to the north and
east (Lake Creek or Plains Woodland
groups) and to the south and southeast
(Blow Out Mountain and other unde-

ﬁned groups). Palo Duro peoples did
maintain some form of cultural contact
with the Jornada Mogollon peoples of
southeastern New Mexico and western
Texas over a long period of time. There
appears to be a signiﬁcant amount of Jor-
nada Mogollon cultural inﬂuence across
the southern Llano Estacado and into the
Caprock Canyonlands, and the Palo Duro
Complex exhibits many traits (e.g., im-
ported brownware pottery and pithouse
architectural styles) that were derived,
whether directly or indirectly, from the
Jornada Mogollon region. In addition,
the similarities between the subsistence
and settlement patterns proposed for the
Palo Duro Complex and those proposed
for their eastern Jornada Mogollon neigh-
bors may be more than a mere coinci-
dence. In summary, it is unclear whether
the Palo Duro Complex represents an ac-
tual migration of Jornada Mogollon or re-
lated peoples or whether it simply repre-
sents indigenous Southern Plains people
who came under the widespread inﬂu-
ence of Jornada Mogollon culture or
something much more complex.

From Stone Slab Architecture to Abandonment
A Revisionist View of the Antelope Creek Phase

Robert L. Brooks

When Francisco Vázquez de Coronado’s
entrada crossed the Texas and Oklahoma
Panhandles in the summer of 1541, there
was no evidence that the region had been
occupied by a village society living in
dwellings built with stone slabs. Coro-
nado encountered the Jumanos, Quere-
chos, and the Teyas, highly mobile bison-
hunting and gathering bands. Yet ﬁfty to
one hundred years before the appearance
of the Spanish, numerous villages of this
culture—which archeologists have termed
the Antelope Creek phase (Lintz 1984,
1986)—were spread throughout the pan-
handle regions of Texas and Oklahoma.
Because of the apparent abandonment of
the region and the absence of oral history
pertaining to these people, their culture
history remains elusive.

Antelope Creek phase sites have been
studied since the early part of the twenti-
eth century, but many questions remain
unanswered concerning the origins of
these people, their way of life, and ulti-
mately, their disappearance from the
Southern High Plains. However, my pur-
pose is not to recapitulate the extensive
work and documentation done on Ante-
lope Creek (see Krieger 1946; Lintz 1984,
1986). Instead, I characterize salient
themes of Antelope Creek culture and ex-
amine them from a revisionist perspec-
tive. Revisionism here is not drawn from
post-processualism (Hodder 1986) but
from an attempt to interpret the archeo-
logical record based on what we currently

know of the material record of Antelope
Creek (Binford 1983, 19 –22). Much of
the existing work on Antelope Creek has
stressed the cultural-historical, albeit ma-
terial culture, record rather than interpret-
ing this information in relation to Ante-
lope Creek social, political, and economic
lifeways. For example, it is well known
that people of the Antelope Creek phase
built stone slab single-room and multi-
room structures. However, what were the
implications of this architectural style for
the ongoing Antelope Creek cultural sys-
tem between ﬁve hundred and eight hun-
dred years ago? I discuss in a similar fash-
ion areas such as subsistence, technology,
social organization, trade, and warfare.
The origins of the Antelope Creek phase
and the biological characteristics of these
people are also explored from this per-
spective of an interpretable record.

A General Overview
of Antelope Creek

The Antelope Creek phase represents a

provocative mix of masonry architecture
reminiscent of pueblos in the southwest-
ern United States and a material culture
bearing many similarities to Central Plains
village farming societies. Between roughly
a.d. 1200 and 1500, numerous settle-
ments of the Antelope Creek culture were
present along the Canadian and North
Canadian Rivers and their principal tribu-
taries in the Oklahoma and Texas Pan-

331

handles (Fig. 11.1). Important studied
sites include Antelope Creek 22 (W. Hol-
den 1930; C. S. Johnson 1939), Ante-
lope Creek 24 (Dufﬁeld 1970), Chimney
Creek (E. Baker and Baker 1941), Coetas
Creek Ruin 55 (Studer 1934), Alibates 28
(Dufﬁeld 1970b), Tarbox (W. Holden
1930), Saddleback ( Green 1967; T. Hol-
den 1934), Arrowhead Point (Green
1967), Medford Ranch (Dufﬁeld 1964),
Footprint (Green 1967), Spring Canyon,
Conner, Pickett, Roper, Sanford, Canyon
City (Dufﬁeld 1970b), and Landergin
Mesa (Lintz 1990a) in Texas; and Stam-
per (Watson 1950), Roy Smith (Schnei-
der 1969), Two Sisters (Lintz 1979; Dun-
can 2002) and McGrath (Lintz 1976),
and possibly Odessa Yates (Brosowske
and Bement 1998) in Oklahoma. Gener-
ally, these sites occur in Southern High
Plains settings, frequently on high ter-
races or mesas at some distance from wa-
ter supplies.

In this portion of the southern Great
Plains, the landscape is characterized by
overlapping sequences of alluvial fans
trending northwest from the Edwards
Plateau to the Rocky Mountains (Lintz
1984, 39). Geomorphological degrada-
tion of these landforms has resulted in
the formation of shallow basins and relic
Pleistocene lake valleys. This degrading of
the alluvial fans has also resulted in ero-
sional remnants to the east and west, es-
sentially circumscribing the area. To the
east, erosion of the fans and relic valleys

Five major plant ecosystems are present
that attest to an extensive array of plants
available within the region (Wright and
Meador 1979). While these associations
are dominated by native grasses, a variety
of edible wild plants such as chickasaw
plum, lambsquarter, and marsh elder also
occur. These plants were used by Ante-
lope Creek phase people as a source of
starchy foods, as were the introduced
tropical domesticates of corn, beans, and
squash (Lintz 1986).

Previous Investigations and
Cultural Taxonomy

Previous Field Investigations

Lintz (1986, 5 –20) has presented an
excellent and thorough overview of previ-
ous studies of the Panhandle aspect and
the Antelope Creek phase. Other signiﬁ-
cant summaries of Antelope Creek can be
found in Krieger (1946, 17-74), Hughes
(1968), R. Campbell (1969), and Hof-
man et. al (1989b). Because of the lim-
ited ﬁeld research undertaken at Antelope
Creek sites since Lintz’s synthesis in the
mid-1980s, I can impart relatively little
new information to the existing literature.
However, a brief history of previous in-
vestigations will set the stage for future
sections of this chapter and also serve to
explain some of our difﬁculties in inter-
preting the archeological record as it per-
tains to the Antelope Creek phase.

Dr. T. L. Eyerly of Canadian Baptist
Academy, between 1907 and 1912 (see
Eyerly 1907), conducted initial investiga-
tions at village sites in the Panhandle re-
gion. Eyerly’s work was focused on sites in
the Wolf Creek valley (Ochiltree County)
and involved minimal excavations, other
than at Handley Ruin (Buried City).
However, Eyerly was the ﬁrst to take note
of the vertically set stone slabs within the
house walls. A few years later, in 1914 –
15, J. Walter Fewkes reportedly con-
ducted limited work at Handley Ruin,
again in the Wolf Creek valley, where a
burial was recovered (Moorehead 1931).
During 1917, Joseph Thoburn of the
University of Oklahoma conducted sur-
vey work in the Oklahoma Panhandle,
and he documented numerous prehistoric
sites, including some later identiﬁed as
Antelope Creek occupations.

Beginning in 1919, Warren K. Moore-
head of Phillips Academy initiated a pro-

Fig. 11.1. Late Prehistoric cultural complexes on the Southern High Plains.

has left a pronounced escarpment, char-
acterized by rugged terrain and steep re-
lief. To the west, the Pecos River dissected
the Llano Estacado, creating a second dis-
tinctive escarpment. From my perspec-
tive, this circumscription may have played
a signiﬁcant role in the continuity and
change observed in Antelope Creek phase
culture. These rather crude boundaries
would have served as permeable barriers
to contact with other groups as well as ex-
pansion of Antelope Creek settlements to
adjacent regions. Other characteristics of
the landscape were also essential to the
formation of this rather complicated cul-
tural context.

Within the Canadian River valley are
found outcrops of Alibates agatized dolo-
mite. Serving as a source for chipped
stone tool manufacture since approxi-
mately twelve thousand years ago (Lintz
1986, 45, 48), the Alibates quarries ap-
pear to have been especially favored dur-
ing Late Prehistoric village farming times.
I think it signiﬁcant that many Antelope
Creek settlements are found in settings
surrounding the “core area” where Ali-
bates ﬂint is most abundant and of the
highest quality. These and other geologic
formations also provided the limestone

slabs that were used in construction of
the masonry architecture. Without the
presence of this geological phenomenon,
such a distinctive style of architecture
probably would not have arisen.

The use of speciﬁc soil types for settle-

ment location does not appear to have
been a major determining factor in site
selection. However, most Antelope Creek
settlements are found on soils that are
well drained and could potentially be re-
charged by alluvial deposition. Because of
the restrictive climatic conditions within
the region, I suspect that fertile soils would
be necessary to foster agricultural produc-
tivity. Christopher Lintz (1986) and L. F.
Dufﬁeld (1970b) have presented a thor-
ough treatment of the animal communi-
ties that are found throughout the Okla-
homa and Texas Panhandles. They list
numerous species of animals, including
bison, pronghorn antelope, mule deer,
elk, jackrabbit and cottontail rabbit,
badger, porcupine, and numerous small
rodents, distributed among three ecosys-
tems. Evidence from Antelope Creek
phase site investigations suggests that bi-
son was a preferred species in the pro-
curement regime, with lesser emphasis on
mule deer, pronghorn, and smaller game.

gram of research in the Canadian River
valley. Although he principally surveyed
the valley for sites (recording more than
one hundred), Moorehead (1921) also
examined Handley Ruins in 1920. Less
than ten years later, University of Penn-
sylvania researchers Ronald Olsen and
J. Alden Mason were present in the Texas
Panhandle studying Plains culture. Olsen
continued earlier efforts at surveying the
Canadian River valley, whereas Mason
(1929) conducted excavations at Alibates
28. William C. Holden of Texas Tech
University undertook some of the more
extensive work at Antelope Creek sites
during this period. Holden excavated at
Tarbox, Antelope Creek 22, and Saddle-
back and Lookout ruins. His reports (see
W. Holden 1933) represent the ﬁrst de-
tailed documentation of Antelope Creek
architecture and site structure although,
as Lintz (1986, 10) notes, there were
sometimes inconsistencies and inaccura-
cies in his accounts. In 1932 E. B. Sayles
of the Gila Pueblo Institute also followed
up on Holden’s work at Alibates 22 and
28 and Saddleback Mesa. Although Sayles
did not conduct extensive ﬁeldwork in
the Panhandle, he had considerable im-
pact on Floyd Studer, who was initially
at Canadian Baptist Academy and later
the Panhandle-Plains Historical Society.
Studer, a protégé of Eyerly’s at Canadian
Baptist Academy, conducted investiga-
tions for almost thirty years at Antelope
Creek phase sites, including major exca-
vations at Saddleback Mesa, Coetas Creek
Ruins, and Alibates 28 (Studer 1931).

The Great Depression, with the fed-
eral Works Progress Administration and
the Federal Emergency Relief Act, ush-
ered in a new era of archeological investi-
gations in the Texas and Oklahoma Pan-
handles. Antelope Creek sites such as
Antelope Creek Ruins 22, 22A, 23, 24;
Alibates 28, 28A, 30; and Chimney Rock
Ruin were the recipient of much of the
federal program’s archeological initiative.
C. Stuart Johnson conducted excavations
at the Stamper site in Texas County, Okla-
homa, although no report was generated
from this work. A short time later, Joseph
Thoburn conducted work at the Roy
Smith site in Texas County, Oklahoma.
However, Thoburn’s investigations fo-
cused on an old stone corral rather than
the more archeologically productive room
block at Roy Smith. In the Texas Pan-

handle, Ele Baker and Jewell Baker (1941)
excavated a number of Antelope Creek vil-
lage ruins, including Antelope Creek 22,
23 and 28A, and Chimney Rock Ruins.

The 1940s and the 1950s were decades
in which relatively little attention was fo-
cused on Plains Village sites in the Pan-
handle region. The decade of the 1960s
marked a return to university-sponsored
research. Archeologists at the University
of Oklahoma conducted further investi-
gations at the Roy Smith site (Schneider
1969). Jack Hughes of West Texas State
University and the Panhandle-Plains Mu-
seum also conducted investigations at a
number of Antelope Creek sites in the re-
gion, among them Roper, Pickett, San-
ford, and Cottonwood Creek Ruins. In
addition, he extended survey efforts into
smaller tributary drainages of the Cana-
dian River. Construction of Sanford
Reservoir in the mid-1960s also resulted
in the study of Antelope Creek villages
that were to be inundated. Most of this
work was undertaken in 1964 by Lathel
Dufﬁeld, who excavated at Spring Can-
yon, Medford Ranch, Conner, 41MO5,
Turkey Creek, Arrowhead Peak, and Foot-
print (Couzzourt and Couzzourt 1996;
Dufﬁeld 1964).

The last three decades of the twentieth
century bear witness to work at a quite a
few Antelope Creek sites. Unfortunately,
only some of these more recent investiga-
tions have resulted in substantial publica-
tions. Chris Lintz, in addition to his syn-
thesis of Antelope Creek, also excavated
at the Two Sisters site, adjacent to the
Stamper site in the Oklahoma Panhandle.
Jack Keller (1975) conducted investiga-
tions at Black Dog Village in connection
with construction done by the Texas De-
partment of Transportation. The Pan-
handle Archeological Society, working
with members of the professional com-
munity, examined the Marsh, Jack Allen,
Zollars, Emery Ruin, and Big Blue Can-
yon sites (Lintz 1986, 18). Work contin-
ued at Lake Meredith (formerly Sanford
Reservoir), as Gerald M. Etchieson inves-
tigated the South Ridge site (Etchieson
1979). Lastly, the Texas Historical Com-
mission and Lintz spent two ﬁeld seasons
at Landergin Mesa (Lintz 1990a).

Over the past century, considerable
work has been undertaken at many Ante-
lope Creek phase sites. However, it must
be recognized that much of the early work

was done without adequate provenience
controls and lacked a grounding in the
complexities of the archeological record.
Even work by professionals beginning in
the 1930s and continuing into the 1960s
suffered from technological limitations.
For example, few excavations utilized
water screening of sediments to extract
a greater yield and variety of material re-
mains. In a similar fashion, ﬂotation as a
data recovery procedure was either not
yet developed enough for ﬁeld use or not
commonly used. Thus, many of the exca-
vated sites suffer in a qualitative and
quantitative sense because of the absence
of statistically representative faunal and
ﬂoral samples. Much could be said for
other objects in an archeological matrix
that could pass through quarter-inch
hardware cloth. Of course, these data re-
covery problems were not unique to the
archeology of the Panhandle region; they
were the methodological paradigm of an
earlier age of archeological ﬁeld tech-
niques. It must be noted, though, that
our understanding of Antelope Creek
phase culture is compromised by such
omissions from the archeological record.

Cultural Taxonomy of Antelope Creek
Rendering order to our universe of
archeological data has been a fundamen-
tal problem in archeology since we began
to make concerted efforts to compare and
contrast site assemblages and to look at
broader regional relationships. In early
twentieth-century archeological studies,
most classiﬁcation efforts were unsystem-
atic and also largely impressionistic. At-
tempts at classifying Antelope Creek were
no exception. To some extent, these ef-
forts in the Panhandle region were exacer-
bated by the complicated nature of the
Antelope Creek culture, which bore re-
semblance to the material culture of the
Plains and to the architecture of the
Southwest. Archeologists attempting to
characterize Antelope Creek were swayed
by these factors as well as the comments
and actions of their peers.

Warren K. Moorehead was the ﬁrst to
name the sites found along the Canadian
River, referring to them as the Canadian
Valley culture, the Texas Panhandle cul-
ture, and the Panhandle culture. With
Moorehead’s classiﬁcation, Antelope
Creek was identiﬁed with a regional land-
scape, the Panhandle, rather than a cul-

334 / HIGH PLAINS AND CANYONLANDS

ture context. Holden followed this lead,
using terms such as Canadian culture,
Panhandle Canadian culture, and Slab
House culture. As is the case with Moore-
head, Holden’s terminology focused more
on geographical or architectural elements
of the sites than on relationships to other
areas. E. B. Sayles, while using a south-
western classiﬁcation system, simply re-
ferred to Antelope Creek sites as the Pan-
handle phase. However, it was too early
for the temporal-spatial deﬁnition of
phase in a general sense, and the term
was viewed as a southwestern derivation.
Floyd Studer added to what was becom-
ing a culture area classiﬁcation problem
by referring to Antelope Creek sites as
Post-Basketmaker culture, Texas Pan-
handle culture, or Pueblo culture. Two
of his terms are clearly southwestern in
origin and hint of relationships to the
Southwest.

It was not until Alex Krieger’s (1946)

efforts to systematize the cultural-taxo-
nomic nomenclature in the 1940s that
Antelope Creek characterizations were
scrutinized and a more pragmatic set of
terms was utilized to deﬁne this complex
culture. While establishing the “Pan-
handle aspect,” Krieger more succinctly
deﬁned the complicated set of material
traits and architecture as the Antelope
Creek focus, pointing out that temporal
parameters were inadequate for more
reﬁned treatment. The Panhandle aspect
remained a viable concept until the
1960s. The only challenge during this pe-
riod was Virginia Watson’s (1950) effort
to establish the Oklahoma Panhandle An-
telope Creek–like sites as a separate com-
plex, the Optima focus. This concept met
with little acceptance, and the “Antelope
Creek focus” remained as a consensus
term. Somewhat later, Robert G. Camp-
bell amended the term “Panhandle as-
pect” to include the Antelope Creek focus
as well as the Apishapa focus (R. Camp-
bell 1969). Fred Schneider (1969) argued
that it was more acceptable to deﬁne a
Panhandle aspect with no subunits. How-
ever, because of Campbell’s work with
the Apishapa focus, this proposal also was
seen as unduly complicating the taxon-
omy of the region.

In the 1980s, Lintz (1986) revised this

cultural historical framework based on
the variant concept as discussed by Don-
ald J. Lehmer (1954). With Lintz’s re-

classiﬁcation, the Panhandle aspect be-
came the Upper Canark variant. Within
this variant were the Antelope Creek
phase and the Apishapa phase. Somewhat
later, David Hughes and Alicia Hughes-
Jones (1987) identiﬁed the Handley Ru-
ins and Buried City as a separate cultural
entity, the Buried City Complex. Thus,
as it currently stands, the Upper Canark
variant comprises the Antelope Creek
phase, the Apishapa phase, and the Buried
City Complex. The Zimms Complex,
initially viewed as possibly related to the
Upper Canark variant, is probably more
properly associated with the Redbed
Plains variant (Brooks and Drass 1996).
Undoubtedly, with further reﬁnement of
the chronology for this cultural expres-
sion, and increasing understanding of
social and political actions within the re-
gion, the taxonomic structure of the re-
gion will be enhanced.

Adjacent Cultural Complexes

Antelope Creek phase people existed
alongside a number of other Plains socie-
ties as well as groups in the Southwest (see
Fig. 11.1). The Apishapa phase that oc-
curs in southeastern Colorado is similar
to Antelope Creek in the presence of ma-
sonry architecture and some aspects of the
material culture (R. Campbell 1969; Gun-
nerson 1989; Ireland 1968). Also within
the region of the Antelope Creek phase is
the Buried City Complex (D. Hughes
1986). Buried City masonry architecture
is very similar to that at Antelope Creek
sites, but this culture contains a different
material assemblage and the subsistence
regime is one less focused on farming
and bison hunting. To the east is found
the Zimms Complex with its Antelope
Creek–like house ﬂoor plan but without
stone slab walls and with a more tradi-
tional Southern Plains cultural assem-
blage (Brooks 1989).

Origins of Antelope Creek

As is the case for most cultural-histori-
cal reconstruction, the origins of the An-
telope Creek phase have been the subject
of considerable interest. Unfortunately,
data pertaining to these origins have been
elusive. From my perspective, some of
the interpretations have served to further
confound this issue. With the obvious
presence of stone slab architecture remi-

niscent of the Southwestern Pueblo cul-
ture, some earlier researchers maintained
that the actual origins were in the South-
west (see Sayles n.d.; Studer 1931). How-
ever, others, such as Mason (1929), rec-
ognized the obvious Plains origin of the
material assemblage and considered Ante-
lope Creek to be a Plains-adapted society.
In subsequent years, many archeologists
examining these Panhandle cultural com-
plexes adopted the position that the Ante-
lope Creek phase was a Plains phenome-
non (Baerreis and Bryson 1966; J. Hughes
1968; Watson 1950; Wedel 1967). Jack
Hughes (1962) argued that Antelope
Creek was of Caddoan afﬁliation and
probably developed from localized Wood-
land populations. Contrary to this, David
A. Baerreis and Reid A. Bryson (1966)
argued that Antelope Creek populations
migrated south from the Central Plains
because of deteriorating climatic condi-
tions. The relationship to Plains groups
was supported by early physical anthro-
pological studies that demonstrated bio-
logical relationships to Plains physical
populations (McWilliams and Johnson
1979; D. Patterson 1974). Robert Camp-
bell (1969) attributed Antelope Creek
culture to groups moving from the Cha-
quaqua Plateau in southeastern Colorado
into the Panhandle region. Others sought
to explain the complexity in cultural iden-
tity to a multiple origin concept (Bous-
man 1974; Krieger 1946).

Lintz (1986, 218 –35) critically ana-
lyzed these multiple origin hypotheses.
His examination demonstrated that most
of these theories have some ﬂaws in their
arguments as well as in their supporting
evidence. In his conclusion to this reex-
amination, Lintz (1986, 253) suggests
that Antelope Creek represents an indige-
nous group (possibly the Lake Creek
Complex) that borrowed architectural de-
sign concepts from the Southwest, partic-
ularly the Pueblo II period architectural
style.

Since Lintz’s analysis, some additional
work has been done that bears on the is-
sue of origins of Antelope Creek. Begin-
ning with the Southwestern District
U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Overview
(Hofman et al. 1989b), Douglas Owsley
of the Smithsonian Institution initiated a
systematic study of the biological charac-
teristics of Southern Plains Village popu-
lations. This project followed on his many

(1993 –95), Owsley examined Archaic,
Woodland, and Antelope Creek remains
at the Panhandle-Plains Museum. Al-
though none of his research had been
published as of 2001, some results from
this work merit discussion. First, there
appears to be considerable confusion in
the craniometric analysis conducted by
Patterson (1974) and McWilliams and
Johnson (1979). Owsley’s work found
little to suggest a biological relationship
between Antelope Creek populations and
other Southern Plains Village groups such
as the Washita River phase or groups in
the Central Plains at this time. Further-
more, there seems to be little continuity
with earlier Archaic and Woodland popu-
lations in the region. Thus, Antelope
Creek may represent a distinct population
with little genetic afﬁnity with earlier
groups in the Panhandle or surrounding
Plains or Puebloan societies. While this
brings into question all of the preceding
arguments for the origin of Antelope
Creek, it does little to clarify the prob-

more easily explained from a biological
perspective. Individuals in the Buried
City Complex have physical traits much
like those found in resident Woodland
groups for the Panhandle. In this regard,
they are distinct from surrounding Ante-
lope Creek populations (Douglas Owsley
1998, personal communication).

no other new evidence on this origin
dilemma has come forth since the mid-
1980s or so. While Lintz (1986, 253)
suggested Lake Creek as a possible pro-
genitor for Antelope Creek, no additional
data have prompted increased support for
this argument. I would suggest here that
no clear linear argument can be supported
for the origin of the Antelope Creek
phase. Previously, I endorsed Lintz’s argu-
ment of an indigenous local group that
had a pronounced ﬂorescence in the
Late Prehistoric period. However, if local
Woodland populations are of different
biological (genetic) origins than the An-
telope Creek population, this argument
quickly loses credibility. It is clear that we
must await further data analysis and in-
sights to explain the origins of Antelope
Creek populations and how they came by

their unique mix of cultural and architec-

Biological Characteristics
of the Antelope Creek
Phase People

I have mentioned that earlier bioarche-
ological studies of Antelope Creek popu-
lations have emphasized close relation-
ships to existing populations of Southern
Plains Villagers (McWilliams and John-
son 1979; Patterson 1974). However,
biometric as well as discrete trait analysis
and paleopathological indicators have un-
dergone signiﬁcant reworking in since the
1980s and 1990s (see Buikstra and Ube-
laker 1994). Reanalysis of Antelope Creek
remains beginning in 1988 by Owsley
has resulted in a restructuring of our
perspective on these Panhandle groups.
Craniometric restudy of individuals from
Antelope Creek sites has demonstrated
that these people were roundheaded with
a moderate cranial vault. They were of
moderate height compared to other Vil-
lage Farming populations and had few
other highly distinguishing characteristics.
Washita River phase groups were long-
headed and had rather pronounced cra-
nial vaults. We also know from Owsley’s
work that Antelope Creek men exhibited
arthritic degeneration in the arm joints,
probably from mining of the sizable lime-
stone slabs used in house construction.
They also exhibited little evidence of den-
tal problems. This condition could have
been due to the large quantity of ﬂuorine
in the groundwater that would have been
absorbed and used as ﬂuoride by the
body to limit tooth decay. Overall, Ante-
lope Creek phase groups demonstrated
few characteristics of a group under se-
vere nutritional distress. Judith Habicht-
Mauche et al. (1994) conducted a study
of changes in plant use from C3 to C4
pathways using stable carbon isotope
analysis of skeletal remains. Their work
showed that there appeared to be little
change in the diet of Antelope Creek
phase communities through time. How-
ever, what was intriguing was a difference
between males and females regarding
diet. This apparent difference in nutrition
may be a function of Antelope Creek
men being out on long-distance hunting
forays, thus eating different plant or ani-
mal foods, while women, left at the vil-

Chronometric Assessment of
the Antelope Creek Phase

Slightly more than sixty radiocarbon
dates, roughly ﬁve archeomagnetic assays,
and some additional relative dates based
on southwestern trade wares and associ-
ated dendrochronology dates (Lintz 1986,
1991) have been obtained for this cultural
complex. These assignments place the
Antelope Creek phase in the Texas and
Oklahoma Panhandle region between
a.d. 1200 and 1500. I would question,
however, based on events in other por-
tions of the Southern Plains, whether
many of the accurate calibrated dates for
Antelope Creek would extend beyond
ca. a.d. 1450, which marks a major tem-
poral juncture between Late Prehistoric
Plains Village society and the ensuing
Protohistoric period. This same phenom-
enon is also observed in the Southwest
and Midwest. A number of researchers
have tied this phenomenon to signiﬁcant
climatic change occurring in the Central
and Southern Plains at this time (Artz
and Reid 1984; S. Hall 1983, 1985;
Webb et al. 1993).

Donald Blakeslee (1994) has con-
ducted a major revision in radiocarbon
dates based on a variety of correction fac-
tors. These revisions demonstrate a high
degree of contemporaneity between
Southern Plains and Central Plains vil-
lage traditions. Thus, settlement of the
Southern Plains and Central Plains by
Plains Village societies was a concurrent
process. There also does not appear to be
any longitudinal variation to the radiocar-
bon dates of Antelope Creek phase sites
in the Panhandle region. The conﬁrma-
tion of this conclusion, however, must
await trend surface analysis of radiocar-
bon assays and their occurrence on the
Panhandle landscape. I found it difﬁcult
to establish the temporal limit of Ante-
lope Creek phase settlements. While
many of the multiroom villages were oc-
cupied for considerable periods of time,
the calibration range for an individual
date and the standard deviation of the ra-
diocarbon sample make it difﬁcult to
qualify the duration of a speciﬁc site. A
site may be occupied for a limited num-
ber of years (e.g., twenty to thirty years).

Because the standard deviation of the ra-
diocarbon sample exceeds this range (e.g.,
ﬁfty years), it becomes impossible to fur-
ther reﬁne the period of time during
which a particular Antelope Creek settle-
ment was occupied.

Settlement and Architecture

Antelope Creek phase sites in the re-
gion are thought to number in the hun-
dreds. These settlements consist of tem-
porary camps; a hierarchy of habitation
sites including isolated farmsteads/home-
steads, hamlets, and larger villages (Lintz
1986); possibly some small bison-kill pro-
cessing stations (Brooks and Flynn 1988);
and quarry sites. The more permanently
inhabited sites are typically situated on
steep terraces, elevated knolls in the ﬂood-
plain, or occasionally, in more westerly
sites, on remote mesas. Surveys in the
Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles (Bro-
sowske and Bement 1998; Etchieson
1980; Guidry et al. 1979) have demon-
strated that the principal tributary streams
have a higher site density than do the
North Canadian and Canadian Rivers.
I suspect water quality issues may have
brought about this location choice. Cli-
matic change would have led to drier
conditions, the water table would have
dropped, and that change would perhaps
have led to higher mineral content in the
major river valleys. An alternate explana-
tion is that good land was often in de-
mand for both residences and agriculture,
prompting Antelope Creek groups to
place settlements near rivers on land that
was not ideal for farming.

The most distinctive element of Ante-
lope Creek phase settlement is the use of
large stone slabs in wall construction.
These slabs were used in single or double
rows, placed vertically to form the wall
base, and plastered in place with adobe
mortar. In a few isolated cases, the slabs
are horizontally mounted, as was the style
in the Southwest. Details of the masonry
construction vary greatly from site to site
and often from structure to structure
within a village. Lintz (1986) has attrib-
uted this variation to functional differ-
ences, engineering constraints, and design
changes over time. In his overview of
these masonry forms at the many Ante-
lope Creek phase villages, he identiﬁed
eleven unit types (Lintz 1986, 86 –129).

These types ranged from isolated circular
masonry structures with no doorway to
large rectangular multiroom dwellings
(Fig. 11.2). Widely spaced single dwell-
ings along tributary streams may reﬂect a
loosely aggregated community political
organization. At the other end of the spec-
trum were large compound room struc-
tures such as Antelope Creek Ruin 22
(Fig. 11.3), which resembled a single-
story pueblo and contained some thirty

rooms, although the archeological evi-
dence indicated that at least some of the
room blocks were accretional. Individual
room size ranged from less than 5 m2 to
more than 60 m2. There is also evidence
that settlement size as well as organiza-
tional structure underwent signiﬁcant
change midway through the Antelope
Creek phase. During the early portion of
the phase, there were greater numbers of
aggregated room units. Around a.d. 1350,

FROM STONE SLAB ARCHITECTURE TO ABANDONMENT / 337

it appears that residential construction
began to emphasize single room struc-
tures, although they were of greater size
than those present during the earlier por-
tion of the phase (Lintz 1986).

Lintz (1986, 133 – 41) established six
different types of residential aggregation.
Typical Antelope Creek phase dwelling
features included a passageway entrance, a
depressed central ﬂoor channel, and occa-
sionally a raised platform (altar?) found on
the west wall (Fig. 11.4). Roof supports
consisted of four interior posts usually
tethered around a well-prepared central
hearth. Storage pits that were subse-
quently ﬁlled with refuse are often pres-
ent within houses or in the village area.

There exists considerable information
on the nature of stone slab architecture as
well as its integration into the community
patterning of the Antelope Creek phase.
What is less well explored are the explana-
tory mechanisms regarding the function-
ality of such dwellings and the social im-
plications of the sometimes multiroom
residential units. Why construct houses
of stone slab architecture and what are
the behavioral implications of such con-
struction? It has been argued that stone
slabs were used as the preferred building
material because of the absence of a reli-
able source of wood timbers. However,
this argument lacks documentation of a
shortage of wooded zones where timbers
would be accessible. Similarly, if the
shortage of wood for timbers was the crit-
ical issue, should we not also expect other
groups on the western edge of the High
Plains to resort to stone for residential
construction? While Late Prehistoric
Plains Villagers in western Kansas and
western Nebraska constructed slightly
subterranean earth lodges (Wedel 1967),
there are no indications that stone was
used anywhere else in the region except
for the Oklahoma and Texas Panhandles.
Patricia A. Gilman (1987) has suggested
that for southwestern pithouses (as well as
above-ground pueblos), climatic factors
may have inﬂuenced architectural choices.
This explanation may also apply to the
stone slab houses of the Antelope Creek
phase. The ﬂoors of the houses can be
considered as shallow subterranean (usu-
ally less than 30 cm) in character. This
below-ground situation, combined with
the stone slab and plastered walls, would
function to ameliorate extreme heat and

cold. This particular architectural design
would also serve as a screen against the
often-brutal winds that push through the

The energy expenditure for mining of

the stone slabs and house construction
was considerable. While I can ﬁnd no
published reports on the volume of stone
slabs used in building some of the larger
aggregated room units at sites such as An-
telope Creek 22 and 28, construction
must have involved well over a ton of
stone. There are clear indications that
many Antelope Creek phase people suf-
fered from the physical effects of quarry-
ing this stone and shaping the slabs for
use in building (Douglas Owsley 1998,
personal communication). The level of
effort involved in stone slab architecture
construction implies that this was an es-
sential part of Antelope Creek society.
The use of masonry architecture also
probably requires greater logistical orga-
nization than the use of wood. Sources of
suitable stone would need to be identiﬁed.
Then, work parties would need to be mo-
bilized to mine the necessary quantity of
stone. Stonemasons undoubtedly had to
shape at least some of the slabs and to
oversee placement of the stones during
wall construction. Many Antelope Creek
phase villages display considerable skill in
wall construction and design, although
the work is not as precision-crafted as
that found in some southwestern pueblos.
As I noted earlier, stone slab architec-
ture also has behavioral implications that
pertain to residential permanence. Arche-
ologists working in the Southwest have
increasingly turned their attention to the
issue of housing construction and what
it means with respect to duration of
stay or village permanence (Diehl 1990;
McGuire and Schiffer 1983). Randall H.
McGuire and Michael B. Schiffer (1983)
have identiﬁed two aspects of time and
energy investment in construction: (1) the
minimization of manufacturing cost and
(2) the minimization of maintenance cost.
As they explain (McGuire and Schiffer
1983, 282), these strategies represent in-
verse relationships; greater investment in
production and construction reduces
maintenance cost, while investment in
maintenance promotes a longer use-life,
although with punctuated periods of resi-
dential upkeep. McGuire and Schiffer
(1983) further suggest that the anticipated

duration of stay is the most important
factor inﬂuencing production and main-
tenance energy expenditures. The im-
plications here are that production and
maintenance costs will be high when a
group intends to remain at given location
for a prolonged period. The use of stone
slabs in wall construction obviously meets
the criteria for high construction/produc-
tion cost as well as the designing of
dwellings for maintainability. This raises
some questions pertaining to the readjust-
ment of the settlement pattern that oc-
curred during the late portion of the
phase. If climatic deterioration was driv-
ing a change in settlement structure to-
ward a less aggregated society, why con-
tinue to invest in the high production
cost of stone slab houses? There is not
currently an answer to this question, and
it must await further research on Ante-
lope Creek residential units, especially as-
semblages found within the single-room
dwellings.

The high level of production and
maintenance needed for masonry archi-
tecture also potentially affects subsistence
practices. While Antelope Creek phase
groups may have participated in bison
hunts, it is not yet known whether these
were of the duration and distance from
the village that are documented for his-
toric Plains societies (see Weltﬁsh 1977).
The high production cost for stone slab
residences makes it unlikely that hunters
would be away from the village for up to
three months of the year. Similar argu-
ments have been made regarding more
eastern Plains Village societies such as the
Washita River phase (Brooks 1993a).

I am also intrigued by the nature of
the aggregated room blocks found in the
Antelope Creek phase and what they im-
ply about social organization. Lintz
(1986) has argued that Antelope Creek
has its roots in the Woodland cultures of
the Texas Panhandle, while others attrib-
ute this cultural complex to prehistoric
Plains societies from areas to the north-
east or the east (Bryson and Baerreis 1966;
J. Hughes 1968). It must be recognized,
however, that none of the Plains Village
societies contemporaneous with Antelope
Creek displays a residential architecture
pattern that features a communal, multi-
room structure. Many Antelope Creek
settlements have aggregate room blocks
that were accretional (rooms were added

to the original units over time); however,
this situation does not apply to all Ante-
lope Creek phase ruins. At some sites,
such as Antelope Creek 28, multiroom
units were added during the same con-
struction phase. It has been well demon-
strated in the archeological record that
kinship and social organization are re-
ﬂected in the spatial conﬁguration of resi-
dence (Rapaport 1969). From my per-
spective, the kinship/social organization
necessary for this type of aggregated, mul-
tiroom residential pattern is inconsistent
with what we ﬁnd for Plains societies. In-
stead, it bears a much greater resemblance
to the type of kinship structure expressed
at southwestern pueblos (Hill 1970). It
may not be a true southwestern puebloan
social organization, but there are more
afﬁnities to the Southwest than to the
Plains. More than anything else, this dis-
cussion demonstrates that much remains
to be learned about the nature of Ante-
lope Creek phase architectural practices;
current and future research efforts should
have greater focus on examining the
underlying structure of architectural
expression.

Subsistence

The subsistence economy of Antelope

Creek phase society was based on the
growing of cultigens, hunting, and the
collecting of edible wild plants, although
the particular mix of the economy proba-
bly varied seasonally as well as annually
based on climatic conditions and others
factors. In general, I doubt that dietary
practices varied much from those found
among other Southern Plains Village
complexes where hunting, especially of
bison, played an equal or greater role
than horticultural pursuits. However, as
noted earlier, much of the archeological
investigation of Antelope Creek sites oc-
curred in the early phases of methodolog-
ical reﬁnements in data recovery. Thus,
charred plant remains and small faunal
elements were highly underrepresented
in the available collections. Corncobs and
cupules, squash, and beans have been re-
covered from the excavations of Antelope
Creek phase sites. What is less clear, how-
ever, is the supporting cast of domesti-
cated native plants and wild species that
were undoubtedly harvested. Limited
studies have identiﬁed acorns, hackberry,
