mesquite, wild buckwheat, plums, per-
simmons, prickly pear, mallow, and cat-
tail (Dean 1986; F. Green 1967; Keller
1975). To demonstrate the disparity that
exists due to the lack of procedures such
as ﬂotation recovery, we need only look at
botanical recovery from the Lonker site
(34BV4). The Lonker site is a Plains Vil-
lage settlement located in the Oklahoma
Panhandle in northern Beaver County,
Oklahoma. Excavated in the winter of
1982, ﬁll from ﬁve refuse pits was pro-
cessed through a ﬂotation device to re-
cover macro- and microbotanical remains.
This procedure resulted in the recovery of
corn, bean, tropical squash, sunﬂower,
purslane, goosefoot, knotweed, domesti-
cated marsh elder, bulrush, and other un-
identiﬁed seeds (Brooks 1994a, 22 –23).
These problems in data collection
methodologies also exist for the study of
hunting practices. Larger species such as
bison, mule deer, antelope, and some
smaller species are present in the collec-
tions from the early excavations. Addi-
tionally, research by Dufﬁeld (1970b)
and Keller (1975) identiﬁed nineteen spe-
cies of mammals, thirteen species of bird,
six species of amphibians, and reptiles,
mollusks, and rarely ﬁsh (see Lintz 1986,
241– 45, for a more detailed account of
faunal exploitation). However, whether
the counts for minimum number of spec-
imens are a reliable witness to their place
in a procurement regime during the An-
telope Creek phase is questionable.

It does appear that substantial change
in subsistence practices took place around
a.d. 1350, at the same time that the settle-
ment system was being restructured.
While Dufﬁeld (1970b) argues that de-
pendence on bison declines after a.d.
1300, Lintz (1986, 243), to the contrary,
argues that bison procurement was in-
creasing at the expense of an agricultural
system suffering from climatic degrada-
tion. More recent analyses of this phe-
nomenon by Habicht-Mauche et al.
(1994), using stable isotope ratios to ex-
amine changes in the percentage of bison
in the diet over time, were inconclusive.
Interestingly, their study revealed that fe-
male diets were more varied, with greater
quantities of C3 and CAM plants com-
pared to what was found in the male diet.
There is also some difference of opinion
pertaining to the processing of bison.
One characteristic of bison processing in

the Antelope Creek phase is the shatter-
ing of the bison bone, presumably to ex-
tract bone marrow for grease production.
Lintz (1998, personal communication)
views this as remaining fairly constant
throughout the Antelope Creek phase,
even with the possible increase in bison
procurement. Jack Hughes (1997, per-
sonal communication), on the other hand,
perceives an increase in bone rendering
with the transition from early to late An-
telope Creek phase bison procurement.

There are also behavioral implications
pertaining to Antelope Creek subsistence
practices that have not been explored.
The ﬁrst of these implications involves
the agricultural system. We casually speak
of Antelope Creek people as agricultural-
ists. But what does this mean? What is
their commitment to agricultural produc-
tion? Ester Boserup (1965), in a seminal
study that addressed the conditions and
pre-conditions of agricultural growth,
noted considerable differences in the
complexity of an agricultural system and
how it evolves. Based on a study of Meso-
american agricultural societies, she identi-
ﬁed ﬁve incremental levels of agricultural
production: (1) forest-fallow, (2) bush-
fallow, (3) short-fallow, (4) annual crop-
ping, and (5) multicropping. Prehistoric
Plains societies have been traditionally as-
sociated with Boserup’s lowest level of
agricultural intensity, that of the forest-
fallow system or what has been more
commonly known as slash and burn agri-
culture. In a slash and burn system, po-
tential garden plots are burned off, with
large trees girdled for clearing. There is
only limited consideration of ﬁeld main-
tenance because the ﬁeld burning im-
pedes weedy plant growth and invasion
until the garden crops are well started.
Thus, the principal tool of the slash and
burn system is the digging stick, with
minimal use of the hoe.

Plains Village agricultural systems in

the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles
provide interesting insights into this tech-
nological adaptation. Returning to the
Lonker site, a Plains Village settlement in
the Oklahoma Panhandle, we ﬁnd only
digging sticks used as potential agricul-
tural tools; there were no scapula hoes
or other hoe-like implements (Brooks
1994a). Antelope Creek phase sites in the
Oklahoma and Texas Panhandles have
limited numbers of bison scapula hoes,

considerably less than the quantity of bi-
son scapula, horn core, and innominate
hoes found at Turkey Creek phase and
Washita River phase sites to the east
(Brooks 1987; Drass 1997). However,
the presence of the scapula hoe in Ante-
lope Creek phase sites creates a series of
questions about agricultural intensity.
Does the occurrence of these items in An-
telope Creek villages indicate that agricul-
tural intensity was perhaps greater than
previously identiﬁed for Plains Village
cultures in the Oklahoma and Texas Pan-
handles? Another possibility is that hoes
have a somewhat different function in
Antelope Creek sites compared to Bose-
rup’s observations. Striations (wear pat-
terns) on scapula hoes run perpendicular
to the blade and demonstrate consider-
able evidence of polish and/or sheen.
Thus, it would appear that the scapula is
being thrust into the soil either in a hoe-
or shovel-like function. This function is,
most likely, an agricultural practice such
as weeding ﬁelds—an activity that would
typically be conducted in bush-fallow or
short-fallow cropping. At this point, there
is no conclusive evidence to support alter-
native models of agricultural production.
Further examination of agricultural tools
from Antelope Creek phase settlements is
needed because these artifacts hold the
power to explain much about the agricul-
tural system in which they were used.
Animal exploitation by Antelope
Creek populations is somewhat more
difﬁcult to address. I have already intro-
duced the concept that bison hunting
may not have involved a lengthy period
away from the village. However, other
factors related to the Habicht-Mauche
et al. (1994) study of stable isotopes may
shed some light on this issue. Males ap-
pear to have a more dominant C4 path-
way signature. This situation possibly
suggests that the men were away from the
village for greater periods and were more
likely to consume bison than the women.

Technology

Artifacts recovered from Antelope
Creek phase sites reﬂect assemblages that
have adapted to local conditions over a
number of centuries. Thus, artifacts re-
ﬂect technological responses to the imme-
diate environment and also larger regional
contexts. Artifact assemblages present at

340 / HIGH PLAINS AND CANYONLANDS

Antelope Creek sites are typically repre-
sentative of prehistoric Plains Village so-
cieties. Artifacts manufactured of chipped
stone are most commonly manufactured
from Alibates agatized dolomite found at
quarries north of Amarillo, Texas. There
appears to be little use of materials ac-
quired from distant sources, with the pos-
sible exception of obsidian. Materials de-
scribed include arrow points, scrapers,
knives, drills or perforators, and crude
hoes. Typical arrow points include trian-
gular forms such as Fresno, Washita, and
Harrell; corner-notched varieties are
found less frequently. Bifacial knives are
often present in the assemblage and in-
clude the characteristic alternately beveled
(diamond) variety. Other bifacial forms
include the guitar pick scraper/preform
(Lintz 1986, 35). Unifacial end and side
scrapers are generally made from large
ﬂakes and reﬂect the Antelope Creek
population’s extensive hide treatment
and working industry. Numerous tools
are also derived from pieces of ﬂaking de-
bris that exhibit little or no intentional
modiﬁcation.

The chipped stone tool industry is an
interesting mix of expedient and curated
tool behavior (e.g., Binford 1979). Hunt-
ing weapons (the arrow points) appear to
be the more expedient tool, whereas the
butchering and hide working tools are
more intensively curated. This distinction
is evident in the manufacture of these
items. The triangular arrow points are
typically made from secondary or interior
ﬂakes derived from a ﬂake-tool reduction
sequence. The arrow points, while well
made, are not elaborately worked and
would probably not be viewed as a high-
cost item. This situation is further sub-
stantiated by the limited instances where
arrow points are recycled or retooled after
breakage. A much different situation is
present with bifacial knives and unifacial
scrapers. Bifacial knives, especially the
alternately beveled knife, are what Peter
Bleed (1986) has termed “overdesigned.”
The thick midsection accomplished
through alternately resharpening the
blade results in a tool that is both highly
reliable and also maintainable. It is likely
that these tools were perceived as high-
cost items; diamond-beveled knives are
one of the more extensively curated or re-
cycled tools in the chipped stone inven-
tory. I would argue that unifacial scrapers

are also manufactured for reliability. The
design of these tools emphasizes a thick
midsection that stands up well to the
high levels of stress resulting from hide
processing. These tools also involve con-
siderable manufacturing cost; the unifa-
cial design is only slightly less costly to
manufacture than a bifacial implement.
Unifacial scrapers were also being re-
sharpened and/or recycled upon break-
age, reinforcing their place in the tool in-
ventory as a curated item.

Implements of ground stone include
grinding basins, manos, abraders, ham-
merstones, ornaments, pipes, and celts.
Manos and metates are frequently of
southwestern style, and in some instances,
manos are of the two-handed variety.
Robert J. Hard (1990) has examined
mano length in the Southwest and found
a general increase in their length with
the transition from pithouse to pueblos.
A similar study of mano length during
the Antelope Creek phase might prove
informative in examining the issue of
changes in agricultural productivity from
the early to late periods. Sandstone abrad-
ers are virtually identical to those found
in the Turkey Creek and Washita River
phases farther to the east on the Southern
Plains. I suspect these abraders are repre-
sentative of considerable bone tool manu-
facture. Celts, typically made from ig-
neous materials, also occur at many
Antelope Creek phase settlements. To
me, it is somewhat paradoxical that the
occurrence of celts roughly parallels that
in more eastern Southern Plains Village
cultures, even though there should be
much less wood processing in the Ante-
lope Creek phase because of the dimin-
ished emphasis on wood in architectural
design. The presence of tubular elbow
pipes, although limited in number, attests
to some smoking activities. From recent
paleoethnobotanical studies on the South-
ern Plains, it is reasonable to assume that
tobacco was being grown and/or possibly
received in trade (Adair 1988). It is less
clear, though, whether the smoking of to-
bacco was strictly a religious practice or
whether it had become more of a social
function by Late Prehistoric times on the
Plains. Many of the pipes are of a distinc-
tive red stone originally thought to be
catlinite from the quarries in Minnesota.
Recent sourcing studies on similar pipes
from other Plains village sites in the

Oklahoma Panhandle have shown that
much of this material is from a separate
source in Kansas (Brosowske and Bement
1998). Lintz (1990b) has also identiﬁed
a source of red stone in eastern New
Mexico. Groundstone ornaments are
infrequently found and are usually in
association with burials. In a few in-
stances, textile samples were recovered.
Plaiting, twining, and coiling were the
manufacturing techniques utilized in this
basketry.

The ceramic assemblage is character-

ized by the predominance of Borger
Cordmarked, typically a globular vessel
with a rounded base and straight rims
that are either vertical or slightly ﬂared
(Fig. 11.5). Vessel walls are of moderate
thickness (ca. 5 to 6 mm) and are slightly
thinner near the rim. Surface treatment
consists of vertically aligned cord impres-
sions or smoothed-over cord impressions.
Because of the lack of distinctiveness
(clarity) in the cordmarking for some of
the Borger/Stamper Cordmarked vessels
noted at the Roy Smith site in the Okla-
homa Panhandle, Schneider (1969) has
commented that it appears the cord im-
pressions were applied when the clay was
nearly dry. There is also occasional treat-
ment of the rim in the form of castella-
tions or rim tabs.

A few collared vessels reminiscent of
the Central Plains tradition ceramic wares
occur at Antelope Creek site. Their oc-
currence has been used to support the hy-
pothesis of Central Plains people migrat-
ing to the Texas Panhandle. Chris Lintz
and Kathryn Reese-Taylor (1997) have
examined collared and noncollared rim-
sherds from the Antelope Creek 22 and
28 sites, as well as from the Roper and
Cottonwood Creek sites in the Canadian
River valley, and, using petrographic
analysis, subsequently compared them to
similar sherds from an Iktari phase site
(25NC29) in central Nebraska. They
found that there was no similarity in the
clay or paste of the Nebraska and Texas
Panhandle sherds, further dispelling the
idea of a migration of people out of the
Central Plains.

Southwestern ceramics occur at many
Antelope Creek phase sites. These are un-
doubtedly trade wares as their paste and
composition bear characteristic signatures
of Puebloan manufacture. Included are a
variety of Black on White types, Jeddito

FROM STONE SLAB ARCHITECTURE TO ABANDONMENT / 341

are erroneously called rasps. Freshwater
mollusks were used for spoons and scrap-
ers and were also shaped into pendants.

The bone tool assemblage is obviously
diverse. What is even more impressive is
the extensive labor investment in the man-
ufacture of agricultural tools. It is not
uncommon for broken scapula hoes to
display evidence of mends. This energy
investment is also interesting in that the
agricultural system is a marginal one
that came under increasing stress around
a.d. 1350. If agricultural productivity is
becoming less efﬁcient, why not revert to
a system that uses simple digging sticks
rather than hoes that require considerable
time and effort to manufacture? There
also appears to be a potential conﬂict be-
tween the use of bison bone for tool man-
ufacture and the use of bison bones in the
production of bone grease. Studies of ele-
ments being shattered for marrow extrac-
tion and grease production may provide
some clues as to whether there is compe-
tition among these two activities for bi-
son elements.

Trade and Warfare

Trade and warfare can be viewed as
alternative responses to the same issue
within prehistoric cultures, that of negoti-
ating social conﬂict (R. Hall 1977, 503 –
505; Pauketat 1994, 20). While most dis-
cussions of the negotiation of social con-
ﬂict have dealt with chiefdoms, there is
little reason to suspect that similar pro-
cesses were not operating at lower levels
of sociocultural complexity, such as that
of tribes. The formation of alliances be-
tween groups can be used as a means of
defusing intersocietal competition and
conﬂict. Alliances can be established
through a variety of social and economic
mechanisms ranging from marriage to ex-
change. Here, material and nonmaterial
“goods” represent trade and/or exchange
(Spielmann 1991b). In the well-studied
example of trade between southwestern
Pueblos and bison-hunting Plains socie-
ties, one of the more critical items of ex-
change is food (Spielmann 1983). This
trade can be viewed as a means of negoti-
ating conﬂict over desired foodstuffs:
corn by the Plains groups and bison
meat, hides, and possibly bone grease
on the part of the Pueblos.

The alternative to trade is organized

yellow ware, Lincoln Black on Red,
St. John’s polychrome, Agua Fria Glaze
on Red, as well as other glaze wares (Lintz
1986, 34). Most of these fall within the
established temporal range of the Ante-
lope Creek phase. Lintz (1991) has sug-
gested that these may originate from a
limited number of eastern “gateway”
pueblos.

As is the case with other Southern
Plains Village cultural complexes (e.g.,
Washita River and Turkey Creek phases),
the most distinctive technological assem-
blage in the Antelope Creek phase is that

of bone tools. Bone tools are abundant at
most village sites, with the most common
forms being bison scapula hoes and
squash knives, bison tibia digging sticks,
bison femur hide grainers, awls made
from rib edges, split ribs and splinters,
and split deer metatarsals. There are also
pins, pegs, and shaft straighteners made
from bison metatarsals, as well as wedges.
Smaller bones or splinters were used in
the manufacture of eyed needles. Antler
billets and tines were used to make
chipped stone tools. There are also forms
such as a modiﬁed bison rib that I suspect

342 / HIGH PLAINS AND CANYONLANDS

warfare. In warfare between societies, the
goal is to force competing groups to aban-
don land or resource areas that are con-
tested. This goal is accomplished through
major attacks on the principal settlements
with the expectation of forcing them to
abandon the whole region or to reduce
their numbers to the point that they are
no longer a threat. Another strategy is
using repeated raids to force groups to
abandon areas of preferred resources.

Trade can also be viewed as one among
a variety of strategies in risk management,
especially in regard to agricultural pro-
duction (Halstead and O’Shea 1989).
Under circumstances of scarce resources,
situational trade relationships would be
arranged with nearby groups. Trade
would be for foodstuffs, with the ex-
change item either being nonfood mate-
rial or an agreement to defer trade until a
later date (deferred reciprocity).

Trade Items

As discussed in the section on technol-
ogy, one of the most frequent trade items
encountered in Antelope Creek phase sites
is southwestern ceramic wares. These in-
clude a variety of styles: Black on White
wares, polychromes, yellow wares, and
glazes (Lintz 1986, 1991). It has been
suggested that most of these sherd types
originate with the more eastern Pueblos
in New Mexico (Lintz 1991, 91). Lintz
also notes that the trade in southwestern
wares appears to intensify through time.
In addition to ceramics from the South-
west, there are also olivella and columella
shell beads, conch shell gorgets and pen-
dants, and tinklers, as well as obsidian,
turquoise, and mica. Obsidian appears
to be a highly valued trade items, per-
haps equal to that of the southwestern
ceramics.

Obsidian as an item of trade has some

interesting characteristics. It is highly
portable and also an item of value because
of its quality and widespread use. The
Odessa Yates site in the Oklahoma Pan-
handle, another Plains village expression,
contains large quantities of obsidian; in
fact, there is more obsidian at Odessa
Yates than at all Antelope Creek sites
combined (Brosowske and Bement
1998). The large quantities of this mate-
rial at Odessa Yates suggest that there may
either be a centralized redistribution point
for obsidian or that a down-the-line redis-

tribution system was operating. Source
analysis of obsidian from Odessa Yates in-
dicates that most of the obsidian was ob-
tained from the Jemez Mountains region
of New Mexico (Brosowske and Bement
1998).

Trade items from the Southeast and
the Plains are extremely limited in the as-
semblages of Antelope Creek phase settle-
ments. There are virtually no Caddoan
wares from the Red River region nor are
there any Spiroan materials from the Ar-
kansas River valley. This may be a signiﬁ-
cant statement on Caddoan social rela-
tionships, as Caddoan sherds are found
on Turkey Creek and Zimms phase sites
in western Oklahoma (Drass 1997). They
do not, however, appear to extend be-
yond this region of western Oklahoma
into the Antelope Creek cultural area.
Few items from the Central Plains region
occur at Antelope Creek sites. These in-
clude principally Niobara jasper materials
in small numbers. As noted earlier, the
collared rim wares that are found at An-
telope Creek phase sites bear no relation-
ship to pottery vessels from Central
Plains settlements.

Warfare

In this chapter, I am suggesting that
the warfare seen in the Antelope Creek
phase archeological record is more a con-
sequence of the defense of territory and
competition for critical resources—such
as bison herds (protein), fertile soils, and
possibly lithic resources (e.g., the Alibates
quarries)—as suggested by Thomas Biolsi
(1984, 144 – 62) than the ethnocentrism
and revenge suggested by John C. Ewers
(1994, 397–98). Evidence for warfare is
present in the destruction of dwellings
and villages, the presence of fortiﬁcations
and/or other defensive structures, and
traumatic injuries resulting from combat
(e.g., fractures, puncture wounds, embed-
ded projectile points, and cut marks re-
ﬂecting scalping, mutilation, or dismem-
berment; see Brooks 1994b, 320). We
must also critically evaluate the spatial
distribution of the archeological and bio-
archeological data.

Burned structures are present at some,
but not all, Antelope Creek sites, includ-
ing a number surrounding the Alibates
chert quarries. While burned dwellings
are often attributed to raids, there are
many other possible reasons for burned

structures, including natural grass ﬁres,
accidents within houses, and the inten-
tional burning of the residence as part of
a mortuary ritual associated with the
death of a household member. Thus,
burned structures are a questionable
source of evidence on conﬂict. The only
burned residence clearly associated with
conﬂict is that found at the Footprint site
(F. Green 1967). Better archeological
support for evidence of warfare includes
the presence of defensive features. Along
the western perimeter of the Antelope
Creek region, four sites occur on high
mesas: Saddleback Mesa, Landergin Mesa,
Mesa Alamosa, and Congdon Butte. To-
ward the east, one occurs, namely Arrow-
head Peak. Considering the difﬁculty in
reaching these high places and their dis-
tance from water, I would suggest these
are either lookouts serving as defensive
outposts or sanctuaries where groups
retreated when invading parties were
sighted.

The bioarcheological data most clearly

reﬂect the conﬂict that Antelope Creek
phase people were experiencing with
other societies. Two individuals from the
Antelope Creek 22 site have physical in-
juries suggestive of conﬂict (Patterson
1974). An adult male has a perforation
of the right scapula, while an adult female
has a perforation of the third segment of
the sternum. More conclusive evidence
is present at the Footprint site (F. Green
1967). Here, the remains of eleven adults,
six subadults, and four infants were found
in three bell-shaped pits within a burned
subterranean structure. These individuals
were disarticulated and intermixed among
the three pits, and some of the remains
were charred from intense heat. Other
disarticulated remains were found in a
layer of clean sand and gravel overlying
the house ﬂoor but underneath charred
timbers from the burned house. In an-
other pit within the same structure, ten
adult skulls were found in a cluster, one
with an attached cervical vertebra and a
ﬂint knife of Alibates chert lying under the
skull (see F. Green 1967 for a sequencing
of these events). A similar cluster of adult
skulls was also reportedly found at a site
in the Oklahoma Panhandle near Guy-
mon (Texas County).

The evidence for warfare points to a
greater intensity of conﬂict in the western
portion of the Antelope Creek phase re-

FROM STONE SLAB ARCHITECTURE TO ABANDONMENT / 343

gion. If exchange and warfare were reﬂex-
ive expressions of the negotiation of con-
ﬂict, then the presence of greater trade
interaction with Puebloan groups to the
west would also explain the greater preva-
lence of warfare to the west (for a differ-
ent perspective, see Spielmann 1991a).
Lintz (1986, 251–52) has suggested that
a Puebloan group from the Chaco Can-
yon area moved into the middle Rio
Grande Valley, thereby disrupting well-
established relationships between the An-
telope Creek phase and Puebloan socie-
ties. One possible group involved in this
disorder was an eastern Mogollon group
living in the Sierra Blanca region of south-
eastern New Mexico and the Texas Pan-
handle. Here, trade in items such as bison
hides and meat may have represented the
motivation for violence. Another possibil-
ity was competition over Alibates chert,
the highly prized stone used in much of
the stone tool manufacture. For Puebloan
societies that were lacking in high-quality
lithic resources, Alibates chert may have
been a reason (although rather unlikely)
to forcibly expel the Antelope Creek
phase people from the region.

Mortality in Antelope Creek
Phase Society

Sample size and biased data collection
strategies signiﬁcantly impede our under-
standing of mortality in Antelope Creek
populations. Particularly during the early
years of archeological work, there was
little systematic investigation of graves
that were encountered at archeological
sites. There are forty-seven burials repre-
senting slightly fewer than seventy indi-
viduals from nine sites. Based on the size
of many Antelope Creek hamlets/villages,
this ﬁgure is a marked underrepresenta-
tion of the number of people likely to
have died during the occupation span of
most communities. Although earlier re-
searchers suggested that cemeteries may
have been present near villages, none of
these reports has been substantiated. Cur-
rently, the only documented cemetery is
Big Blue Creek (Couzzourt and Couz-
zourt 1996; Lintz 1986, 164). It is un-
clear whether village inhabitants did not
utilize cemeteries, instead burying indi-
viduals in separate locations, or whether
cemeteries were perhaps established on a
community-wide scale with one cemetery

serving a number of villages. The absence
of data limits our ability to establish mor-
tality proﬁles for communities, to exam-
ine the wellness of the population, to
identify the causes of death, and to un-
derstand the overall respect for the de-
ceased as reﬂected in mortuary practices.
Deceased members of Antelope Creek
society were typically placed as individual
interments in shallow graves. In most in-
stances, the individuals were buried in a
ﬂexed or semiﬂexed position. The ab-
sence of cremations would suggest that
treatment of remains did not follow the
mortuary pattern of burning observed for
the nearby Zimms phase (Brooks et al.
1992). Rocks were frequently piled over
the burials (87 percent), possibly in an ef-
fort to discourage scavengers (e.g., dogs
and coyotes). Roughly half of the recorded
burials (n!24) have been found within
houses, with the remainder occurring
within 50 to 100 m of architectural fea-
tures (Lintz 1986, 164).

Of particular note is the placement of
burials within structures. More than 80
percent of the twenty-four burials are ei-
ther at ﬂoor level or above the ﬂoor. Based
on additional information on this phe-
nomenon compiled by Lintz (1986, 165),
it appears that the deceased were interred
in the rooms at the time of, or shortly af-
ter, abandonment. He further suggests
that the use of the architectural features
may serve as markers for the society. I
suspect that detailed study of the nature
of the abandonment process and the mor-
tuary behavior associated with burial may
lead to better understanding of this prac-
tice. However, as few burials are currently
being excavated due to ethical consider-
ation of Native American beliefs about
the disturbance of human remains, de-
tailed research of this nature is not likely.
Attempts to discern status differentia-
tion through the examination of associ-
ated funerary objects has also proven elu-
sive. Lintz’s (1986, table 33) tabulation of
funerary inclusions with Antelope Creek
phase burials indicated that slightly more
than half of the studied burials contained
grave offerings. There does not appear to
be any marked discrimination based on
age or sex; children and adults, males and
females exhibit approximately the same
proportions of funerary objects. The only
revealing status information comes from
examination of funerary object distribu-

tion by category when compared to age
and sex criteria (Lintz 1986, table 34). If
we discount the burials from the Foot-
print site, which may represent special-
ized mortuary practices related to a con-
ﬂict event, there are some interesting
patterns in grave associations. First, non-
indigenous grave goods are almost exclu-
sively objects of southwestern derivation.
They are also found only with women
and children (Lintz 1986, table 34).
Grave goods found with males, on the
other hand, appear to be of indigenous
origin. With the above-noted exclusion
of the Footprint site remains, there is a
clear correspondence in the association
of items with gender-related work activi-
ties. For example, there are no projectile
points found in funerary association with
women. It is my impression that the so-
cial dimension of mortuary behavior por-
trays two signiﬁcant patterns. First, there
is little differential treatment of deceased
members of Antelope Creek phase soci-
ety, and second, most of the status varia-
tion noted in burials can be attributed to
the presence of objects derived from the
Southwest.

Abandonment

The Antelope Creek phase represents
one of the more striking cultural manifes-
tations to appear on the Southern Plains.
This distinction is especially signiﬁcant
when we consider that this phase rapidly
disappeared from the Texas and Okla-
homa Panhandles sometime after a.d.
1450/1500. Two important questions
bear on the disappearance of the Ante-
lope Creek phase: (1) What are the fac-
tors that brought about the decline of this
culture and eventual abandonment of
their settlements, and (2) what happened
to the Antelope Creek people?

Lintz (1984, 1986) has stressed the de-

terioration of climatic conditions favor-
able to agriculture as a principal reason
for the decline in Antelope Creek socie-
ties. Around a.d. 1350, there are three
signiﬁcant changes in the settlement/sub-
sistence regime that he argues are indica-
tive of these stressful times. First, there is
a restructuring in architectural /residence
design. Greater numbers of single-room
structures replace the multiroom settle-
ments of the early subphase. This restruc-
turing, Lintz (1986) argues, is a means of

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

11-A2946  4/13/04  12:22 PM  Page 344

344 / HIGH PLAINS AND CANYONLANDS

dispersing the population to meet declin-
ing agricultural production. Second, the
settlement pattern changes from an em-
phasis on the main valley of the Canadian
River to drainages where spring-fed tribu-
taries are present. Such a locational shift
likely reﬂects a search for better sources of
water. Considering the labor investment
in residence construction, this shift repre-
sented a major commitment on the part
of the Antelope Creek people. They were
shifting their settlement location and con-
structing new stone slab houses, albeit
now as single-room dwellings. The third
consideration is what appears to be a sig-
niﬁcant increase in the procurement of bi-
son. However, John D. Speth and Susan L.
Scott (1988) have suggested this change
was a function of increased trade rather
than diminished agricultural productivity.
Lintz’s argument is well reasoned, es-

pecially in light of the climatic change
documented for the region (Baerreis and
Bryson 1966) and the abandonment of
settlements and regions taking place at
this time in the Southwest and the South-
ern Plains (Cameron and Tomka 1993).
What I ﬁnd especially compelling, how-
ever, is the commitment of Antelope
Creek people to retain a labor-intensive
architectural way of life. Why attempt
to retain this stone architecture pattern
rather than abandon it in favor of more
portable dwellings?

The other issue involved with aban-
donment of the Antelope Creek phase is
the question of where the people went.
Arguments in the past have suggested that
they moved onto the Central Plains to es-
cape drought conditions and evolved into
the Pawnee ( J. Hughes 1968). This argu-
ment is based on the remarkable similar-
ity in the internal house design of the
Pawnee and the Antelope Creek phase
(Weltﬁsh 1977). However, this hypothe-
sis leaves the Antelope Creek phase people
with approximately ﬁfty years to evolve
from the use of stone slab architecture to
earth lodges. Lintz (1986) and John Lud-
wikson (1978) have discounted this argu-
ment based on chronological consider-
ations and ethnohistoric accounts. It is

more difﬁcult to assess the argument that
Antelope Creek people evolved into one
or more of the nomadic bison-hunting
groups encountered by Coronado in
1541. If so, then the ethnohistories and
tribal oral histories are lacking informa-
tion on this episode in the past. A signiﬁ-
cant factor here is the absence of continu-
ity between the material assemblages from
the Antelope Creek phase and that from
the Jumanos, Querechos, Teyas, and pos-
sibly other groups found in the region
some ﬁve hundred years ago.

Information about the demise of the
Antelope Creek phase remains just as elu-
sive as that of its origins. However, we can
examine the nature of the abandonment
process and hope to gain some insight into
how settlements were abandoned and/or
rebuilt at new locations. By examining the
processes taking place when settlements
are permanently abandoned, I think we
can also gain some insight into the nature
of this people’s ultimate destination.

Conclusion

With this chapter I have reintroduced
some of the questions and paradoxes that
have plagued our understanding of the
Antelope Creek phase over three-quarters
of a century. While my summary of Ante-
lope Creek obviously leaves substantial
ground uncovered, it does discuss many
of the critical areas one must study in or-
der to understand this cultural complex.
It should be clear from this overview that
vast areas of the Antelope Creek phase are
poorly understood or not understood at
all. However, this situation is as it should
be, as it reveals our lack of understanding
and our need to better comprehend the
past. I have a few suggestions and com-
ments pertaining to the future study of
the Antelope Creek phase:

1. Most of the work conducted on the
Antelope Creek phase took place in the era
prior to reﬁnement of our data recovery
techniques. Some of the previously studied
sites may yield signiﬁcant new information
if further investigations are initiated. This is

especially true in the areas of subsistence
practices, artifact discard, and the examina-
tion of site abandonment processes.

2. Much of the Antelope Creek mys-
tique is linked to the biological characteris-
tics of the population. While study of this
area is clouded by the propriety of examin-
ing human remains, for tribes as well as
archeologists, systematic evaluation of the
biological nature of these groups is critical
to our understanding of the origin and
ultimate destination of the group and its
culture.

3. The Antelope Creek phase has been
bereft of much interest in archeological in-
vestigation for the last quarter of the twen-
tieth century. However, this scenario is
rapidly changing. In Oklahoma, one disser-
tation was recently completed on Antelope
Creek (Duncan 2002), and a second disser-
tation is well underway on another Plains
village cultural complex in the Panhandle.
There possibly may be an equal number in
Texas. This renewed study, I think, reﬂects
the lack of knowledge about this culture,
which is an obvious challenge in the arche-
ological community. It is to be hoped that
these studies will bring with them a clearer
understanding of this dynamic culture.

Acknowledgments

While responsibility for the content of
this chapter rests solely with the author, a
number of individuals have contributed
to its development. First of all, I am in-
debted to Chris Lintz for graciously al-
lowing me to explore the mystique of An-
telope Creek culture. He is the foremost
expert on this paradoxical and enigmatic
cultural expression and would have been
the most logical choice to write this chap-
ter if not for other commitments. I have
beneﬁted from discussing many of the
concepts introduced in this chapter with
various members of the Oklahoma
Archeological Survey. They include Lee
Bement, Scott Brosowske, Richard Drass,
and Marjy Duncan. Finally, I want to
thank my wife Pam for critically reading
this manuscript and improving the clarity
of some of my arguments.

The Archeology of the Post Oak Savanna of East-Central Texas

Ross C. Fields

The primary goal of this chapter is to
present an overview of the culture history
of the Post Oak Savanna of east-central
Texas. This aim is accomplished by sum-
marizing the wealth of data recovered
during the last two decades of the twenti-
eth century in and near ﬁve project ar-
eas— Cooper Lake, Lake Fork Reservoir,
Richland/Chambers Reservoir, Jewett
Mine, and Gibbons Creek Mine—that
provide a north-south transect along the
western edge of east Texas. This chapter
focuses on data from the two areas with
which I am most familiar (Cooper Lake
and Jewett Mine); I use them as a spring-
board to point out overall trends in the
prehistory of the region. Even within
these two areas, I chieﬂy discuss the
archeological data from the sites where
the most work has been done and where
components can be isolated. What this
leaves out are the data from survey and
testing projects, as well as the data from
excavated sites where the remains of mul-
tiple components cannot be separated.
Where appropriate and feasible, informa-
tion from the other project areas listed
above is discussed, but I have not at-
tempted detailed evaluations of the arche-
ological data from these other projects.
The Post Oak Savanna occupies that
part of the western Gulf Coast Plain that
lies between the pine forests of deep east
Texas and the Blackland Prairie to the
west (Fig. 12.1). As such, it is at the west-
ern edge of the eastern U.S. woodlands.

As the name indicates, it is a vegetational
region characterized by hardwood for-
ests mixed with prairies. The forests are
dominated by a variety of species of nut-
producing oaks and hickories, and these
natural plants apparently played a vital
role in prehistoric subsistence. The region
also supports a rich fauna, with taxa such
as white-tailed deer, turtles, and various
small mammals being especially impor-
tant prehistorically.

The southern part of the area under
study here is drained by the southeastward-
ﬂowing Trinity and Brazos Rivers, while
the Sulphur and Sabine Rivers ﬂow east-
ward through the northern part. The cli-
mate throughout the region is temperate.
Mean annual temperatures range from
63° F in Delta County in the north to
68° F in Grimes County in the south, with
a corresponding increase in the length
of the growing season from 233 days to
278 days. Mean annual precipitation
varies from 36.6 inches to 45.0 inches;
rainfall tends to be more abundant in the
northern counties (Delta, Hopkins, Rains,
Van Zandt, and Wood) and in Grimes
and Madison Counties at the southeast-
ern edge of the region, while rainfall aver-
ages less than 40 inches elsewhere (Nat-
ural Fibers Information Center 1987).
Just when this modern climate, and
ﬂora and fauna approximating those of
the Historic period prior to disruption by
modern land use practices, became estab-
lished remains debatable, but the data

347

presented by Michael B. Collins and
C. Britt Bousman (1993, 59) suggest that
this happened about three thousand years
ago. Offering abundant natural resources,
the region was occupied intensively by
Native Americans at this time and later,
and this intensive habitation partly ex-
plains the high frequency of archeologi-
cal sites dating to the Late Holocene
(Fig. 12.2). Also contributing to the
scarceness of earlier archeological re-
mains, however, are changes in the land-
scape that removed many pre–Late Holo-
cene sites through erosion and deeply
buried others. Thus, while the record re-
covered to date is primarily a Late Holo-
cene one, this record almost certainly ex-
aggerates a general increase through time
in occupational intensity in the Post Oak
Savanna. Because earlier sites are so few
and paleoenvironmental conditions are so
poorly understood, this narrative focuses
mainly on the last few thousand years of
the archeological record.

The study area for this summary is
based only partly on environmental fac-
tors. This review is limited to the Post
Oak Savanna and the adjacent eastern
edge of the Blackland Prairie speciﬁcally
to avoid dealing with northeastern Texas
on the east, and north-central and central
Texas on the west. Thus, this study inten-
tionally skirts the Caddo heartland, and it
ignores the wealth of data obtained from
numerous projects on the central and
western Blackland Prairie, the Eastern

tance east of chert-rich central Texas (see,
e.g., Frederick and Ringstaff 1994).

The study area for this summary, then,

encompasses parts of fourteen counties,
extending some 300 km from Delta
County on the north to Grimes County
on the south. The northern edge is de-
ﬁned to include Cooper Lake because,
while it is actually in the eastern Black-
land Prairie, this part of the Sulphur
River valley has recently yielded impor-
tant information about the prehistory of
this edge of the Caddoan area, and Post
Oak Savanna habitat is present in part of
the Cooper Lake basin. The study area is
not extended any farther north, however,
to avoid the distinctly different (at least
during the Late Prehistoric period) Red
River valley (Bruseth 1998; see also Pert-
tula, chapter 13, this volume).

The second anchor for this discussion

is the Jewett Mine and adjacent Lake
Limestone. These project areas are about
200 km south of Cooper Lake in the up-
per Navasota River valley, with some of
the Jewett Mine sites straddling the divide
between the Navasota and Trinity Rivers.
Important projects between Cooper Lake
and the Jewett Mine include Lake Fork
Reservoir, which is in the Sabine River
drainage, and Richland/Chambers Reser-
voir, which is situated near where the
Trinity River enters the Post Oak Savanna.
One of the notable gaps in archeological
coverage for the region occurs down-
stream from this latter project area—the
stretch of the Trinity River Valley that
separates Freestone and Leon Counties
on the west from Anderson and Houston
Counties on the east.

The southern limit of the study area is

marked by the Gibbons Creek Mine on
the lower Navasota River. While the Post
Oak Savanna runs southwestward from
Grimes County all the way to the other
side of the Guadalupe River, the study
area discussed here does not extend be-
yond the Brazos River. There are two
main reasons for this delimitation. First,
the prehistory of the southwestern part
of the Post Oak Savanna apparently has
more to do with the archeology of central
Texas and the coastal area than that of
eastern Texas (see, e.g., Rogers 1995b,
1997). And second, while there have been
some interesting recent studies of sites in
the Brazos River valley (e.g., Bowman
1985, 1991; Roemer and Carlson 1987;

Cross Timbers, and the eastern Edwards
Plateau (e.g., Ray Roberts Reservoir,
Lewisville Lake, Lavon Lake, Lake Ray

well Lake, Navarro Mills Reservoir,
Aquilla Reservoir, Whitney Lake, Waco

North Fork Reservoir, and Granger Lake
[see Prikryl 1993 for a summary]). For at

were distinctly different from those of
east-central Texas, and this differential
provides some rationale for viewing them
separately. This is not to say, of course,
that these areas are irrelevant to the arche-
ology of the Post Oak Savanna. In fact,
one of the things that makes east-central
Texas interesting is its position at the edge
of the Caddoan area and only a short dis-

Pre–Late Archaic Period

Cooper Lake

Only one site with an isolable compo-

nent dating to this interval, the Finley
Fan site (41HP159), has been excavated
and analyzed (Gadus et al. 1992), al-
though it is likely that materials of this
age are intermixed with later deposits at a
number of sites, especially along the up-
land edge adjacent to the valley. The Fin-
ley Fan site is situated in the upper depos-
its of a thick Holocene alluvial fan. Most
of the archeological materials are Late Ar-
chaic in age, but a Middle Archaic com-
ponent (Analysis Unit 3/4) dating to
4500 –3000 b.c. was found in the lower
part of the excavations. The work in this
low-density cultural deposit uncovered
four cultural features, all of which are
burned rock concentrations interpreted
as food-processing facilities or general-
purpose hearths, and recovered a small
collection of 465 lithic artifacts. The arti-
facts are dominated by unmodiﬁed deb-
itage, but small numbers of dart points
(one Yantis and two untyped fragments),
other shaped tools, modiﬁed ﬂakes, cores,
and ground/battered stones were found
as well (Fig. 12.3). Because of poor pres-
ervation, no faunal or macrobotanical re-
mains were recovered.

The remains appear to represent small
occupational loci adjacent to the hearths.
The intensity of use appears to have been
quite low, and comparisons with later sites
at Cooper Lake suggest that the Middle
Archaic occupations of Finley Fan were
relatively short lived and infrequent.
Nonetheless, the materials recovered are

the Brazos and beyond to the Colorado
River have been relatively limited in scope
(with Rogers’s 1995b and 1997 work at
the Sandow Mine in Lee County being
an important exception), and this limited
scope makes it difﬁcult to incorporate the
results of these projects into a cultural-
historical narrative.

The summary below is broken down

into three major time periods, the ﬁrst
dealing with archeology that is more than
about four thousand years old (i.e., pre-
dating the Late Archaic period), the sec-
ond encompassing the interval from ca.
2000 b.c. to about a.d. 800 (i.e., the Late
Archaic and Woodland or Early Ceramic
periods), and the third discussing prehis-
toric archeology postdating a.d. 800
(i.e., the Late Prehistoric period). Use of
this simple scheme accomplishes several
things. First, it provides a way to separate
out the earliest remains, which are so
skimpy that it is hard to do more than
catalog their existence. Second, it partly
parallels traditional chronologies based on
technological changes in weaponry and
food preparation (i.e., the introduction of
the bow and arrow and pottery vessels),

so it should be easy to relate what is said
here to chronologies in other areas. And
third, it allows for more narrative ﬂow
than would be possible if the timeline
were segmented into a greater number of
temporal units, some of which currently
have only limited support in the radio-
carbon evidence.

One issue that this summary does not

address is use of the region by Native
Americans during the Historic period.
Materials dating to this interval are few
and far between in the project areas listed
above, with the most conspicuous historic
Native American sites in the Post Oak
Savanna— Gilbert, Pearson, and Vinson
(Dufﬁeld and Jelks 1961; Jelks 1967;
J. Smith 1993)—representing Norteño
or Wichita groups that moved southward
into Texas in the seventeenth and eigh-
teenth centuries. While this topic is
certainly an interesting one, its proper
geographic frame of reference is all of
north-central Texas rather than the Post
Oak Savanna. Further, except for the pub-
lication of the report on the 1960s excava-
tions at the Vinson site ( J. Smith 1993),
not much new information has appeared
recently on these “Norteño” sites.

Jewett Mine and Lake Limestone

Components predating the Late Ar-
chaic period also are scarce in the upper
Navasota River basin, with only two exca-
vated sites apparently containing substan-
tial materials dating to this temporal in-
terval (Fields 1990). Both sites are in the
uplands along a tributary to the Navasota
River, and the archeological remains are
contained in sandy colluvium. The earlier
of these is Analysis Unit 4/5 at the Lambs
Creek Knoll site (41LN106), where a
single radiocarbon assay of ca. 8000 b.c.
and the small collection of classiﬁable
dart points (one Golondrina, one Hoxie,
one Woden, one untyped specimen with
a parallel stem, and four untyped lanceo-
late points [Fig. 12.4]) suggest that a Late
Paleoindian–Early Archaic component is
present (although a couple of sandy-paste
sherds in these deposits attest to the in-
clusion of later materials as well). These
deposits contained a single burned rock
hearth and yielded a modest collection of
997 lithic artifacts. The formal tool as-
semblage contains an unusually high per-
centage of unifaces, with most of the
other tools being dart points and other
bifaces. Because of poor preservation, al-
most no faunal or macrobotanical re-
mains were recovered.

A somewhat later component was
identiﬁed as Analysis Unit 4/5 at the
Charles Cox site (41LN29A). While no
radiocarbon dates were obtained from
these deposits, a pre–Late Archaic age is
suggested for some of the remains by the
dated Late Archaic deposits above and by
the relatively high proportion of untyped
expanding-stem and parallel-stem dart
points (n!9; Fig. 12.5), although four
later points (Axtell, Gary, and Neches
River types) and a single earlier point
(San Patrice) are included as well. No cul-
tural features were found in this unit, but
scattered burned rocks suggest the former
presence of burned rock hearths. The
lithic artifact collection consists of 2,359
specimens, with the formal tools being
dominated by dart points and other bi-
faces. This component yielded no faunal
remains at all and very few macrobotani-
cal remains.

Late Archaic and
Woodland Periods

Cooper Lake

In the upper Sulphur River basin,
components dating to the Late Archaic
and Woodland periods are moderately
common, with the best excavated ex-
amples occurring at six sites: Finley
Fan (41HP159), Tick (41DT6), Spike
(41DT16), Johns Creek (41DT62), Hur-
ricane Hill (41HP106), and 41HP137
(Fields et al. 1993, 1997; Gadus et al.
1992; McGregor 1996; Perttula 1990a).
Analysis Unit 1/2 at the Finley Fan site is
the sole isolated and excavated Late Ar-
chaic component. Although datable ma-
terials were scarce, the evidence suggests
that this component dates to ca. 1650 –
150 b.c. The work in this part of the site
identiﬁed two burned rock hearths and
yielded 2,937 lithic artifacts. The formal
tools are dominated by bifaces and a vari-
ety of dart points, including two Dawson,
two Gary, two Kent, two Morrill, two
Trinity, one Wesley, one Yantis, four Yar-
brough, four untyped specimens, and
12 fragments (Fig. 12.6), but gouges,
unifaces, cobble tools, and ground/bat-
tered stones also were recovered. Faunal
and macrobotanical remains were not
preserved.

As in the earlier component at this
site, the Late Archaic remains appear to
represent small, hearth-associated occupa-
tional loci. The intensity of use, although
somewhat higher than for the earlier
component at the Finley Fan site, is low
compared to later sites in the area, and it
is suggested that the Late Archaic occupa-
tions of the Finley Fan site were short

both being situated in alluvium on low
ﬂoodplain knolls adjacent to the South
Sulphur River. Both have middens dating
to the Woodland and Early Caddoan pe-
riods and containing abundant artifacts

and faunal remains. The Woodland com-
ponent at Tick (Analysis Unit 3/4) ap-
pears to date chieﬂy to ca. a.d. 50 –700,
while that at Spike (Analysis Unit 3/4)
dates primarily to ca. a.d. 1–800. No fea-
tures were found in the Woodland com-
ponent at Tick, but the Woodland depos-
its at Spike contained two possible dumps
of hearth debris, one small pit, one large
pit, and one possible posthole. The arti-

Site 41HP137, which is located in an
upland setting near Hurricane Hill, is a
small site that appears to have both
Woodland and Late Prehistoric compo-
nents. Because of uncertainty about the
extent to which materials from these
components may be mixed, it is difﬁcult
to interpret 41HP137 on an assemblage
level. Regardless, the site did yield an in-
teresting collection of botanical remains
from two pit features that were dated to
the Woodland period (uncorrected dates
of 140 b.c. and a.d. 490). This collection
consists of hickory nutshells, cultivated
squash rind fragments, acorn shells, and
tuber and rhizome fragments identiﬁed
tentatively as Psoralea (McGregor 1996),
and this hints at a subsistence base con-
taining both wild and cultivated plants.
In sum, it appears that the Woodland

period saw a substantial increase in the
intensity of site use over the Archaic pe-
riod, and this change probably at least
partly reﬂects increased population densi-
ties. Occupations of at least moderately
long duration are suggested for most, if
not all, of the Woodland components at
Cooper Lake, and frequent reuse is indi-
cated for several. This increased redun-
dancy in the use of certain locales sug-
gests decreased residential mobility. The
Cooper Lake sites appear to have been
used for broad ranges of procurement,
processing, and maintenance activities,
but there is no evidence of fully sedentary
populations. Subsistence pursuits focused
on the hunting of a wide variety of wood-
land, woodland-edge, and aquatic taxa
and on the gathering of wild plant foods.
While there is some indication of the use
of squash, there is no evidence for sub-
stantial reliance on horticulture. Thus,
these Woodland components may be in-
terpreted as hunter-gatherer residential
bases.

Jewett Mine and Lake Limestone

The upper Navasota River basin was
occupied intensively during the Late Ar-
chaic and Woodland periods (Fields 1987,
1990; Fields and Klement 1995; Fields
et al. 1991; M. Mallouf 1979). Late Ar-
chaic components have been isolated at

the following eight sites: Buffalo Branch
(41FT311, Analysis Unit 3), Rena Branch
(41FT334, Analysis Unit 5/6), Charles
Cox (41LN29A, Analysis Unit 3), Alley
Road (41LN149B, Analysis Unit 4/5),
Moccasin Springs (41LN247C, Analysis
Units 3 –5), Old Union Bridge (41LT12,
Analysis Unit 4), Carl Sadler (41LT17,
Analysis Unit 4/5), and 41LT44 (Analy-
sis Unit 1). Components dating predomi-
nantly to the Woodland period are pres-
ent at the Rena Branch (Analysis Unit 4),
Charles Cox (Analysis Unit 2), Harris
Hole (41LN30, Analysis Unit 1/2), Alley
Road (Analysis Unit 3), Old Union
Bridge (Analysis Unit 3), and Carl Sadler
(Analysis Unit 3) sites. The Bottoms
(41FT89, Analysis Unit 3), Buffalo
Branch (Analysis Unit 2), Lambs Creek
Knoll (41LN106, Analysis Unit 3), and
Cottonwood Springs (41LN107, Analysis
Unit 2/3) sites have components with
mixed Late Archaic and Woodland mate-
rials or components dating to the Late
Archaic–Woodland transition. In all,
twenty components dating to this inter-
val have been isolated, and sixty-two of
the eighty-ﬁve radiocarbon dates from
archeological contexts at the mine pertain
to this interval (4000 –1250 b.p.; see
Fig. 12.2).

Three of these sites (Old Union

Bridge, Carl Sadler, and 41LT44) are sit-
uated along the Navasota River, ﬁve sites
(Charles Cox, Harris Hole, Lambs Creek
Knoll, Cottonwood Springs, and Alley
Road) are along tributaries to the Nava-
sota River, and four sites (Bottoms, Buf-
falo Branch, Rena Branch, and Moccasin
Springs) are along the upper reaches of
tributaries to the Trinity River. Old
Union Bridge, Carl Sadler, and Harris
Hole sites are in alluvial settings, while
the deposits at the other sites are primar-
ily colluvial. Midden staining was present
at Charles Cox (Analysis Units 2 and 3)
and maybe Old Union Bridge, and most
sites have limited ranges of feature types.
The features identiﬁed include the fol-
lowing: ﬁfty-one concentrations of burned
rocks interpreted as hearths, shallow bak-
ing pits, or discarded hearth debris (and
large quantities of scattered burned rocks);
one possible nonrock hearth; two pits of
unknown function; one concentration
of groundstone tools; and eight deﬁnite
or possible human burials. Seven of the
burials were at a single site (Cottonwood

Springs), where they constituted a small
cemetery dating to ca. 2800 –2000 b.p.
Six of the burials in this cemetery con-
tained cremations, and two were accom-
panied by exotic offerings (galena and a
slate gorget).

The artifact collections from these
twenty components consist of 59,441
lithic items and just 104 ceramic vessel
sherds. Most of the formal lithic tools are
dart points and other bifaces, but other
tool types—perforators, gouges, unifaces,
cobble tools, ground and battered stones,
pitted stones, and pigment stones— oc-
cur as well. Small numbers of arrow points
were recovered from some components
(totaling 29 points and fragments), but
they appear to be intrusive from later oc-
cupations. The dart point collection con-
sists of more than 400 specimens. The
best represented groups among the clas-
siﬁable specimens are Dawson (19 per-
cent), Gary (9 percent), Kent (8 percent),
Neches River (6 percent), and Godley
(5 percent), as well as a variety of untyped
expanding-stem (14 percent), parallel-
stem (14 percent), and contracting-stem
(7 percent) forms (Fig. 12.8). Dawson,
Gary, Godley, and Kent points appear to
have been used throughout this interval,
while Neches River points are most fre-
quent in Woodland components. Minor
types that are most common in Late
Archaic components are Axtell and
Yarbrough.

Most of the ceramics (92 percent)
are in Woodland components or mixed
Woodland and Late Archaic components,
and it is certain that the few sherds in
Late Archaic contexts are intrusive. The
ceramics are almost evenly split between
the sandy-paste ware that one would ex-
pect for this time period (e.g., Story
1990) and grog- or bone-tempered ce-
ramics, which are found more often in
later contexts at the mine and elsewhere
in the southern part of east Texas. Given
this, it is possible that many of these are
intrusive later specimens and that ceram-
ics were an even less prominent part of
the material culture than is implied by
the small number of sherds found in
Woodland contexts at the mine. Another
interesting aspect of the ceramic collec-
tion is the inclusion of two additional,
unusual kinds of pottery: two sherds that
are tempered with shell and two sherds
that are untempered but have a ﬁne

354 / EASTERN AND NORTHERN TEXAS

are predominantly hickory (Carya),
with a few sites also containing walnut
(Juglans). Based on these limited data, it
appears that subsistence pursuits focused
on woodland resources, and there is no
evidence for horticulture during this time.
Of these twenty Late Archaic and Wood-
land components, ﬁfteen (at eleven sites)
are interpreted as residential bases and
ﬁve (at three sites) as procurement/pro-
cessing locations. Five of the residential
base components (at three sites) are lo-
cated along the Navasota River, while the
others are in the uplands to the east. All
ﬁve of those in riverine settings are inter-
preted as general-purpose residential bases
(i.e., lacking a special focus on particular
activities). In contrast, the upland com-
ponents consist of two general-purpose
residential bases (at two sites) and eight
residential bases at which activities fo-
cused heavily on plant processing and sec-
ondarily on hunting (at seven sites). This
distinction suggests that Late Archaic–
Woodland settlement systems were sched-
uled based on the occurrence of plant
foods. Eleven of the residential sites ap-
pear to have been occupied with low or
moderately low frequency, suggesting low
population densities overall. A greater in-
tensity of use is indicated for the other
four residential bases, and this situation
probably reﬂects more frequent reoccupa-
tion, the relatively long-term nature of
the occupations, or both.

The ﬁve analysis units interpreted as
procurement/processing locations appear
to have had a primary focus on plant pro-
cessing and a secondary focus on hunt-
ing-related activities. Four components
(at two sites) are in the Trinity River ba-
sin in the eastern part of the study area,
while the ﬁfth is along a Navasota River
tributary to the west. The moderately
high to high frequency of use suggested
for three of these is surprising in view of
the low use frequency indicated for most
of the residential sites, and it suggests
highly scheduled reuse of particular re-
source patches.

The data from these twenty compo-
nents are consistent with the idea that
Late Archaic–Woodland groups were
chieﬂy foragers. Procurement/processing
locations suggesting logistical use are not
frequent, and the few that have been
identiﬁed suggest intensive exploitation
of particular locales. Settlement systems

are too few and too small to contribute
much information about the range of ves-

nondistinctive decorations (e.g., random
body punctations or incised lines).

Because of the sandy sediments and
poor preservation, some of the Late Ar-
chaic and Woodland components at the
Jewett Mine and Lake Limestone have
yielded no faunal remains at all. Where
animal bones have been recovered, they
tend to be few in number and highly
fragmented. The only identiﬁable speci-
mens are deer and turtle. Macrobotanical
remains are not well preserved either, al-
though most of these components have
yielded burned nutshells. The nutshells

appear to have been highly scheduled,
probably on a seasonal basis, with resi-
dential sites in riverine settings differing
from those in the uplands. Comparisons
with earlier components are difﬁcult, but
the much greater frequency of Late Ar-

Late Prehistoric Period

Cooper Lake

The Cooper Lake area has yielded
abundant information on the Late Prehis-
toric period, especially for the early part
(a.d. 800 –1200). Components dating
mostly to this interval have been fully iso-
lated at ﬁve of the excavated sites— Tick
(41DT6, Analysis Unit 2), Spider Knoll
(41DT11), Spike (41DT16, Analysis
Unit 1/2), Thomas (41DT80), and Doc-
tors Creek (41DT124)—and these are
the ones providing most of the summary
data below (Cliff 1995; Fields et al. 1993,
1994a, 1997; W. Martin 1996). In addi-
tion, the Hurricane Hill site (41HP106)
has an important early Late Prehistoric
component recognized on the North rise
(Perttula 1999). Many other excavated
sites (e.g., Manton Miller [41DT1],
Ranger, [41DT37], Luna [41DT52],
Lawson [41HP78], Arnold [41HP102],
Cox [41HP105], and 41HP137) have
cultural deposits of this age as well, al-
though separation of the early Late Pre-
historic remains from earlier or later ones
has proven difﬁcult.

Three of the six sites where early Late

Prehistoric components have been iso-
lated are on ﬂoodplain knolls adjacent to
the river and appear to be in alluvial con-
texts, while the other three are on old ter-
races (Spider Knoll and Doctors Creek)
or upland landforms (Hurricane Hill)
with limited colluvial deposition. All six
sites have middens, and all but Tick have
numerous cultural features, including
nineteen hearths, three possible hearth
dumps, one rock hearth, one shell-ﬁlled
pit, eighty-two other pits, thirteen pits/
postholes, eighty-seven postholes, three
shell concentrations, and thirteen human
burials.

The features associated with the early
Late Prehistoric component at Hurricane
Hill occur mostly in the part of the site
known as the North rise (Perttula 1999).
Most of the postholes may represent two
overlapping, and hence sequentially occu-
pied, houses. Because they were not fully
exposed, it is difﬁcult to interpret them
fully, but the number, arrangement, and
size of the postholes and their apparent
association with two middens, a number
of pits, several isolated postholes, two
hearths, and several burials indicate that
this part of the Hurricane Hill site sup-
ported a small permanent settlement dur-
ing the Early Caddoan period.

At the Spider Knoll site, the spatial
arrangement of the features suggests the
patterned use of the site over time. One
area was used most consistently for domi-
ciliary activities and outside activities as-
sociated with small and medium pits and
probably structures such as brush arbors
and drying racks. Another area was used
primarily for outside activities associated
with large pits, and a third area was used
chieﬂy for trash disposal. This patterned
use of space implies residential occupa-
tions that were long lived, but the houses
built at the site were not the sorts of sub-
stantial structures expected for year-round
occupations. Instead, they probably were
more like brush arbors (albeit large ones,
measuring 8 to 10 m in diameter) sup-
ported by small, widely spaced posts and
were more suitable for seasonal use. Deci-
pherable feature patterning was not found
at the Spike, Thomas, or Doctors Creek
sites, but this probably can be ascribed to
the more limited excavations there.

The artifacts from the ﬁve components

assigned most securely to the early part
of the Late Prehistoric period consist of
38,178 lithic items, 2,500 ceramic ves-
sel sherds, 6 ceramic pipe sherds, and
777 bone/shell /antler tools or ornaments
(mostly awls, but also engraved pins, antler
pressure ﬂakers, beamers, gravers/scrapers,
pestles, beads, and a ﬁshhook). The for-
mal lithic tools are dominated by bifaces
and projectile points, and other tool
forms—perforators, gouges, unifaces,
cobble tools, ground stones, pitted stones,
and hammerstones— occur in smaller
numbers. Arrow points occur about three
times more frequently than dart points
(855 versus 279), but the latter occur in
sufﬁcient numbers to show that the atlatl

continued to be used after the introduc-
tion of the bow and arrow. The most
common arrow point groups are Colbert
(29 percent of the classiﬁable specimens)
and Steiner (22 percent), with Catahoula
(7 percent), Friley (4 percent), Scallorn
(3 percent), Alba (2 percent), and a vari-
ety of other forms occurring in smaller
numbers (Fig. 12.9); the largest group
of untyped specimens have contracting
stems (9 percent). Gary points are by far
the most numerous among the classiﬁable
dart points (67 percent), with most of the
remainder typed as Gary/Kent (8 percent)
or Kent (6 percent).

Most of the ceramics (65 percent) are

tempered primarily with grog, while
bone, sometimes in combination with
grog, is the second most common tem-
pering agent (30 percent). Shell temper-
ing occurs infrequently (2 percent), and
these sherds almost certainly are intrusive
from later deposits at the sites. Because
the sherds tend to be small, it is difﬁcult
to determine vessel forms, but it seems
that they represent primarily simple
bowls, globular bowls, barrel-shaped jars,
small globular jars, and large restricted
jars. Only 14 percent of the pottery is
decorated, mostly with punctations
and/or incised or engraved lines. Relating
the sherds to deﬁned types usually is not
easy, but most of the decorated specimens
bear similarities to such Caddoan types as
Crockett Curvilinear-Incised and Pen-
nington Punctated-Incised (Fig. 12.10).
Present in small numbers are sherds with
decorative treatments (e.g., overhanging
incised lines, incised lips, or punctated
raised panels) that are more common on
ceramics from the Lower Mississippi Val-
ley (Phillips 1970), and some of these have
been classiﬁed as Coles Creek types. Also
present in consistently small numbers are
base-body sherds from ﬂowerpot-shaped
vessels that are strongly reminiscent of
Williams Plain. Most of the ceramic pipe
sherds are not very distinctive, but at least
one represents a long-stemmed Red River
pipe (Hoffman 1967).

All ﬁve sites yielded large faunal collec-

tions, as did the Hurricane Hill Early
Caddoan component. All show that deer,
turtles, rabbits, and mussels were impor-
tant subsistence resources, and all contain
a variety of other taxa as well, including
ﬁsh, amphibians, turkey and other birds,
and various small mammals. None of the

portance of maize and other cultigens re-
mains one of the major unanswered ques-
tions for the area. Based on the absence
of constructed mounds or elaborate buri-
als (all of the burials at Cooper Lake lack
grave goods), it is clear that the area was
occupied by groups with less complex so-
cial systems than those of early Late Pre-
historic Caddoan groups to the north,
east, and south.

Evidence for Native American use of
the Cooper Lake area during the second
half of the Late Prehistoric period is
much sparser, and it appears that the area
was essentially abandoned by about a.d.
1500. Only two excavated sites, Hurri-
cane Hill (41HP106) and Peerless Bot-
toms (41HP175), have isolable compo-
nents that date to this interval (Fields
et al. 1993; Perttula 1999), although
some of the early Late Prehistoric sites
discussed above, particularly Spider
Knoll, probably continued to be used
into the 1200s (Fields et al. 1993, 1997;
Perttula 1999).

The part of the Hurricane Hill site
that was occupied during this time is
known as the South rise. While the arti-
facts and subsistence remains associated
with this component have not been fully
analyzed and reported, the component
has been dated and the feature assemblage
has been isolated. The features consist of
four middens, two clay-lined hearths,
twenty-three pits, three burials, one dog
burial, and ninety-eight postholes. Most
of the postholes apparently represent two
overlapping houses with central hearths.
Because the hearths partly overlap and be-
cause several large interior postholes may
mark main support post locations for
both structures, it is surmised that the
structures were associated and used se-
quentially. The radiocarbon evidence in-
dicates that one structure dates to the last
half of the a.d. 1200s, with the other dat-
ing to the ﬁrst half or three-quarters of
the 1300s (Perttula 1997, 173 –75).
Neither set of postholes exhibits a well-
deﬁned pattern clearly indicating the
house walls, but Perttula (1999, 106 –
109) suggests that the two structures
measured approximately 6.0 by 7.5 m
and about 7.1 by 7.6 m. Based on these
two structures, the associated middens
and other features that may represent out-
side activity areas, and a possible third
structure, it is clear that the South rise

sites yielded bison remains. Hickory nut-
shells occur ubiquitously (but not abun-
dantly), and a variety of other kinds of
macrobotanical remains have been recov-
ered. Included are acorns, pecans, Pedio-
melum rhizome fragments, squash rind
fragments, maize, and seeds of Rubus,
vetch/peavine, hackberry, maygrass, sun-
ﬂower, knotweed, cheno-am, grape,
honey locust, sumpweed, bedstraw, sedge,
spurge, bindweed, pigweed, wood sorrel,
and wild plum.

The archeological data from the early
Late Prehistoric components at Cooper
Lake indicate an increase in the intensity
of site use over the Woodland period, and
this change probably reﬂects continued
increases in population densities. All of
the components summarized above show
evidence of long-duration occupations
and frequent reuse, which suggests in-
creased redundancy in site use and fur-
ther decreases in group mobility. The

sites appear to have been used for broad
ranges of procurement, processing, and
maintenance activities, and at least one
(Hurricane Hill) apparently supported
year-round (or maybe multiseasonal) oc-
cupation. The variety of features present
at most of the other the sites hints that
they may have been used as seasonal camp
sites. The macrobotanical remains indi-
cate primary reliance on wild plant foods,
with tropical cultigens making modest
contributions, and this theory may be
supported by the moderate caries rates
presented by Diane Wilson and D. Gen-
try Steele (1997, 231) in their summary
of the human remains from Cooper Lake.
On the other hand, substantial consump-
tion of maize is implied by the delta 13C
values ranging between "15.3 ‰ and
"17.6 ‰ for the collagen fractions of
bones from three Early Caddoan burials
at Hurricane Hill (Wilson and Steele
1997, 233). The issue of the dietary im-

stakes—and recovered a large artifact
sample consisting of 1,947 ceramic vessel
sherds, 7 pipe fragments, 1 ceramic bead,

other chipped stone tools (including an
unusually large number of small end
scrapers), 219 cores, 13,365 pieces of un-
modiﬁed debitage, 30 ground or battered

of the typable arrow points are classed as
Turney (37 percent) or Perdiz (34 per-
cent), with most of the remainder being
Cliffton, Fresno, and Talco (Fig. 12.11).
Both of the classiﬁable dart points are
typed as Gary.

The ceramic collection is unusual not
only because of the large number of sherds
but also because many of the sherds are
relatively large, allowing reconstruction of
vessel sections. The sherds are distinctive
in that 41 percent contain shell temper
(the remainder have grog and/or bone)
and 5 percent are red slipped. A number
of vessel forms are represented, including
several kinds of carinated bowls, simple
bowls, deep bowls, globular jars, large
and small cylindrical jars, and bottles and
a couple of the forms that are more typi-
cal of Plains vessels than Caddoan ones
(Fields et al. 1993). Nonetheless, most of
the ceramics can be related comfortably
to such Caddoan types as Ripley En-
graved, Avery Engraved, Simms Engraved,
McKinney Plain, Nash Neck-Banded, and
Emory Punctated-Incised (Fig. 12.12).
Only two of the pipe fragments are dis-
tinctive; one appears to be part of an
elbow-shaped pipe, while the other has
a short stem that is not typical of either
elbow-shaped or Red River pipes. The
bone tool collection, although small, is
interesting because it contains a grooved
bison (?) rib possibly representing a rasp.
Faunal remains were not well pre-
served, and only a small collection was re-
covered. The best represented taxa are
deer and turtles, with birds, small mam-
mals, bison, and pronghorn occurring in
smaller numbers. The macrobotanical re-
mains consist mostly of hickory nutshells,
with Pediomelum rhizome fragments,
honey locust and water locust seeds,
pecans, acorns, black walnuts, hackber-
ries, squash rind fragments, and maize
cupules occurring less commonly. The
subsistence data are consistent with the
interpretation of a mixed hunter-gatherer
and horticultural economy. The distribu-

supported a small permanent occupation
during the ﬁrst part of the second half of
the Late Prehistoric period. The delta 13C

from Burial 13 on the South rise suggests
that C4 plants contributed signiﬁcantly to
the diet, but it is difﬁcult to relate the
earlier carbon isotope data from Hurri-

certainty.

The Peerless Bottoms site is buried
within alluvial fan deposits along Finley
Branch on the south side of the South
Sulphur River ﬂoodplain. The chrono-
metric and artifactual evidence indicates
that it dates primarily to the latter part
of the Late Prehistoric period, probably
ca. a.d. 1400 –1500. The excavations lo-
cated ﬁve potential cultural features—
one hearth and four possible posts or

tional evidence suggests that the area
sampled represents an outside activity area
associated with an undiscovered structure,
and comparisons with other sites in the
project area suggest that this component
represents a single long-lived residential
occupation, probably a small farmstead.
In sum, the middle and late parts of

the Late Prehistoric period at Cooper
Lake are somewhat difﬁcult to interpret
because of the limited number of exca-
vated components, but it is clear that
there were changes in settlement strate-
gies from the early part of this period.
The two analyzed components appear to
have seen long-lived occupations involv-
ing broad ranges of activities, and at least
one, and probably both, were used by
sedentary groups. Limited residential mo-
bility is indicated, and these sites proba-
bly were similar functionally (i.e., they
were small farmsteads occupied by groups
with mixed hunter-gatherer and horticul-
tural economies). There is no evidence for
substantially greater reliance on cultigens
than during the early part of the period,
and there is no indication of a shift to a
bison-oriented hunting strategy, although
bison are present at Peerless Bottoms and
not at the earlier sites (except the Wood-
land component at the Spike site).

The small number of isolable compo-
nents dating to this late interval makes it
clear that this stretch of the Sulphur River
valley was occupied less densely during
this time than before. In fact, small num-
bers of late artifacts occur at many sites
that predominantly predate ca. a.d. 1200,
and because of their small numbers these
artifacts suggest that most of the late com-
ponents in the project area represent non-
intensive, presumably limited-purpose
use. Thus, there is reason to question
whether the two excavated components
discussed above are typical for the area.
From this perspective, it appears that
settlement systems during the second half
of the Late Prehistoric period may have
included limited numbers of residential
sites but relatively large numbers of lim-
ited-function procurement/processing
sites. This situation implies an increase in
logistical mobility over the early Late Pre-
historic period.
