ent population growth. There are only a
few well-dated Late Archaic period com-
ponents known in northeastern Texas,
however.

Some Late Archaic occupations in
riverine settings in the Pineywoods and
Post Oak Savanna contain earthen mid-
dens (e.g., the Yarbrough site along the
Sabine River), but generally, sites of this
age contain burned rock features and/or
concentrations of burned rocks as well as
small pits. The Late Archaic occupation
in Area C at the Unionville site (41CS151)
had a buried anthrosol or surface that had
been darkened or stained by cultural ac-
tivities, while within the anthrosol were
two clusters of burned rock features (Cliff
et al. 1996a). Large pits and rock hearths
in a Late Archaic component at the Her-
man Bellew site (41RK222) have cali-
brated dates that range from 1590 to
380 b.c. (Nash and Perttula 2000). At the
Mockingbird site (41TT550) in the Big
Cypress Creek drainage, the Late Archaic
component (dated 830 – 410 b.c.) con-
tained only scattered burned rocks and
small amounts of stone tools and projec-
tile points, suggesting that it was used only
as a temporary encampment or “limited
use” area. There are many other Late Ar-
chaic sites or components with relatively
abundant amounts of burned rocks from
hearth construction and use, along with
projectile points, bifacial and ﬂake tools,
and ﬂake debris. Cases of extensive burned
rock features suggest that the cooking and
bulk processing of plant foods in ovens
and pits were important to some Late Ar-
chaic populations in the region.

These settlement data are compatible
with higher population densities and lim-
ited group mobility but also a wide dis-
persion of camp and foraging areas, the
possible establishment of deﬁnable terri-
torial ranges, and a well-developed forag-
ing economy based on the hunting and
gathering of local food resources. There is
no paleobotanical evidence to indicate
that the Late Archaic populations in
northeastern Texas cultivated native plant
species (such as sumpweed, sunﬂower,
and chenopod), as was the case by the
ﬁrst millennium b.c. in many parts of
eastern North America (G. J. Fritz 1994,
25 –27). Nutshells and prairie turnip
(Pediomelum sp.) are documented in Late
Archaic components at the Unionville
site (Cliff and Hunt 1995; Cliff et al.

1996a) along the lower Sulphur River.
The extensive use of local lithic raw mate-
rials during the Late Archaic in the Sul-
phur, Sabine, Cypress, and Neches/
Angelina basins speaks to a more limited
interregional interaction at this time
(Fields and Tomka 1993; Perttula and
Bruseth 1995). By contrast, in the Missis-
sippi River basin of northern Louisiana,
Late Archaic sites are marked by extensive
quantities of nonlocal lithic raw materials,
particularly novaculite and Boone and
Pitkin cherts ( J. W. Saunders and Allen
1997, 19).

Woodland Period

The Woodland period (ca. 200 b.c. to

ca. a.d. 800) in much of northeastern
Texas, particularly from the Sabine River
to the Red River, is recognized primarily
by plain and relatively thick ceramic
bowls and ﬂowerpot-shaped jars, double-
bitted axe heads, the smaller and thinner
Gary projectile points, and later in the
period by corner-notched arrow points
(Thurmond 1990a). In several instances,
as at the Resch, Bert Davis, Tankersley
Creek, Herman Bellew, and Folly sites in
the Sabine, Sulphur, and Big Cypress
drainage basins (see Fig. 13.3), Lower
Mississippi Valley (LMV) related ceram-
ics (such as Tchefuncte Stamped, Chu-
rupa Punctated, Marksville Incised, Troy-
ville Stamped, and Marksville Stamped)
occur with some frequency in Woodland
period components in northeastern Texas
(Story 1990, 246). These ceramics may
be trade items that provide evidence of
contact and interaction between Trans-
Mississippi South Native Americans and
groups in the LMV, or they were ceramics
whose stylistic decorative attributes were
borrowed by local potters (see Perttula and
Bruseth 1995; Schambach 1982, 1998).
At Woodland period sites along the
Red River in southwestern Arkansas and
northeastern Texas, ceramics are abun-
dant and constitute a signiﬁcant propor-
tion of the artifact assemblages, while in
many other Woodland period sites in
much of northeastern Texas (particularly
between the Sulphur and Sabine Rivers),
the use of ceramics was not as prevalent.
This situation suggests regional differ-
ences in Woodland period food process-
ing (i.e., boiling of foods in vessels to
make them palatable and a change from
stone to wooden food preparation tools)

and dietary habits (i.e., an increased con-
sumption of carbohydrate-rich foods,
probably including some amounts of
maize). It is probable that there were also
differences in sedentism between Wood-
land populations across the region, based
on strong correlations between sedentism
and pottery making (e.g., Skibo and Blin-
man 1999, 172).

Later LMV Coles Creek period ceram-

ics (and expanding-stem arrow points
similar to the Colbert and Friley types)
are present in notable quantities in several
sites along the Sabine River and the Red
River, particularly at James Pace in a con-
text dated between ca. 1300 and 1000
years b.p. (Girard 1994) and at the gener-
ally contemporaneous Ray site (41LR135)
(Bruseth 1998). Similar ceramics occur in
stratiﬁed contexts at the Crenshaw (3MI6)
and Mounds Plantation (16CD12) sites
in burial mound features (Schambach
1997; Webb and McKinney 1975), and
the Woodland period is also when larger
villages and multiple mound centers
begin to be constructed on the major
streams (e.g., the Red and Sabine Rivers)
in the Trans-Mississippi South. Generally
contemporaneous components in the up-
per Sabine River basin have ceramic as-
semblages dominated by horizontally in-
cised decorative motifs on vessel rims,
and Friley arrow points also occur in as-
sociation (Bruseth and Perttula 1981).

To the south of the Sabine River, but
concentrated in the Angelina and Attoyac
drainage basins, Woodland period sites
contain plain sandy-paste ceramics of the
Mossy Grove tradition (Story 1990,
ﬁg. 39) as well as decorated ceramics
with LMV afﬁliation. Woodland period
components account for at least 25 to
50 percent of the known prehistoric ar-
cheological sites in the Angelina-Neches
conﬂuence area and points west (W. Mar-
tin et al. 1995, table 2; Perttula et al.
1993c) and represent the camp sites and
habitation locales of peoples that had sea-
sonal foraging-gathering and hunting
adaptations. Aboriginal pottery was
adopted and used by Mossy Grove groups
for the cooking and processing of plant
and animal foods by about two thousand
years ago, and by a.d. 600/700, if not
earlier (see L. Patterson 1995), the Mossy
Grove populations were using a variety of
stemmed arrow points for hunting.

Changes in the density and placement

PREHISTORIC AND CADDOAN ARCHEOLOGY OF THE PINEYWOODS / 377

of Woodland period sites across the land-
scape—particularly focusing on sandy in-
terﬂuves—have led James E. Corbin
(1998, 114 –15) to suggest that horticul-
ture may have been introduced in the
Neches-Angelina River basins at that
time. Corbin also suggests that the num-
ber and distribution of Woodland period
sites in that part of east Texas “may have
been tied to . . . moving closer to a sig-
niﬁcant plant food source (i.e., plants
that were restricted to valley margins
and/or the ﬂoodplain) whose use was fa-
cilitated by processing via cooking in ce-
ramic vessels” (Corbin 1998, 115). Settle-
ment data from the McGee Bend area at
the conﬂuence of the Angelina River and
Attoyac Bayou indicates that middens
and occupational components are present
in Woodland period contexts that range
from 0.5 to 8 acres in size (Dufﬁeld 1963;
Jelks 1965).

While there is much archeologists do
not know about the aboriginal peoples of
northeastern Texas during this period,
what has been learned over the last forty
or so years of the twentieth century is that
they were still primarily hunter-gatherers
who lived in increasingly larger groups
and resided for longer periods of time at
certain sites. The fact that some of these
sites have relatively substantial midden
deposits (particularly along the Red River
and in the upper Sulphur River basin
[Fields et al. 1997; Schambach 1982])
and some evidence for structures (proba-
bly daubed pole and thatch structures)
suggests more intensive occupations, de-
creased residential mobility, and higher
population densities, but the degree of
permanence is still less than that seen in
the subsequent long-term Caddo settle-
ment of northeastern Texas (Perttula et al.
1993c, 99). At the Ray site, for example,
portions of several late Woodland period
structures and two middens were inves-
tigated by the Texas Archeological So-
ciety in the early 1990s (Bruseth 1998).
Frank F. Schambach suggests that Wood-
land (or Fourche Maline) period settle-
ments along the Great Bend of the Red
River included “small to medium sized
villages of from 1 to 4 ha” (Schambach
1983, 5).

On the basis of the available paleo-
botanical information, Woodland period
groups may have cultivated squash (see
McGregor 1996) and used native seeds

and tubers/roots, as well as a variety of
woodland and aquatic animal resources,
particularly white-tailed deer. At the
Resch site, a typical case, the rather exten-
sive midden deposits (dated from cal b.c.
555 –354 to a.d. 71–261 at 1-sigma)
contained only burned rock features
(probably used for the cooking and bak-
ing of plant foods) and dense quantities
of charred nutshells and poorly preserved
animal bones (C. Webb et al. 1969). The
presence of chipped stone axes and hoe-
shaped tools in Woodland occupations
suggests that some horticultural practices
(perhaps the use of colonizing weedy an-
nuals) and forest clearance may have be-
gun. James E. Bruseth (1998) also sug-
gests that maize was also being cultivated
during the later portions of the period,
but stable isotope analyses of human re-
mains of some twenty-ﬁve or more Late
Archaic, Fourche Maline, and Forma-
tive–Early Caddoan period samples indi-
cate that maize was not a major part of
the diet of Woodland period groups (see
Rose et al. 1998). The examination of
skeletal pathologies in Woodland period
contexts from the Red River area and east
Texas indicates low levels of infection but
high levels of degenerative diseases rela-
tive to subsequent Caddoan populations
(Rose et al. 1998, table 6-4). These data
further support the idea that Woodland
period populations were primarily hunter-
gatherers with a nutritionally adequate
diet, who probably lived across the region
in relatively low population densities but
whose lifestyle was characterized by
chronic stress (on the joints) and heavy
workloads (Rose et al. 1998, 121). Maize
is also poorly represented in the archeo-
logical record before ca. a.d. 700 –900.

In much of northeastern Texas, Wood-

land period sites are not very common,
perhaps because much of the area was not
heavily settled during this time (e.g.,
Story 1990, 310). In the Cypress Creek
basin, for instance, most Woodland pe-
riod components were “limited use sites
(i.e., rather short term camps) and . . .
only a few . . . were small settlements”
(Story 1990, 310). Dated components at
sites such as 41TT370, 41TT372, and
41TT409 (on upland projections and up-
land slopes) in that basin had burned
rock features and quantities of burned
rock from the apparent cooking and pro-
cessing of plant foods, and ceramics were

notably absent (Barnhart et al. 1997;
Kotter et al. 1993). One of the few well-
studied Woodland period components in
the Sabine River drainage is at the Her-
man Bellew site (41RK222; see Fig. 13.3),
where the component dates between
70 b.c. and a.d. 685 (Nash and Perttula
2000) and which had rock concentrations
as well as small and large pits, contracting-
stemmed dart points, and a small amount
of mainly plain ceramics. By contrast,
settlements of this period are common
throughout the Sulphur (see Fields, chap-
ter 12, this volume) and Neches-Angelina
River basins (Corbin 1998). In the Sul-
phur River sites, the Woodland period
components (with calibrated dates rang-
ing from 195 b.c. to a.d. 896) have mid-
dens, burials, and other features, and the
Hurricane Hill site (41HP106) had
ﬂexed, bundle, and cremation burials in
a small cemetery on a prominent sandy
rise (Perttula 1999) that dates between
cal a.d. 59 and 449.

No Woodland period burial mounds

have been documented in the Piney-
woods and Post Oak Savanna of north-
eastern Texas, although they have been
found in blufftop and alluvial valley set-
tings on the Red River in northwestern
Louisiana and southwestern Arkansas
(Schambach 1982, 1997; C. Webb 1984)
and on the Angelina, Neches, and Sabine
Rivers in deep east Texas (Story 1990,
310; see also Jelks 1965 and Jensen 1968).
Associated with the construction and use
of mounds in the Woodland period were
the procurement and dispersal of costly
nonlocal raw materials and artifacts, in-
cluding cherts, copper, and LMV ceramic
vessels that were included as grave goods
or caches in the burial mounds.

The two or three mounds at James
Pace (16DS268) on the Sabine River ap-
parently did not, however, serve as plat-
forms for burials or structures, or as caps
for these features, and their functional sig-
niﬁcance is equivocal (Girard 1994, 15).
The appearance of burial mounds (and
mounds covering crematoria) in the
broader region around northeastern Texas
does suggest that more complexly orga-
nized local groups did develop during the
Woodland period in these localities (see
Schambach 1996, 1997).

In nonmound contexts, there is also
evidence of mortuary or ritual practices in
the Woodland period. The Hurricane

communities. In the broadest sense, the
establishment of cemeteries clearly corre-
lates with an increasing sedentism in the

The Formative and the Early
and Middle Caddoan Periods

When we turn to a consideration of
the Formative (ca. a.d. 800 –1000) and
the Early (ca. a.d. 1000 –1200) and
Middle (ca. a.d. 1200 –1400) Caddoan
period occupation of the Pineywoods and
Post Oak Savanna of northeastern Texas,
there is an abundance of archeological in-
formation to draw upon. Many an arche-
ologist has been captivated by the beauti-
fully manufactured ceramics and other
material goods, the earthen mounds, the
well-preserved villages and hamlets, and
the existence of an ethnohistorical record
(e.g., Bolton 1987; Swanton 1942) that
has helped to bring to light behavioral
analogs with which to interpret the arche-
ological story of the Caddo people. Con-
sequently, our view of the lifeways of
these prehistoric Caddo groups is much
fuller, and perhaps more behaviorally
meaningful, than has been the case for
the Paleoindian, Archaic, and Woodland
regional archeological record.

First, Caddo archeological sites of
these ages are quite common throughout
the Pineywoods and Post Oak Savanna
(Cliff et al. 1996b; Story 1990; Thur-
mond 1990a). About 80 percent of the
more than ﬁve hundred radiocarbon
dates available from northeastern Texas
archeological sites pertain to occupations
at prehistoric and protohistoric Caddoan
sites (Fig. 13.5). The largest number of
dates fall in the Middle Caddoan period
(ca. a.d. 1200 –1400), followed by the
Early Caddoan period (ca. a.d. 1000 –
1200). Using calibrated ages and age
midpoints of 1-sigma calibrated age
ranges (Fig. 13.6), the largest number
of Caddoan radiocarbon dates fall within
the a.d. 1201–1300 interval (Perttula
1998b). While the number of dates in
this period is probably inﬂated to some
degree by the extensive series of dates
from the George C. Davis site (n!130;
see Story 1997; Story and Valastro 1977),
it does appear to be the case that Middle
Caddoan period occupations are rather
commonplace throughout much of north-
eastern Texas (Middlebrook and Perttula
1997), which conﬁrms the results of the
radiocarbon dates from the region.

Caddoan sites of Formative to Middle
Caddoan period age are situated primar-

Hill site contained a small cemetery on a
prominent hill, and the Mahaffey site on
the Kiamichi River in southeastern Okla-
homa also had a large cemetery with
ﬂexed and semiﬂexed burials without
grave goods (Perino and Bennett 1978).
Later Woodland period cemeteries with
nine to twenty-one or more burials—
dating after ca. a.d. 200 –500 —have also
been identiﬁed at sites such as Snipes
(41CP8; Jelks 1961) in the lower Sulphur
River basin (see Fig. 13.3) and at several
sites in southwestern Arkansas, including
Shane’s Village (Schambach 1982). These
later, shallow extended burials contained
an occasional whole vessel, boatstone,
celt, or chipped biface. The vessels in-
clude ﬂowerpot-shaped Williams Plain
and Coles Creek Incised types (see Jelks
1961, plate 4). The Crenshaw site also
had many late Woodland period extended
burials in village midden contexts (the
large village is estimated to cover 8 ha),
and these midden contexts also contained
ceramic vessels as funerary objects
(Schambach 1982, 152).

Comparable burial cremation practices

at the Hurricane Hill site in the upper
Sulphur River basin and the contempora-
neous Johnny Ford site (3LA5), an early
Fourche Maline village (ca. 200 b.c.– a.d.
300) in the Great Bend area of the Red
River valley (Stewart 1993), suggest the
existence of similar belief systems among
aboriginal Woodland period groups in
the Red and Sulphur River basins. Scham-
bach (1996, 36) describes the burials at
Johnny Ford as occurring in a “cremation
cemetery,” and he further suggests that
everyone in the village may have been cre-
mated (adults and children were also cre-
mated at Hurricane Hill) in the bluff-
edge crematoria at mound sites such as
Cicero Young and Bellevue (Schambach
1997, 57).

The identiﬁcation of formally bounded

cemeteries at a number of Woodland
period habitation sites in the Trans-
Mississippi South (see Rose et al. 1999) is
consistent with the existence and settle-
ment of distinctive social groups (based
on kinship and/or residence) of afﬁliated
individuals at sites and various locales
during that time. It appears that children
and adults were buried together in these
cemeteries, suggesting that these Wood-
land populations had an egalitarian social
organization within local settlements and

1997). Similar kinds of Early Caddoan
components have been identiﬁed at the
Spike, Thomas (41DT80), Doctors
Creek (41DT124), and Spider Knoll
(41DT11) sites at Cooper Lake. The lat-
ter site had numerous postholes (from
two possible structures and drying racks
or arbors), pits, and a large midden de-
posit (Fields et al. 1997, 93 –96). The
North rise at Hurricane Hill had a similar
array of features and extensive midden
deposits dating from ca. a.d. 1000 –1200,
including portions of two structures, sev-
eral middens, hearths, burials, and pits,
while the South rise had three structures
(two superimposed), middens, burials, a
dog burial, features, and an extensive
Caddoan ceramic assemblage from a
Middle Caddoan period component
dated about a.d. 1250 –1375 (Perttula
1999).

The Middle Caddoan Tigert site
(41TT36) on Hart Creek had a small
midden and an associated burial with
grave goods (K. Brown 1975), while the
contemporaneous component at the
Grifﬁn Mound site (41UR142) in the
Little Cypress Creek drainage contained
a dense midden and a large (more than
2 m in diameter and 1 m in depth) stor-
age pit feature, probably associated with
a Caddoan structure (Nelson et al. 1994).
The Musgaño site (41RK19) covered
about ﬁve acres and had at least one cir-
cular structure, midden deposits, numer-
ous pits (including two with charred
corncobs [Clark and Ivey 1974, 22]), and
an extensive ceramic and faunal assem-
blage (Fig. 13.7). One area of features to
the east of the one excavated circular
structure was suggested by John W. Clark
and James E. Ivey (1974) to have been a
granary built on stilts, with smoky ﬁre
pits under it (i.e., the feature was ﬁlled
with charred corncobs, which would
have produced a large amount of smoke).
William G. Driggers (1985, 96) suggests
that the Caddoan occupation/midden at
the Benson’s Crossing site (41TT110),
situated on an alluvial terrace along Big
Cypress Creek and occupied perhaps dur-
ing the late part of the Middle Caddoan
period (ca. a.d. 1300 –1400), was the
product of at least two extended families
living in a farmstead or small hamlet for
more than twenty to thirty years.

Larger communities (covering more
than ten acres) that occur in association

ily on elevated landforms (alluvial terraces
and rises, natural levees, and upland edges)
adjacent to the major streams, as well as
along minor tributaries and spring-fed
branches. Settlement locations near arable
sandy loam soils were preferred, presum-
ably because of good drainage for habita-
tion and for cultivation purposes.

The majority of these Caddo sites are

“permanent settlements that have evi-
dence of the structures, including posts,
pits, and features marking their residency,
along with the cemeteries and graves
where the dead were buried; the middens
where the animal and plant food refuse
was discarded amidst broken stone tools
and pottery vessels; and the material re-
mains of tools and ceramics used in the
procurement and processing of the boun-
tiful resources of the region. They repre-
sent the settlements of Caddoan commu-
nities and sociopolitical entities, and the
civic-ceremonial centers that were their
focus” (Perttula 1993c, 125). The distri-
bution of Caddoan settlements across the
landscape suggests that all habitats were
used to some extent, either intensively as
locations for the sedentary communities
and farmsteads (that may have been occu-
pied for single or multiple generations) or
periodically by groups in logistical camps
where speciﬁc natural resources could be
procured in bulk by the Caddos. Along
the Red River, a particular focus of settle-
ment was the natural levees in recently
abandoned meander belts, and these

habitats “served as an ideal context for a
dispersed community” in a major ﬂood-
plain landscape (Girard 1997, 156).

The most common types of Caddoan
settlements in the region during these pe-
riods of time appear to be small year-
round hamlets and farmsteads with circu-
lar to rectangular structures (Bruseth
1998; Bruseth and Perttula 1981; Cliff
1997; Cliff et al. 1996a; Cruse 1994,
1995; Largent et al. 1997; Middlebrook
1994, 1997; Perttula et al. 1986; Thur-
mond 1990a). These settlements some-
times occur in association with small
household cemeteries (see Goldschmidt
1935; Middlebrook and Perttula 1997).
A larger cemetery, with at least twelve to
eighteen burials, has been documented at
the Vasturtium site (41UR209) in the
Little Cypress Creek basin (Nelson and
Perttula 1997).

In the Big Cypress drainage, for ex-
ample, Early and Middle Caddoan period
components at 41TT372 are interpreted
as a “seasonal campsite or a small family-
based agricultural farmstead, at least on a
periodic basis” (Barnhart et al. 1997,
235), principally because of the lack of
middens or structural features. At the
Unionville site, Area C, 41CS150,
41CS155/156, Area B, 41BW553, and
41TT670 along White Oak Creek, Early
and Middle Caddoan components had
well-preserved middens, hearths, post-
holes, and other features (Cliff and Hunt
1995; Cliff et al. 1996a; Largent et al.

Certainly the most thoroughly studied
Formative and Early Caddoan period site
in the region is the George C. Davis site,
a large village and mound center on the
Neches River (Fig. 13.10). Calibrated ra-
diocarbon dates from village contexts es-
tablish that the site was occupied begin-
ning in the ninth century a.d. and then
was continuously settled through the end
of the thirteenth century a.d. (Story
2000). A large number of structures were
built on and adjacent to Mound A, and
the extensive structure rebuilding there
indicates that the Caddos preferred the
area for settlement (Fig. 13.11). Cali-
brated dates from a few contexts (such as
Units 11, 43, and 109; see Story 1997)
suggest that the site was inhabited to
some degree as late as ca. a.d. 1350.
There were three mounds at the Davis
site, including Mound A (ﬂat-topped
platform) and Mound C (burial mound),
built over the large pre-mound burial pit

F134 (Fig. 13.12) in the latter part of the
Formative Caddoan period and contain-
ing an estimated twenty-ﬁve to thirty elite
burial pits (Fig. 13.13), and Mound B
(ﬂat-topped platform), constructed about
a.d. 1200 or slightly earlier (Story 1997,
1998).

One of the more signiﬁcant Caddoan

sites investigated recently in the north-
eastern Texas Pineywoods, the Oak Hill
Village (41RK214), estimated to date be-
tween ca. a.d. 1200/1300 and 1450, has
at least forty-two circular and rectangular
structures. Some of the structures had
been rebuilt and some overlapped earlier
structures, particularly at the northwestern
end of the ridge and plaza (Fig. 13.14),
and they were arranged over the 3.5-acre
village in a circular pattern around a cen-
tral plaza area (Cruse 1994, 1995; Rogers
et al. 1994, ﬁg. 11; Rogers and Perttula
1999). Several small structures on the
eastern side of the plaza have been iden-

tiﬁed as possible granaries for the storage
of harvested corn (Rogers and Perttula
1999). A small mound (covering a burned
structure) is at the north end of the site,
and several midden deposits (including a
large, possibly communal trash dump
near the south end of the site) have been
identiﬁed and appear to be associated
with individual structures. Two large
circular structures have extended en-
tranceways that pointed toward the plaza
(Fig. 13.15), and their special form and
orientation suggest that they were proba-
bly public buildings used by the Oak Hill
Village community for special (public
and/or ritual) purposes. Ceramic analyses
and radiocarbon dating indicate these
structures were built after ca. a.d. 1350
during the extensive Late Village (Rogers
and Perttula 1999).

Another important Middle Caddoan

site is Tyson (41SY92) in the Attoyac
Bayou basin (Middlebrook 1994), dating

settlement contains evidence for struc-
tures and cooking as well as storage pit
features (Fig. 13.16), and it has extensive
midden deposits, well-preserved plant
and animal remains, and a small cemetery
containing child burials. Tom Middle-
brook (1994, 1997) suggests that the
Tyson site represents the residence of a
caddi or chieﬂy elite.

One of the calibrated dates from the
Tyson site was on mussel shell included as
grave goods with Feature 14, the burial of
a three- to four-year-old child accompa-
nied by many grave goods (Middlebrook
1994, 16). Among the burial offerings
were eight ceramic vessels near the head
and feet of the child (Fig. 13.17), two
large paired deer antlers over the child’s
head (perhaps as part of a headdress),
carved shell inlays near the head, two
carved bone earspools, thirty-two Olivella
shell beads, three columella beads from a

necklace, a turtle rattle, a cache of mussel
shell, smoothed stones, two pitted stones,
a cache of six deer ulna awls and two
beaver teeth, and a cache of lithic pebble
cores, ﬂakes, preforms, and a notched
shell point (Middlebrook 1994, 16). John
E. Dockall and Helen D. Dockall (1999,
557 and app. 1) suggest that the latter
two caches represent a generalized knap-
ping tool kit.

These Formative-Middle Caddoan
groups seem to have been horticulturists,
cultivating maize and squash along with
several kinds of native seeds (Perttula and
Bruseth 1983); they also gathered nuts
and tubers/storage roots and were proﬁ-
cient hunters of deer, ﬁsh, and many
other animal species. The available paleo-
botanical and bioarcheological evidence
(including stable carbon isotopes on hu-
man remains) from northeastern Texas
(and elsewhere in the Caddoan area; see
Rose et al. 1998) does not indicate, how-

ever, that Caddoan groups became de-
pendent upon maize and other domesti-
cated crops until after about a.d. 1300;
by ca. a.d. 1450, maize comprised more
than 50 percent of the diet (see Burnett
1990; Perttula 1996; Rose et al. 1998). In
portions of the Sulphur River basin, par-
ticularly the upper basin in the Cooper
Lake area, however, the use of cultivated
plants appears to have been rather limited
during these periods, with only small
amounts of maize and squash being re-
covered from the ﬂotation of feature con-
tents (Cliff 1997; Largent et al. 1997;
Perttula 1999; see also Fields, chapter 12,
this volume).

Both temple and burial mounds were
built by these Pineywoods and Post Oak
Savanna Caddoan groups. The larger sites
are important civic-ceremonial centers
containing multiple mounds and associ-
ated villages, and these generally date af-
ter ca. a.d. 900. The multiple mound

in the middle Sabine River drainage has a
single substructural mound that dates be-

1995), and there are contemporaneous
mounds covering structures with ex-

(41SM193) and Bryan Hardy (41SM55)
sites (see Walters et al. 1998). The Middle
Caddoan occupation at Redwine also
included an extensive midden deposit,
hearth and pit features, and a small ceme-

type) per burial (Walters et al. 1998, 26).

The Hale (41TT12) and Keith
(41TT11) multiple mound sites (see
Fig. 13.18) may also have had a civic-
ceremonial function in the Big Cypress
Creek basin, and the same may be said
for the Roitsch (41RR16), Wright Plan-

Sanders (41LR2) sites in the Red River

Roitsch–Sam Kaufman, four calibrated

Only a few possible Caddoan mounds
are known in the lower Sulphur River ba-
sin of northeastern Texas (see Fig. 13.18)
and southwestern Arkansas (Cliff 1997;
J. Miller 1986), and they appear to con-
sist of single mounds rather than large
mound centers with both earthen plat-
forms and burial mounds. The distribu-
tion, number, and spacing of mound cen-
ters, particularly the sites with multiple
mounds in east Texas and adjoining parts
of southwestern Arkansas and northwest-
ern Louisiana, clearly indicate that the
Caddoan peoples who built and used
these mounds were integrated into socie-
ties of considerable sociopolitical com-
plexity. The premier mound centers in
the Neches-Angelina River basins include
George C. Davis and Washington Square
(Corbin and Hart 1998; Story 1997).

and postholes in nonmound contexts,
and several large burial pits in a mortuary
mound (the Reavely-House Mound). No
clear evidence for on-site permanent Cad-

assortment of large sherd-ﬁlled pits (rep-
resenting many vessels) was encountered
in one area between Mound 1/2 and the
mortuary mound (see Corbin and Hart
1998, ﬁg. 14). These pits may represent
deposits from public feasting activities led
by Caddo elite (see, e.g., S. Scott and
Jackson 1998) who used the Washington
Square mound site as a ceremonial center
from a.d. 1200 –1400.

The radiocarbon dating of the Wash-
ington Square and George C. Davis sites
hints at the possibility that the Washing-
ton Square Mound center began to ﬂour-
ish about the time (after ca. a.d. 1250)
that the George C. Davis site was losing
power and social authority. This change
suggests that the Caddoan community
that built and used the Washington
Square Mound site—more advanta-
geously located eastward at the nexus of
north-south (later known as the Caddo
trace) and east-west (later known as the
Camino Real) aboriginal trails—achieved
preeminence at the expense of the long-
lasting (four hundred years) polity on the
Neches River. The George C. Davis site
was abandoned by the early fourteenth
century.

The Formative, Early, and Middle
Caddoan Pineywoods groups possessed a
rich material culture. Well-made, corner-
notched, and rectangular-stemmed arrow
points were common, along with silt-
stone and greenstone celts, perforators
and borers (Fig. 13.20), large Gahagan
bifaces, and a variety of more expedient
stone tools (unifacial ﬂake scraping and
cutting implements). Long-stemmed Red
River (Hoffman 1967) and cigar-shaped
ceramic pipes were made by the Caddos
at this time, as were ceramic earspools
and ﬁgurines (see Newell and Krieger
1949).

The Character of Prehistoric
Caddoan Ceramics

The most distinctive material culture
item of the Caddo groups living in north-
eastern Texas was the ceramics they made
for cooking, storage, and serving needs
(see Perttula et al. 1995b). The styles and
forms of ceramics found on sites in the
region hint at the variety, temporal span,
and geographic extent of a number of
prehistoric Caddoan groups spread across
the landscape (see Thurmond 1985,
1990a). The diversity in decoration and
shape in Caddoan ceramics is substantial,
both in the utility ware jars and bowls, as
well as in the ﬁneware bottles, carinated
bowls, and compound vessels. However,
prehistoric ceramics had been manufac-
tured in northeastern Texas for about one
thousand years before the development of
the Late Prehistoric Caddoan ceramic tra-
dition (after ca. a.d. 800/900).

Story (1990, 246 – 47, 277–319) indi-

cates that the earliest ceramics in the re-
gion date between ca. 500 and 100 b.c.
and are closely related to the kinds of ce-

Table 13.1. Caddoan Vessel Forms

ramics being produced in the Lower Mis-
sissippi Valley (LMV). Groups manufac-
turing these early ceramics were relatively
sedentary hunter-gatherers. South of the
Sabine River, the earliest locally produced
ceramics are plainwares with sandy pastes
(sharing similarities with the coastal and
inland southeast Texas ceramic Goose
Creek Plain; see Ricklis, chapter 6, this
volume), while north of the Sabine River
to the Red River, the early ceramics are
principally from thick, plain grog (Wil-
liams Plain) and bone-tempered (Cooper
Boneware) vessels (see Schambach 1998),
although sandy-paste wares are also pres-
ent in low numbers (Story 1990, 246).

Between the introduction of ceramics
in the region, and the emergence of dis-
tinctive Caddoan vessel forms and deco-
rative motifs around a.d. 800, the local
plainware traditions seem to have contin-
ued relatively unchanged. Also present,
although not in great numbers, are LMV-
related ceramics, including distinctive
Marksville, Troyville, and Coles Creek
Incised and Stamped vessels (see Phillips

1970) from sites such as Resch, Coral
Snake, Tankersley Creek, Herman Bellew,
and James Pace in the Sabine River and
Cypress Creek basins.

As Story notes, “sometime probably
between a.d. 700 and a.d. 900 (there is a
lot of room for arguing the age), Caddoan
ceramics came to dominate the northeast-
ern part of [Texas]. These ceramics are
distinguished by certain vessel forms (es-
pecially a long-necked bottle with a glob-
ular body and a carinated bowl), engraved
decorations, and other attributes. Al-
though the bottle form and engraving
may have an exotic origin, most of the
Caddoan ceramics can be recognized as
local developments with strong inﬂuences
from the LMV” (Story 1990, 247). A
diverse and distinctive ceramic assem-
blage characterizes the Caddoan ceramics
from northeastern Texas. Ceramics are
quite common in domestic contexts on
habitation sites across the region (i.e.,
it is not unusual to recover more than

ects, and assemblages with upwards of
100,000 sherds are not uncommon at the
larger sites), and they also occur as grave
goods in mortuary contexts (see, for ex-
ample, the large, well-analyzed sherd as-
semblages from George C. Davis [Newell
and Krieger 1949; Stokes and Woodring
1981], Deshazo [Fields 1981, 1995],
Benson’s Crossing [Driggers 1985], and
41MX5 [Brewington et al. 1995]). Much
attention has been paid by archeologists
over the years to the well-made ceramics
manufactured by the Caddo peoples, and
the analysis of Caddo ceramics is integral
to the study of any Caddo site in the
four-state Caddoan archeological area.

The Caddos made ceramics in a wide

variety of vessel shapes (see Reynolds
1992) and with an abundance of well-
crafted and executed (L. Johnson 1992)
body and rim designs and surface treat-
ments (Table 13.1). From the archeologi-
cal contexts in which Caddo ceramics
have been found, as well as inferences
about their manufacture and use, it is evi-
dent that ceramics were important to the
prehistoric Caddos in the cooking and
serving of foods and beverages, in the
storage of foodstuffs, as personal posses-
sions, as beautiful works of art and crafts-
manship (i.e., some vessels were clearly
made to never be used in domestic con-
texts), and as social identiﬁers (certain
shared and distinctive stylistic motifs and
decorative patterns marked closely related
communities and constituent groups)
(David et al. 1988; Thurmond 1985).
The Caddos made both ﬁnewares
(with very ﬁnely crushed temper [Scham-
bach and Miller 1984, 109]), including
bottles and many bowls, and utility wares
(some of the simple bowls, as well as the
jars that were made in a variety of sizes).
Almost without exception, Caddoan ce-
ramics were tempered with grog (crushed
sherds) or bone, although burned and
crushed shells were used as temper after
ca. a.d. 1300 among most of the Red
River Caddo groups (see Bruseth 1998;
Schambach and Miller 1984) and on later
Caddoan sites in the lower and upper
Sulphur River basin (see Cliff and Perttula
1995; Fields et al. 1994b). After adding
the temper to the clay, the kneaded clay
was formed into clay coils that were added
to ﬂat disk bases to form the vessel, and
the coils were apparently smoothed with
a round river pebble to create the ﬁnished

added before as well as after baking in an
open ﬁre, and commonly the vessels were
then burnished and polished; red ochre
and white kaolinite clay pigments were
often added to or painted onto the deco-
rations on bottles and carinated bowls.

These kinds of ceramics were designed

to serve different purposes within Cad-
doan communities and family groups—
from use as a cooking pot to the mortuary
function of a ceremonial beaker—and
this functional variety is reﬂected in dif-
ferences in paste, surface treatment, ﬁring
methods, decoration, and vessel form be-
tween the two wares. Both the early and
the later Caddoan ﬁnewares were usually
well polished and decorated with ﬁne-
line incised and engraved designs. The
earlier Caddoan ﬁneware designs are cur-

vilinear, rectilinear, and horizontal and
frequently cover the entire vessel surface
(Figs. 13.21a–n and 13.22a–p); other
ﬁneware designs simply are placed on the
rim, or sometimes on the interior rim sur-
face. In general, the earlier Caddoan ﬁne-
wares across northeastern Texas (and
indeed extending across much of the
Caddoan area itself ) are quite uniform
in style and form, suggesting broad and
extensive social interaction between
Caddoan groups across the region. The
use of a red hematite slip on interior
and/or exterior surfaces of carinated
bowls and bottles occurs with some regu-
larity in Early and Middle Caddoan pe-
riod ceramic assemblages in various parts
of northeastern Texas (particularly the
upper Sabine and Cypress drainage ba-
sins), and in the case of Maxey Noded

ceramics in individual drainages, or even
within speciﬁc smaller segments of river
and creek basins (e.g., Thurmond 1985,
1990a; Perttula et al. 1993a). This diver-
sity can be reasonably interpreted to be
representative of speciﬁc Caddoan social
groups. In historic Caddoan times, ce-
ramic vessel forms and decorations are
considerably more homogeneous across
much of the Caddoan area, suggesting ex-
tensive intraregional contact between
contemporaneous Caddoan groups (Pert-
tula 1992a, 154 and Table 14).

There is an interesting temporal trend
in the Caddoan ceramics from parts of the
Red River valley (in northwestern Louisi-
ana) below the Great Bend, the middle
Sabine River basin, and the Neches-
Angelina River basins for larger portions
of vessel surfaces to be decorated, particu-
larly with the introduction of brushing on
the bodies of utility jars. Consequently,
through time, ceramic assemblages have
lower proportions of undecorated sherds
(see Girard 1996, 24). Analyses of the
ceramics from several different contexts
in the Red, middle Sabine, and Neches-
Angelina River basins document this trend
nicely, with pre– a.d. 1200 Caddoan sites
such as Festervan (16BO327), 41SY81
(Robinson 1997b), and Bison (Mc-
Clurkan et al. 1966) having plain/deco-
rated sherd ratios between 2.97 and 4.80.
Thirteenth- and fourteenth-century sites,
including Vanceville (16BO7, submound
midden and residential areas) and Tyson,
have plain/decorated sherd ratios of 1.30
to 1.61. Late Caddoan sites at McGee
Bend Reservoir (including Walter Bell,
Etoile, and Wylie Price; see Jelks 1965),
Toledo Bend Reservoir (Salt Lick, Goode,
and Bison, Area B; see McClurkan et al.
1966; Woodall 1969), and Vanceville dat-
ing between ca. a.d. 1450 and 1650 have
ratios of 0.56 to 1.03. Just the opposite
trend is apparent, however, on the middle
Red River in Late Caddoan contexts, as
the plain/decorated sherd ratio in Mc-
Curtain phase contexts at the Roitsch–
Sam Kaufman site is 49.0. This ratio
clearly indicates that the McCurtain
phase ceramics are from a different Late
Caddoan stylistic tradition, one compris-
ing predominantly plain vessels and large
rim-decorated vessels with plain bodies.

The Caddoan utility vessels usually
have a coarser paste, a rougher surface
treatment, and thicker body walls than the
ﬁnewares, probably because the cooking
pot needed to withstand thermal shock
and cracking during use (see the experi-
mental studies by Schiffer et al. 1994 on
the thermal response of cooking pots).
Typical utility vessel shapes included small

to large jars (see Figs. 13.21t, 13.22q, and
13.23f, g) as well as a variety of conical
and simple bowl forms, most of the latter
in the earlier Caddoan ceramics (and the
historic Caddoan ceramics) having been
plain and unpolished. The utility vessels
have carbon encrustations, food residues,
and soot stains, suggesting they were em-
ployed by the Caddos as cooking pots.
Some of these kinds of vessels (those with
large oriﬁce diameters and vessel volumes)
were used primarily for storage of food-
stuffs and liquids.

While plain utility vessels were com-
monly used by Caddoan groups in north-
eastern Texas, particularly before ca. a.d.

1300 –1400 (see Table 13.1), they were
also decorated in a variety of ways. The
earlier Caddoan utility wares had hori-
zontal (see Fig. 13.21o–r) and cross-
hatched incised lines; ﬁngernail impres-
sions (see Fig. 13.21s, t); pinching,
ﬁngernail, and tool punctates on the rim
and bodies; and neck-banding, at least
south of the Sabine River (see Newell and
Krieger 1949; also Fig. 13.22q). Brushing
of vessel bodies is a form of surface treat-
ment that is notable after ca. a.d. 1300 in
the Cypress Creek basin, in Middle Cad-
doan period sites such as Carlisle and
Bryan Hardy on the middle reaches of
the Sabine River (Perttula et al. 1993b),

Caddoan ceramics were apparently
widely traded in Texas, as they have been
found in signiﬁcant quantities at north-
central, east-central, central, and inland
southeastern Texas archeological sites
(Story 1990, 247). The earlier Caddoan
ceramics (dating before ca. a.d. 1300)
were most widely distributed in the upper
Trinity and Brazos River basins of north-
central Texas (see Perttula et al. 1995b,
190), and in inland southeastern Texas,
while the Late Caddoan ceramic wares
appear to have been most commonly ex-
changed with east-central and central
Texas groups after a.d. 1300, as well as
with prehistoric peoples living along the
Trinity River in inland southeastern Texas
(McClurkan 1968). Caddoan ceramic
ﬁnewares were also traded extensively in
parts of the Midwest and southeastern
United States, most notably after ca.
a.d. 1300 –1400 with Native American
groups living in the Lower Mississippi
Valley of Arkansas and Louisiana (Early
1993, 232 –33), as well as far aﬁeld (such
as central Kansas [Wedel 1959]).

Other types of ceramic artifacts manu-

factured by prehistoric Caddoan groups
include ceramic earspools and disks, ﬁgu-
rines, and a variety of pipe forms (A. Jack-
son 1933, 71). The earliest types of Cad-
doan clay pipes were plain, tubular, and
cigar-shaped forms, followed by the long-
stem “Red River” pipes (Hoffman 1967)
with burnished and polished stems and
bowls; rectangular platform pipes and
some elbow pipe forms (Bruseth and Pert-
tula 1981, ﬁgs. 5 –11a, b) have also been
recovered in Caddoan sites dating before
a.d. 1200. The later Caddoan pipe forms
in northeastern Texas are biconical and
elbow pipe forms with small bowls (less
than 25 mm) and small stem diameters
(less than 25 mm) (see A. Jackson 1933,
plates 16 –18).

Two recent advances in the study of
Caddoan ceramics hold great promise for
increasing our knowledge about prehis-
toric stylistic, technological, and func-
tional changes in this material culture.
First, compositional analyses using petro-
graphic and chemical characterizations
are now being used on samples of Cad-
doan ceramics (see Fischbeck et al. 1989;
Steponaitis et al. 1996) to discern manu-
facturing techniques, the source and re-
gional distributions of particular wares,
and the functional characteristics of dif-

and at Knight’s Bluff on the lower Sul-

1961).

Engraved curvilinear, scroll, and hori-
zontal and/or diagonal motifs were com-
monly employed on the carinated bowls
and bottles. These designs include such
deﬁned types as Hickory Engraved, Holly
Fine Engraved, Spiro Engraved, Sanders
Engraved, and Haley Engraved for pre–
a.d. 1400 sites (D. Suhm and Jelks 1962;
R. Turner 1995). The types of decora-
tions and/or surface treatments on later
Caddoan utility vessels included neck-

banding or corrugation (Fig. 13.24c),
brushing, ridging, appliqué (Perino 1994,
ﬁgure 7e, f, h), and combinations of
zoned and diagonal incised and punc-
tated designs on the rim and body of jars
(see Fig. 13.24b, d). In historic Caddoan
times, dating after ca. a.d. 1650/1700,
rows of ﬁngernail punctations on the rims
of everted-rim Emory Punctated-Incised
jars are also a common decorative treat-
ment in artifacts from Caddoan sites
along the Red River and in the Sabine
River basin. Handles and lugs were pres-
ent on some of the utility vessels.

1961), while Belcher phase sites are dis-
tributed from about Fulton, Arkansas, to
below Shreveport, Louisiana (D. Kelley
1997; Schambach 1983; C. Webb 1959).
Upstream from the Texarkana phase, the
McCurtain phase represents another Late
Caddoan archeological complex (Bruseth
1998) (Fig. 13.26).

In the Texarkana and Belcher phase ar-

eas, sites include large, permanent settle-
ments with mounds and cemeteries,
hamlets, and farmsteads. The mound
centers were marked by the construction
of earthen mounds that were used as
temples, burial mounds, or ceremonial
ﬁre mounds (see D. Kelley 1998; C. Webb
1959). These settlements were inhabited
by sedentary Caddo agricultural commu-
nities with complex societies led by indi-
viduals with high status who lived at the
mound centers (e.g., Story 1990). Sites
such as Belcher (16CD13), Battle Mound
(3LA1), Hatchel (41BW3), Moore/
Higginbotham (3MI3/30), and Cabe
Mounds (41BW14) represent the larger
villages or towns (Creel 1996; D. Kelley
and Coxe 1998; Kelley and Guccione
1997; Perttula et al. 1995a; Sierzchula
et al. 1995), while known Texarkana
phase and Belcher phase hamlets or farm-
steads have been investigated at the Sher-
win, Atlanta State Park (Harris et al.
1980), and 41MX5 (Brewington et al.
1995) sites for the Texarkana phase,
and Cedar Grove (3LA97), Spirit Lake
(3LA83), and Cox for the Belcher phase.
These settlements—both the larger com-
munities and the smaller hamlets/farm-
steads—had pole and grass structures,
outdoor ramadas or arbors, household
cemeteries, and midden deposits from
household refuse. The 1691 Terán de los
Rios map of the Nasoni village on the
Red River documented the likely charac-
ter of individual farmstead compounds
(see Perttula et al. 1995a, ﬁg. 3) and the
layout of a dispersed village. In north-
western Louisiana, Belcher phase sites are
distributed along recently abandoned Red
River channels and its inactive meander
belt, including Cowhide Bayou and Red
Chute Bayou in the Shreveport area (Gi-
rard 1997, ﬁg. 1).

Christine Lee’s bioarcheological analy-

ses of Middle to Late Caddoan burials
from the Hatchel-Mitchell-Moores com-
plex on the Red River near Texarkana
conclude that the “health of the Caddo

ferent kinds of vessels (Neff et al. 1998;
Perttula 1998c, 2000; Reese-Taylor
1995). For example, recent analyses of
the chemical and petrographic constitu-
ents in the pastes of Caddoan ceramic as-
semblages in the Sabine River, Cypress
Creek, and Sulphur River basins have
shown that there appear to be consistent
paste differences between the ceramics
in each of the river and creek basins
(Fig. 13.25). These differences in turn
seem to reﬂect the local basin-speciﬁc
production by Caddoan groups of ce-
ramic vessels from locally available clays
(Neff et al. 1998; Reese-Taylor 1995),
with limited evidence for the exchange of
vessels from one group to another in dif-
ferent basins. This type of analysis should
continue to prove of great utility in exam-
ining the archeological record in north-
eastern Texas (and adjacent regions) for
considerations of cultural afﬁliation, and
trade and exchange between Caddo and
non-Caddo groups, as well as for discern-
ing manufacturing techniques, raw mate-
rial use, source/regional distributions of
particular wares, and speciﬁc functional
characteristics of different kinds of vessels
(Neff 1995; O’Brien et al. 1994).

Second, a very detailed analytical clas-
siﬁcation system for decorative motifs and
patterns has been developed for Caddoan
ceramics by Frank F. Schambach of the

Arkansas Archeological Survey (Scham-
bach 1981; Schambach et al. n.d.) that
has proved useful in detecting ﬁne-scale
temporal and stylistic changes (on the or-
der of twenty to thirty years) in ceramic
decoration among prehistoric Caddoan
groups on the Red and Ouachita Rivers
in Arkansas and Louisiana (e.g., Early
1993; D. Kelley 1994, 1997; Schambach
and Miller 1984). The deﬁnition of such
stylistic attributes is well suited to the rec-
ognition of comparable design, vessel, and
rim sets across the Caddoan area. With
this kind of speciﬁc and idiosyncratic in-
formation on prehistoric vessel decora-
tions (element as well as placement) and
forms, as well as the character of stylistic
variation present at different times among
related groups (e.g., Neiman 1995), we
can conﬁdently explore the nature of so-
cial relationships among Caddo groups
“from the message and meaning ascribed
to ceramic design” (Early 1995, 4).

The Late Caddoan Period

In the Great Bend area of the Red
River, Late Caddoan archeological sites
are included in the contemporaneous
Belcher and Texarkana phases (Scham-
bach 1983). Texarkana phase sites occur
on the Red River northwest of Texarkana
to the Arkansas/Oklahoma state lines, as
well as on the lower Sulphur River ( Jelks

394 / EASTERN AND NORTHERN TEXAS

C. Sierzchula et al. (1995) suggest that
the Moore/Higginbotham mound center
and community a few miles downstream
from the Cabe site represents the upper
Kadohadacho village that was eventually
abandoned in 1788 (see F. Smith 1995,
77). The Belcher phase is thought to date
from ca. a.d. 1500 to the late seventeenth
century (D. Kelley 1998; Perttula 1992a).
Bruseth (1998) provides the most cur-
rent discussion of the archeological char-
acter of the Late Caddoan McCurtain
phase. As stable isotope and bioarcheo-
logical evidence has shown, the McCur-
tain phase Caddos were agricultural
peoples, depending heavily on the culti-
vation of maize as the main staple of the
diet (Colby 1997; Rose et al. 1998). Like
other Late Caddoan groups on the Red
River (see Fig. 13.26), the McCurtain
phase settlement pattern includes numer-
ous habitation sites (with household
cemeteries and substantial midden depos-
its) and mound centers, though the
mounds appear to have mainly been con-
structed between ca. a.d. 1300 and 1500.
In some instances, mound centers were
not directly associated with permanent
settlements or middens (see Wyckoff
1967). The McCurtain phase mounds
were generally constructed in one or two
stages over important public structures,
with the structure abandoned, dismantled
and/or burned, then capped with a ﬁll
zone of soil scraped from nearby deposits.
Simple and elaborate single and multiple
burials were also placed in the mounds, as
with the East Mound at the Roitsch–
Sam Kaufman site on the Red River
(Skinner et al. 1969).

Bruseth (1998) suggests that the
Caddo settlements along this stretch of
the Red River resembled the Terán-Soule
model (Schambach et al. 1983; Trubo-
witz 1984) in that Caddo villages were
composed of individual compounds of
houses and other structures associated
with mounds and the residence of a caddi
or chief. The density of McCurtain phase
sites indicates that “greater numbers of
people are living in closer proximity than
before” (Bruseth 1998, 90). At the Roitsch
site, the mound was used in McCurtain
phase times as a place for the burial of the
social elite. The mound contained a shaft
tomb with ten individuals near its center,
and many grave goods were placed in the

fractures, the low to moderate severity of
arthritis, mild anemia, and periostitis im-
ply a fairly successful adaptation. . . . The

(Lee 1997, 176). Mean stable carbon iso-

Although poorly dated, the Texarkana
phase Caddoan sites appear to date from
ca. a.d. 1300 –1700, and mound con-
struction seems to coincide with the main
period of settlement at the Hatchel site,
from about a.d. 1400 to 1700 (Creel
1996). Both archeological and historical
information suggests that the main plat-
form mound at the Hatchel site may be
the templo or temple mound shown on the
1691 Terán de los Rios map (M. Wedel
1978, 8). The Cabe mound may also have
been occupied at this time, and Michael

tomb (Skinner et al. 1969). Special pur-
pose salt-processing areas (such as the Salt
Well Slough site [41RR204]) are also com-
mon in the vicinity of the Roitsch site.
Radiocarbon dates from McCurtain

phase contexts at the Roitsch–Sam
Kaufman, Holdeman (41RR11; Perino
1995), and Rowland Clark (41RR77;
Perino 1994) sites indicate that the Mc-
Curtain phase can be divided into early
(ca. a.d. 1300/1350 –1500) and late (ca.
a.d. 1500 –1700) contexts (see Bruseth
1998), with corresponding changes in ce-
ramic decorative styles and arrow point
shapes. The early McCurtain phase resi-
dential and mortuary features at the
Holdeman site date to a.d. 1392 –1478 at
1-sigma and a.d. 1332 –1513 at Roitsch-
Sam Kaufman (Perttula 1998a, table 1),
while calibrated dates from later ceramic
features at the Rowland Clark site range
from a.d. 1502 to 1603. Calibrated ra-
diocarbon dates from the Peerless Bot-
toms site (41HP175) in the upper Sul-
phur River basin, having virtually the
same variety of Caddoan ceramics as early
McCurtain phase sites on the Red River,
range between a.d. 1330 and 1524
(Fields et al. 1994b).

The Frankston phase comprises farm-
steads, hamlets, and small villages in the
Neches and Angelina River basins in
northeastern Texas (see Fig. 13.26) that
date from ca. a.d. 1400 –1650. Only a
single Frankston phase mound is known,
the A. C. Saunders site (41AN19; see
A. T. Jackson 1936; Kleinschmidt 1982).
This small mound (2.2 m in height and
26 by 33 m in length and width) had a
thick ash beds and ﬁll zones and probably
represents a Caddoan ﬁre temple used
by the social and political elite of one
Frankston phase “afﬁliated group” (Story
and Creel 1982, 36 and ﬁg. 8). South of
the mound a short distance was a large
midden deposit that capped a circular
structure, perhaps an important public fa-
cility based on its impressive size (14 by
13 m), and several large interior hearths.
The structure was built and dismantled in
the sixteenth century (based on Klein-
schmidt’s seriation of Frankston phase ce-
ramics, then capped by the midden de-
posits [Kleinschmidt 1982, 240 and 46,
respectively]). The midden deposits con-
tained an abundance of Caddoan artifacts
from apparent residential settlement, in-

cluding an estimated 1,291 ceramic vessel
sections (dominated by Poynor Engraved
bowls, Bullard Brushed and Maydelle In-
cised jars, and LaRue Neck-Banded jars),
elbow pipes, Perdiz arrow points, stone
drills, mussel shell digging tools, an as-
sortment of bone tools (awls, needles, and
beamers), and columella shell beads.
Other Frankston phases are repre-
sented by small residential settlements in
dispersed agricultural communities, with
small family and/or community cemeter-
ies not used for long periods of time (see
K. Anderson 1972; K. Anderson et al.
1974; L. Johnson 1961b; Shafer 1981b).
Keith M. Anderson notes that the con-
centration of Frankston phase sites in one
section of the upper Neches River basin
comprises “base settlement clusters [with
middens, burials, and structures, likely
representing permanent settlements] on
streamside ﬂats with fertile soils in the . . .
uplands. Other site types include scat-
tered sherds, gathering stations in which
pitted stones are found with a few sherds,
and small campsites” (K. Anderson 1972,
163) The Omer and Otis Hood cemetery
with twenty burials (Kleinschmidt 1982;
D. Suhm et al. 1954) is one of the larger
known Frankston phase cemeteries.
Many others have fewer than ten individ-
uals (Kleinschmidt 1982, 214), laid out
individually in extended supine position,
with a variety of grave goods (principally
ceramic vessels). In at least one instance, a
Frankston phase cemetery in the upper
Neches River basin in Smith County,
Texas, contains the burial of socially elite
individuals in a family and/or village
cemetery context. This particular burial
was in a pit 3.6 m wide and had three in-
dividuals. Among the funerary objects
placed with the multiple burial were
twenty-one pottery vessels, a groundstone
celt, and a large chipped biface ( Jowell
knife); baskets or matting were apparently
also present in the grave (K. Anderson
1972, 139 – 40).

Tom Middlebrook (1994, 26 –29, and

ﬁg. 4) discusses the character of “late”
Angelina focus or phase sites in the McGee
Bend Reservoir (Lake Sam Rayburn; see
Jelks 1965), segregating them from other
earlier Caddoan sites in the lake and
nearby areas (such as the Tyson site) on
the basis of: (1) an abundance of ceramic
elbow pipes; (2) high proportions of

brushed sherds (from Broaddus Brushed
jars); and (3) lower proportions of Pine-
land Punctated-Incised sherds compared
to the brushed utility wares. He identiﬁes
the Walter Bell (41SB50) and Etoile
(41NA11) sites as “late,” and Wylie Price
(41SA94) also appears to have a “late”
component. Additionally, these late or
ca. post–a.d. 1450/1500 Angelina focus
or phase sites have plain/decorated sherd
ratios between 0.80 and 1.03 (see dis-
cussion above), while ratios of 1.53 to
1.83 at the Sawmill (41SA89), Blount
(41SA123), and Tyson sites indicate that
they date to the Middle Caddoan period.
Both the Walter Bell and the Etoile
sites have small midden deposits, evi-
dence for circular structures, pit features,
and/or burials. The three structures at
Walter Bell range from 6.4 to 12 m in di-
ameter ( Jelks 1965, 56 – 60, and ﬁg. 22).
This site also had a small cemetery with
extended and ﬂexed burials of children
and adults. Funerary objects placed with
the deceased included one to six vessels
per individual, Perdiz arrow points, conch
shell beads, deer ulna tools and deer food
offerings, mussel shells, and engraved bird
bone ﬂageolets ( Jelks 1965, ﬁg. 93b, c).
The engraved designs included small and
large rows of triangles.

Late Caddoan communities are pres-

ent in the Toledo Bend area along the
Sabine River and tributaries in north-
western Louisiana and extreme eastern
Sabine and Shelby Counties in northeast-
ern Texas (see Fig. 13.26), particularly
along Palo Gaucho Creek near the La
Nana and Camino Arriba crossings of El
Camino de los Tejas, an ancestral Caddo
trace (W. Martin et al. 1995; McClurkan
et al. 1966; Woodall 1969). These sites—
such as Goode (16SA1), Bison, Area B
(16SA4), and Salt Lick (16SA37a)—
have extensive midden deposits (0.3 to
1.5 acres) with evidence of residential fea-
tures (postholes, hearths, and trash pits)
and small cemeteries. At Bison, Area B,
J. Ned Woodall (1969) encountered two
large trash/storage pits, ﬁve possible char-
coal-ﬁlled smudge pits, and a number of
postholes from a possible rectilinear
structure or an arbor near a family resi-
dence. Plain/decorated sherd ratios of
0.69 to 1.21 from Bison, Area B, Salt
Lick, and Goode indicate the Late Cad-
doan settlements along this stretch of the

Angelina phase Caddoan communities in

The Titus Phase: Boundaries,
Time, and People

The Late Caddoan Titus phase (ca.
a.d. 1430 –1680) represents the archeo-
logical remains of a number of Caddoan
groups who lived between the Sabine and
Sulphur Rivers in the northeastern Texas
Pineywoods. These Caddoan peoples
lived in dispersed year-round settlements
where they farmed and hunted, buried
their dead in planned cemeteries, and
manufactured culturally distinctive ce-
ramics of considerable stylistic and func-
tional diversity. The same may be said for
the contemporaneous Frankston phase
groups in the upper Neches and Angelina
River basins (Kleinschmidt 1982; Story
and Creel 1982) and Late Caddoan
groups living in the Angelina River and

Attoyac Bayou basins (Middlebrook
1994).

Sociopolitically, these Pineywoods
Caddos were somewhat akin to the Kado-
hadacho Caddo groups on the Red River
that had elite-controlled and hierarchi-
cally ranked societies (see Barker and
Pauketat 1992). There are considerable
archeological similarities in patterns of
mound construction and mortuary be-
havior between the Titus phase groups
and the Belcher, McCurtain, and Texar-
kana phase groups along the Red River
(Bruseth 1998; Gregory 1980; Thur-
mond 1990a; C. Webb 1959) and in
terms of inferred sociopolitical organiza-
tion (e.g., F. Smith 1994). In historic
times, however, Europeans described
these Pineywoods Caddo groups in the
Sabine and Cypress basins in only a cur-
sory fashion, unlike the Kadohadacho
and Hasinai groups to the north, east,
and south (see F. Smith 1995). Scrutiny
of the archeological record of these Piney-
woods Caddos illustrates their social, eco-
nomic, and political dynamism during
times of signiﬁcant cultural change in the
Caddoan area (e.g., Jeter et al. 1989; Pert-
tula 1992a; Story 1990).

Several hundred Titus phase compo-
nents have been identiﬁed in the Piney-
woods of northeastern Texas. The largest
concentration of Titus phase components
is found in the Cypress Bayou (or Big
Cypress Creek) valley (Perttula 1995b,
ﬁg. 10; Thurmond 1990a, ﬁg. 35), with a
scattering of sites throughout the Little
Cypress Creek valley, the middle portions
of the Sulphur River, the middle and up-
per portions of the White Oak Creek
drainage, and the upper and middle
reaches of the Sabine River drainage
(Fig. 13.27). Related Late Caddoan com-
munities are present in the Toledo Bend
area along the Sabine River in north-
western Louisiana and extreme eastern
Sabine and Shelby Counties in north-
eastern Texas, and J. Peter Thurmond
(1991, personal communication) refers
to them as the Toledo Bend subcluster
within the Titus phase Cypress cluster
(see above).

For the most part, the general regional

limits of the Titus phase are well estab-
lished, but information on the intra-
regional density of sites (including large
cemeteries) is still rather biased due to
limited professional investigations across

the region as a whole (see Perttula et al.
1986, 35 –59; Thurmond 1990a, ﬁg. 5),
extensive pot hunting on Cypress Bayou,
and the lack (until quite recently) of an
avocational archeological network in the
Pineywoods (Nelson and Perttula 1993,
1997). Thus, “apparent site density
within the Cypress basin . . . is largely a
function of survey intensity” (Thurmond
1990a, 32).

The Late Caddoan period as currently
deﬁned extends from a.d. 1400 to 1680
(Story 1990, 334). In the northeastern
Texas Pineywoods, both the Whelan and
Titus phases extend into this period. Cal-
ibrated radiocarbon dates for the Whelan
phase indicate it began around a.d. 1350,
with the Titus phase dated from ca. a.d.
1450 to the mid- to late 1600s (Perttula
1992a, 102 –107; Perttula et al. 1998;
Thurmond 1990a). The chronological
span of the earlier of the two phases is
poorly developed because of the virtual
absence of absolute dates for the Late
Caddoan period sequence (Story 1990,
table 81; Thurmond 1990a, table 60),
but archeologists undertaking recent ex-
cavations in the Big Cypress Creek, White
Oak Creek, and Sulphur River basins
(e.g., Fields et al. 1994b; Galan 1998;
Horizon Environmental Services 1995;
Kotter et al. 1991, 1993; Nash et al.
1995; Parsons 1998; Perttula et al. 1998;
Perttula n.d.) have aggressively pursued
site dating strategies. More than 80 cali-
brated radiocarbon dates and more than
160 oxidizable carbon ratio (OCR) dates
(see, e.g., Frink 1994) from Titus phase
contexts suggest that this phase dates
from ca. a.d. 1430 –1680 (Perttula n.d.;
Perttula and Nelson 1998, table 21).

Thurmond (1985, 1990a) has pro-
posed that the Titus phase is composed of
four contemporaneous spatial subclusters
within the larger Cypress cluster: the
Three Basins, Tankersley Creek, Swauano
Creek, and Big Cypress Creek (Thur-
mond 1990a, ﬁg. 35). This spatial sub-
cluster model is in contrast to the inter-
pretations of Robert L. Turner (1978),
who proposes early and late chronological
subdivisions within the Titus phase based
on motif variations on Ripley Engraved
carinated bowls and on changes in vessel
form. Examination of the association of
vessel forms, motifs, arrow point types,
and available radiocarbon dates for the
Titus phase suggests a simple alternative:

that both spatial and temporal factors con-
tribute to the archeological character of
the Titus phase and its subclusters (Pert-
tula 1992a). The subclusters appeared to
have maintained a regional or local spatial
integrity, “while at the same time there
were diachronic changes in their formal
composition that . . . permit establishing
a detailed temporal sequence” (Perttula
1992a, 106).

Each of the subclusters are deﬁned by
Thurmond (1985, 1990a) on the basis of
different Ripley Engraved bowl motifs or
motif combinations, other shared pottery

types of the engraved ﬁnewares, and dif-
ferent proportions of various arrow point
styles. The subclusters are characterized
by a distinctive constellation of ceramic
and lithic styles (Thurmond 1985, 193 –
94). In Period 2 of the Cypress cluster,
dating from ca. a.d. 1450 to 1550/1600
(estimated), Ripley Engraved is most
common, along with Maydelle Incised,
Bullard Brushed, and Harleton Appliqué
ceramic types. Period 3 of the Cypress
cluster, the “classic” Titus phase, may
have lasted only into the early 1600s, and
it certainly seems to have ended by 1700

at the latest (Thurmond 1990a, 1990b).
Again, Ripley Engraved is the most com-
mon ﬁneware in the grave lots. There are
also a number of Red River valley trade
wares present in the Period 3 burials of
the Titus phase, such as Avery Engraved
(see Fig. 13.24a) and Simms Engraved.
Thurmond (1985, 191) has argued
that the Titus phase spatial groups denote
sociopolitically integrated separate tribes
or subtribes similar to the confederacies
known historically among the Hasinai or
the Red River Kadohadacho groups.
Thus, the larger Cypress cluster is “the

archeological manifestation of a series of
social groups banded together in a so-
ciopolitical structure analogous to and at
least partially contemporaneous with that
of the Hasinai to the south and the Kado-
hadacho to the northeast. Four subclus-
ters . . . are believed to represent the indi-
vidual component groups comprising this
afﬁliated group” (Thurmond 1985, 196).
No direct measurements of prehistoric

demography are possible for the Titus
phase, but changes in settlement count
over time in the Cypress Creek and Lake
Fork Creek basins do indicate that there
was a steady increase in the number and
relative frequency of prehistoric sites
through the lengthy Archaic period
(6000 b.c. to a.d. 1), followed by a de-
crease in the Woodland period (a.d. 1–
800), and then a substantial increase in
the Early and Middle Caddoan periods
(Bruseth 1987; Thurmond 1990a). The
highest number and density of compo-
nents occur during the Late Caddoan
period (Table 13.2).

Studies in the Lake Fork Creek basin

(Bruseth 1987; Bruseth and Perttula
1981; Perttula et al. 1993a) and investi-
gations in portions of the Big Sandy
Creek (Perttula et al. 1986) and Little
Cypress Creek basins (Glander et al.
1993; Horizon Environmental Services,
Inc., 1993, 1995), as well as at Caddo
Lake (Cliff and Peter 1994a, 141), are
similar to Thurmond’s overall results for
the Cypress Creek Basin in conﬁrming
the high frequency of Late Caddoan oc-
cupations. Clearly, regional Caddoan

populations were extensive throughout
much of the Pineywoods after ca. a.d.
1350. Nevertheless, certain areas within
the region, such as the upper portions of
the Sulphur River basin (see Fields et al.
1994b; Cliff et al. 1996b) and much of
the middle reaches of the Sabine River
basin, were not apparently regularly occu-
pied on a permanent basis by Late Cad-
doan groups. Ross Fields and his coau-
thors suggest that after ca. a.d. 1400, the
upper Sulphur River basin area was the
scene of “nonintensive, presumably lim-
ited-purpose use” (Fields et al. 1997, 115).
Late Caddoan period settlements in the

Pineywoods of northeastern Texas have
been termed rural Caddoan community
systems (Perttula 1992a, 96) because they
were distributed along secondary streams,
were widely dispersed, and consisted of
functionally equivalent farmsteads and
hamlets. Similar kinds of rural communi-
ties occur throughout much of the Cad-
doan area ( Jeter et al. 1989; Story 1982,
1990).

Small mound centers were being con-
structed and used by Titus phase groups
and other Late Caddoan societies up to
ca. a.d. 1500 (and possibly later) in north-
eastern Texas, but they lack evidence of
burial mounds or large platforms; rather,
they contained mounds that buried
burned structures. The larger Caddoan
“towns” were distributed along the major
stream valleys, such as the Red, Ouachita,
and Little Rivers. These communities
were hierarchically arranged. At the top
were civic-ceremonial centers (those with

ciated “towns” of linear but dispersed
farmstead compounds with several struc-
tures, such as bark- or brush-covered shel-
ters and storage platforms (Schambach
1983, 7–8), then hamlets, farmsteads,
and specialized processing and/or pro-
curement locales (such as salt-making
sites [Early 1993]) (see also Gregory
1980, 356 –57).

Thurmond (1990a) recognizes three
types of Titus phase settlements: limited
use areas, small settlements, and large
settlements. The limited use areas were
seasonally occupied locations where ex-
tractive/processing activities took place,
while the settlements were year-round
habitations. Small settlements (ranging
between 0.2 and 1.8 ha in size, with mid-
den accumulations and wattle-and-daub
concentrations) account for 73 percent of
the known Titus phase settlements in the
Cypress Creek basin, the limited use areas
account for 23 percent, and the large
settlements (those larger than 1.8 ha, with
midden accumulations as well as wattle-
and-daub concentrations) account for
only 4 percent of the sample. One of the
more intensively investigated large Titus
phase settlements is the Pilgrim’s Pride
site (41CP304) along Big Cypress Creek
at its conﬂuence with Walkers Creek
(Perttula n.d.). Residential areas at the
site cover between 5 and 10 acres, with
more than one hundred pit features, sev-
eral circular structures, midden deposits,
and more than twenty burials, along with
an open, plaza-like area. Several of the
burials appear to have been placed in and
near the ﬂoors of structures, but the Pil-
grim’s Pride site also had a planned ceme-
tery with at least nineteen burials.

The settlements appear to have been
composed of one to several family units,
with house middens/daub concentrations
and trash midden mounds. The range of
domestic materials recovered in the mid-
den mounds (see, e.g., Perttula et al.
1993c), along with limited evidence of
structure rebuilding, suggests that most
Titus phase settlements were occupied
only about a generation, when the settle-
ment was moved to another area where
farming was possible. Small family ceme-
teries typically occurred nearby (Bruseth
1987; Perttula et al. 1993c; Thurmond
1990a) (Fig. 13.28).

avocational focus on the cemeteries that
occur on Titus phase settlements, few
speciﬁcs are available on the types of
houses and storage structures used by
these groups. (Recent excavations at the
Rookery Ridge [41UR133] and Earspool
[41TT653] sites have uncovered houses
of this period that will provide much use-
ful information when the results of the
excavations are published; see Galan 1998
and Parsons 1998.) Based on a few exca-
vated Late Caddoan structures in the
Pineywoods (some of which were in
mounds and may thus not be at all
characteristic of domestic structures
[Fig. 13.29]), the single pole structures
were probably circular in shape, were
thatched and wattled, measured between
5 and 8 m in diameter, and may have
had, on occasion, extended entranceways
(Clark and Ivey 1974; Galan 1998; Par-
sons 1998; Perttula n.d.; Thurmond
1990a, 144, 146, 148, 168, 210 –11).
Structures had central hearths and center
posts, possible interior benches and racks
for sleeping and above-ground storage
purposes, as well as storage and trash pits.
Residential structures had some midden
accumulation on their ﬂoors (i.e., house
middens), which were not prepared or
lined with clay, but the vast majority of
the daily trash and refuse was deposited
on the nearby trash midden mound.

When Pedro Vial visited the Nadaco
Caddo “village” near the Sabine River
in 1788 (probably in the vicinity of
Longview and Marshall, Texas), he de-
scribed it as having thirteen to ﬁfteen
houses scattered over a distance of three
leagues (about eight miles) (Nasatir and
Loomis 1967, 344 – 45). The houses or
ranchos of the Nadaco were evidently dis-
tributed mainly along tributaries of the
Sabine River (B. Jones 1968; Perttula
1992a, 177).

The best information on the distribu-

tion of Titus phase settlements in the
Pineywoods comes from Thurmond’s
(1990a) study of the archeology of the
Cypress Creek basin. Titus phase sites
tend to occur on valley terraces, upland
projections, and upland slope landforms,
with the greatest use of minor (2 to
10 km2) and upland basins. Fifty-four
percent of all Titus phase components
(including farmsteads, hamlets, villages,
cemeteries, and a small number of ex-
tractive/processing sites) occur in the up-

at the Burks site (41WD52), a Three Ba-
sins subcluster component, indicate that
the disposal of broken pottery vessels,
tools, and animal bones was patterned
across the site itself (Perttula 1995b, ﬁg.
13). The materials were concentrated in
trash midden deposits (Middens A and
D) adjacent to other middens that may
mark the locations of two to four struc-
tures; a family cemetery was present
south of the residential compound (see
Fig. 13.28). Midden mounds up to one

meter in height were common on Titus
phase settlements before they began to be
plowed in historic times. Excavations at
Late Caddoan Pineywoods settlements
also suggest that many activities occurred
outside the houses, resulting in trash-
ﬁlled pits, hearths, and posts in these ar-
eas. There may also have been ramadas
and granaries in these areas, along with
concentrations of artifacts and debris
(Bruseth and Perttula 1981; Thurmond
1990a; Woodall 1969).
