diocarbon and OCR dates from the Camp
Joy mound (41UR144) and Shelby
Mound at the Tracy site (41CP71) sug-
gests that mound building may have con-
tinued in the Titus phase “heartland” un-
til about a.d. 1600 or later (Perttula n.d.;
Perttula and Nelson 1998). Only a small
number of Late Caddoan period mounds
are known in the region (Fig. 13.30),
ranging from one to four small mounds
per site, and they are unlike the types of
mound complexes typically constructed
in the major river valleys at this time
(Story 1990). Pineywoods mounds were
substructural mounds; no pyramidal plat-
form or burial mounds are known for this
time period. Substructural mounds are
generally restricted to mounds that cap a
burned circular structure that was con-
structed on the ground surface or in a
small, shallow pit. In at least two in-
stances, the mounds contained sequent
structures, but the “structures originated
at higher levels in the mound[s] due to
occupational accumulations of soil and
ash, and not the result of any deliberate
capping” (Thurmond 1990a, 168).

Thurmond suggests that the locations

of Late Caddoan period mounds in the
Cypress Creek basin appear to be associ-
ated with clusters of contemporaneous
settlements, cemeteries, and limited use
areas, “and it is therefore possible that
these concentrations of components rep-
resent the archeological manifestation
of . . . Cypress cluster constituent groups
during the [preceding] Whelan phase”
(Thurmond 1990a, 234 –35). A similar
association has been noted for Middle
Caddoan mounds and settlements in
part of the middle Sabine River basin
(see Fig. 13.19 and Perttula 1989b,
1994a, ﬁg. 9).

There are two types of cemeteries used
by the Titus phase groups: the small fam-
ily cemetery and the large supralocal or
community cemetery. More than 115
Titus phase cemeteries have been docu-
mented to date (Perttula and Nelson
1998, table 22 and ﬁg. 137). Demo-
graphic proﬁles from these small cemeter-
ies appear to be representative of a family
group in that they contain roughly equal
numbers of adult males and females (see,
e.g., Rose 1984, 240). The family ceme-
tery is typically situated in immediate
proximity to the farmstead or hamlet (as
at the Burks site described above), con-

lands. Given that the majority of archeo-
logical survey efforts in the Cypress Creek
basin have concentrated on major streams
and stream valleys in general, “the fre-
quent occurrence of sites along smaller
streams is indicated. One suspects that
the occurrence of sites in upland areas
may be higher than the present data
would indicate” (Thurmond 1990a, 220).
This distribution of Titus phase settle-
ments indicates that both farmsteads and
hamlets were equally dispersed in prehis-
toric times; they were usually situated near
springs, on arable soil and level ground,
but the banks along tributary streams also
seemed to be preferred settings.

The permanent settlements and ceme-

teries of the Titus phase tend to occur in
association with freshwater springs (Thur-
mond 1990a, table 58 and ﬁg. 33).
Known Late Caddoan mound centers,
however, typically do not occur in prox-
imity to a spring but rather are on the
ﬂoodplain ﬂoor in major and intermedi-
ate basins, or they are situated on upland
projections. Associated occupations are
present on terraces, ﬂoodplain rises, or
upland projections, but are not found on
ﬂoodplain ﬂoor landforms.

Mound building in the Late Caddoan
period in the Pineywoods outside of the
Red River valley was once thought to
have ceased between roughly a.d. 1400
and 1500 (Perttula 1989a, 1993c; Thur-

tains few interments (typically about ten
to twenty individuals in cemeteries along
the western margins of the Titus phase
and between twenty and forty individuals
in the “heartland” along Big Cypress
bayou [Perttula and Nelson 1998]), and
offers no evidence of differential status or
social rank in grave goods associations
and burial treatment.

Burials within the family cemeteries

include single extended inhumations
within a patterned arrangement of burials
in rows; burials are oriented roughly east-
west (see M. Bell 1981; Hunt et al. 1996;
R. Turner 1978). Children were typically
buried in subﬂoor pits within the house-
hold structures themselves. According to
Thurmond, artifact associations in family
cemeteries differ only by age and sex:
“Adolescents were buried with more of-
ferings than children or infants, and with
fewer offerings than adults. The graves of
males often contain clusters of arrow-
points in patterns suggesting quivers of
arrows, and those of females contain pol-
ishing stones or more numerous pottery
vessels. Items of exotic material . . . are
extremely rare. The occurrence of graves
containing very large numbers of artifacts
is also quite limited” (Thurmond 1990a,
235 –36).

The large community cemeteries of
the Titus phase (Fig. 13.31) are the prod-
uct of interments from a number of com-
munities in the vicinity, and thus they are
reﬂective of a wider community-based
participation in ceremonial and mortuary
activities (Perttula and Nelson 1998; Story
1990, 338 –39). These cemeteries usually
contain at least 60 to 70 individuals, but
some are known that contained at least
150 to 300 individuals (Perttula 1993c;
Perttula and Nelson 1998, 1999; Story
1990; Thurmond 1990a; R. Turner
1978).

The large community cemeteries con-
tain excellent evidence for the existence of
social differentiation within the Titus
phase Caddoan communities. Since com-
munity cemeteries are recognized by the
type of burial interment, their relative
size, grave goods associations, and their
relative separation from habitation sites,
they are analogous in functional context
to the mound centers. Known commu-
nity cemeteries are not uniformly distrib-
uted among the Titus phase groups (see
Fig. 13.31) but are concentrated on Big
Cypress Bayou and several of its eastward-

The larger community cemeteries are
internally organized by space and struc-
turally divided by rank (Thurmond
1990a, ﬁg. 20; R. Turner 1978, ﬁg. 3).
There is little evidence for graves’ overlap-

The social status ranking apparent in
the Cypress cluster burials is based on four
criteria seen in the archeological record:

1. High-status burials include large
shaft tombs and multiple interments; all
other Titus phase burials are single, individ-
ual burials. Family cemeteries do not con-
tain shaft tombs or multiple interments.

2. Quantities of grave goods are signiﬁ-

cantly higher (approximately fourteen to
ﬁfteen per burial [Perttula 1992a, table 7])
than the mean average for the regional bur-
ial population as a whole. Higher-status
burials differ from the population primarily
in the frequency of arrow points and ce-
ramic vessels placed as grave offerings (Pert-
tula 1992a, table 8).

3. Certain types of artifacts are found in
higher-status burials. One such example in
the Cypress and upper Sabine basins is the
large chipped Galt-style biface (Thurmond
1990a, 235).

4. The burials are always of adult males.

Burials of presumed high-status indi-
viduals occur in eighteen known Piney-
woods Titus phase sites, such as J. E. Galt,
Caldwell, Lower Peach Orchard, Tuck
Carpenter, H. R. Taylor, and others (see
Perttula 1992a, table 8; Perttula and Nel-
son 1998, table 24); these burials are

The large Titus phase cemeteries with
individuals of high status are distributed
within each of the four spatial subclusters
identiﬁed by Thurmond (1985, 1990a)
in the Cypress Creek basin (see Figs. 13.31
and 13.32). The earliest appearance of this
type of community integration occurs in
the Tankersley Creek, Three Basins, and
Swauano Creek subclusters, with the lat-
est being present in the Swauano Creek
and Big Cypress Creek subclusters. No
post–a.d. 1550 –1600 community ceme-
teries are known in the Three Basins and
Tankersley Creek subclusters, with the ex-
ception of Tuck Carpenter, which sug-
gests that many of these areas were aban-
doned by resident Caddoan groups about
this time.

In general, these community cemeter-

ies are relatively short-term mortuary
phenomena that were used intensively in
portions of the Pineywoods after about
a.d. 1550 to the early 1600s. It is proba-
bly no coincidence that the intensive use
of community cemeteries in the region
occurs generally contemporaneously with
the initial contact between Titus phase
Caddoan populations and the Spanish De
Soto/Moscoso entrada of 1542 – 43 (see
Thurmond 1990b). Bruseth (1992, 91)
interprets the short-term use of these
cemeteries as reﬂecting the passage of the
army as well as increased mortality from
European diseases. The timing in the in-
tensiﬁcation of this form of community
cemetery in the region is also of consider-
able signiﬁcance because the Titus phase
community cemeteries appear to have
replaced the use of mounds for commu-
nity ceremonial and religious functions
by about the 1550s. I have argued that
this process of replacement is a reﬂection

account for 19 and 23 percent of the
burials at the two sites. Lower-status indi-
viduals at these community cemeteries
were usually adult females, juveniles, or
children. Overall, in the Titus phase mor-
tuary populations high-status individuals
account for less than 2 percent of all
known burials (Thurmond 1990a, 235).
The majority of Titus phase burials of
presumed high status appear to date after
ca. a.d. 1550 –1600 (see Perttula 1992a;

404 / EASTERN AND NORTHERN TEXAS

sity of vessel forms is impressive: cari-
nated bowls, compound bowls, bottles,
conoidal bowls, ollas, everted-rim jars,
square bowls, globular peaked jars, and
chalice forms. Other ﬁnewares include
zoomorphic efﬁgies and rattle bowls.

The utility vessels were tempered with

grog and grit and had a coarser paste
along with a thicker body. Small to large
jars (more than 30 cm in height with
oriﬁce diameters greater than 25 to 30
cm) and plain conical bowls were typical
utility vessel shapes. The presence of car-
bon encrustations, food residues, and
soot on many of the utility vessels indi-
cates that these pots were used for cook-
ing (e.g., Skibo 1992); the large oriﬁce
diameters and vessel volumes also sug-
gest that some utility vessels were used
primarily for storage of foodstuffs and
liquids.

The types of decorations and/or
surface treatment on the utility vessels
(Fig. 13.35) included neck banding or
corrugation, brushing, appliqué, incision,
punctation, or various combinations
thereof (Perttula et al. 1995a; R. Turner
1995, table 1). Small handles or lugs were
present on some of the utility vessels.
Based on sherd samples from domestic
contexts, utility vessels probably com-
prised between 50 and 70 percent of the
ceramic assemblages in Titus phase sites,
with proportionally fewer utility vessels in
mortuary contexts (Perttula and Nelson
1998; Thurmond 1990a).

Other ceramic artifacts manufactured
by Late Caddoan Pineywoods groups in-
clude ceramic earspools, as well as biconi-
cal and elbow pipes (see A. T. Jackson
1933). Different types of earspools in-
clude ones manufactured from siltstone
and sandstone as well as wood (R. Turner
1992, 84). One set of earspools from the
Tuck Carpenter site had been covered
with copper plate. The elbow pipes are
commonly decorated with engraved lines
that have been painted with hematite or
kaolin clay.

Generally speaking, lithic tools and
debris are uncommon on Late Caddoan
period sites in the Pineywoods, and pre-
sumably this rarity reﬂects the strong de-
velopment of wood and bone tool indus-
tries, few examples of which are preserved
in the archeological record. The tool di-
versity is low, consisting primarily of tri-
angular and corner-notched arrow points,

Fig. 13.34. Engraved ﬁnewares found in Titus phase cemeteries: a–g, Ripley Engraved;
h, Wilder Engraved; i, j, Taylor Engraved; k, Bailey Engraved; l, m, Simms Engraved;
n–p, Belcher Engraved (after Krieger 1946).

of changes in social complexity and the
scope of community integration, per-
haps accompanied by a spatial coales-
cence and/or decrease in settlement
density within the Pineywoods (Perttula
1992a, 115).

One of the most notable aspects of the
Late Caddoan Pineywoods archeological
record is the diverse and distinctive ab-
original ceramics that occur in domestic
and mortuary contexts. The wide variety
of vessel shapes and decorations, as well
as their frequency in domestic contexts,
demonstrates the importance of ceramics
in the Titus phase for the cooking and
serving of food, as personal possessions,
and as social identiﬁers. Both ﬁnewares
and utility wares were manufactured in
the Titus phase. Differences in paste (and
decoration) between the two wares pre-

sumably relate to technological and func-
tional variability in the way these kinds
of vessels were made and designed to be
used (e.g., Steponaitis 1984, 85 –114; see
also Reese-Taylor 1995).

The ﬁnewares were tempered with
ﬁnely crushed grog and bone and were
well polished; shell-tempered vessels are
quite rare and, when found, are typically
trade wares from the Red River Caddos.
The ﬁneware was decorated with en-
graved lines, with scrolls, scrolls and
circles, pendant triangles, and other cur-
vilinear motifs being the most common
decorative elements in the Titus phase
ceramics (Fig. 13.34). Other forms of
decoration were the application of a red
hematite slip on both interior and exte-
rior surfaces and the painting of engraved
lines with hematite or kaolin. The diver-

13-A2946  4/13/04  12:33 PM  Page 405

PREHISTORIC AND CADDOAN ARCHEOLOGY OF THE PINEYWOODS / 405

have been of lesser importance in the
Titus phase than they were between ca.
a.d. 900 and 1400 (Crane 1982; Perttula
and Bruseth 1983; Perttula et al. 1982).
In fact, the subsistence evidence from the
Titus phase in the Pineywoods, as well as
elsewhere in the Caddoan area, suggests
the successful development of a Caddoan
maize-based economy at this time (G. J.
Fritz 1990, 421, 425).

Vertebrate species identiﬁed in Titus
phase trash middens include deer, turkey,
cottontail rabbit, jackrabbit, squirrel, and
beaver. Turtle and ﬁsh were also present
but were relatively uncommon compared
to mammals and birds. Deer and turkey
appear to have been the dominant ex-
ploitable species (Perttula et al. 1982,
1993a).

The examination of bioarcheological
remains sheds some additional light on
the subsistence character of the Titus
phase populations, but to date the results
have not been substantial because of the
relatively small samples of human remains
that have been analyzed from Pineywoods
Late Caddo sites (Burnett 1990, 402 –
408). Based on admittedly limited bio-
archeological evidence, principally the
low frequency of dental caries and porotic
hyperostosis in the few studied human re-
mains from Titus phase sites, Barbara
Burnett suggests that the Late Caddoan
inhabitants of the Cypress/upper Sabine
and the middle Sabine consumed little to
no maize and “were not dependent upon
a maize-rich diet” (Burnett 1990, 405,
408). The lack of conditions such as os-
teoarthritis and osteoporosis in the Late
Caddoan samples, while again rather
small, may indicate both a different life-
style and workload than Caddoan resi-
dents on the Red River, as well as a high
measure of adaptive success (Burnett
1990, 404). It is important for current
Pineywoods Caddo research that better
archeological and bioarcheological evi-
dence regarding the nature of Titus phase
subsistence be obtained.

Although many of the details are

sketchy, mortuary goods and other exotic
artifacts (such as conch shell, lithic raw
materials, and so forth) suggest that intra-
regional contacts and the exchange of re-
sources between rural and town Caddoan
communities ﬂourished at the time of ini-
tial European contact in the sixteenth cen-
tury. Interregional exchange and contact

Fig. 13.35. Titus phase utility vessels: a, b, LaRue Neck Banded; c, Karnack Brushed-Incised;
d–f, Harleton Appliquéd; g–i, Bullard Brushed (after Krieger 1946).

ﬂake tools (drills, scrapers, and retouched
pieces), lithic debris and cores, and an ar-
ray of groundstone implements. These in-
clude petaloid and tabular celts, metates
and manos, battered and polished cobbles
and pebbles, hematite and limonite pig-
ment stones, and abrading slabs (Thur-
mond 1990a; R. Turner 1992).

Although bone is not usually well pre-

served on Titus phase sites, bone tools
have been recognized at a number of sites.
They include deer mandibles, deer beam-
ers, ulna punches, antler tines, and deer
and bird bone pins. Turtle carapace
rattles have also been noted.

Titus phase subsistence remains with

interpretive signiﬁcance are currently lim-
ited to a few sites in the upper Sabine
River and upper Cypress Creek basins,
near the western edge of its settlement
distribution (e.g., Perttula 1993c). How-
ever, well-preserved subsistence remains
are known from a number of other sites
of this age in northeastern Texas, but they
have as yet received little professional
attention (Perttula 1993a; Thurmond
1990a). Floral evidence from trash mid-
den deposits suggests that the tropical
cultigen maize (Zea mays) was a dietary
staple, and beans (Phaseolus vulgaris) were
also an important food source. Nuts and
seeds were gathered, but they appear to

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

13-A2946  4/13/04  12:33 PM  Page 406

406 / EASTERN AND NORTHERN TEXAS

were also well developed between Caddoan
polities and the horticulturists living in the
southwestern United States, the Southern
Plains, and the Lower Mississippi Valley
(see Baugh 1998; Kidder 1998).

Ceramic wares imported from the Red
River Caddoan groups are present in the
Titus phase. They include such ﬁnewares
as Belcher Ridged, Belcher Engraved, Glas-
sell Engraved, and Hodges Engraved from
the Belcher phase to the east (C. Webb
1959, 153) and shell-tempered Avery En-
graved and Simms Engraved pottery types
of the McCurtain and Texarkana phases
to the north some one hundred kilometers
(see Bruseth 1998).

An analysis of the grave goods associa-

tions in a large sample of Whelan and
Titus phase burials indicates that a mod-
icum of interaction occurred between the
Pineywoods groups and Caddoan popula-
tions to the north between a.d. 1350 and
1450, and this interaction increased dur-
ing the Titus phase proper. Glassell En-
graved is a signiﬁcant item of ceramic
trade after a.d. 1450, with interaction to
the north and east seemingly intensifying
after about the mid-1500s. In fact, be-
tween 3.2 and 7.6 percent of ceramic
vessels in this sample of Titus phase buri-
als are Red River trade wares (Perttula
1992a, 249).

Signiﬁcant quantities of nonlocal lithic

raw materials are also present in Titus
phase assemblages. Detailed examination
of lithic raw materials in Three Basins sub-
cluster components in the upper Sabine
River basin indicates that Red River gravel
cherts and chalcedonies comprised about
20 percent of the lithic tools and debris
(Perttula 1984). These lithic raw materi-
als were available from Red River Cad-
doan groups who lived in the vicinity of
the large McCurtain phase Arnold Roitsch
(41RR16) civic-ceremonial center. Hat-
ton tuff and siliceous shales (e.g., Banks
1990) were obtained from the Ouachita
Mountains for the manufacture of celts.

In one study of the lithic raw materials

present in Three Basins subcluster sites
(Perttula 1984), Edwards chert from cen-
tral Texas (Banks 1990) represented about
8 percent of the lithic tools and debris.
This material had to have been obtained
by Caddoan peoples through trade and
exchange with non-Caddoan peoples liv-
ing more than 150 kilometers to the west
and southwest of the Pineywoods Caddo.

Large Galt bifaces, possible “badges of

rank or ofﬁce” (Thurmond 1990a, 35),
found with high-status Titus and Belcher
phase burials from a number of sites
(Perttula and Nelson 1998, table 24), are
made from nonlocal high grade cherts as
well as novaculite. Documentation of sev-
eral Galt bifaces from the Pleasure Point
(41MR63) community cemetery on Big
Cypress Bayou indicate that they were
also manufactured from a dark brown
Edwards chert (Mike Turner 1993, per-
sonal communication).

The presence of Norteño phase ceram-
ics (Womack Engraved) from Titus phase
sites in the Three Basins subcluster sug-
gests that the Norteños (or Wichita-
speaking groups who moved into Texas)
interacted to some extent with the Piney-
woods Caddo. None of the sites with Nor-
teño ceramics contained European trade
goods (e.g., Scurlock 1962), though, and
the period when there was Norteño and
Titus phase contact can only be suggested
to have occurred in perhaps the early to
late seventeenth century.

Gulf Coast conch shell was obtained
by Pineywoods Late Caddo peoples for
the manufacture of conch columella
beads and pendants. This exotic material
is rarely used in the Titus phase (R. Tur-
ner 1978), however, compared to what
has been found at sites inhabited by the
Red River Belcher and McCurtain phase
Caddo groups (D. Kelley 1994; Skinner
et al. 1969; Trubowitz 1984; C. Webb
1959).

The Demise of the
Titus Phase

A reconsideration of Titus phase chro-

nologies, in combination with new as-
sessments of the route of the De Soto/
Moscoso 1542 – 43 entrada through
northeastern Texas (Bruseth 1992; Hud-
son 1990, 1997; Kenmotsu et al. 1993;
Schambach 1989; Thurmond 1990b),
suggests that: (1) the Spanish entrada en-
countered the Titus phase peoples—
probably described by the chroniclers as
the Lacane province—and (2) that within
100 to 150 years of that encounter the
area occupied by the Titus phase had been
virtually abandoned. There was a consid-
erable interval of time between the initial
European-Caddo encounters in the Piney-
woods and the abandonment of the re-

gion by the Titus phase Caddo groups.
While it is likely that some Titus phase
peoples went to live with either the Red
River Kadohadacho or among the Hasinai
Caddo south of the Sabine River, current
explanations for the demise of the Titus
phase peoples hinge on the introduction
and, more importantly, the continued ex-
posure of Caddoan groups to European
epidemic diseases (Perttula 1992a; Thur-
mond 1990a, 233; 1990b), which led
eventually to substantial depopulation
among these Pineywoods groups.

Late Caddoan period Pineywoods
sites, such as those of the Titus phase,
hold great promise for documenting the
nature of sociopolitical, demographic,
and economic changes in the region dur-
ing an eventful time in Caddoan prehis-
tory and protohistory. This promise is due
in large part to their potential for ﬁne-
scale chronological control, say on the
order of twenty to thirty years. As other
studies of Caddoan archeology make
clear, there were substantial changes in
Caddoan societies from ca. a.d. 800 to
European contact (see Jeter et al. 1989;
Story 1990), with one of the more im-
portant being the development and elab-
oration of complex versus egalitarian so-
ciopolitical systems after ca. a.d. 1400 in
many regions of the Caddoan area, in-
cluding the Pineywoods of northeastern
Texas (Perttula 1996).

The apparent intensiﬁcation of maize-

based economies after ca. a.d. 1400 in
much of the Caddoan area may be in
large part responsible for the elaboration
as well as the demise of many of the civic-
ceremonial centers at a time when there
was a reorganization of social and politi-
cal relationships within Caddoan culture
on a regional level. The tangible develop-
ment of predictable maize surpluses at all
levels, the “quality of abundance” referred
to by Mary W. Helms (1992, 188), would
have led to the development of sizable
populations of Titus phase groups and a
strong leadership. Through time, how-
ever, the agricultural surpluses would
have led to the social homogeneity noted
above among Late Caddoan groups in the
Pineywoods because household agricul-
tural sufﬁciency eventually negated the
regionally expansive role of the elite-
controlled social and political economy.
After this time, therefore, social and po-
litical integration appears to have been re-

G&S Typesetters PDF proof

13-A2946  4/13/04  12:33 PM  Page 407

PREHISTORIC AND CADDOAN ARCHEOLOGY OF THE PINEYWOODS / 407

gionally and locally redeﬁned at a smaller
community scale.

Subsequent to the discontinuation of
large community cemeteries in the early
to mid-seventeenth century, most of the
upper Sabine River and Cypress Creek
basins were abandoned (Perttula 1992a;
Thurmond 1990b). The only post-1680
Caddoan occupations that can be related
to earlier use of the Pineywoods are to be
found in the lower Sulphur and Sabine
Rivers (Perttula 1995b, ﬁg. 19a) at known
trade portages or along trail crossings of
these major streams (Harris et al. 1980;
B. Jones 1968; Perttula 1992a, 172 –77).
None of the Caddoan communities in
the Cypress Creek/upper Sabine basins
appears to have been ethnographically de-
scribed, and what is known from ethno-
graphic and archival documents pertains
principally to the Nadaco or Anadarko
Caddo (Perttula 1995b, ﬁg. 19b). This
group’s prehistoric antecedents are poorly
known, and they appear to have settled in
the Sabine River basin only after ca. 1770
(F. Smith 1995, 74).

Concluding Remarks

Since the 1950s, a great deal has been

learned by a dedicated group of avoca-
tional and professional archeologists about
the prehistory of this part of northeastern
Texas, particularly regarding the last one
thousand to two thousand years, when
the ancestors of the Caddo Tribe of Okla-
homa are known to have settled in the
area and thrived (Carter 1995; F. Smith
1995). The knowledge gained about the
native American past in the region, about
the challenges faced during times of pre-
historic cultural change, and during the

wrenching episode (still ongoing) of
contact and interaction between the
Caddo peoples and European and Anglo-
American colonizers and settlers (Perttula
1998b) helps to make “native history” an
integral part of—rather than a footnote
to—the ongoing study of Texas’ cultural
heritage.

While there is every reason to think
that our knowledge of northeastern Texas
prehistory will continue to grow by leaps
and bounds, there are tremendous re-
search and preservation challenges ahead
for each prehistoric era. On a mundane
level, it is important that we continually
cast a critical and discerning eye at our re-
search priorities for prehistoric and Cad-
doan archeological sites, the value of our
methodological approaches, and the
worth of our cultural resource manage-
ment planning documents. From the in-
novative use of these tools come the new
perspectives and conceptions that lead to
a broader understanding of the past.

Changes in research strategies are criti-

cal, but in northeastern Texas they are,
unfortunately, only part of the archeolog-
ical story. Of the utmost concern for the
long-term protection and preservation of
the region’s priceless archeological heri-
tage is dealing directly with the unabated
looting and vandalism of prehistoric
Caddo villages and cemeteries— on pri-
vate as well as state and federal lands
(Perttula and Nelson 1999). The archeo-
logical landscape is pitted and pocked
with the looter’s holes and backdirt piles.
Many of the most important archeologi-
cal sites in the region have been irretriev-
ably damaged and destroyed, and it is
questionable that the looting frenzy can
be quelled even should an unmarked

burial protection bill ever be made law in
Texas; the situation is not much better in
Arkansas, Louisiana, or Oklahoma. The
cultural patrimony of the Caddo peoples
is being taken from them, with almost no
hand being lifted to help protect these
signiﬁcant cultural treasures. This chal-
lenge is our greatest in the years ahead:
to ﬁnd a way, in concert with the Caddo
people, to protect and preserve this cul-
tural legacy: “In 1541 when the Span-
iards arrived, every place in the Caddo
country had, of course, a Caddo name
but almost all of those names are gone
now, like the people who bestowed them”
(Schambach 1993, 7).
